Chance to Fix

by Haeyongsshi (BiancaValin)

Summary

Rio stood, her movements slow and deliberate, like a predator that didn’t need to rush. "It means," she said, stepping toward her, "there are things about yourself, about us, that you’ve forgotten."

Something cold curled around Agatha’s spine.

"But you’re starting to remember now," Rio continued, her voice softer, more knowing. "Aren’t you?"

And suddenly, she was.

The image hit her like a slap, flashes of a dense forest, a hand gripping hers, laughter echoing in the trees, a warmth that felt like home. It was there, just out of reach, teasing at the edges of her mind.

She staggered back, her breath catching. "What... what are you?" she whispered, voice barely audible.

Rio’s lips curled into a faint smile. "That’s the right question, darling." Her eyes gleamed. "And when you’re ready to hear the answer, I’ll tell you."

Or

After Agatha's death, Rio waited for every day, year or timeline until her Agatha was reborn. And after a game, Agatha summoned Rio back into her life.

Chapter 1: Chapter 1

Agatha Harkness had never experienced a typical adolescence. Her life was marked by turmoil: a father who betrayed her mother and abandoned their family when she was just a child, and a mother, Evanora, who arranged for her to marry far too young. 

 

At twenty, Evanora married Agatha off to the first man she found, Ralph O’Connor. But Agatha never loved him.

 

By the time she turned thirty, Agatha had done everything in her power to avoid pregnancy. Yet, despite her efforts, she gave birth to a daughter, Nicole. The moment Nicole was born, Agatha was struck by the baby’s appearance. She didn’t resemble either of her parents.

 

Nicole was hauntingly beautiful. Her features were delicate and well-defined, arched brows, sharp cheekbones, a petite nose, and piercing eyes that seemed to hold far more depth than a child her age should possess. Her dark, wavy hair framed a porcelain complexion, lending her an ethereal, almost otherworldly presence. 

Evanora wasted no time accusing her daughter of infidelity, but a DNA test confirmed Ralph was the father with 70% certainty. The remaining 60% was attributed to a lab error, a common anomaly, they assured her. Still, Agatha couldn’t shake the nagging feeling that Nicole’s existence had something to do with her own subconscious longing to never have children with Ralph.

 

A decade later, despite her wishes, Agatha became pregnant again. Her second child, Nicholas, didn’t resemble Ralph much either. Instead, he shared many of Agatha’s traits and looked strikingly similar to his sister, Nicole.

 

Though her marriage was loveless, Agatha found happiness in her two children. However, her resentment toward Ralph never faded. She couldn’t stop wishing he would simply vanish. One day, he did. Ralph disappeared without a trace. For six months, there was no word, no evidence, no sign of his existence. The police were on the verge of declaring him dead.

 

Late one night, as the clock passed midnight, Agatha sat in her living room with her closest friends, Wanda, Jen, Alice, and Lilia. Her children were asleep upstairs while the women shared laughter and glasses of wine.

 

Wanda, a history professor with a penchant for the occult, pulled a book of witchcraft from her bag. Alongside it, she placed a Ouija board.

 

“Let’s find Ralph,” Wanda suggested with a mischievous grin.

 

Agatha frowned. “I don’t want him back, Wanda. I’m fine with him gone.”

 

“It’s just for fun,” Wanda teased. “And you’re the only one who can pronounce the Latin spells correctly.”

 

Rolling her eyes, Agatha muttered the words Wanda pointed to in the book. Silence followed.

 

“See? Nothing happened,” Agatha said flatly, standing up. “This is ridiculous.”

 

Frustrated, she excused herself to the bathroom. Inside, she splashed water on her face, trying to clear her head. But as she looked up, she froze.

In the mirror stood a woman who didn’t belong there. Her dark hair cascaded in effortless waves, her almond-shaped eyes glimmered with mischief, and her sharp, angular features held an air of danger. She wore a dark red lipstick that highlighted her smirk.

 

Agatha stumbled back, her scream echoing in the small bathroom. She turned, and collided with someone standing behind her.

 

The woman from the mirror was there, smirking at her. “I imagined you’d scream, but not like that, sweetheart,” the woman said, her tone amused.

 

Agatha’s breath hitched. “Who the fuck are you?! How did you get into my house?”

 

The woman tilted her head, her smile deepening. “You invited me in, of course.”

 

"I'll call the police," Agatha said, gripping the doorknob. But the door wouldn’t budge.

 

“It’s useless,” the woman replied, her tone sweet and mocking. “They can’t see me, my love. Only you can. You’re the only one who can see me.”

 

“What the hell are you talking about?! Get out of my house!” Agatha snapped.

 

“You summoned me here.” The woman’s lips curved into a sly smile as she recited in a low, melodic tone: “‘Mortem vocasti; hic sum.’ “I must say, your Latin pronunciation is, ” she kissed her fingertip “simply exquisite.”

 

“That was just a game!”

 

“I know... It’s always a game. Until it isn’t. In centuries, you’re the first to pronounce it correctly. Where did you learn?”

 

“At university,” Agatha answered hesitantly, still pressing against the locked door.

 

“Hmm...” The woman tilted her head. “I believe in past lives, darling. Do you?”

 

“I believe you need to leave.”

 

“It’s not that simple.”

 

“Then I’ll banish you!”

 

“It’s not that simple,” the woman repeated with an almost pitying smile.

 

“Then how—” Agatha’s voice faltered as the woman’s smirk deepened.

 

“You really don’t remember me, do you, Ag?”

 

“Ag? No one calls me Ag...” Agatha paused, and then, as if a veil lifted in her mind, a memory surfaced.

 

A dream, long forgotten but now so vivid it made her knees weak. A beautiful woman with that same face, dressed in white, standing beside her. The woman had called her Ag, and she had been furious. “It’s Agatha,” she had corrected sharply in the dream.

 

“You... You appeared in my dream... fifteen years ago... But—”

 

“You summoned me, my love, and I came.”

 

“But I don’t know you.”

 

“Oh, you do,” the woman said, stepping closer. “Just not in this life.”

 

“What are you—”

 

“Agatha! Did you fall in the damn toilet or what?” came Jen’s frantic voice, followed by rapid knocking on the bathroom door.

 

Agatha spun around toward the sound. When she turned back, the woman was gone.

Agatha unlocked the door with a frustrated tug, her heart still racing as she faced Jen, who stood with an eyebrow raised and arms crossed. Behind her, Wanda, Alice, and Lilia hovered curiously.

 

“Well?” Jen demanded. “Did you fall in? Or were you having a moment with the mirror? Because your lipstick is still on point.”

 

“Very funny,” Agatha snapped, stepping past her into the living room.

 

Alice sniffed the air dramatically. “Hmm... the bathroom has this faint, mysterious ghostly tension. Did you summon Ralph in there?”

 

“Or,” Wanda interjected, smirking, “was it something hotter than Ralph?”

 

Agatha glared at them, her hands on her hips. “Yes, Ralph materialized, and I immediately threw him out the window. Any other stupid questions?”

 

Lilia grinned. “Oh, come on, Agatha. You’ve been in there for ages, and you come out looking like you’ve seen a ghost. Spill it!”

 

Agatha grabbed her wine glass from the table, taking a slow sip as she let the tension hang. “If you must know,” she finally said, her voice dripping with sass, “I saw the future in the mirror.”

 

“Oh?” Wanda leaned forward, intrigued.

 

“Yes.” Agatha’s lips curled into a sly smile. “And it said that none of you will ever get a boyfriend with those horrible fashion choices.”

 

The room erupted into laughter.

 

“Oh, she’s got jokes now!” Jen howled, nudging Wanda.

 

“Bold words coming from someone who has been wearing that same cardigan since, what, 2005?” Alice teased.

 

“I’m sorry, I wasn’t aware you needed instructions to recognize timeless fashion,” Agatha shot back, settling onto the couch. “Besides, let’s not forget who convinced you that bangs were a good idea.”

 

Lilia gasped. “Oh, burn. Someone get the salt.”

 

Agatha held up her wine glass, looking smug. “Ladies, remember: I only roast the people I care about. Consider yourselves blessed.”

 

Wanda raised her glass in mock salute. “To being blessed by Agatha Harkness. And her terrifying, sassy bathroom adventures.”

 

They all clinked glasses, the tension easing into laughter. But as Agatha joined in, her mind lingered on the woman in the mirror.

 

Who the hell was she?

The morning light streamed through the kitchen windows as Agatha stood at the stove, flipping pancakes with one hand and clutching her coffee mug with the other. Nick sat at the table, kicking his legs and scribbling something on a piece of paper, a crayon drawing that, from the looks of it, was either a dinosaur or an oddly-shaped horse.

 

“Another pancake, Mom!” he chirped, his plate already clean.

 

“Sure, sweetie,” Agatha muttered, her mind still clouded with thoughts of the strange woman from the night before. She told herself it had to be a hallucination, stress, wine, or Wanda’s stupid games catching up with her.

 

Just as she plated the next pancake, a familiar voice sliced through her thoughts.

 

“Good morning, darling.”

 

Agatha spun around, the spatula clattering onto the counter with a sharp clang. Her breath caught in her throat. There she was, leaning casually against the doorway as if she belonged there, Rio. The dim kitchen light caught the sharp angles of her face, her dark hair framing her smirk, which was equal parts infuriating and unsettlingly charming.

 

Nick gasped, nearly toppling off his chair. His eyes were wide, a mix of excitement and disbelief dancing across his face. “You can see her?!”

 

Agatha's stomach twisted. “What?”

 

Nick scrambled down from his seat, crayons forgotten, his small hands gripping the edge of the counter for balance. His face was alight with excitement as he pointed to Rio. “You can see her! I thought she was just mine! Like… my secret friend!”

 

Agatha’s heartbeat stuttered. Secret friend? She blinked, looking from Nick to Rio and back again, a cold dread creeping up her spine. “Your what?”

 

Nick nodded eagerly, as if this were the best news he’d received all day. “Rio! She’s been my friend forever! I mean, since I can remember!”

 

Agatha’s hands tightened around the edge of the counter, her knuckles white. The air in the room suddenly felt too thick, too heavy. “What are you talking about, Nick? She hasn’t been here forever.”

 

“Yes, she has!” he insisted, his crayon-stained fingers still pointing at Rio as though she might disappear if he stopped. “She talks to me when I’m bored, and she knows everything about dinosaurs, and she said I can call her whenever I want!”

 

Agatha’s gaze snapped to Rio, sharp and accusing. “You’ve been... talking to my son? For years?”

 

Rio remained utterly unfazed, her smirk curling at the edges as if she found the entire situation amusing. She tapped a fingernail against the counter, her dark eyes gleaming. “He’s a very charming conversationalist, I must say. Much more pleasant than you were last night.”

 

Agatha’s stomach twisted into knots. Last night. The words clawed at the edges of her memory, just out of reach.

 

Nick tugged at Agatha’s robe, his eyes full of innocent curiosity. “Mom, how come you can see her now? Did you do the magic, too?”

 

Agatha took an instinctive step back, a tremor running through her hands. Magic. The word sent a shiver down her spine. “Nick, listen to me. This… person isn’t real. She’s not your friend, and she’s definitely not supposed to be here.”

 

Nick frowned as if his mother had just said something completely ridiculous. “But she’s always been here.”

 

Rio sighed dramatically, pushing off the counter. “Oh, Agatha. Stop scaring the poor boy. You’re acting like I’m some kind of monster.”

 

Agatha’s pulse pounded in her ears. Her hands curled into fists at her sides. “You are a monster.”

 

Nick let out a horrified gasp. “Mom! Don’t be mean to Rio!”

 

“I’m not being mean, Nick. I’m protecting you!” Agatha snapped, her voice sharp enough to cut through the thick air.

 

Rio tsked, shaking her head as she leaned against the counter again, utterly at ease. “Let’s get a few things straight, darling. I didn’t ask to be here. You called me, remember? And now I’m stuck with you until we figure out why.”

 

Agatha’s breath came fast, her chest rising and falling in rapid succession. “I didn’t call you!” Her voice was raw, her throat tight. “I don’t even know you!”

 

Nick looked up at Rio, completely unbothered by his mother’s rising panic. “You don’t remember her, Mom?”

 

A sharp, ice-cold sensation slithered down Agatha’s spine. “What?”

 

Nick shrugged, his expression calm, as if he were explaining something as simple as the weather. “You used to talk to her, too. Before I was born. You just forgot.”

 

The room seemed to tilt. The floor beneath Agatha’s feet felt unsteady, as though the world had suddenly become something she no longer understood.

 

“Nick, what are you—”

 

“Oh, hush,” Rio interrupted, waving a dismissive hand. “Don’t frighten her too much. She’s already teetering on the edge of a breakdown.”

 

Agatha clenched her fists so tightly her nails bit into her palms. “Get out of my house.”

 

Rio tilted her head, her smile lazy and knowing. “We’ve been over this, love. It doesn’t work like that.”

 

Agatha’s breath came in sharp, shallow bursts. “Then how does it work?”

 

Rio stepped closer, her presence a force in the small kitchen. Her dark eyes met Agatha’s, something unreadable lurking beneath them. “It works like this: You figure out why you called me here. You remember why we’re connected. Until then... I’m not going anywhere.”

 

Agatha’s stomach lurched. The air crackled between them, something electric, something old.

 

Nick, oblivious to the storm brewing between the two women, tugged on Rio’s sleeve. “Rio, can we play dinosaurs later?”

 

“Nick!” Agatha’s voice snapped like a whip, harsher than she intended.

 

Nick looked up at her, startled, confusion etched across his small face. “What? She’s my friend!”

 

Agatha turned her glare back to Rio, her voice low, dangerous. “Stay away from my son.”

 

Rio raised her hands in mock surrender, her smirk never fading. “Relax, Agatha. I’m not here to hurt anyone. I’m here because you brought me here. If you have a problem with that, take it up with yourself.”

 

The words sent a chill skittering down Agatha’s spine, her pulse roaring in her ears. Because deep down—somewhere buried in the part of her she had long forgotten—she feared Rio might be telling the truth.

 

“Your mom’s quite the character, isn’t she?”

 

Agatha clenched her jaw, the words echoing in her head. She’s been here forever… Agatha marched up the stairs, knocking sharply on her daughter’s door. “Nicky! You’re late for school. Let’s go!”

 

A groan from inside was followed by the slow, creaking protest of the door. Nicole, Nicky, emerged, her expression one of practiced disinterest. At fifteen, she had perfected the art of looking like she wanted to disappear from existence entirely. Black nails, multiple piercings, clothes that looked like they had been stolen from a 90s grunge catalog, her aesthetic screamed rebellion, though Agatha knew better. Beneath the dark eyeliner and oversized hoodies, Nicky was responsible, smart, and, most importantly, followed Agatha’s three rules: no drugs, no criminal behavior, and definitely no teenage pregnancies.

 

"Good morning," Nicky mumbled, her voice flat, devoid of even the slightest effort to sound awake.

 

"Not with that attitude, it's not," Agatha quipped, stepping back so her daughter could pass.

 

Nicky trudged past her, dragging her feet down the hallway like the weight of existence itself was just too much. "Who were you yelling at earlier?"

 

"Your brother," Agatha replied without hesitation, smoothing down her robe as if it could straighten out the morning's chaos. "Just one of his usual... things. Now go have breakfast before you're even later."

 

She followed Nicky down the stairs, bracing herself for another encounter with her unwanted guest. And, sure enough, there she was, Rio, perched on the kitchen counter like she owned the place, lazily eating strawberries from Agatha's fruit bowl, the very picture of ease.

 

Agatha clenched her jaw. "Really?" she muttered under her breath.

 

But before she could launch into another round of exasperated demands for Rio to leave, she noticed Nicky had stopped in the doorway, her entire body stiff. Her breath hitched, her hands curled into fists at her sides, and her wide eyes were locked on the woman lounging on the counter.

 

Nicky wasn’t just looking at Rio. She was staring at her like she had just seen a ghost.

 

"Keep moving," Agatha said, nudging her forward. "She’s no one. Just go eat your breakfast."

 

But Nicky didn’t budge. She turned to her mother, her expression somewhere between shock and disbelief. "You can see her?" Nicky whispered, her voice unsteady.

 

Agatha frowned. "What are you talking about now?"

 

"The woman. Rio," Nicky said, her voice rising, frantic now, as she pointed straight at Rio.

 

Agatha’s breath stalled in her chest. A creeping unease slithered up her spine. "How do you know her name?"

 

Nicky didn’t answer. Instead, she dropped her backpack with a heavy thud, crouching down to unzip it with trembling fingers. Her movements were rushed, frantic, as she flipped through the pages of a worn notebook before shoving it into Agatha’s hands.

 

Then, without hesitation, she turned and ran straight to Rio.

 

Agatha barely had time to register what was happening before Nicky threw her arms around the woman, clinging to her with a desperation that sent cold panic rushing through her veins.

 

"You’re back, mama!" Nicky cried, her voice cracking. "I missed you so much!"

 

Agatha’s world tilted on its axis. Her hands tightened around the notebook as her vision blurred.

 

Mama. The word rang in her ears, foreign and impossible.

 

Her gaze dropped to the notebook. On the first page, a child’s drawing, two figures, one in green, one in purple, each holding hands with smaller versions of Nicholas and Nicky. Agatha’s brow furrowed. She didn’t recognize the taller figures, but there was no mistaking the young faces of her children in the drawing.

 

Her fingers flipped through the pages, breath quickening, until she reached near the end. A sharp inhale caught in her throat.

 

There, etched in ink with remarkable detail, was a perfect sketch of Rio. Her mischievous smile, the sharp arch of her brows, the playful gleam in her eyes. Every detail was there, as if the artist had known her intimately. And beneath it, in a child's shaky handwriting: I miss you, mama.

 

Agatha’s knees went weak. Her pulse roared in her ears, drowning out everything else. She turned her gaze back to the kitchen.

 

Nicky was still wrapped around Rio, her fingers clutching the fabric of the woman’s jacket like she was afraid she’d disappear. And for the first time since Agatha had laid eyes on Rio, the woman wasn’t smirking. Her expression had softened, her usual air of teasing arrogance replaced with something quiet. Something... almost fond.

 

"You’re... back..." Nicky murmured, voice muffled against Rio’s shoulder.

 

The world tilted again. Agatha's fingers slackened on the notebook.

 

"This is not..." She swayed, stomach twisting, the weight of the moment suffocating. "What the hell is happening?"

 

She took a step forward, her legs barely holding her, before the room swam around her. The floor rushed up too fast.

 

The last thing she heard was Nicky’s panicked voice. "Mom!"

 

And Rio, utterly unbothered, plucking another strawberry from the bowl, her voice dripping with amusement.

 

"Oh dear," she mused, popping the berry between her lips. "She took that better than I expected."

The forest was alive with the soft rustle of leaves and the chirping of birds. Sunlight filtered through the canopy, painting golden patterns on the mossy ground. Agatha leaned against the trunk of a towering oak tree, her lips curled into a rare smile as Rio twirled in the clearing.

 

“Come on, Ag,” Rio called, her voice full of laughter. “You can’t just stand there looking grumpy. Dance with me!”

 

Agatha crossed her arms, feigning annoyance. “I don’t dance.”

 

“Of course you don’t,” Rio teased, stepping closer. “You’re too busy being stoic and mysterious.”

 

“Someone has to keep you out of trouble.”

 

Rio grinned, her dark eyes glimmering with mischief. “Trouble? Me? Never.”

 

She reached for Agatha’s hands, pulling her into the clearing. Agatha resisted for a moment before finally giving in, rolling her eyes as Rio spun her around.

 

“This is ridiculous,” Agatha muttered, though her smile betrayed her.

 

Rio laughed, her voice rich and warm. “Life’s too short to be serious all the time. Especially when we’re together.”

 

Agatha paused, her breath catching as she met Rio’s gaze. There was something magnetic about the way Rio looked at her, like she was the only person in the world.

 

“You’re annoying, y'know” Agatha said softly.

 

“And yet, here you are,” Rio replied, leaning in closer.

 

The moment hung between them, timeless and fragile, as the world seemed to fade away...

"Mom! Wake up!"

 

Agatha groaned, her head pounding as consciousness dragged her back into reality. Her body felt heavy, her limbs sluggish, and a dull ache throbbed behind her eyes. Slowly, she pried her eyelids open, the soft glow of the living room light blurring into focus. She was lying on the couch. Nick and Nicky hovered over her, their faces tight with worry.

 

“What... what happened?” she murmured, sitting up and pressing her fingertips to her temple. The room felt slightly off-kilter, as if the world had shifted while she was unconscious.

 

Nick, eyes wide with something between excitement and concern, pointed across the room. "She carried you, Mom. She’s super strong!"

 

Agatha followed his gaze.

 

Rio sat languidly in one of the armchairs, one leg draped over the other, her arms resting on the chair’s sides as if she were a queen on her throne. She looked infuriatingly comfortable, utterly unbothered, lazily twirling a strand of dark hair between her fingers.

 

Agatha's stomach twisted.

 

Nicky, however, was anything but calm. She turned to Rio, voice sharp with accusation. "Since when can she see you?"

 

Rio barely glanced up from her nails. "Since yesterday, when she called me."

 

The muscles in Nicky’s jaw tightened. Her hands clenched into fists at her sides. "You said this couldn’t happen," she hissed under her breath. "Why did it happen?"

 

Rio finally looked at her, the usual playful lilt absent from her voice. "I don’t know, Nicole."

 

Nicky flinched at the use of her full name, but she didn’t back down. "You’re supposed to know everything! You’re the—"

 

"Mama!" Nick interrupted, tugging insistently on Agatha’s sleeve, pulling her focus back to him.

 

Agatha exhaled shakily, rubbing her temples, her thoughts a chaotic mess. The pounding in her head grew worse. "What is going on? Who are you two whispering about?"

 

Nicky hesitated, biting the inside of her cheek. "It’s... complicated."

 

She exchanged a look with Rio, one that made Agatha’s stomach clench. It was the kind of look that said they knew something she didn’t.

 

Rio smirked faintly but stayed where she was, still lounging like she had all the time in the world. "She’s taking this better than expected," she murmured, more to herself than anyone else.

 

Agatha’s patience snapped. She turned to Rio, her voice low and dangerous. "Rio... who are you?"

 

Rio’s expression didn’t change. If anything, she looked almost amused. "You called me, darling." She shrugged, as if that answered everything. "You should already know."

 

Agatha’s nails dug into the fabric of the couch. "It was a joke!" she snapped, frustration boiling over. "I wasn’t serious!"

 

Rio’s smirk vanished. Her eyes darkened, her voice turning sharp as glass. "And do you think I’d be here if it were just a joke?" Her words cut through the room like a blade. "Do you think I wanted this? To be stuck here? With you?"

 

Agatha surged to her feet, her hands trembling, rage and confusion tangling in her chest. "Then why is my daughter calling you Mama? And why the hell have you been following me?"

 

For the first time, something flickered in Rio’s expression, something softer. It was gone almost as soon as it appeared, but Agatha caught it. A crack in the armor.

 

"I’ve been with you longer than you’ve been alive, Agatha," Rio said, her voice quieter now, but no less intense.

 

The room turned suffocating. Agatha felt the words press down on her chest, thick and impossible. Her breath came out in shallow, unsteady bursts. "What does that even mean?"

 

Rio stood, her movements slow and deliberate, like a predator that didn’t need to rush. "It means," she said, stepping toward her, "there are things about yourself, about us, that you’ve forgotten."

 

Something cold curled around Agatha’s spine.

 

"But you’re starting to remember now," Rio continued, her voice softer, more knowing. "Aren’t you?"

 

And suddenly, she was.

 

The image hit her like a slap, flashes of a dense forest, a hand gripping hers, laughter echoing in the trees, a warmth that felt like home. It was there, just out of reach, teasing at the edges of her mind.

 

She staggered back, her breath catching. "What... what are you?" she whispered, voice barely audible.

 

Rio’s lips curled into a faint smile. "That’s the right question, darling." Her eyes gleamed. "And when you’re ready to hear the answer, I’ll tell you."

 

Chapter 2: Chapter 2

Chapter Summary

I'm sorry for the delay

“Nicky,” Agatha said, her voice steady despite the storm brewing in her mind. Her jaw was tight, shoulders stiff with tension as she fished the car keys from the pocket of her coat. The metallic jingle was sharp in the stillness of the hallway. She held them out to her daughter with a hand that trembled just slightly. “Take your brother to school.”

 

Nicky blinked, her eyes widening before lighting up with excitement. The gray fog of her morning sulk evaporated in an instant. “Wait, really? I get to drive?” Her voice rose with disbelief, hope crashing into joy.

 

“Yes,” Agatha replied, closing her eyes for a second as she pinched the bridge of her nose, trying to hold back a pounding headache and the mounting anxiety creeping up her spine. Her voice came out low and tired. “But no detours, no loud music, and—”

 

“No speeding, I got it!” Nicky cut in with a wide grin, already reaching for the keys. She bounced on the balls of her feet, her hands cold as she snatched them from her mother’s grip. The keys felt heavy and thrilling in her palm. Freedom.

 

Across the room, Nick looked up from the worn sneakers he was hurriedly tying, one lace already tangled. His expression brightened with mischief. “Can we stop for donuts?”

 

“No,” Agatha and Nicky said in unison, Nicky shooting her brother a quick glance and a half-smile, Agatha’s tone sharp enough to slice through the request.

 

“Aw, come on!” Nick groaned, slinging his backpack over one shoulder. The zipper caught slightly on the fabric, and he gave it a yank.

 

Agatha didn’t respond. She simply pointed toward the door, her arm stiff, her lips a firm line. “Out. Now.”

 

Nicky grabbed her own bag from the hook by the door and slung it over her shoulder. The zipper jangled against the metal hook, echoing through the house like a starting bell. She grabbed Nick by the sleeve and practically hauled him toward the door. “Come on, squirt. Let’s go before Mom changes her mind.”

 

“I’m not a squirt!” Nick whined, his voice cracking slightly as he tried to dig in his heels, but he was no match for his sister’s momentum.

 

The front door creaked open, letting in a sharp gust of morning air that smelled like damp asphalt and the faint tang of gasoline. The chill bit at their cheeks as they stepped outside. Nicky’s laugh rang out, teasing and triumphant, while Nick grumbled under his breath, kicking at a loose pebble on the driveway.

Inside, Agatha stood frozen for a moment in the doorway. The silence left behind was heavier than she expected. She pressed a hand to her forehead and let out a long breath, her fingers brushing the worry lines etched deep into her brow.

 

Agatha turned toward Rio, who was still lounging in the chair like it was a throne, legs lazily crossed, fingers toying with the frayed edge of her sleeve. She looked annoyingly comfortable, like she belonged there, like this wasn’t a seismic shift in Agatha’s carefully constructed reality.

Agatha crossed her arms tightly across her chest, the leather of her jacket creaking under the pressure. Her eyes narrowed, sharp as cut glass.

 

“Alright,” she said, her voice low and clipped, the kind that came right before a storm. “Talk. Who are you, really? And why the hell is my family wrapped up in this... whatever this is?”

 

Rio’s lips curved into a familiar smirk, but it lacked its usual spark. It was tired, almost bittersweet. She tilted her head, studying Agatha the way a chess master would eye a board mid-game.

 

“Straight to the point. I like that,” she said, voice smooth like velvet dragged across something jagged.

 

“Save the flattery,” Agatha snapped, her tone as icy as her stare. “Start explaining.”

 

Rio leaned forward, her movements slow and deliberate, resting her elbows on her knees. Her voice dropped with gravity.

 

“Alright, darling. But you’d better sit down. This isn’t going to be easy to hear.”

 

“I’ll stand,” Agatha shot back, lifting her chin. Her posture was rigid, fists clenched at her sides. She needed control — if not over Rio, then at least over her own body.

 

Rio shrugged, a languid motion that seemed to mock Agatha’s tension. “Suit yourself.”

 

Then, she looked up, eyes locking onto Agatha’s with such intensity it felt like a tether had snapped taut between them.

 

“You summoned me, Agatha. And not just yesterday. You’ve been calling me, consciously or not, for years.”

 

The words hit like a slap. Agatha’s breath hitched, barely audible, but her eyes gave her away—widening with confusion, flickering with fear she didn’t want to name.

 

Her voice, though, stayed steady. “What do you mean, years? I’ve never met you before last night.”

 

“Not in this life,” Rio said softly, her tone coated in something heavier now, grief, maybe, or reverence. “But in another? We knew each other. Intimately.”

 

The room felt smaller suddenly, as if the air had thickened with invisible weight. Agatha’s mouth went dry. She took an involuntary step back, her heel brushing against the edge of the carpet, grounding her to the moment. Her heart pounded against her ribs, each beat screaming lie, lie, lie — but something deeper hummed beneath it. Recognition. Terror.

 

“I don’t believe in reincarnation,” she said, but the words lacked bite.

 

Rio smiled, soft this time. Not mocking, not triumphant. Just… sad. “You don’t have to. I remember enough for both of us.”

 

Agatha’s fingers twitched, as if resisting the urge to reach for something, magic, memory, maybe even Rio. Her gaze flicked toward the window, where rain tapped against the glass in a steady rhythm, like a heartbeat she couldn’t name.

 

“And what exactly did we mean to each other in this other life?” she asked, her voice quieter now, but no less firm.

 

Rio looked at her for a long moment, then stood, her movements fluid, like the gravity in the room bowed to her. She stepped closer, not enough to touch, but close enough that Agatha could feel the subtle heat radiating from her. Her eyes, endless and dark, searched Agatha’s face.

 

“Everything,” Rio whispered. “You were everything.”

 

The words hung heavy in the air, pressing on Agatha's chest like invisible hands. She didn’t move, didn’t speak, but something inside her shifted — an ache in her ribs, a tightening behind her eyes. For a fleeting moment, her mind drifted to that dream, or was it a memory? The dream of the forest. The light filtering through the trees. Rio’s laughter, rich and warm, echoing like a song she almost remembered. The way Rio had looked at her then — like she was the center of the world. Like she always had been.

 

“You’re insane,” Agatha muttered, her voice low and brittle. She shook her head, as if the motion could cast off the creeping weight curling around her spine. “This is insane.”

 

Rio tilted her head, the dim lighting catching the curve of her cheekbone. Her eyes sparkled with something unreadable. “Is it? Or is it that deep down, a part of you already knows I’m telling the truth?”

 

Agatha parted her lips to retort, but no words came. They caught, snagged on the edge of something fragile inside her. The memory sharpened, the sensation of fingers intertwined, the warmth of skin, a voice — Rio’s voice — calling her name in the hush of trees.

 

“What do you want from me?” she asked finally, barely more than a whisper. The question wasn’t laced with accusation now, but desperation. Her hands trembled slightly, tucked beneath her crossed arms to hide the quake.

 

Rio leaned back again, sinking into the chair like a queen on her throne, that maddening smirk returning. “Oh, darling. The better question is, what do you want from me?”

 

Agatha’s jaw tightened. Her fists clenched. Her whole body felt wired, caught between rage and something far more dangerous, curiosity. “I want my life back.”

 

The words came out rough, scraped raw from somewhere deep. Her life had been twisted, yanked off its axis since the moment she met this woman. And worse, it felt like she had been waiting for it.

 

Rio’s smile faltered just slightly, softening into something mournful. Her eyes held something ancient and tender. “Then we’d better figure out why you called me here. Because until we do...” She leaned in, her voice gentler, more intimate. “I’m afraid you’re stuck with me.”

 

Agatha exhaled sharply through her nose and squared her shoulders, burying the flicker of unease that danced up her spine. “Can you stop speaking in riddles? You’re not a sphinx.”

 

Rio’s laugh rolled out low and melodic, tinged with something far too amused. She shook her head slowly, brushing her fingers through her hair. Her posture was unbothered, almost amused, as if she were enjoying Agatha’s unraveling.

 

“If I told you the whole truth at once, Agatha, you’d succumb to madness,” she said, her voice smooth as silk but laced with weary undertones.

 

Agatha scoffed, a bitter sound. “So you’re protecting me?”

 

“That,” Rio said with a smirk, “and the fact that I’m not allowed to talk about past lives to any living soul. Not in this world, this timeline, or any other.” She arched an eyebrow. “I can’t. It’s forbidden. The only way is for you to discover it piece by piece. Like breadcrumbs through the dark.”

 

A long, frustrated sigh escaped Agatha’s lips. She paced a step, then stopped, her boots heavy on the hardwood. Her voice cracked through the tension. “Then what are you?”

 

Rio’s expression changed, something deeper rippling beneath her skin. A shadow, a truth waiting just behind the veil. Her smile stretched wider, and yet it wasn’t threatening. It was reverent. Inevitable.

 

“I am the natural order of things, my love,” she murmured. “I am the balance between life and death. No one lives without eventually passing through me. I can be the beginning...” she paused, leaning forward slightly, “but I am also the end.”

 

“Cut the Shakespearean crap,” Agatha snapped, her voice sharp, but there was an edge of fear to it now. She hated that.

 

Rio stood.

 

The movement was quiet, graceful, but with weight, like the air itself shifted around her. She stepped forward slowly, until she was inches from Agatha’s face. The scent of her, like smoke and cold earth, wrapped around Agatha’s senses, familiar and wrong at once. Her eyes locked onto Agatha’s, unwavering.

 

Then something happened.

 

Her flawless features shifted. Not like illusion or magic, but like a crack in a mask. Her face twisted, her skin turning pale as ash, lips darkening, eyes hollowing until they glowed with an eerie light. A skeletal edge peeked through her cheekbones, as if death itself were pressing just beneath her skin. Yet Agatha didn’t recoil. Her heart thudded violently in her chest, but she wasn’t afraid. Not of her.

 

“I. Am. The...” Rio whispered, each word like thunder muffled by silk.

 

Then, her voice dropped low, inhuman and cold enough to steal the warmth from the room:

 

“Death.”

 

A beat of silence followed. The clock on the wall ticked once.

 

Agatha stared at her. Not with fear. With recognition.

 

“…Figures,” she muttered under her breath, more to herself than to Rio, but her voice betrayed the chill crawling down her spine.

 

Rio’s monstrous face relaxed, softening back to human. Beautiful. Familiar.

 

“I told you,” she said softly, “you called for me.”

 

Agatha blinked, her breath catching in her throat as the weight of the word settled into her bones like frost. "Death?" she repeated, voice thinner than she liked, her hand instinctively moving to her chest, as though trying to still the sudden thrum of her heart.

 

Rio didn’t flinch. She took a step closer, slow and deliberate, her voice rich and dark, soaked in silk and thunder. “That’s right, darling... Death.”

 

The sound of that word, wrapped in honey and warning, made Agatha’s skin prickle. Her body was tense, rooted in place, caught between flight and the inexplicable pull toward the woman in front of her. Every part of her screamed danger — run, scream, protect — but her pulse betrayed her. She was curious. She was drawn in. That scared her more than anything.

 

Agatha’s voice sharpened, the sting of disbelief slicing through her composure. “And why are you here?”

 

Rio hesitated, and it was so brief, so unnatural, that Agatha noticed immediately. That flicker of something... human. Vulnerable. A crack in the mask.

 

“I don’t know,” Rio said softly, almost like it pained her to say it.

 

“Liar,” Agatha hissed, stepping forward now, her anger finally overtaking the fog of confusion. Her hands balled into fists at her sides, her nails digging crescent moons into her palms. “You’re lying.”

 

“I don’t lie, Agatha!” Rio snapped, her voice slicing through the room like a whip. Her control cracked for the first time, the edge of command in her tone unmistakable. “You know that! It’s not allowed.” Her voice dipped again, thick with emotion and something darker. “You begged me to never appear to you again. To leave you alone. To stop making your life a living hell. And I did.”

 

Agatha’s breath hitched, her eyes searching Rio’s face for deception, for theatrics. But there was none. Only truth, raw and terrifying.

 

“For centuries,” Rio continued, her jaw tight. “But then one day, you called me back. And I tried not to come. I tried…”

 

Her voice broke just slightly, just enough to stir something in Agatha’s chest that she didn’t want to name.

 

“When did I call you?” Agatha asked, quieter this time, like the question itself held teeth.

 

Rio exhaled through her nose, her gaze unblinking. “When you got married.”

 

The words landed like a slap.

 

“You wished it would end, that you could die,” Rio said, stepping forward again. Her tone was gentler now, but commanding, like a hand at Agatha’s throat, not choking, just reminding her who was in control. “That your suffering would stop. But I couldn’t take you. I made a promise. So every night, you prayed and begged not to get pregnant, even though deep down… you wanted a child.”

 

The memory slammed into Agatha like a wave, her knees pressed to the cold floor, candlelight flickering, whispering please, not like this, night after night, until silence answered back. Or so she’d thought.

 

“So I gave you one... two,” Rio said, her voice thick now, laced with quiet reverence. “A child that doesn’t belong to your husband, but to you and —”

 

Agatha’s lips parted, and the word slipped out before she could stop it. “You.” Her knees buckled slightly. “Nicole looks like you. Nick looks like you.”

 

Rio didn’t smile. Her expression was solemn, proud, almost possessive. “I gave you what you asked for. Somehow, the children could see me. Talk to me. So I stayed close. With them. To protect. To keep them safe.”

 

She took another step closer. Agatha didn’t move.

 

“But every time you were nearby, I disappeared. Nicole figured it out first. That’s why she calls me ‘Mama.’” A soft pause. “Nick still sees me as his imaginary friend. The last time I did what you asked... was six months ago.”

 

Agatha’s voice barely rose above a breath, her lips pale. “Ralph.”

 

“He’s very annoying,” Rio muttered without remorse, rolling her eyes, but her tone was edged with something sharper — dark amusement.

 

Agatha’s face paled. “You killed my husband?”

 

Rio tilted her head, the corner of her mouth curling. “Do you want that?”

 

“No!” she snapped, too quickly.

 

Rio raised a single eyebrow, her voice dipped into something sinful. “Are you sure?”

 

The air between them crackled. That question wasn’t just about Ralph anymore, and Agatha knew it. Her throat tightened.

 

“Anyway,” Rio said, almost flippantly, stepping back just an inch, letting Agatha breathe. “After that, I left. Until you summoned me again. With that spell. So here I am.” She spread her arms with mocking grace. “Stuck with you, Agatha. Until you figure out how to send me away… again.”

 

Agatha stumbled back a step, trying to put distance between them that no longer existed. Her back hit the wall, cold against her shoulder blades. Her fists were still clenched, her breathing shallow. Her heartbeat thundered in her ears.

 

Rio tilted her head again, that smirk returning with the kind of control that made Agatha’s skin flush. “You look like you want to hit me... or kiss me. Which is it, honey?”

 

“Get out of my head,” Agatha spat, but her voice trembled, traitorous.

 

Rio leaned in until her breath kissed Agatha’s cheek. “Darling,” she whispered, “I’ve lived in your head. I know every dark corner... and every place that makes you ache.”

 

Agatha’s breath hitched as Rio’s words slid under her skin like smoke, unseen, but suffocating.

 

“You’ve got some nerve,” Agatha hissed, voice low and trembling, not just with anger, but with the raw, volatile emotion barely caged beneath her skin. Her fists were clenched so tightly her knuckles had gone pale, nails biting into the flesh of her palms. “You’ve been meddling in my life, in my family, for years. And now you just expect me to accept that?”

 

Rio leaned back lazily against the wall, one boot casually crossed over the other, her arms folded like she had all the time in the world. That damned smirk curled across her lips, equal parts amusement and arrogance. “I didn’t meddle, darling,” she said, the word like a purr, a tease, a leash tug. “You called me. I simply answered.”

 

Agatha took a step forward, the distance between them charged like a live wire. Her jaw tightened, eyes flashing with fury. “You’re twisting everything!” she snapped, the pitch of her voice rising. “You talk about balance, about being death, but you’ve been manipulating me from the start! You—”

 

“I gave you exactly what you asked for,” Rio interrupted, voice razor-sharp now, her smirk vanishing like mist. She unfolded her arms, her entire posture shifting into something more dangerous, controlled, focused, like a predator just before the strike. “You prayed for freedom. I gave it to you. You begged for children who didn’t tie you to that pathetic man. I gave you that, too. Every time you’ve reached out, I’ve answered, Agatha. So don’t you dare stand there and act like I forced myself into your life.”

 

Agatha’s breathing was shallow now, chest rising and falling too fast. Her pulse thundered at her temples. She was unraveling, and she hated that Rio could see it.

 

“You still should’ve stayed away,” she said, but it came out like a gasp. A plea. A lie.

 

Rio pushed off the wall with a single, fluid movement, the air shifting as she moved. She was suddenly there — inches away. Agatha could smell her now, that strange scent of smoke and earth and something faintly sweet like lilac clinging to leather. Rio’s dark eyes locked onto hers, searing.

 

“Stayed away?” she repeated, voice dropping into something low and velvet-smooth. “You think I wanted to come back? You think I chose to be tied to you?” Her lip curled just slightly, but her eyes betrayed her, there was pain there, and longing. “You called me, Agatha. Over and over again. And now I’m stuck here. With you.”

 

Agatha's knees threatened to give out, but she stood her ground. Their faces were so close now that she could feel the warmth of Rio’s breath against her lips, could see every detail in her eyes, stormy, endless, filled with memory.

 

“Then leave,” she said, though her voice faltered. “If you’re so miserable, then just leave.”

 

Rio’s lips twitched into a faint, humorless smile, one that didn’t quite reach her eyes. “I can’t. Not until you figure out why you summoned me.”

 

Agatha scoffed, trying to wrestle back some control, even if it was slipping like sand through her fingers. “Why I summoned you? You’re the all-powerful, mysterious Death,” she mocked, her voice a shade too brittle. “Why don’t you just figure it out yourself?”

 

Rio laughed then, but there was no real joy in it. It was low and dry, like wind through dead leaves. “You think this is easy for me?” she said, stepping even closer until their bodies almost touched, heat sparking between them like flint. “Being here? Being near you? It’s torture.”

 

Agatha’s anger flickered, her brow knitting. Confusion cut through the fury like a blade. “What are you talking about?”

 

Rio’s voice dropped to a whisper, dark and reverent. “You. Being near you is torture.”

 

The words landed hard. Heavy. They reverberated through Agatha’s chest and made her stomach twist.

 

“I remember everything,” Rio continued, her tone shifting again, softer, more intimate, yet commanding. Her fingers brushed along Agatha’s arm, feather-light, barely a touch but enough to ignite fire beneath the skin. “The lives we’ve lived. The things we’ve shared. I remember all of it, Agatha. Every moment. Every touch. And now I’m here, and you don’t even remember me.”

 

Agatha’s breath caught. Her body was frozen, betraying her mind, which screamed to pull away. But she didn’t. She couldn’t. Her heart thudded violently against her ribs, her skin tingling where Rio’s fingers trailed.

 

“Stop it,” she said, voice trembling, smaller than she intended.

 

Rio’s eyes darkened, pupils dilated. She stepped into Agatha’s space like she belonged there. “Stop what?” she murmured, her voice a silk thread coiled tight. “Reminding you of what you’ve forgotten... or getting too close?”

 

“I said stop,” Agatha repeated, but it was a whimper now, not a command.

 

Rio’s lips curled again, this time not in amusement, but understanding. Knowing. Dominance wrapped in velvet. “You’re trembling.”

 

“I’m not,” Agatha lied, voice barely audible.

 

“You are,” Rio whispered, her other hand rising to brush a loose strand of hair from Agatha’s cheek. Her touch was gentle, reverent, as if she were worshipping a ghost. “I could leave you alone right now. Walk out that door. Vanish. Never touch your life again.” Her fingertips dragged just beneath Agatha’s jaw, tilting her chin slightly, controlling her without force. “But we both know,” Rio continued, eyes locked on hers, “you don’t want that.”

 

Agatha didn’t answer. Couldn’t. Her body was aflame, her mind a battlefield of denial and desire. And Rio... Rio stood there like sin incarnate, like punishment wrapped in pleasure, like a promise whispered at the edge of surrender.

And God help her, Agatha wasn’t sure which part she feared most: the truth... or how much she wanted it.

 

The air between them was thick, charged, almost suffocating, as if the room itself held its breath, waiting to see who would shatter first. Agatha’s fingers, which had been clenched just moments before with the kind of fury that left crescent-shaped marks in her palms, now found themselves pressed against Rio’s shoulders. She pushed, not hard, not with intent to repel, but just enough to reclaim a fraction of space, a sliver of clarity she didn’t actually want.

 

“This is a mistake,” Agatha muttered, though her voice betrayed her. It was raw. Low. And she didn’t let go.

 

Rio didn’t move back. Her body stayed rooted, steady beneath Agatha’s touch, like she knew how little resistance meant in the presence of want. Her lips hovered just a breath from Agatha’s, their exhale mingling, hot and intimate.

 

“Maybe,” Rio whispered, her voice like velvet dragged over bare skin. “But it’s one we’ve made before.”

 

A shiver coiled down Agatha’s spine. Her grip tightened at Rio’s collar, fingertips curling into the fabric like claws desperate for control. But control had already slipped through her fingers. The burn in her chest, the pounding in her ears, it wasn’t anger anymore. It was hunger. Frustration. Longing. Her. She hated how Rio always unraveled her, how she pulled the strings without ever trying, how she exposed truths Agatha had buried lifetimes ago.

 

But right now, thought was a luxury she didn’t have.

The pull between them snapped. And then, finally — finally — their lips met.

 

It wasn’t soft. It wasn’t sweet. It was war.

 

Their mouths crashed together with the kind of violence only repressed desire could conjure. Agatha kissed like she was furious, like she needed to punish Rio for existing, for returning, for knowing her too well. Rio answered with fire, her lips parting just enough to tease, to command, to take. Their teeth clashed briefly, breath mingling in sharp gasps, and it felt like drowning, and neither of them cared.

 

Agatha’s hands slid up to the back of Rio’s neck, fingers threading through thick strands of dark hair, pulling her closer like she needed her closer or she’d burn alive. Rio didn’t hesitate; her arms wrapped tightly around Agatha’s waist, dragging her against her body with enough force to make Agatha’s breath catch. She was solid. Warm. Unshakable. The world tilted, disappeared, no walls, no floor, no time. Just skin. Just friction. Just them.

 

Agatha moaned against her mouth, low and guttural, and for a heartbeat she hated how good it felt. How right. How dangerous.

 

But just as quickly as it started, she tore herself away, gasping like she’d broken the surface of deep water. Her chest heaved with shallow, ragged breaths, her lips swollen, her pupils wide. Her fingers hovered midair, unsure of whether to hold or hit.

 

“This doesn’t mean anything,” she said, but the words cracked at the edges, trembling with everything it did mean.

 

Rio’s lips, red and glistening, curled into a slow smirk, but this one wasn’t sharp. It was soft. Dangerous in a different way. “If that’s what you need to tell yourself, darling...” Her voice was low, almost a purr, rich with satisfaction and the certainty of someone who knew she’d already won.

 

Agatha stumbled back a step, needing air, space — distance — but her body betrayed her, still humming, still hot. Her pulse thudded beneath her skin, and every nerve was painfully aware of where Rio had touched her. Of where she still wanted her to.

 

“I hate you,” she said, trying to conjure venom, but the words came out husky, breathless, more like a confession than a curse.

 

Rio's smile widened, slow and indulgent, like a queen watching her favorite servant try to rebel. Her gaze slid over Agatha’s flushed cheeks, down to the subtle tremble in her hands. “You always say that,” she murmured, voice as intoxicating as wine spilled down silk. “Right before you let me ruin you again.”

 

And Agatha had no answer, because part of her, deep, aching, undeniable, wanted to be ruined.

Agatha stood barefoot on the cool wooden floor, in front of her open closet, her fingers rifling through hangers with a little too much force. Fabric whispered and swayed with each frustrated tug. She was trying to find something, anything, that made her feel put together, in control. But her mind refused to stay focused. It kept replaying the kiss, the way Rio's lips had felt against hers, fire and fury and inevitability.

 

She gritted her teeth and forced the memory away, yanking out a white blouse like it had personally offended her. Not now. Not again. She didn’t have time for emotional sabotage, not when work was already hanging over her like a guillotine. Taking a break wasn't a luxury she could afford — not with everything unraveling at once.

 

As she buttoned her blouse, hands slower than usual, she could still feel Rio. It was ridiculous. The house was empty. She’d checked. The bathroom mirror no longer held shadows, and the bedroom was devoid of footsteps or lingering heat. But somehow, Rio’s presence clung to the air like expensive perfume, haunting and warm and maddening. It curled in the corners of rooms, danced along the baseboards, pulsed in the echo of silence.

Agatha sighed and stepped into her heels, grabbing her purse and slinging it over her shoulder with a bit more force than necessary. A sharp honk pierced the fog in her mind, snapping her attention toward the window.

 

Wanda’s red car sat idling at the curb, the windows slightly fogged from the cold morning. Agatha took one last glance at the house, her jaw tense, then walked out, heels clicking down the front steps. She opened the passenger door with a practiced flick, tossed her bag into the backseat, and slid in with a heavy exhale.

 

Wanda barely turned her head, one brow already arched. “What happened to your car?”

 

“Nick and Nicky missed the bus,” Agatha muttered, rubbing her temples with two fingers. Her head throbbed — not from lack of sleep, but from thinking too much.

 

“And you’re in such a great mood 'cause...?”

 

Agatha tilted her head back against the seat, her voice flat. “I don’t know yet.”

 

Wanda glanced sideways, lips twitching into a smirk she didn’t bother to hide. “Is this about Ralph?”

 

“Can we not talk about him?” Agatha snapped, fumbling for the seatbelt as if the motion could end the conversation by itself.

 

Wanda didn’t flinch. She simply rested her hands on the wheel, drumming her fingers. “Agatha,” she said, her tone walking the line between playful and interrogative. “I’m not a cop, but refusing to talk about your missing husband every time someone brings him up kinda makes you look like a suspect.”

 

Agatha turned her head slowly, fixing Wanda with a razor-sharp glare that could’ve sliced through steel. Her voice was low and deliberate. “Explain to me how I’m a suspect in his disappearance when I was literally in the hospital, Wanda. Vomiting blood. From food he bought.” She let the words hang, acidic. “I just don’t want to talk about it. Okay?”

 

Wanda blinked once, raised her hands in mock surrender. “Yikes. Someone’s cranky today.”

 

Agatha scoffed and finally buckled her seatbelt, the metal click sounding too loud in the tension between them.

 

“You need to get laid,” Wanda said under her breath, lips curling into a wicked grin.

 

“You need to mind your own damn business,” Agatha retorted, giving her a look that dared her to keep pushing. Her voice was sharp, but her cheeks were a shade pinker than before.

 

Wanda didn’t miss it.

 

“Whatever you say, boss,” she teased, her smirk full of secrets as she shifted the car into gear.

 

Agatha stared out the window, arms crossed tightly, jaw set, but her heart thudded a little faster than usual. And no matter how hard she tried to ignore it, the taste of Rio still lingered on her lips.

Agatha stood at the podium, the cool varnish of the wood smooth beneath her fingertips as she adjusted her notes into a neat, controlled pile. Her eyes, sharp behind thin-framed glasses, swept over the rows of students. The low hum of casual chatter faded as the weight of her presence settled over the lecture hall. She didn’t need to raise her voice, her authority came naturally, with a quiet, commanding elegance that demanded attention.

 

"Today," she began, voice clear and deliberate, “we’re diving into a fascinating and ancient concept, the beings said to govern the sacred balance of the universe.”

 

She paused just long enough to let the words land.

 

"These are the personifications of fundamental forces: Life, Time, Space, Destiny, and Death." Her tone was even, but her heart skipped slightly at the final word. She forced herself to ignore it. "In almost every culture, these forces appear not as abstract ideas, but as conscious entities — beings with purpose, often wielding immense power."

 

A soft click echoed as she pressed the projector remote. The screen behind her flickered, casting a golden glow that highlighted the edges of her figure, a mosaic of the Moirai materialized, the ancient Greek depiction of fate taking form.

 

"Humanity has always sought to understand the forces that govern existence," she continued, her heels clicking softly as she stepped to the side. "In early cultures, these forces were explained through mythology and personification. The Greeks imagined the Moirai as three women who controlled the thread of life, Clotho spun it, Lachesis measured it, and Atropos cut it."

 

She turned to face her class, her gaze steady.

 

"This triad represented the inevitability of birth, the passage of time, and death."

 

Agatha's voice didn’t waver, but her fingers curled slightly around the edge of the podium. Her skin felt too warm. The room, usually clinical and bright, felt heavy, like the air had thickened around her. She wasn’t thinking about the Greeks anymore. She could still feel the ghost of Rio’s breath on her lips.

 

She clicked to the next slide: a fresco of the Trimurti, bold and colorful, bathing the room in reds and golds.

 

"This framework wasn’t unique to the Greeks. In Hinduism, the Trimurti embodies creation, preservation, and destruction — Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva. In Norse mythology, the Norns wove fate beneath Yggdrasil, the World Tree."

 

As she spoke, she paced slowly across the stage, her heels echoing, voice flowing like silk through stone. The rhythm was second nature, but the center of her chest ached with pressure. Her body moved with precision, but her mind... her mind was spiraling.

 

She kissed me. I kissed her back.

 

She clicked again.

 

A medieval image filled the screen: Death, skeletal and robed, holding a scythe that glinted under the light of a painted moon.

 

"And then, there’s Death," she said, and her throat tightened involuntarily.

 

The word felt heavier today. Not symbolic. Not philosophical. Personal.

 

"Often portrayed as a solitary figure, Death is universally feared and revered. From the Grim Reaper of Western folklore to the Aztec goddess Mictecacihuatl, who governs the underworld, Death is not simply an end but a necessary part of the cycle."

 

She stepped away from the podium, walking slowly to the front edge of the platform. Her fingers brushed against her thigh, restless. She let her gaze drift upward toward the students, though she didn’t see them.

 

"But where did this theology arise? Why personify these forces at all?"

 

Her voice softened, layered with a deeper question, one that wasn’t in the script.

 

"The answer lies in our ancestors' need to understand the incomprehensible."

 

She exhaled slowly through her nose, grounding herself.

 

"Life, time, destiny, and death are universal constants. They are intangible, yet their effects are deeply felt. By giving them form, humanity made them relatable — something they could pray to, fear, or blame. These personifications became a way to impose order on chaos."

 

A final click. A modern graphic appeared, elegant and minimal, five interlocking symbols: a flower, a clock, a thread, a star, and a scythe.

 

“Over millennia, the stories evolved. Oral traditions turned into sacred texts, then into art, and now, into academic study.” Her voice rose again, regaining its structure. “These beings, whether real or imagined, represent our quest to understand not only the universe… but our place within it.”

 

She paused. A calculated beat of silence. But her eyes drifted down, unfocused, lost in thought.

 

"And yet,” she said quietly, “despite all our theories and stories, we must ask ourselves, what if these beings are not just myths? What if they exist, not as deities or metaphors, but as manifestations of universal laws? Beings that maintain the balance, ensuring the cycle continues… whether we understand it or not."

 

The classroom was silent. The hum of the projector was the only sound, punctuated by the scratch of a few pens moving slower now.

A muscle in Agatha’s jaw twitched as she glanced at the symbol of the scythe glowing behind her.

 

Balance is necessary... The thought echoed like a whisper in her bones.

 

But what happens when the balance becomes personal? When Death lives in your house, sleeps in your air, wears your memories like perfume?

 

She cleared her throat lightly, pushing the tremor aside.

 

“Now,” she said, her voice crisp again, sliding easily back into her professor's tone, “let’s break this down further by examining how these concepts manifest in different cultural frameworks. We'll start with the concept of Life through the lens of ancient Egyptian theology, Ma’at, the goddess of truth and balance.”

 

The projector changed slides and Agatha, poised, composed, unraveling quietly beneath a professional mask, continued her lecture, while the scent of lilac and ash lingered faintly on her skin.

 

Agatha stood poised behind the podium, the wood warm beneath her palms despite the faint chill clinging to the air-conditioned room. A quiet hum of concentration filled the lecture hall, pages turning, pens scratching, students leaning in slightly, drawn into the rhythm of her voice. She thrived in this space, where logic ruled and curiosity had structure. But today, her foundation felt fragile.

 

She was halfway through her explanation of the symbolic evolution of Ma’at when a hand shot up, quick and firm, slicing through the lull in her lecture. Agatha paused, nodding toward the source.

 

“Yes?” she said, her tone smooth but cautious.

 

A young man in the third row adjusted his glasses and cleared his throat. “So, are these beings supposed to be, like, gods? Or are they something else entirely? You mentioned the Moirai, but how do they compare to, say, the Judeo-Christian God?”

 

Agatha exhaled slowly through her nose, folding her arms and leaning slightly against the podium, one ankle crossing over the other. “Good question,” she said with a slight nod. “These beings aren’t gods in the traditional sense, at least not in the sense of creators or moral arbiters. They don’t seek worship. They don’t punish or reward.”

 

She lifted her hand, gesturing toward the symbolic graphic on the screen, clock, flower, thread, star, scythe. “They’re more like… caretakers. Embodiments of cosmic function. If we’re comparing them to familiar theology, they’d be closer to archangels or sentient laws of nature than omnipotent deities.”

 

The room murmured with scribbles and shifting bodies. Another hand rose in the back, feminine, fingers stained faintly with highlighter ink, her pen still tapping against her spiral notebook.

 

“But wouldn’t that mean they still have free will?” the girl asked. “If they’re sentient, can’t they choose not to, you know… maintain balance?”

 

Agatha tilted her head, intrigued by the phrasing. “In theory? Yes,” she said, voice steady but thoughtful. “If they possess free will in the human sense, they could choose to abandon their roles. But most mythologies suggest that their purpose is their essence. Death doesn’t choose to take. She is the taking. Time doesn’t move forward because it wants to, it moves because it must.”

 

The girl’s brow furrowed, her pen slowing. “So… they’re trapped by their own existence?”

 

Agatha’s gaze softened for a moment. “In a sense,” she admitted, her voice lowering just a bit. “But whether they feel trapped is unknowable. They exist on a level beyond our comprehension. They may not experience time, or choice, or emotion the way we do. They just are.”

 

She glanced around, letting the words settle. The faint hum of the projector buzzed behind her like a second heartbeat.

 

Then, from the front row, another hand lifted, a boy, bright-eyed and eager. “What about Death specifically?”

 

Agatha’s spine stiffened. Her breath caught for just half a second, so quick it was barely noticeable. But she felt it. She felt it.

 

“What about her?” she asked, too fast.

 

There was a beat of silence. A flicker of confusion. Then the boy leaned forward. “Well, Death shows up a lot in stories as, like, a guide. The Grim Reaper, Charon, even some modern books and movies. But if Death’s just a cosmic force, why interact with humans at all? Why not just… happen? Like gravity.”

 

Agatha placed her palms flat on the podium, grounding herself. Her fingers tensed subtly. She kept her voice calm.

 

“Death is… unique,” she began carefully. “Unlike Time or Space, Death is personal. She touches everything. Every living being meets her, eventually. She doesn’t create or destroy, she transitions. And because of that intimacy, many cultures gave her form. A face. A name. A role.”

 

She took a step forward from the podium, her heels quiet against the floor. “To us, the end of life is terrifying. Abstract. So we imagined Death as someone who could guide us. Someone who… understands.”

 

A few students glanced at one another. Whispers floated just out of earshot. It wasn’t the content that struck them — but the word choice. She.

 

“But… why would it care?” the boy pressed again, frowning. “If Death’s just doing her job, why give comfort at all? Why show compassion? Why guide?”

 

Agatha’s chest tightened. She glanced down, her fingers curling into her palm. She could still feel Rio’s lips on hers, still hear the whisper, I remember everything. A breeze that didn’t exist seemed to drift across the back of her neck.

 

She looked back up, forcing stillness into her voice. “Maybe she doesn’t care,” she said, her words flat. “Maybe it’s just projection, us giving a face to something faceless.”

 

But even as she said it, she knew she didn’t believe it. Not anymore.

 

“Or maybe…” Her voice faltered.

 

“Maybe what?” a girl asked, leaning forward.

 

Agatha swallowed. Her gaze drifted toward the window, to the pale sky beyond the glass. “Maybe Death cares because she has to. Because without compassion, there is no true balance. Without empathy, death becomes chaos. Horror. And she is not chaos.” She turned back to the room, her expression unreadable. “Death isn’t just an end. She’s the threshold to something else. Whether we want to cross it or not.”

 

Silence blanketed the room, thick and heavy. Several students stared, pens paused mid-sentence. Others exchanged glances, uncertain. Then, slowly, a single hand rose.

 

“So… do you think Death could ever make mistakes?” the student asked. “Like, take someone she wasn’t supposed to?”

 

Agatha blinked. Her throat tightened, heat creeping up the back of her neck. She pictured Rio’s smirk, her sharp eyes, the way she’d whispered You summoned me.

 

Was Ralph a mistake? Or a choice?

Did she come for him… or for me?

 

“No,” Agatha said sharply, the word cutting through the stillness. “Death doesn’t make mistakes.”

 

Her tone was final. Too final.

 

More glances passed between students, now laced with confusion and curiosity. Whispers stirred again — soft, speculative.

 

“And… why do you keep calling Death she?” someone asked cautiously. “Is that from a specific myth?”

 

Agatha straightened, hands folding behind her back. “That’s just the interpretation I use. It’s… personal.” Her voice was clipped, cool again, the professor mask sliding neatly back into place.

 

No one questioned her further.

 

“Alright,” she said briskly, clapping once, the sound echoing like a reset. “Let’s move on to Destiny, and how it functions as both a narrative device and a metaphysical force. Any more questions about Death can wait until the end of class.”

 

But as she turned back toward the screen, the weight of her own words clung to her like a second skin.

 

And she couldn’t help but wonder, if Death didn’t make mistakes…Then what, exactly, had she become?

Jen raised an eyebrow, her manicured fingers delicately circling the rim of her iced coffee as she tilted her head. Her gaze was fixed on Agatha, who sat across the café table, utterly unmoving, her eyes locked on something, or someone, outside the window.

 

“What’s with her?” Jen muttered, her voice pitched low but unmistakably laced with judgment. “She looks… off. Like she’s watching a UFO landing.”

 

“Lack of sex,” Wanda replied without missing a beat, spearing a cherry tomato with surgical precision, her tone matter-of-fact.

 

Jen’s mouth curled into a smirk. “She looks more like she’s high. Staring out that window like she’s expecting to see something magical. What’s she hoping for, the moon at noon?”

 

Both women leaned in slightly, conspiratorial. The chatter around them in the bustling café — clinking cutlery, steaming espresso machines, low jazz playing from ceiling speakers, faded behind the hum of their curiosity.

 

Agatha didn’t respond. She hadn’t even blinked.

 

Her fingers were wrapped tightly around her coffee cup, its warmth long since faded. Her gaze remained locked on the window, or more accurately — on the figure just beyond it.

 

Rio.

 

She stood as if placed there by a mischievous god, backlit by the early afternoon sun, her silhouette golden, her posture far too casual to be natural. She wore a laughably cliché high school uniform: pleated plaid skirt, fitted white shirt, navy sweater tied over her shoulders, and black knee-high socks. The disguise might’ve worked if not for the way Rio carried herself, with an undeniable, almost predatory elegance. She didn’t blend in. She dominated the space, even as she leaned lazily against the glass with her head tilted and a smirk dancing on her lips.

 

Agatha’s jaw clenched. Her pulse throbbed at her temple.

 

Rio lifted a single brow, cocking her head, lips parting just slightly as if to say, Well? Say something, pet.

 

Agatha inhaled sharply through her nose, pretending to be deeply focused on the lukewarm coffee in front of her.

 

Jen nudged Wanda with her elbow. “Seriously. She’s been zoning out like that all lunch. You think something’s up with Ralph?”

 

Wanda shrugged, her fork spinning idly in her salad. “I don’t know. But I’m betting on a midlife crisis. Probably fantasizing about running away with some sexy twenty-five-year-old and trading her minivan for a convertible.”

 

“Mm. Classic projection,” Jen mused, raising her cup.

 

Agatha’s eyes snapped back to her tablemates. Her voice cut the air cleanly.

 

“I can hear you, you know.”

 

Both women jerked slightly, caught mid-sip, guilty smiles spreading across their faces like children caught whispering during class.

 

“Good,” Wanda said without missing a beat. “Maybe if you can hear us, you can explain why you’re acting like a ghost just walked over your grave.”

 

Agatha’s grip tightened on the cup, her knuckles blanching. “I’m fine,” she said, the words brittle and sharp-edged.

 

Jen crossed her arms and raised a skeptical brow. “You sure? Because you’ve been staring at that window like it owes you money. What’s so interesting out there?”

 

Agatha’s jaw flexed. She refused to look back, she could feel Rio’s stare. Could practically hear her smirk.

 

“Nothing,” she muttered, reaching for her fork again.

 

Behind the glass, Rio crossed her arms in a near-perfect imitation of Wanda’s earlier posture, then raised one elegant hand to mime sipping from an invisible wine glass, pinky out, exaggerated. Her smirk widened into a grin so smug it made Agatha’s eye twitch.

 

Wanda leaned forward, resting her chin in her palm, her bracelets clinking softly against her wrist. “Come on, Agatha. Spill it. You’ve been acting weird since I picked you up this morning. Did something happen? Like… major?”

 

Agatha dragged a hand through her hair, her fingers catching slightly in a tangle. “It’s just work stress. The usual.”

 

Liar, Rio mouthed dramatically, placing both hands over her heart like a swooning heroine in a soap opera. Then she mimed vomiting, complete with a full-body retch.

 

Agatha’s eye twitched again. Her fork hovered above her plate, unmoving.

 

Jen narrowed her eyes. “You know, if you keep bottling stuff up like that, you’re gonna end up on one of those viral TikToks. The kind where some suburban mom explodes in a Trader Joe’s.”

 

Agatha sighed heavily, forcing a tight, teeth-baring smile that didn’t reach her eyes. “Really. I’m fine.”

 

Jen shrugged, not buying it but deciding to let it slide. “Alright. But if you start talking to the moon or howling at it, we’re calling a therapist.”

 

Across the glass, Rio pressed her hands together in prayer, mouthing Please do before bursting into silent laughter, her shoulders shaking, eyes gleaming with delight.

 

Agatha glared at her before turning back to her plate, stabbing a piece of lettuce with unnecessary force.

 

“Can we just eat?” she snapped.

 

“Sure,” Wanda said, stretching lazily and settling back into her chair with a grin. “But for the record? I’m still voting for lack of sex.”

 

Agatha groaned and let her fork drop onto her plate with a metallic clatter.

 

Rio, doubled over in laughter now, mouthed That’s two for two, then blew her a kiss through the glass.

And Agatha, cheeks burning, could only stare at her salad and hope the universe would swallow her whole.

Agatha sat hunched over a long oak table in the quiet solitude of the library, her fingers buried in her hair, eyes burning from too much reading and not enough sleep. The faint scent of aging paper lingered in the air, mingled with the musty, familiar scent of polished wood and the distant hiss of air vents overhead. Towering stacks of books framed her like barricades, some half-read, others covered in sticky notes and scribbled annotations. Her pen danced frantically across the page, but her thoughts were fractured.

 

Focus, she told herself, under her breath. Just focus. She’s not here. You’re alone.

 

Her hand trembled slightly as she underlined a phrase, “Transcendental Manifestations of Eternal Forces”, for the third time. It didn’t matter. None of it was sticking. Not with Rio still haunting the edges of her memory like perfume you couldn’t wash off.

 

Then—

 

“Hello, darling.”

 

The voice curled behind her ear like smoke, warm, amused, and maddeningly soft.

 

Agatha screamed.

 

The pen shot from her hand and skittered across the table like a spooked insect. She jerked around in her chair, heart slamming into her ribs, breath caught somewhere between fury and fear.

 

And there she was.

 

Rio sat casually on the edge of the table beside her, one leg draped over the other, fingers pressed against the wood as she leaned back like she owned the place. She wore all black, tight slacks, an open blazer over a fitted turtleneck, boots with heels sharp enough to be illegal in several countries. Her expression was all teeth and mischief.

 

“Ms. Harkness!” The librarian’s stern voice cracked from across the room like a whip. “This is a library, not a rock concert. Silence, please.”

 

“Sorry,” Agatha mumbled quickly, cheeks burning as she sank lower into her chair, avoiding the judgmental glares from the nearby tables.

 

Rio snickered under her breath, her voice like velvet soaked in wine. “Subtle as always, I see. Honestly, you’re making it too easy.”

 

Agatha narrowed her eyes and hissed, “What is wrong with you? You can’t just sneak up on me like that!”

 

Rio shrugged one shoulder with practiced indifference, the movement sending a silky ripple down her sleeve. “I can, and I did. Besides,” she said, glancing around with exaggerated curiosity, “this place is so… quaint. Old wood, soft lighting, the smell of dust and desperation. Really does something for me.”

 

“This is a library, Rio,” Agatha hissed, her voice sharp but low. “People come here to study.”

 

“Yes, yes,” Rio murmured, leaning closer until her breath ghosted over Agatha’s cheek. “And you came here to bury yourself in a pile of crumbling theories so you can pretend you’re not unraveling. But you are, aren’t you, darling?”

 

Agatha stiffened, her fingers curling into fists. She hated how Rio could say so little and yet push her to the edge so effortlessly. “What do you want, Rio?” she asked, her voice colder now, controlled.

 

Rio pressed a hand over her heart in mock offense. “What makes you think I want anything? Maybe I just missed you. Maybe I just wanted to see how stunningly tense you look under all that righteous fury.”

 

“Go enjoy someone else’s company,” Agatha snapped, snatching her pen off the floor and trying to refocus on her notes. Her handwriting was shaking. "Out! You’re distracting me.”

 

Rio gave a throaty chuckle and reached for one of the books in Agatha’s pile. She flipped it open with casual arrogance, skimming the pages like they were a menu. “Hmm... ‘Ancient Concepts of Universal Balance’. How very on-brand. This is bullshit 

 

Agatha’s jaw clenched. She reached out and yanked the book back, slamming it shut. “Put that down,” she growled through gritted teeth.

 

“Touchy, touchy,” Rio teased, her lips curving upward. “You used to love when I touched your books. And your—”

 

“Do not finish that sentence,” Agatha snapped, a whisper of warning in her voice. Her face was flushed again, but not from embarrassment, this time, it was the heat of tightly leashed fury... and the sting of memory.

 

Rio leaned forward, voice dropping to a purr. “Your hands are shaking, professor. I’m starting to think it’s not the workload that’s got you so flustered.”

 

Agatha turned away, jaw tight, her chest rising and falling faster than it should. She kept her gaze locked on the open book in front of her, even though she couldn’t read a single word.

 

Rio smiled, lazy, confident, a little cruel. She reached across the table and plucked a sticky note from one of the pages, holding it up. “You still use these? Adorable.”

 

Agatha snatched it from her fingers. “You have five seconds to leave before I forget this is a public place.”

 

Rio arched an eyebrow. “And then what? You’ll make a scene?” Her smile deepened, eyes gleaming. “Oh, please, darling. Do.”

 

Agatha exhaled sharply, trying to calm her pulse. But Rio was close now, too close, and the scent of her, smoke, lilac, and something ancient, wrapped around her like a noose.
