“I will make you regret this,” Agatha muttered under her breath.

 

Rio leaned in again, her voice a soft sigh against Agatha’s ear. “You already do, baby. That’s the fun part.”

 

She slid off the table with fluid grace, her boots landing soundlessly against the library’s worn floorboards. The scent of her followed, smoke and wildflowers and something older, something Agatha refused to name. Rio circled her like a predator amused by the prey’s attempt at calm, her presence overwhelming, her silence deliberate.

 

“You know, darling,” she said, voice low and teasing, her words like silk wrapping around Agatha’s spine, “you could just ask me.”

 

Agatha didn’t look up. Her grip tightened on the page beneath her fingers. “Ask you what?” she whispered, already regretting the question, because Rio always answered.

 

“Anything,” Rio replied, her heels echoing softly as she continued her slow orbit. “Everything.”

 

She stopped behind her and bent down, the heat of her body grazing Agatha’s back. Her lips brushed the shell of Agatha’s ear, her breath warm and maddening. “Why you summoned me. Why I’ve stayed close all these years. Why you’re so drawn to me… even though you’d rather die than admit it.”

 

Agatha’s whole body tensed. Her knuckles blanched as she gripped the edge of the table with enough force to splinter it. She tried to steady her breathing, but her chest was tight, her skin prickling with tension.

 

Her words came out brittle. “You’re delusional.”

 

“Am I?” Rio purred, satisfaction dripping from every syllable.

 

“Ms. Harkness!” the librarian’s voice cracked through the air like a whip, her glare slicing over her glasses with the precision of a dagger. “Do I need to ask you to leave?”

 

Agatha straightened abruptly, clearing her throat. “No,” she said quickly, jaw clenched. “I’ll be quiet.”

 

Rio leaned away, laughing softly as she dropped into the chair beside her with the ease of someone who believed she belonged anywhere. She tucked a leg beneath her, smirking as she balanced on the edge, completely at home in Agatha’s discontent.

 

“You’re fun when you’re flustered,” she murmured, biting her lip. “I should do this more often.”

 

Agatha closed her eyes, breathing through her nose like she was about to commit a felony. “If I ignore you, will you go away?”

 

Rio hummed thoughtfully. “Unlikely.” She reached for another book, flipping it open without glancing at the title. “But feel free to try. Watching you pretend I’m not here is incredibly entertaining.”

 

Agatha let her head drop into her hands, fingers pressing into her temples. Her voice was low, strained. “You told me you couldn’t tell me anything. That it wasn’t allowed.”

 

“Exactly.” Rio propped her boots up on the edge of the table, her movements slow and unapologetic. She pulled a small nail file from her pocket, examining her fingers with the disinterest of someone who already knew she was winning. “But you called me. Which means I can play with the boundaries.”

 

Agatha’s eyes narrowed. “Then why say you’d answer anything?”

 

Rio glanced up from her nails, her smirk never wavering. “Because I will answer. It just might not be in a language you understand.” She blew on her nails and examined them. “But hey, you’re smart. Might be fun to see you try.”

 

Agatha’s sigh was long and sharp, like a valve releasing steam before she exploded. She turned back to the thick, yellowed tome splayed before her — the fragile pages etched with Latin phrases and chaotic sketches of hooded figures and skeletal forms. Her fingers hovered over a passage detailing Death’s presence during the Black Plague. Something about cold winds. Unseen eyes. A presence that arrived before breath left the lungs.

 

She swallowed.

 

“Why do you appear to some people and not others?” she asked, her voice careful.

 

Rio didn’t look up from filing her nails. “Imagine explaining to your dear friend Wanda that you’re seeing Death. That’s why. I only appear to those who are dying, Agatha.”

 

Agatha flinched at the bluntness. Her heartbeat quickened. “But I’m not dying.”

 

Rio stilled. The nail file stopped mid-stroke. Then, slowly, she set it down. Her lips curved into a knowing, dangerous smile. Her voice dropped to a velvet murmur.

 

“Ah… but you did die.”

 

She leaned back in her chair, folding her arms across her chest, letting the silence linger between them like bait.

 

Agatha’s breath caught in her throat. She turned to her, eyes wide. “What do you mean, I died? When?”

 

Rio tilted her head, the soft golden light of the library catching the edge of her cheekbone like a halo, or a warning. “You’re clever,” she said, her tone syrupy and mocking. “Figure it out.”

 

Agatha stared at her, heart pounding. Her palms were slick. The overhead lights buzzed faintly, as if the universe itself leaned in to hear what she’d say next. But Rio simply reclined, arms behind her head, smiling as if she held every secret in the world, and Agatha was just now beginning to realize how many of them were about her.

 

Agatha snapped the book shut with a sharp thud, the sound echoing through the vaulted hush of the library like a gunshot. Heads turned briefly, but she didn’t care. Her glare was laser-focused on Rio, who remained impossibly composed, perched like a queen bored of her court.

 

“Fine,” Agatha growled, her voice low and furious. “Let’s try this. Why do you care about me and my family? Why are you still here?”

 

Rio raised a single brow, her smirk softening into something that looked almost… introspective. Her tone shifted, warmer, lower, as if laced with genuine gravity. “Because your family is closer to me than most,” she said, gaze never leaving Agatha’s face. “Closer than they should be.”

 

Agatha narrowed her eyes, the words sinking like cold lead into her gut. “What does that mean?”

 

“It means,” Rio continued, taking a slow, predatory step closer, “you’re not tangled up in this because of bad luck, Agatha. There’s more at play here than you realize. This isn’t random. You’re chosen.”

 

The table creaked under Agatha’s weight as she leaned forward, the tension in her body crackling just beneath the surface. Her voice trembled with frustration. “Then explain! Stop talking in circles like this is some twisted riddle!”

 

Rio’s mask cracked just slightly. Her calm, cool air gave way to a sliver of restrained emotion—tension pulling tight across her shoulders, her mouth set firm, the corners twitching with something she didn’t let spill.

 

“I told you,” she said, her voice lower now, more commanding, “I can’t give you direct answers. There are rules. Chains. And I wear them better than most, but they’re there.”

 

She stepped closer, her boots whispering against the wood. She stopped just beside Agatha, her voice brushing against her skin like silk drawn across a blade. “But I’m here for a reason, and so are you. Now, if you’re done interrogating me, maybe ask yourself why you keep coming back to these books. Why you need to know.”

 

Agatha’s hands curled into fists again, the edge of the table digging into her palms. She didn’t answer. She couldn’t. The truth was an ache in her throat she didn’t want to name.

 

Rio paced slowly, circling her again like a tide, inescapable, slow, seductive. Her presence filled every inch of Agatha’s senses: the soft rasp of her boots, the barely-there scent of lilac and ash, the way the air seemed to shift when she moved.

 

“You keep digging into these dusty old pages,” Rio murmured, her tone almost sing-song, teasing. “Reading about Death in plagues, in myths, in tragedies. But you’re not just curious.”

 

She stopped behind Agatha and leaned in, her breath a warm ghost across Agatha’s ear. Her voice was intimate now, sultry and dangerous.

 

“You’re not looking for answers. You’re looking for me.”

 

The words ignited something in Agatha’s chest, a flare of heat that shot straight down her spine.

 

With a sudden motion, she shoved the book shut again and stood, her chair groaning in protest. “Enough, Rio.” Her voice shook, part fury, part something else she refused to name. “I don’t have time for your riddles. Either help me or leave me alone.”

 

Rio tilted her head, the amusement returning, slow and wicked. “Oh, but you love my company,” she said, stepping into Agatha’s space without hesitation. “Admit it. Even if I annoy you. Even if I frustrate you. You want me here. Why do you think that is, Agatha?”

 

Agatha turned to face her, jaw tight, eyes blazing. “You’re insufferable. That’s why.”

 

Rio placed a hand over her heart in mock offense, the motion graceful and theatrical. “Insufferable? Me? I’m being helpful.”

 

“You’re not helping,” Agatha snapped, stepping forward, their bodies almost brushing now. “You’re dancing around every question. You appear out of nowhere, refuse to leave, and act like this is all some game.”

 

Rio’s smile faltered, not gone, but changed. It became something deeper. More dangerous. She stepped closer still, until their breath mingled, until Agatha could see the quiet intensity simmering behind those dark, ancient eyes.

 

“It’s not a game,” Rio said, voice low and lethal. “You think I enjoy this? Being here? Bound to you like this? I’m not here because I want to be. I’m here because you brought me back. And until you figure out why, neither of us is going anywhere.”

 

Agatha’s breath hitched, her spine pressing back against the table. The weight of those words dropped hard in her chest.

 

“I didn’t ask for this,” she said quietly, but there was no conviction in it. Only guilt. Regret.

 

Rio’s gaze softened, not quite kind, but understanding. “Didn’t you?” she said gently. “Every whispered prayer. Every desperate plea. Every night you begged for change, for freedom, for something real. You may not remember, but some part of you does know.”

 

Agatha’s fists clenched. Her pulse thundered in her ears.

 

“Knows what?” she demanded, her voice a whisper, hoarse.

 

“That we’ve done this before,” Rio said. “And we’ll do it again, until you’re ready to understand.”

 

For a moment, the room held its breath. Even the books seemed to hush.

 

Then Rio pulled away, the tension in her body unraveling like a bow being untied. She perched herself back on the edge of the table, effortlessly elegant, a wicked glint returning to her eyes.

 

“Take your time, darling,” she said with a slow smile, twirling the nail file between her fingers again like a weapon she didn’t need to use. “I’m not going anywhere.”

 

Agatha glared at her, fury and confusion churning in her gut, before she snatched the book from the table and turned on her heel. Her footsteps echoed as she stormed down the aisle, heart pounding, throat tight.

And from behind her, Rio’s voice followed like smoke curling through keyholes, soft, amused, and impossible to ignore.

 

“We’ll talk again soon, Agatha,” she purred. “I’ll make sure of it. Te veo.”

 

Chapter 3: Chapter 3

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The late afternoon sun bled through the tall windows of Agatha’s living room, casting long, golden shafts of light across the hardwood floor. Dust hung in the beams like suspended time, and everything felt too quiet, too heavy. The couch’s fabric itched against her palms as she sat stiffly, back straight, hands clasped tight in her lap. On either side of her, her children sat unnaturally still.

Nicole, usually full of side-eye and snark, stared down at her knees, her fingers anxiously tugging at a loose thread on her shirt. Nick, half-leaning against Agatha's arm, held his breath like he was trying not to exist. Both of them watched the officers standing in front of them as though waiting for a verdict.

 

One of the officers, an older man with a kind face half-hidden behind a graying beard, cleared his throat, shifting the clipboard in his hands. “Mrs. Harkness, we understand this isn’t easy,” he said gently. “But we need to go over a few more details about Ralph’s disappearance.”

 

Agatha forced a smile that didn’t quite reach her eyes. Her lips were dry, and she tasted the coppery tang of anxiety at the back of her throat. “Of course, Officer Daniels,” she said, her voice even but brittle. “Ask what you need to.”

 

The younger officer beside him, a woman with short dark hair and sharp, calculating eyes, flipped open her notepad. Her gaze flicked from Agatha to Nicole and back again, missing nothing.

 

“We’ve been reviewing the timeline again. Ralph was last seen about six months ago, correct? Around the time you were hospitalized for food poisoning?”

 

Agatha nodded once, tightly. “Yes,” she said, careful. Measured. “I was in the hospital for two days. Ralph had gone out to pick up groceries... and I never saw him again.”

 

She could still remember the moment clearly, lying in that sterile hospital bed, nausea clenching her stomach, and the eerie, oppressive silence that followed. No calls. No visits. But being watched.

 

Nicole shifted beside her. The couch cushion creaked under her small, nervous movements. “Do you think he’s…?” Her voice cracked, too thin to finish the sentence.

 

Dead. The word hung there, thick and silent, like fog.

 

“We’re not drawing conclusions yet,” Officer Daniels said gently, giving the girl a reassuring nod. “But it’s been a significant amount of time without contact or leads.”

 

Nick looked up, his wide, dark eyes brimming with something too complicated for his age. “Are you going to arrest my mom?”

 

The question sliced through the room like a knife. Agatha’s body jerked, her head snapping toward him. “Nick,” she said sharply, cheeks flushing. “Don’t say that.”

 

The young officer smiled, but it was a tight, forced thing. “No, of course not,” she said. “We’re just gathering information right now. These things take time.”

 

Agatha exhaled slowly, a controlled breath to push down the panic rising like bile in her throat. Her pulse pounded in her temples, and she could feel Rio’s presence, like a whisper at the edge of her thoughts. She could sense her. Somewhere in the house. Watching. Listening. Feeding off this.

 

She did this, Agatha thought. This is her chaos. Her mess. And mine to clean.

 

“Is there anything else you remember, Mrs. Harkness?” Officer Daniels asked, snapping her back into the moment. His eyes were kind, but searching. “Anything unusual Ralph might’ve said or done before he disappeared?”

 

Her mind flicked through a thousand images. A cold look across the dinner table. The way his voice snapped just before she doubled over in pain. The moment she realized he knew she was going to get sick. And Rio’s voice, You wished for it to end. So I ended it.

 

Agatha clenched her fists in her lap. Her nails bit into her palms.

 

“No,” she said finally, forcing the word through clenched teeth. “Nothing unusual. He was his normal self.”

 

The younger officer looked up, her eyes narrowing just slightly. “We noticed some tension between you two,” she said carefully. “Statements from neighbors suggest arguments, about finances, time spent away from home… anything like that escalate?”

 

Agatha’s jaw tightened. She could feel her children tense beside her.

 

“We had disagreements,” she said flatly. “Like any couple. But nothing extreme.”

 

There was a pause. A beat too long.

 

Then Officer Daniels nodded slowly, jotting something down. The tension in the room crackled like static.

Nicole leaned a little closer to Agatha, and Agatha could feel her daughter’s gaze flicker to her face, searching for something solid to hold onto. Nick stayed quiet, but his small hand crept into Agatha’s lap and curled around hers.

 

She squeezed back. She couldn’t protect them from everything. But she could lie to keep them safe.

 

Behind them, somewhere beyond the walls and the careful silence, she swore she heard the faint sound of a soft laugh, lazy, feminine, and cruel.

 

Rio.

 

Agatha’s eyes flicked toward the hallway. Her voice when it came was calm, composed, but laced with steel.

 

Nicole crossed her arms, her body tense, her voice a bitter whisper that cut through the thick air. “He wasn’t exactly a great dad,” she muttered, her eyes flicking toward her mother with equal parts defiance and weariness.

 

“Nicole,” Agatha snapped quietly, her tone sharp and immediate, slicing through the tension like a whip. Her glare was brief but unmistakable. Not now.

 

The two officers exchanged a quick glance, some silent agreement passing between them, a note of interest logged without needing words. But before either of them could follow up, a sound broke through the silence.

 

Laughter. Soft, distant. Dripping with mockery. It floated down from upstairs like a ghost’s breath.

 

Agatha froze. Her blood iced over in an instant. Her pulse stuttered. Her body went rigid, fingers curling into fists where they rested against her thighs.

 

The younger officer’s eyes sharpened, already stepping forward. “Did you hear that?”

 

“It’s probably just the pipes,” Agatha said, too fast, her voice strained at the edges. She forced a short, brittle chuckle. “This house is old. It groans like it’s alive sometimes.”

 

Nicole and Nick shifted nervously beside her. Nick reached out instinctively, his small fingers brushing the back of Agatha’s hand. Nicole pressed her lips together, not buying the excuse, but not daring to say more in front of strangers.

 

Officer Daniels hesitated, clearly unconvinced, but unwilling to push. “Mrs. Harkness,” he said slowly, his voice dipping into something almost sympathetic, “if you remember anything — anything at all — you need to let us know.”

 

Agatha rose, smoothing her skirt with trembling hands, concealing the tension in every breath. “I will,” she said. “Thank you, officers.”

 

The front door clicked shut behind them. The moment it did, the house seemed to exhale, like it had been holding its breath the whole time. Silence pressed in again, heavy, suspicious.

 

Nicole turned to her mother, her voice low, loaded. “Mom… was it her?”

 

Agatha didn’t answer. She couldn’t. Her mouth opened, but nothing came out. Instead, she moved slowly toward the stairs, her bare feet almost soundless against the polished wood floor. Her hands were trembling.

She stopped at the bottom step. The air was colder now, thick with her presence. That scent again: lilac and ash, sweet and ancient.

 

“Rio!” she hissed, barely above a whisper, her voice cracking with fury. “Where are you?”

 

No reply. But Agatha knew better. The silence wasn’t absence, it was intention.

 

“Mom?” Nick’s voice was soft. Fragile. He tugged at the hem of her sleeve. “Is everything okay?”

 

Agatha forced a smile so strained it felt like it might shatter her jaw. She crouched, smoothing back his hair, pressing a kiss to his temple. “It’s fine, baby. Go upstairs. Both of you.”

 

Nicole hovered for a moment longer, brows pinched together in quiet suspicion. But after a glance at her little brother, she grabbed his hand and led him up the stairs without another word. Their footsteps faded with each step, until only silence remained.

 

And then, like smoke sliding from shadow, she appeared.

 

Rio leaned lazily against the bannister of the staircase, one leg crossed over the other, fingers trailing along the railing as if admiring her own entrance. She looked effortless, stunning, wrapped in a dark silk robe over a lace bodysuit that was entirely too inappropriate for the setting. Her lips curled into a smirk so sharp it felt like a blade pressed to Agatha’s neck.

 

“Miss me?” she purred, head tilted, a glint of something cruel dancing in her eyes.

 

Agatha’s entire body coiled with fury. Her arms crossed as if holding herself together. “What the hell was that?” she snapped, her voice trembling with the effort to stay low. “Are you trying to get me arrested?”

 

Rio’s smirk widened as she descended a step, her voice as soft as it was infuriating. “Please, darling. If I wanted you arrested, I’d let them find what’s left of Ralph in the crawlspace.” She paused, then added with mock innocence, “Oh wait, there’s nothing left.”

 

Agatha’s jaw clenched. Her fists balled at her sides.

 

Rio moved in, slow and deliberate, her bare feet silent against the staircase. “That laugh?” she whispered, voice sliding over Agatha’s skin like a lover’s hand. “That was just a reminder. A little heartbeat in the walls. A taste of what happens when you keep pretending this isn’t real.”

 

Agatha held her ground, even as Rio stepped onto the same level, their bodies just inches apart. The heat between them was unbearable. She could smell her now, sweet and smoky, dizzying and maddening.

 

“You’re reckless,” Agatha hissed. “My children were right there.”

 

“And yet, you lied for me,” Rio whispered, her tone molten. “Defended me. Protected us.” She leaned closer, her lips grazing Agatha’s ear. “You’re mine, Aggie. And you always will be.”

 

Agatha’s breath hitched. She hated her body for responding, heart pounding, heat crawling up her spine, every nerve aware of Rio’s proximity.

 

“I should hate you,” she whispered, trembling.

 

Rio smiled against her skin, her voice a dark promise. “Oh, you do. Just not enough.”

 

“They could’ve taken me!” Agatha hissed, her voice barely above a whisper but brimming with venom. Her fists trembled at her sides, her whole body taut like a drawn bow. “Arrested me. In front of the kids!”

 

Rio’s laughter spilled from her lips like silk sliding over steel, soft, smooth, and laced with mockery. She leaned against the banister with an effortless grace that made Agatha’s rage feel clumsy and hot-blooded by comparison. “Relax, darling,” she purred, crossing her arms slowly over her chest. “I was just having a little fun. Those cops wouldn’t believe you even if you told them the truth.”

 

Agatha’s eyes narrowed. “How do you know that?”

 

Rio tilted her head, her dark hair slipping over one shoulder, voice low and mocking. “Because, Agatha, the truth sounds insane. ‘The embodiment of Death took my husband and now she’s haunting my house’? Really? They’d have you in a straitjacket before you could finish the sentence.”

 

Agatha’s jaw clenched so tight it ached. Her nails dug crescent moons into her palms. “You took him, didn’t you?” she spat, stepping forward. Her voice cracked with the weight of everything she’d been trying not to say. “Ralph. You took him.”

 

Rio’s playful smirk flickered, like a candle caught in a breeze. It didn’t vanish entirely, but her gaze sharpened, settled, steady now, darker. “He was annoying, yes,” she said, her voice cool and smooth as polished stone. “But you know I don’t take anyone who isn’t ready. Ralph’s disappearance isn’t on me... not entirely.”

 

Agatha’s throat tightened. “Then what happened to him?”

 

Rio gave a shrug that was too casual, too perfect, like it had been rehearsed. “That’s something you’ll have to figure out for yourself, darling.” She took a slow step closer, her eyes never leaving Agatha’s. “But let’s just say... your little wish for him to disappear? It didn’t go unheard.”

 

Those words hit like a slap.

 

Agatha’s stomach turned, a sharp twist of guilt and horror and helplessness. Her lungs felt too small. Her vision tunneled. “I never meant —” she started, voice breaking, but Rio cut her off.

 

“Didn’t you?” she asked, softly now, almost sympathetically. “Even if it was just for a moment, with your head buried in your hands, choking on bitterness. You thought it. And darling…” she smiled, stepping into her space, “I hear everything.”

 

The heat in Agatha’s chest turned to fire. She surged forward, grabbed the front of Rio’s silk blouse, and yanked her close. Their faces were inches apart, breaths mingling, eyes locked.

 

“Where is he, Rio?!” Agatha growled, her voice shaking, her grip tight and trembling.

 

Rio’s eyes sparkled with amusement, but the corners of her mouth twitched into something darker. She didn’t resist, didn’t even flinch. Instead, she grinned, slow and dangerous. “Careful, darling,” she murmured, her tone suddenly thick with suggestion. “Don’t make me fall in love with you. Again."

 

Agatha’s eyes burned. “Rio, I swear to God—”

 

“I don’t know,” Rio said, cutting her off. And for once, the smile faded completely. Her voice was calm. Flat. Honest.

 

“Li—”

 

“Ah, ah, ah.” Rio raised a finger between them, resting it gently against Agatha’s lips. The touch was feather-light, but it made Agatha freeze. “Before you accuse me of lying, remember, I can’t. It’s against the rules, my dear.”

 

Agatha slapped her hand away, her chest heaving. “He’s the father of my children,” she spat, voice raw.

 

Rio arched an elegant brow, the smirk sliding back into place like it had never left. “Technically and biologically,” she said, her tone mock-casual, “I’m the father of your children.”

 

Agatha’s face froze in disbelief. Her eyes widened. “What—?”

 

Before she could think, her hands jerked, giving Rio a sharp shake, nothing painful, but violent enough to crack the illusion of calm between them.

 

Rio threw her head back and laughed, the sound rich and delighted. “What?” she said breathlessly. “I’m just saying!”

 

“I’m going to kill myself,” Agatha muttered, stumbling back from her, hands trembling, pressing them into her forehead like she could push the moment out of her mind.

 

Rio straightened her shirt, completely unbothered, and adjusted her collar with the air of someone having far too much fun. “Oh, don’t be so dramatic,” she cooed. “You’d just end up back with me faster.”

 

Agatha turned away, needing the distance, her hands pressed against the nearest wall like it was the only thing keeping her upright. Her chest ached. Her mind spun. “You’re impossible,” she whispered, barely able to speak. “You just stand here, making jokes, while my life — my family — falls apart.”

 

Rio didn’t speak right away. When she did, her voice had changed. Softer. Still sensual, still teasing, but layered now, like honey poured over something deeper.

 

“Darling,” she said, stepping behind Agatha, just close enough for her presence to be felt. “Your life isn’t falling apart. It’s rearranging itself.”

 

She reached out slowly, one fingertip brushing a stray strand of hair from Agatha’s neck. The touch was too gentle. Too careful.

 

“Painfully?” she continued, her voice a warm hum. “Yes. Messily? Absolutely. But sometimes... things have to break before they can be put back together.”

 

Agatha exhaled shakily, but said nothing.

 

“That’s not comforting,” she finally muttered, her tone brittle, distant.

 

Rio’s hand lingered, just barely touching the curve of her shoulder. “It wasn’t meant to be,” she said, voice like velvet stretched thin over something sharp. “But you’ll figure this out, Agatha. You’re stronger than you think.” A pause. “Even if you don’t see it yet.”

 

Agatha stood there, staring blankly ahead, her throat tight, her heart unsteady. And Rio just smiled behind her, patient. Waiting.

 

Agatha stood rooted at the bottom of the stairs, arms crossed tightly over her chest like a shield. Her fingers dug into the soft knit of her sweater, nails pressing crescents into the skin beneath. The dim light from the hallway above cast long shadows across the floor, pooling around her feet like tension made visible. Her eyes were locked on Rio, burning with frustration, her jaw clenched tight enough to ache.

 

“You’re not as helpful as you think you are,” she said coldly, the words laced with exhaustion and something deeper, fear, maybe, or longing she refused to name.

 

Rio chuckled softly, stepping forward with a lazy grace that made Agatha want to scream. Barefoot, each movement soundless, sensual — deliberate. Her robe slipped slightly off one shoulder, revealing just enough skin to be distracting without being indecent, and she clearly knew it. Every step brought that scent closer — warm skin, lilac, something unplaceably ancient.

 

“And yet,” Rio murmured, voice like velvet soaked in smoke, “you keep pulling me closer every time. What does that say about you, Agatha?”

 

Her eyes shimmered with mischief and challenge, glinting beneath the soft golden glow of the hallway sconces. There was no cruelty in her tone, but there was power — calculated, restrained, and wielded with precision.

Agatha opened her mouth to snap back, ready to tear her apart with whatever sharp words she had left in her, but stopped herself just as quickly. Her lips parted, then pressed into a firm line. She couldn’t think straight with Rio standing there — so close, so calm, so in control. Her heartbeat was too loud in her ears.

 

Instead, she turned, spine rigid, and started up the stairs with quick, angry steps. “I don’t have time for this,” she muttered under her breath, more to herself than to Rio.

 

But Rio’s voice followed her, effortlessly composed, with that maddening, light-as-air tone that always made Agatha feel like she was one step behind.

 

“Let me know when you want to continue our little therapy sessions,” she called, amusement curling at the edges of each word. “I’m always here for you, darling. Te veo.”

 

Agatha paused at the landing, one hand braced on the railing, her back to Rio. Her body tensed as if debating whether to turn around, whether to yell, cry, or fall apart completely. But she didn’t give her the satisfaction.

 

She climbed the rest of the stairs in silence, teeth grinding, heart thudding. Behind her, Rio stood at the base of the steps, her smile slow and certain, watching the woman she’d been bound to for lifetimes walk away again, pretending it meant nothing. Knowing it meant everything.

Agatha descended the stairs with brisk, purposeful steps, her fingers gripping the banister like she might snap it off if it gave her even the slightest resistance. Her breath was sharp in her chest, her jaw set in a tight line. All she wanted was distance, just a sliver of normalcy, a moment to gather herself. But normal had left this house a long time ago.

 

She glanced back over her shoulder. Of course.

 

Rio was right behind her, as always. Her bare feet made no sound on the wooden steps, her pace unhurried, almost amused. The contrast between Agatha’s tension and Rio’s elegance was maddening.

 

By the time Agatha stepped into the living room, her pulse skipping with irritation, Rio had already claimed the couch like a throne. She lounged languidly between Nicole and Nick, one arm draped lazily over the backrest, her legs tucked underneath her like a lounging cat. She wore a smirk that had no business being so natural on the lips of Death.

 

Agatha’s eyes darted to her children.

 

Nick leaned against Rio’s side, utterly at ease, grinning as if this were just another Saturday morning. Nicole sat with her legs crossed, chatting comfortably, as though she weren’t casually sharing the couch with the end of all things. The sight sent a hot, crawling sensation across Agatha’s skin, rage, disbelief, and something deeper... a flicker of fear.

 

“I’m going to make dinner,” Agatha said, her voice controlled but tight as piano wire. She turned sharply, heading toward the kitchen, needing to move, to do something. She stopped in the doorway and turned just slightly, her gaze cutting toward Rio. Her voice was flat, too casual to be casual. “Do you... eat? I mean, do you eat food? Human food?”

 

Rio, now stretched belly-down across the back of the couch like a lounging cat, rested her chin on her hands and tilted her head, her eyes sparkling with amusement. “Human and non-human,” she said lightly. “Technically, I don’t need sustenance like you mortals, but I do find the idea of a family dinner amusing. Sitting around a table, passing bowls of things. Tension simmering over casseroles. It’s... quaint.”

 

Agatha’s fingers curled tightly around the doorway, her knuckles pale. “So... that’s a yes?”

 

Rio’s grin widened as she winked. “Of course.”

 

“Fine,” Agatha muttered, already turning away. Her footsteps hit the tile harder than necessary. “Dinner with Death. Wonderful. Just another normal day.”

 

The kitchen was cooler, quieter, but only marginally. The air carried faint notes of old garlic and citrus cleaner, but it did little to soothe her frayed nerves. She yanked open the fridge, pulled out ingredients with clipped movements. Tomatoes. Chicken. An onion that she nearly crushed in her grip. Every slice of the knife hit the cutting board like punctuation.

 

From the living room came the sound of Nick’s excited voice, high and bright with joy.

 

“Rio, do you like dinosaurs? Because I have this awesome T-Rex toy upstairs, and he’s super cool!”

 

Agatha paused, knife mid-chop.

 

“I do love a good T-Rex,” Rio replied, her voice warm, playful. “Strong, determined… though I’ve met a few who were rather dramatic about their extinction.”

 

Nick giggled like it was the funniest thing he’d ever heard.

 

Nicole chimed in, dry and amused. “What about people who think they’re the center of the universe?”

 

“Oh, darling,” Rio said with a theatrical sigh, “I’ve met plenty of those.” Her voice curved around the words like silk, and then she added with a glance toward the kitchen, “Some even cook dinner like they’re being watched by fate itself.”

 

Agatha’s grip on the knife tightened, her lips pressed into a razor-thin line. She chopped a bell pepper like it had personally offended her.

The sizzle of oil in the pan couldn’t drown out the laughter from the other room. The clatter of utensils couldn’t mute the sight that played over and over again in her head, Rio, not just lingering in the periphery of her world, but nestled into the heart of it. Trusted. Loved by her children.

 

Her chest ached, a slow coil of guilt and helplessness wrapping tight around her ribs.

 

“Just get through dinner,” she muttered to herself, voice barely audible over the crackling oil. “Just survive dinner.”

 

But even as she said it, she knew, Death didn’t just visit. She moved in.

 

Nick climbed up onto the couch with the graceless energy only a child could pull off, legs folding beneath him as he settled beside Rio like it was the most natural thing in the world. He looked up at her, eyes wide and bright, face flushed from excitement and warmth. The cartoon on the TV continued to flash colors across the room, but his attention was fully on her.

 

“If you’re friends with Mom,” he asked curiously, “does that mean you’ve known her for a really long time?”

 

Rio turned her head toward him, her dark eyes catching the light, glinting with quiet amusement. A knowing smile played at her lips as she tucked a lock of hair behind her ear. “Oh, sweetie,” she said, her voice smooth and velvet-soft, “your mom and I go way back. Longer than even she remembers.”

 

On the other end of the couch, Nicole gave a small scoff, though there was no real sarcasm behind it. She folded her arms and leaned back, head tilting slightly. “That’s hard to believe. Mom walks around like she’s got her entire life catalogued and under control. You’re saying there’s stuff even she doesn’t know?”

 

Rio laughed, a rich, warm sound that melted into the soft hum of the living room. Her fingers tapped lightly on her knee. “Oh, your mom knows plenty. But there are some... chapters of her story that haven’t quite come back to her yet.”

 

Nick’s face lit up, legs bouncing beneath him. “So that means you’re like... a superhero or something?”

 

Nicole rolled her eyes, but it was playful. “She’s not a superhero, dork. If anything, she’s like... the mysterious aunt who shows up in black leather and sunglasses and makes all the neighbors nervous.”

 

Rio pressed a hand to her chest in faux offense, her expression dramatic. “Excuse me, I am always the most interesting person at the party. And I don’t even need sunglasses to prove it.”

 

Nick giggled, inching closer. “So what do you do then? For real?”

 

Rio hesitated — just a flicker of something crossing her features, her smile dimming as her tone dropped into something more intimate. “I... help people find what they’re looking for,” she said gently. “Even if they don’t know they’re looking yet.”

 

Nicole raised an eyebrow, her voice softening into something almost teasing. “That’s vague. Are you like, I don’t know, a therapist?”

 

Rio chuckled, brushing a strand of hair from her face as she leaned forward, arms resting on her thighs. “Let’s just say I specialize in endings... and beginnings.”

 

Nick tilted his head, one hand resting on her arm now, completely at ease. “Like when a book ends and you find another one to read?”

 

Rio turned to look at him fully, her expression warming. “Exactly, sweetheart. You’re a clever little one, aren’t you?”

 

Nicole smiled, and the teasing left her tone. She watched Rio with an odd fondness, the kind that didn’t come from just knowing someone, but from recognizing them in a deeper way.

 

“So you’re not just here for Mom,” she said, almost as a statement. “You’re here for us, too.”

 

Rio paused, her gaze flickering toward the kitchen where Agatha was still moving noisily around, the clatter of pots underscoring the hum of domestic chaos. For a moment, her features softened completely. She leaned back slowly, exhaling through her nose.

 

“Let’s just say,” she murmured, “your family is... special. You’re more connected to me than most. That makes you important.”

 

“Important like superheroes?” Nick said eagerly, throwing his arms up with an exaggerated grin.

 

Rio laughed and pulled him into a side hug, kissing the top of his hair. “Sure, baby. Just like superheroes.”

 

Nicole leaned against the arm of the couch, gaze thoughtful. “Do you think Mom will ever remember everything?”

 

“She will,” Rio said, her voice certain, her fingers absently brushing Nick’s curls. “When she’s ready.”

 

Nicole nodded slowly. Then, after a beat, she said softly, almost shyly, “You’re a little dramatic sometimes, Mama.”

 

Rio blinked.

 

She stopped mid-motion. The moment hung, suspended between a heartbeat and the next. Her eyes widened just slightly, not with shock, but with something else. Something far more tender.

 

Her lips parted. “You… Can't you repeat that?”

 

But Nicole didn’t repeat it. She just smiled faintly, her gaze drifting back to the TV.

 

Rio stared for a breath too long, her throat tightening as she blinked away something suspiciously close to emotion. Her hand curled around Nick just a little tighter, and when she finally spoke again, her voice was quiet, warm.

 

“Well,” she murmured, “I suppose I do like the sound of that.”

 

And from the kitchen, Agatha stood silently by the doorway, a wooden spoon in hand, unnoticed. Her eyes lingered on the three of them, her children curled against the most dangerous creature she’d ever known, and for a moment… safe.

 

Agatha’s voice cracked through the cozy hum of the house like a whip: “Dinner’s ready! Get in here!”

 

It shattered the moment in the living room, pulling everyone from the warmth of cartoons and low murmurs. Rio turned her head slowly, a grin unfurling across her lips as her dark eyes danced between the kids. “Looks like it’s time to see what your mom whipped up,” she said with a wink. “Shall we?”

 

Nick didn’t hesitate. He grabbed her hand, small fingers curling around hers as if they’d done it a hundred times before, and tugged her eagerly toward the dining room. His laughter echoed off the hallway walls.

Nicole trailed just a step behind, arms folded, her gaze locked on Rio’s back. Her expression was unreadable, sharp and quiet, a look that sat between intrigue and caution. She didn’t say anything, but she didn’t look away either.

 

In the dining room, the warm scent of roasted vegetables and garlic filled the air, undercut by the faint citrus tang of the floor cleaner Agatha had used earlier, too harsh, too sterile, like she’d tried to scrub the day away. She was already at the table, laying plates down with more force than grace, the silverware clinking loudly against ceramic. Her shoulders were stiff, jaw clenched, and the fake calm stretched across her face was wearing thin.

 

Rio entered last, still hand-in-hand with Nick, her bare feet silent on the hardwood. She looked around with an amused hum, taking it all in: the too-neat table, the simmering tension clinging to the walls like steam. She locked eyes with Agatha just as the final plate landed on the table with a sharp clack.

 

“This should be fun,” she murmured, sliding into the seat between the kids with a catlike smirk.

 

Dinner started in a quiet lull. Forks clinked against plates. Nick hummed between bites, swinging his legs under the table. Agatha didn’t look up. Her eyes stayed trained on her food, chewing mechanically, as if pretending hard enough could will Rio out of existence.

Rio, on the other hand, looked completely at ease. She sat back with the kind of confidence that came from knowing she was the most interesting person in the room. She cut her chicken slowly, delicately, savoring every bite like it was a performance meant just for Agatha.

 

Then Nicole, casual as air, reached across the table and said, “Mama, can you pass the salad?”

 

Everything stopped. Agatha’s hand froze halfway to her glass, the word hitting her like a slap. Her heart stuttered.

 

Rio looked up, blinking in surprise. For a breath, her smirk faded, replaced by something softer, quieter. Her eyes met Nicole’s, and her voice caught ever so slightly before she recovered.

 

“Oh,” she said with a smile that trembled just at the corners. “Of course, sweetheart.”

 

But at the same moment, Agatha reached for the salad bowl too. Their hands touched. Flesh against flesh. Warm. Electric.

 

Agatha jerked her hand back like she’d touched fire. Her chair scraped violently against the hardwood as she recoiled, breath catching in her throat. She choked on a mouthful of food, eyes wide as panic surged through her.

 

“Mom?” Nicole leaned forward.

 

Agatha coughed, gagging, hand clutching at the edge of the table. Rio moved before anyone else could.

 

She was behind Agatha in a flash, one arm around her midsection, the other bracing her with practiced strength. “Hold still, darling,” she whispered into Agatha’s ear, her voice a calm undercurrent of control.

 

Three firm compressions. Then Agatha sputtered, the bite of food dislodging onto her plate, saliva on her chin, breath coming in sharp gasps. She leaned over the table, both hands braced against the wood, her face flushed deep red.

 

“Better?” Rio asked, brushing a hand down Agatha’s back like one might soothe a panicked animal.

 

Agatha waved her off, her voice raw. “Yes... thank you.”

 

Rio stepped back without gloating, her touch vanishing like smoke. She returned to her seat with graceful ease, wiped her hands on a napkin, and picked up her fork again, as if nothing had happened.

 

But Agatha wasn’t done.

 

She turned toward Nicole, her voice cracking with the weight of everything that had just erupted. “She’s not your mother!”

 

The words hit like a thunderclap.

 

Nicole flinched, but only slightly. She sat up straighter, her face defiant. “She is!” she snapped, voice rising. “I look like her, don’t I? You’ve said it yourself, Mom!”

 

“That doesn’t mean anything,” Agatha fired back, her eyes wild. “It’s coincidence. It’s genetics—”

 

Nicole slammed her hand on the table. “It does too! I’ve seen her before!”

 

Agatha froze. “What are you talking about?” she said slowly, her voice hushed now, like she was afraid of the answer. “You couldn’t have seen her before. That’s impossible. You're imagining things!”

 

Nicole looked away for the first time, her voice quieter. “I used to talk to her when I was little. In my room. I didn’t know her name then... but I knew her.”

 

Rio sat silently between them, eyes calm, watching the storm she hadn't created, but had never tried to stop. She glanced at Nicole, her expression unreadable but tinged with warmth, then looked to Agatha, something unspoken passing between them. Something deeper than fury. Older than rage.

 

Agatha sank into her chair, her body suddenly heavy.

 

Nicole sat up straighter, her hands curled into small, pale fists on the edge of the table, eyes fixed on her mother with unshakable resolve. “I saw her,” she said, voice steady and unflinching. “When Father yelled at you about my crib being too expensive. She was standing by the door. She looked at me and told me everything was going to be okay.”

 

Agatha’s breath caught in her throat. “What?” she whispered, her voice barely audible, trembling like a leaf caught in the wind. “That’s... that’s impossible, Nicky. You were...” her voice cracked, “you were inside me.”

 

But Nicole didn’t flinch. She didn’t soften. Her voice only grew more certain. “Not for her, Mom. She told me you were upset. And I didn’t like it. I started kicking because I was scared. I didn’t understand why you were sad, but I knew something was wrong. Then I saw her. She wasn’t in the room with you. She was in a forest...”

 

Nicole’s eyes flicked toward Rio, who remained perfectly still, her hands folded in her lap, gaze steady and unreadable.

 

“She said if I stopped kicking, she’d play with me someday,” Nicole continued. “And I did. I stopped. Because she made me feel... safe.”

 

The room went silent. Even the clinking of forks had stopped.

 

Nick, who normally couldn’t sit still for more than a minute, sat frozen in his seat, his fork still hovering in midair. His eyes were wide as saucers, flicking between his sister, his mother, and the calm, dark presence of Rio, who watched it all unfold without a word.

 

Agatha’s hand came up slowly, instinctively, pressing to her mouth as emotion surged through her like a tide. Her fingers trembled. The kitchen light above flickered once, unnoticed.

 

She couldn’t breathe. Her mind dragged her backward through time, unbidden—

 

That day.

The nursery wasn’t finished. The walls still unpainted, the floor littered with unopened boxes and empty promises. She had been kneeling beside the half-assembled dresser, her back aching, one hand absently stroking her swollen belly, when Ralph burst through the doorway.

 

His voice was loud. Angry.

 

“You used my card for that overpriced piece of wood?” he barked, waving the receipt like a weapon. “You think we can afford this shit? You think you’re the only one that matters now just because you're carrying it?”

 

He didn’t say her. He said it.

 

Agatha didn’t respond. She barely heard him. The baby was kicking hard, rhythmic bursts like tiny fists hammering from inside. Not just movement, panic.

 

She wrapped both arms around her belly, trying to still the frantic rhythm, trying to soothe the child who didn’t yet have words, only fear. She whispered nonsense, soft things: It’s okay, baby. I’ve got you. I’ve got you. But it didn’t stop.

 

Until...

 

It did.

 

Suddenly, utterly.

 

Like a hush had fallen across her womb. The air had stilled. The pounding in her chest quieted. Peace.

 

A strange, enveloping stillness had wrapped around her and the child inside her. A warmth, not hers. Not from the house. Something older. Calmer. As if another presence had taken her daughter into invisible arms and said, shh. I’m here.

 

Rio.

 

Agatha blinked back to the present, eyes stinging with tears. Her heart thundered in her chest, her limbs heavy with disbelief and something far more dangerous: recognition.

 

Across the table, Rio met her gaze. Calm. Composed. But there was something new in her eyes now, an unspoken yes. She didn’t need to say it.

 

She had been there. She always had.

 

Agatha shoved her chair back abruptly. The scrape of wood against tile jolted Nick, who jumped in his seat. Agatha rose on trembling legs, swaying slightly as she found her footing. Her voice cracked as she forced the words out.

 

“Excuse me.”

 

She didn’t look at Rio again. She couldn’t. Her eyes burned. Her chest was too tight.

 

She turned and left the dining room, each step up the stairs heavier than the last. Her legs barely obeyed her, the air in her lungs too thick, like she was breathing under water.

 

In the hallway above, she closed the door to her bedroom behind her, leaned back against it, and finally let the tears fall, silent and hot, tracking down her cheeks as her hands came to cradle her belly in memory.

 

Rio had held her child before she ever had. And somehow, that broke her more than anything else ever could.

Agatha sat hunched at the edge of her bed, elbows on her knees, face buried in her hands. Her breathing came in short, uneven bursts as if the weight in her chest had grown too heavy to lift. Her skin was warm and flushed, sticky with the salt of her tears, and the once-soft cotton of her sweater clung uncomfortably to her damp skin. The room felt too still — too intimate — as if the air itself were waiting for her to break.

 

She didn’t notice the door open.

 

Not until the unmistakable sound of soft footsteps crossed the threshold like silk brushing over stone.

 

“Agatha.”

 

Her name, spoken low, smooth, and careful, curled around her spine like smoke. She looked up sharply, her tear-streaked face hardening instantly as her eyes locked on the figure in the doorway.

 

Rio.

 

“What are you doing in here?” Agatha snapped, voice rough. “Get out.”

 

Rio didn’t flinch. She stood calmly in the doorway, her usual amusement absent. No grin. No sharp edges in her voice. Just stillness. That unsettling, graceful calm that made Agatha want to scream.

 

“You’re upset,” Rio said quietly.

 

“Brilliant observation,” Agatha shot back, whipping her head away as she turned her back to her. Her voice cracked with strain. “Leave me alone.”

 

But Rio, inevitably, infuriatingly, didn’t move away. She stepped inside instead, shutting the door behind her with a soft click that felt final.

 

“You know I’m not going to do that.”

 

Agatha’s fists clenched at her sides, the anger bubbling again beneath her grief. “You’ve already done enough,” she spat, spinning around. Her eyes were glassy, her cheeks flushed and streaked, but her voice was fire. “My kids, my daughter, thinks you’re her mother. Do you even realize what that feels like? What it means to me?”

 

Rio didn’t move from her spot near the wall. Her expression didn’t shift defensively. She absorbed the words like a stone absorbs rain, quietly, completely.

 

“I didn’t ask for this,” she said, her voice like the edge of a lullaby. “I didn’t choose to be seen by them. They saw me because they could. Because they’re...” her eyes flicked downward for a beat, then back to Agatha, softer now, “connected to me in ways you don’t yet understand.”

 

Agatha barked a laugh, bitter and broken. “That doesn’t make it okay,” she snapped, standing abruptly. Her legs shook under her, but she didn’t falter. “You’ve been in their lives without my permission. Without my knowledge. Without my consent.”

 

Her voice shook, too thick with fury and grief to hold steady.

 

Rio’s expression didn’t falter. If anything, it grew... tender. No less commanding, but touched by something close to sorrow.

 

“I was never here to harm them,” she said. “Or you. I'm here to help.”

 

Agatha scoffed, wiping angrily at her face. “You’ve turned my life into a twisted myth,” she muttered. “You walk in and speak in riddles and pull apart everything I thought I knew. And you call that help?”

 

Rio took a slow, deliberate step forward. Her voice dropped into something intimate, something rich with dark sweetness. “You’re scared,” she said, voice like velvet. “And I get it. But Agatha...” Another step. “You’ve been scared for a long time. Long before I ever came back.”

 

Agatha’s breath hitched. Her eyes flicked up, meeting Rio’s. The air between them thickened. Her lips parted to argue, but the words never made it out. Instead, her shoulders sagged, slowly, like all the fight had been wrung out of her. She turned away again, but this time, she didn’t run. She didn’t shout.

 

She stared at the floor, her voice small.

 

Rio stepped closer, her bare feet soundless against the hardwood floor, the faint scent of ash and lilac wrapping around Agatha like a memory she hadn’t realized she missed. Her voice dropped lower, velvet-smooth, intimate enough to stir something fragile.

 

“You’re carrying so much, Agatha,” she said, her breath brushing the space between them. “Too much. Let me help.”

 

Agatha’s head shook once, sharply, as if trying to dislodge the very idea. “I don’t want your help,” she whispered, the words tight and cracking.

 

Rio’s lips curved — not into a smirk, but into something far more dangerous: understanding. She stepped in until her presence filled the space behind Agatha like a second shadow, her voice a soft hum of inevitability.

 

“Liar,” she murmured against the nape of Agatha’s neck, just close enough that the warmth of her breath kissed skin. “You’ve been holding this alone for so long… you’ve forgotten how it feels to let someone in.”

 

Agatha’s breath hitched. Her hands rose to her face again, fingers trembling as they pressed into her cheeks. She wanted to scream. Or disappear. Or be held. She didn’t know which.

 

“I don’t need you,” she said, her voice a tremor pretending to be defiance.

 

“You don’t need me,” Rio echoed, her tone calm, certain, laced with dangerous patience. “But right now… you could use someone.”

 

The silence between them deepened, thick as velvet. Agatha’s shoulders rose and fell with shallow breaths, and for a moment, she stayed frozen, like a glass figure balanced on the edge of a shelf.

 

Then Rio lifted her hand and placed it gently on Agatha’s shoulder. It was nothing more than fingertips at first, barely a touch. But it was grounding. Anchoring. A silent command wrapped in care.

 

“I’m here,” Rio said, and there was no mockery in it. No riddles. Just her voice. Just her.

 

Agatha stood perfectly still, her pride fraying at the edges. Her heartbeat pounded in her ears, a wild rhythm behind her ribs. And then, slowly, with the resistance of someone who didn’t know how to be soft anymore, she turned.

 

Her eyes were red, lashes damp, mouth set in a line that wanted so badly to tremble. Her gaze flicked from Rio’s face to her outstretched arms, uncertain. Unwilling. Needing.

 

For a long beat, she hesitated. And then she stepped forward.

 

Rio’s arms came around her instantly, no hesitation, no permission needed. She pulled Agatha in close, firm but careful, like she’d been waiting to do this for centuries. Her hand splayed across Agatha’s back, her thumb brushing in slow, calming circles. The other slid up to cradle the back of her head, fingers threading through her hair with gentle command.

 

Agatha’s body was stiff at first, her fists pressed against Rio’s chest. But that warmth,  so steady, so maddeningly familiar, seeped into her. She sagged into the hold, her forehead dropping to Rio’s collarbone as the tension in her spine began to dissolve.

 

The room smelled like wood and lavender, and Rio. That distinct, otherworldly scent that clung to skin and memory and dreams. Agatha breathed it in like air after drowning.

 

Rio tilted her head, resting her chin lightly against Agatha’s crown. “That’s it,” she whispered. “Let it go, love. Just for now.”

 

Her tone wasn’t sweet, it was dominant, coaxing, commanding, and kind all at once.

 

Agatha’s hands opened slowly, clutching the back of Rio’s shirt, her fingers curling into the silk. Her breathing slowed. The ache in her chest loosened, not gone, but lighter. Bearable. Neither of them spoke. The only sound was the low hum of Rio’s breathing, the occasional creak of the house settling around them, and Agatha’s quiet, uneven exhales against her skin.

 

Agatha stayed pressed against Rio, her forehead resting lightly against the dip where Rio’s collarbone met the soft curve of her shoulder. Her breath was shallow, trembling through parted lips, as if even the act of breathing was too vulnerable now. The warmth of Rio’s embrace soaked into her skin, her body betraying her by melting into it. And for a fleeting moment, it was quiet. Not the kind of quiet that left space for thought, but the kind that blurred reality, that made everything outside the room feel like static on a forgotten channel.

 

But then she felt it.

 

It wasn’t physical, not at first. It was a pulse, subtle, electric, buried deep under her skin like a memory rising from the bones. The kind of memory that doesn’t belong to any one moment, but lives in the body regardless. Her lungs faltered. Her chest tightened. The air thinned.

 

Something was waking up.

 

Rio’s hand moved slowly against her back, her fingertips dragging in slow, deliberate circles, grounding and hypnotic. The scent of her skin, wild earth and burnt sugar, filled Agatha’s lungs. Her touch wasn’t demanding, but it held weight, intention. It lingered with purpose.

 

“You’re holding your breath,” Rio murmured, her lips brushing the shell of Agatha’s ear, the warmth of her breath threading over her skin like silk.

 

Agatha tensed. She jerked slightly in Rio’s arms, breath catching. Her heart beat harder, faster, and her body turned rigid, like a deer cornered between the urge to run and the desire to stay. She pulled back, not far, just enough to look up.

 

Their eyes met.

 

That spark flared again, sharp and intimate, like a match being struck in a dark room. It wasn’t lust, not exactly. It was deeper than that. It was recognition. Like a word sitting on the tip of the tongue, begging to be remembered. Like a name written across time.

 

“I’m fine,” Agatha lied, her voice shaky, brittle around the edges. She tried to step back, to sever the tether between them.

 

But Rio didn’t move. Her arms remained, loose but certain, her dark eyes following Agatha’s every flicker, like she was memorizing her all over again. “You don’t have to pretend with me,” she said softly, her voice like velvet dragged across skin. “Not anymore.”

 

Agatha’s breath hitched again, and her pride twisted painfully. She hated how Rio’s voice, her hands, her gaze, could peel back every barrier she had carefully built. “I’m not pretending,” she managed to say, though it sounded like a child insisting they weren’t crying.

 

Rio’s lips curled, slow and knowing, her tone laced with fondness and just a hint of dominance. “You always were a terrible liar.”

 

That sentence struck something inside her, sharp and disarming. It reached places Agatha had forgotten existed. She felt naked under it.

 

“This,” she whispered, her voice almost inaudible, “this isn’t... it’s not...”

 

“Not what?” Rio murmured, dipping her head slightly, her breath brushing across Agatha’s cheek. Her voice held that teasing restraint again, low and coaxing, like a hand sliding under silk sheets. “Not real? Not dangerous? Not familiar?”

 

Agatha’s lips parted, but no words came. Her mind tried to form protests, but they collapsed under the weight of Rio’s closeness. She couldn’t lie — not to her. Not when every cell in her body was betraying her calm facade.

 

“Stop looking at me like that,” she breathed, voice fraying at the edges. “Like... like you know something I don’t.”

 

Rio’s eyes darkened, glinting with quiet fire. She tilted her head just slightly, a slow drag of her gaze over Agatha’s face. “Maybe I do,” she said, the words soft but molten. “Maybe I’ve always known.”

 

Agatha’s chest burned. Her fingers curled into fists, nails pressing crescent moons into her palms. She couldn’t take it. The way Rio looked at her like she belonged to her. Like she always had.

 

Suddenly, with a jolt of desperation, she stepped back, freeing herself from Rio’s hold as if it had scalded her. She turned away, pressing a hand to her sternum, her palm flat against her hammering heart.

 

“This is ridiculous,” she muttered. “This is insane.”

 

Behind her, Rio remained still. Poised. Patient. But there was something softer now, something that lingered behind her teasing. A gentleness that carried power.

 

“Is it?” she asked, voice quieter now, less silk and more shadow. “Or is it something you’ve known all along?”

 

Agatha’s jaw clenched. Her hand trembled against her chest. “I don’t know what you’re talking about.”

 

“Yes, you do.” Rio’s voice throbbed with certainty. “You feel it. That spark. That pull. You’ve felt it before. You’ll feel it again. You just need to remember.”

 

Agatha closed her eyes. And in that instant, she did.

 

Not clearly, but flashes. A forest. Hands brushing hers. A promise spoken in another lifetime. A kiss that burned through lifetimes. Her breath hitched again, this time a gasp of grief and longing wrapped around a name she couldn’t say.

 

“Get out,” she whispered, her voice cracking, soft but no less commanding.

 

Rio didn’t answer right away. For a moment, the silence was heavy, thick with all the things unsaid. Then her voice came, gentle and reverent.

 

“If that’s what you want… te veo.”

 

She stepped away. The absence of her body left the room colder. Emptier.

 

When Agatha finally opened her eyes again, Rio was gone. But the ache remained. Pressed deep into her chest, under her skin, like an ancient truth waiting to rise.

The house had fallen into a hushed rhythm, a lull that only came once little feet stopped pattering across the floor and voices quieted behind closed doors. After Agatha sent her message, short, apologetic, raw, Nicole responded with a single word: Okay. And just like that, she stepped in, shouldering a responsibility too heavy for someone her age but worn like second skin.

 

Downstairs, Rio did everything as Agatha would have done, but softer, smoother, with an ease that came not from routine but from an intimate knowledge of how this home moved when no one else was watching. She cleared the plates, her movements graceful and deliberate, as if every clink of porcelain was a ritual. She washed the dishes by hand despite the dishwasher, her fingers caressing each piece like it mattered.

 

When she found Nick, he was half-asleep on the couch, curled around a stuffed dragon. Rio lifted him easily, carried him upstairs in silence, and guided him through brushing his teeth, washing his face, and climbing into his pajamas. He didn’t ask questions. He never did. He trusted her without ever needing to say why.

 

Tucking him in, Rio leaned close, her palm resting gently over his heart as she whispered a single word in Latin, her lips brushing the shell of his ear like a kiss: Somnum.

 

The boy’s lashes fluttered once, then stilled. His body relaxed instantly, the kind of peace that no dream would dare disturb. Rio stayed there for a moment, fingers brushing his hair from his forehead, her eyes dark and ancient. There was grief in her silence, but also reverence.

 

She stood slowly and moved to Nicole’s room.

 

The door was slightly ajar, the golden light from inside spilling into the hallway like warmth. Nicole sat at her vanity, brushing her long, dark hair in slow, practiced strokes. Her eyes were fixed on her own reflection, but her mind was far from it.

 

Rio stepped in without knocking. She didn’t have to. She simply walked in like she belonged there, barefoot and quiet as dusk. Without a word, she picked up the comb and took over. Her fingers were cool and steady, weaving through Nicole’s hair like she was untangling memory itself.

 

Nicole didn’t resist. She simply lowered her eyes, her voice barely audible.

 

“Why can’t I tell her the truth, Mama?”

 

Rio paused, the brush stilled in her hand. Their eyes met in the mirror, one gaze steady, the other searching.

 

“Because her spirit wouldn’t survive it,” she said, her voice soft, tinged with sadness but never weak. “She has to remember on her own, amor meu. The truth has to rise from her bones, not fall from someone else’s lips.”

 

Nicole’s brow furrowed. She tugged at the hem of her sleeve, a gesture she’d picked up from Agatha. “But she’s suffering. She doesn’t remember the magic. She doesn’t remember... Nick. Not the first version of him. Not what happened to him. And she doesn’t even know where I came from. What I am.”

 

Rio’s hand moved gently down a lock of Nicole’s hair, smoothing it.

 

“She remembers his face. His laugh. But not his death. Not yet. That pain would shatter her right now. She’s still holding herself together with spit and saltwater.”

 

Nicole’s voice cracked. “She doesn’t remember me at all. That I didn’t come from her body. That I wasn’t born. That I happened because she loved you.”

 

Rio knelt beside her now, one hand resting on the girl’s knee, the other cradling the side of her face.

 

“No,” she whispered. “You weren’t born. You were created. Not from flesh, but from love so ancient and fierce it defied every law the universe tried to place on us. You came into being not because she knew me, but because her soul remembered mine. Because it needed me.”

 

Nicole’s eyes shimmered, the tears catching in the soft glow of the vanity bulbs.

 

“I’ve always been different,” she whispered. “I can feel when someone lies. I can see... things people can’t. I knew you weren’t human the second I saw you.”

 

Rio smiled faintly, brushing a tear from Nicole’s cheek with the back of her knuckle. “No. I’m not.”

 

“Then what are you?” Nicole asked, voice trembling, not from fear, but need.

 

Rio hesitated.

 

She brushed the comb once more through Nicole’s hair, gaze fixed on the mirror. “I’ll tell you, someday,” she said finally. “When it’s time.”

 

Nicole didn’t press. She nodded, accepting. Trusting. And yet the question still hung there, like incense in the air, sweet, thick, unanswered.

 

Rio rose and kissed the top of her head.

 

“It was you, Nicky,” she murmured. “You were the light that called her back to me. Through death, through lifetimes, through dimensions. You are love itself. Born not from pain, but from hope.”

 

Nicole turned in her chair and wrapped her arms around Rio’s waist, burying her face against her. “What if she never remembers?”

 

Rio stroked her hair, her voice steady as a vow. “Then I will stay. I will wait. Like I always have. Because love doesn’t yield, and neither do I.”

 

They stayed like that for a long moment. The room humming with something invisible, timeless, aching, eternal.

 

Then Rio pulled back slightly and smiled. “Now. One more brush and then bed. Your mother will need you tomorrow.”

 

Nicole nodded, wiping at her cheeks, her smile small but true. And as Rio finished combing through her daughter’s hair, the threads between them glowed with something more powerful than magic: love that defied death itself.

 

Chapter End Notes

Just a reminder, not everything that happened in the MCU will happen here. One example is the existence of Nicole. She is an original character, where I placed her to be the personification of love, which in the MCU is that little girl from Thor's movie Love&Thunder.In that film she is the daughter of Eternity, here she is the daughter of Death.
Thank you, and see you in the next chapter.

Chapter 4: Chapter 4

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Agatha thrashed beneath the tangled sheets, her breath ragged, her skin slick with sweat. The blanket had slipped halfway off the bed, her legs tangled in the fabric as though she were trying to escape something unseen. Moonlight spilled through the window in pale streaks, casting her room in shifting shadows, but it was the chaos behind her closed eyes that held her captive.

 

In her dream, she was no longer herself.

 

She was younger , barely past twenty. Her face, unmarred by time, was smeared with soot and blood, strands of her dark hair clinging to her damp skin. Her heart pounded so loudly it drowned out the silence of the forest. The scent of iron hung thick in the damp night air, mixed with the earthy musk of crushed leaves and the sharp tang of ozone — residual magic still crackling in the aftermath of battle.

Around her, the clearing was a grave.

Bodies lay strewn in twisted shapes, limbs contorted, mouths frozen mid-scream. The witches she had fought — some familiar, some once-friends — were now nothing more than bloodstained corpses, their charms and talismans shattered beneath them. Their magic, once brilliant and wild, now gone like smoke in the wind.

 

Agatha stood in the center of the carnage, her chest heaving, her palms soaked in red. Her fingers trembled, still glowing faintly with the residue of deadly spells.

 

She had survived. She had won.

And she felt nothing but dread.

 

“You think this is strength?”

 

The voice came like a blade across her skin, familiar, sharp, and cold. Agatha’s spine straightened with instinctive fear as she turned.

 

From the mist beyond the trees, her mother emerged. Evanora’s form was regal, untouched by the blood that marred Agatha’s own. Her long cloak trailed behind her like smoke, and her eyes, those pale, glacial eyes, locked onto Agatha with judgment so potent it stole the air from her lungs.

 

“They attacked me,” Agatha gasped, her voice hoarse. “They wanted to dismantle the coven. I had no choice—”

 

Evanora’s lip curled in disgust. “There is always a choice.”

 

She walked through the corpses like they were scenery, her boots never touching blood. She stopped in front of Agatha, who could barely meet her gaze. “You could have disarmed them. Bound their magic. Rendered them powerless.”

 

“They wouldn’t have stopped,” Agatha cried, her voice cracking. “They called me a threat. They came for me. For us.”

 

“And so you slaughtered your own kind,” Evanora said flatly, her voice a cold wind. “Witches, Agatha. You killed witches.”

 

Agatha’s hands curled into fists, nails biting into her palms. “I protected the coven. I protected you.”

 

Evanora raised her hand without warning. An invisible force crashed into Agatha’s chest like a hammer, throwing her to her knees. Her vision blurred from pain as magic ripped through her body, searing her nerves.

 

“You are reckless,” Evanora hissed, stalking closer, her magic pulsing like fire. “You think power is permission. You think domination is security. But you are wrong.”

 

Agatha screamed, her back arching as another wave of magic surged through her, carving pain deep into her bones. “I was trying to save—”

 

“Silence!” Evanora’s voice cracked through the forest like thunder, and the air turned heavier. The leaves trembled in the trees above, the very ground beneath Agatha seeming to recoil.

 

“You are a disgrace,” Evanora seethed. “You don’t understand balance. You don’t know restraint. You are dangerous, and if you don’t learn control, you will destroy everything left in your path, including yourself.”

 

Agatha’s body convulsed with agony, her tears turning the dirt beneath her into mud. Her mother’s magic crushed her — merciless, suffocating. And then—

 

Darkness.”

 

“Agatha!”

 

A voice sliced through the storm.

Agatha’s body lurched upright with a violent gasp, her hands clutching the sheets like a lifeline. Her heart slammed against her ribs, every breath a desperate gulp for air. She blinked wildly, disoriented. The nightmare still clung to her skin.

 

The moonlight had shifted across the wall, painting the room in shades of pale silver and gray. Her bedroom, her sanctuary, felt alien and fragile.

 

And sitting beside her was Rio. Not smug. Not teasing. Serious.

 

Her hand was firm on Agatha’s shoulder, grounding her, her thumb brushing in slow, soothing circles against her collarbone.

 

“You were screaming,” Rio said softly, her voice lower than usual, less a sound, more a balm.

 

Agatha’s entire body trembled beneath the damp fabric of her nightshirt. Her face was flushed, tears still clinging to her lashes. Her voice, when it came, was raw.

 

“She was there,” she whispered. “My mother. She called me a disgrace. Said I’d kill myself if I didn’t control it.”

 

Rio didn’t speak right away. She simply moved her hand from Agatha’s shoulder to her back, rubbing slow, even strokes between her shoulder blades.

 

Agatha dropped her face into her hands, her voice muffled and small. “I killed them. I remember now. I killed all of them.”

 

Rio leaned closer, her breath grazing Agatha’s temple. “They tried to kill you. You survived.”

 

“That doesn’t make it right,” Agatha said, her voice crumbling. “It doesn’t make me right.”

 

“It makes you human,” Rio whispered, her words soft but edged with power. “Even if you aren’t.”

 

Agatha looked up slowly, her eyes haunted. “She hated me.”

 

Rio’s face softened. She tucked a strand of hair behind Agatha’s ear, her fingers lingering against her cheek. “She feared you. That’s not the same.”

 

Their gazes locked, and in that silence, something old stirred again, something vast and familiar, painful and magnetic.

 

“You were never a disgrace,” Rio added, her voice a quiet command. “Not then. Not now.”

 

Agatha blinked, her vision blurring with tears she made no effort to wipe away. One slipped down her cheek, carving a slow, glistening trail to her chin. It clung there a moment, suspended, before falling, unnoticed, onto the thin cotton of her nightshirt. And still, she made no move to hide her face, no attempt to pretend she wasn’t crumbling.

For the first time in years, she allowed herself to feel, fully, deeply, painfully, and not apologize for it.

 

Her hands fell from her face, limp against the blankets pooled in her lap, and she turned her head slowly to look at Rio. There was no armor in her expression anymore. No sarcasm, no deflection. Her gaze searched Rio’s with unguarded vulnerability, as if reaching for something — anything — that could dull the burn of memory still raw on her skin. Her voice, when it came, was a fragile thing, hoarse and low, coated in ash and regret.

 

“I don’t know if I can forgive her,” she said.

 

Rio didn’t hesitate. Her reply came with the clarity of someone who’d watched the world end more times than she could count, and still stood.

 

“Then don’t,” she said simply, her voice gentle, but edged with quiet command. “Not yet. Maybe not ever. Forgiveness isn’t for them, Agatha. It’s for you. And it doesn’t have to happen now.”

 

The words settled over Agatha like warm mist, seeping into the cracks she didn’t even know she had. They didn’t lift the weight entirely, but they shifted it — made it something she could carry for a little longer. Her chest ached, her ribs tight, but she didn’t feel like she was suffocating anymore.

 

She leaned back slowly against the headboard, her spine brushing the cool wood, the pressure grounding her. The mattress dipped with her weight, her body finally beginning to ease from its coiled tension. Her head tilted slightly toward Rio, as if drawn by gravity, or something older.

 

Rio didn’t speak. She didn’t reach for her. She simply remained beside her, close enough for Agatha to feel the heat radiating from her skin. The scent of her — dark spice, warm earth, and something unnameable, wrapped around the space like a spell. She didn’t command attention, she claimed it, without force, without demand.

 

“You’re stronger than she ever gave you credit for,” Rio murmured, her voice lower now, velvet wrapping around steel. “And you don’t have to prove that to anyone but yourself.”

 

Agatha turned her face slightly, her cheek brushing the edge of the pillow, her lashes heavy with salt. She didn’t respond, not out loud. But something inside her softened, shifted. Her breath left her chest in a long, trembling sigh. Her shoulders dropped, the knot in her spine loosening.

 

The silence that followed wasn’t empty.

 

It pulsed between them, charged, dense, intimate. It spoke in glances, in the brush of breath, in the way Agatha’s fingers curled slightly in the blanket, so close to Rio’s hand but not quite touching.

Agatha sat still, her breath finally beginning to steady, though her pulse continued to beat erratically beneath her skin. Her fingers trembled as she wiped the sheen of sweat from her brow, the lingering weight of the dream clinging to her like smoke. Her lips parted as she tried to speak, but the words caught in her throat, heavy and confused.

 

“That... that never happened,” she managed, her voice raw and uncertain, like something scraped from the edge of memory.

 

Rio didn’t flinch. She tilted her head, the dark pools of her eyes unreadable, too calm for the storm swirling between them.

 

“What do you mean?” she asked, her voice low, threading through the quiet like silk on skin.

 

Agatha swallowed hard, her throat dry. “My mother... she was cruel, yes. She controlled everything. She made me feel small, unworthy. But those lights. That kind of magic. That forest. That pain...” Her voice cracked, and she drew in a shaky breath. “She never used magic like that on me. Magic doesn't exist.”

 

Rio shifted closer without a word. Her movements were slow, deliberate. She reached up and tucked a loose strand of damp hair behind Agatha’s ear, her fingers grazing her temple in a touch so careful it sent a tremor down Agatha’s spine.

 

“Are you sure, my love?”

 

The words were soft, but they pressed like fingertips against a bruise.

 

Agatha stiffened at the endearment, her eyes locking onto Rio’s. For a second, she forgot how to breathe. Her heartbeat echoed in her ears like a warning and a plea. “Yes. No... I—” She closed her eyes briefly, then forced them open again. “I don’t know. It felt so real. It felt like it happened, but it couldn’t have. Could it?”

 

Rio's hand lingered in the air for a second before falling gently to her thigh. The motion was casual, yet there was nothing careless about it. Her gaze didn’t waver.

 

“Sometimes,” she murmured, “the mind doesn’t remember the way the soul does. Sometimes, what we bury buries us back. You might not remember the details, but your heart... your heart never forgets.”

 

Agatha’s shoulders tensed, her fists tightening around the edge of the blanket. Her voice dropped to a whisper. “Then why now? Why would I dream that now?”

 

Rio leaned in, and the space between them thinned to almost nothing. Her breath brushed against Agatha’s cheek, warm, steady, maddeningly calm. The air grew heavier, thicker, the scent of her — earth and dusk and something ancient, curling around them like smoke.

 

“Because you’re starting to remember.”

 

The room stilled. Every sound, the wind outside, the rustle of fabric beneath them, the creak of the bed frame, seemed to hush as Agatha stared into Rio’s eyes, desperate for a foothold. The answer terrified her, even as it sang with a familiar ache she didn’t want to admit she missed.

 

“Remember what?” she asked, barely audible, barely brave.

 

Rio didn’t answer immediately. Instead, she reached out again, her fingers brushing softly along Agatha’s cheek. The touch was feather-light but searing, as if her fingertips carried memory in their heat. Agatha’s eyelids fluttered, involuntarily, her breath catching.

 

“You tell me.” Her voice was a challenge and a balm all at once. The kind of voice that could command kingdoms or whisper you apart.

 

Agatha’s jaw clenched, but not with anger, with resistance. Or maybe need. She couldn’t tell anymore. Her skin prickled under Rio’s touch, and she hated how easily her body betrayed her.
