The ache in her chest swelled again, sharp and intimate, the kind of pain that whispered in her bones and made her knees weak.

 

“You do this on purpose,” she breathed, her voice cracking. “You push too close.”

 

Rio didn’t flinch. Instead, her thumb dragged slowly along the edge of Agatha’s jawline, tracing the tension there like it belonged to her.

 

“And you don’t stop me. Never do.”

 

The words fell between them like a key in a lock, soft, final, undeniable. Agatha’s breath hitched. She could feel it now — the heat of Rio’s breath brushing her lips, the quiet tremble in her own hands, the pull beneath her skin like a tide dragging her in.

 

“This is a mistake,” she whispered, the plea in her voice trembling with something that wasn’t quite conviction.

 

Rio didn’t move away. Her lips hovered just a breath from Agatha’s, her dark gaze locked onto her like a tether.

 

“Maybe,” she murmured, her voice a soft, sinful promise. “But sometimes, mistakes are the only way forward.”

 

Agatha’s heart thundered in her chest, a frantic rhythm pounding against her ribs. Her fingers curled tightly around the edge of the bed, the sheets beneath her knuckles wrinkled and damp with the sweat clinging to her palms. She leaned forward before she could stop herself, her breath hitching. Rio was close — too close — their lips brushing invisible space. Heat pulsed between them, thick and electric, like a storm caught just beneath her skin.

But just as Rio’s scent, warm, earthy, and faintly metallic, like rain on stone, filled her lungs, Agatha’s eyes widened. A shiver ran down her spine. She jerked back sharply, as though burned, the tension snapping like a bowstring. Her hand flew to her chest, as if to calm the aching throb building beneath her sternum.

Across from her, Rio didn’t flinch. She remained still, watching Agatha with unsettling calm, but her eyes flickered — dark, endless, unreadable. There was something ancient in her gaze, something hungry but patient.

 

“You feel it, don’t you?” Rio asked softly, her voice a velvet whisper that seemed to curl beneath Agatha’s skin.

 

Agatha didn’t answer. She pushed herself to her feet instead, her legs stiff and unsteady. The carpet was cool beneath her bare feet, a sharp contrast to the heat rising in her chest. Her breathing was shallow, like she was trying to outrun something that had already caught her.

 

“This... this can’t happen,” she said, the words scraping out of her like a confession. “You need to leave.”

 

Rio didn’t move. “I’ll leave when you’re ready for me to go. But not before.”

 

Her voice didn’t hold defiance. It was certainty. The kind that made Agatha’s spine stiffen even more.

Agatha turned her face away, unable to meet Rio’s eyes. The air between them was thick now, heavy with the scent of memory and unsaid things. Her hands trembled slightly as she rubbed her temples, the pressure of exhaustion pressing against her temples like a vice.

 

"You should sleep, Agatha."

 

She scoffed without humor. “I can’t.”

 

"I could sing for you."

 

Agatha let out a dry, breathy laugh and turned her head sharply toward her. “Death is going to sing me a lullaby?”

 

Rio’s lips curved, slow and knowing. “You’d be surprised by my talents,” she said, her voice low and almost sinfully smooth. “But you do need sleep, so... I will if you let me.”

 

Agatha stared at her for a moment, her jaw clenched. Then, slowly, she reached forward and caught the edge of Rio’s sleeve between her fingers. The fabric was soft, softer than it looked, and her grip was firm, but hesitant, as if she hated herself for needing the touch.

 

“If you don’t annoy me, I’ll let you stay.”

 

Rio raised an eyebrow, her smirk spreading. “Oh, I wouldn’t dream of annoying you.” She leaned in just slightly, her voice dropping. “Except when it’s fun.”

 

“Get out,” Agatha snapped, the flush on her cheeks betraying her.

 

“Okay, okay.” Rio raised her hands in mock surrender, her smile widening. “I’ll stay quiet. I’ll just stand right here. Silent. Like an incredibly charming and attractive spirit haunting your room.”

 

Agatha groaned and narrowed her eyes, rubbing the bridge of her nose with two fingers. “You’re not staying in my room like some obsessive ghost.”

 

Rio leaned back against the dresser, her arms folding loosely across her chest, her hips tilting in that infuriatingly relaxed posture she always used when she knew she was winning. “Then where should I stay? The closet?” She smirked. “Took me ages to come out of there.”

 

“Oh my God,” Agatha muttered, exasperated. “Just lie on the damn bed and shut up, Rio Vidal!”

 

It happened in an instant. Rio froze, completely. Her smirk faltered, lips parting as her breath caught in her throat. Her body went perfectly still, like something delicate had cracked deep inside her.

 

Agatha frowned, caught off guard. “What’s with that face now?”

 

Rio’s voice was softer when it came, almost reverent. “Vidal.”

 

“What about it?”

 

“It’s my last name.” Her gaze locked onto Agatha’s, steady and slow. “But... Agatha, I’ve never told you that.”

 

The silence that followed was deafening. The room shrank around them. Agatha’s chest rose and fell in uneven breaths, her fingers slowly loosening their hold on her frustration as her mind scrambled.

The name had come too easily. It had rolled off her tongue like something she’d said a thousand times before.

 

Her lips parted, but nothing came out.

Rio stepped forward slowly, each movement deliberate, prowling more than walking. Her bare feet whispered across the wood floor, and the soft scrape of skin against lacquered grain was the only sound that dared to exist between them. The air felt charged, thick with heat and silence, like the moment before lightning splits the sky.

 

Her posture was elegant, predatory in the way only something ancient and certain could be. Shoulders squared, chin tilted down ever so slightly, her dark eyes locked on Agatha like she already owned every secret buried in her bones. She wasn’t approaching to conquer. She was approaching to reclaim.

There was no malice in her expression, just focus. A stillness that vibrated. Curiosity shimmered just beneath the surface of her calm exterior, but deeper still, like a current beneath ice, was something more dangerous. Longing. Hunger. Something primal wrapped in silk.

 

“So tell me, Agatha,” she purred, her voice low, smooth, and thick like honey pulled from the comb. “How do you know my name?”

 

Agatha’s breath caught in her throat. Her heartbeat surged violently, thudding against her ribs with such force she swore Rio could hear it. The name still echoed in her head like a song she didn’t remember learning but had known all her life. Her body had stilled, but her insides were rioting, blood rushing hot, nerve endings alight, her skin tight with tension.

 

Her lips trembled. “I—I don’t know,” she whispered, voice trembling like a wire pulled too taut.

 

But she did. Not with logic. Not with memory.

 

It was in the way her body leaned in when Rio stepped closer. In the tremble beneath her skin. It was in the ache low in her belly, the goosebumps on her arms, the sudden burn behind her eyes. A knowing that bypassed thought entirely, soul-deep, bone-deep. Old.

 

She couldn’t explain it. But she felt it.

 

A scent caught her, the faintest trace of clove, of warmth and storm-soaked leaves, the scent she now recognized as her. It wrapped around her like a cloak, thick and intoxicating. Familiar. Too familiar.

Rio’s gaze didn’t waver. She stepped even closer, so close now that Agatha could feel the warmth radiating off her body. Inches between them. No more.

 

“That name, my name, lives in your bones, doesn’t it?” she whispered, her breath a brush of heat against Agatha’s cheek. “You’ve said it before. With your mouth on my skin, with your teeth at my throat, with your body under mine.”

 

Agatha’s eyes fluttered, her lashes heavy with the weight of something unspeakable. A moan tried to claw up her throat and she swallowed it hard. Her hands clenched at her sides, fingers digging into the flesh of her palms as if pain could ground her.

 

“Stop,” she breathed, but the word came out like a plea, not a command.

 

Rio didn’t stop.

 

She leaned in until her lips hovered just beside Agatha’s ear, her voice a caress against the sensitive shell. “You called me home,” she murmured. “You always do.”

 

Agatha’s entire body shivered. Her knees softened, but she locked them tight. The ache beneath her ribs twisted, tightened, unfurled. Her throat was dry, her breath shaky, her skin hypersensitive to every molecule of Rio’s presence.

 

“Why do I feel like this?” she asked, voice cracking open like a confession too long denied.

 

Rio pulled back just enough to look her in the eyes, those endless eyes that held centuries, storms, and tenderness like weapons. Slowly, deliberately, she raised her hand and let her thumb trace the curve of Agatha’s bottom lip. The contact was featherlight, but it burned.

 

“Because you remember,” she said, her tone dark and reverent. “Even if your mind can’t say it, your soul already has. You remember me.”

 

Agatha’s eyes flickered shut, overwhelmed by the weight of sensation and memory and want. She saw flashes in the dark behind her lids — hands tangled in hair, bodies pressed together in moonlight, a voice gasping her name with reverence and hunger.

 

Magic. Ruin. Devotion.

 

She opened her eyes slowly, her gaze glossy, raw. “What were we?” she whispered.

 

Rio leaned in again, close enough that her lips barely brushed Agatha’s mouth, a phantom touch that sent a bolt of electricity straight to her core.

 

“Everything,” she breathed. “We were everything.”

 

Agatha’s breath trembled. And still, she didn’t pull away. “I can't”

 

Because somewhere inside her, she still belonged to Rio… And Rio... had never once stopped coming back to claim her.

Agatha drew in a shallow breath, her lungs tight, her throat aching from the weight of everything she couldn’t say. Her body still buzzed from Rio’s proximity, from the ghost of a touch that hadn’t quite happened, but nearly had. She closed her eyes for just a second, willing herself to stay grounded, to breathe past the fire curling low in her stomach and the overwhelming urge to give in.

 

Her hands trembled. Not from fear. From restraint.

 

Then she found her voice, cracked and breathless but steady enough. “Don’t make me do this...” she whispered, barely louder than a breath, her eyes fluttering open and locking onto Rio’s.

 

For a long second, Rio said nothing. Her expression didn’t flinch, but something behind her gaze softened. She stepped forward, close again, but not suffocating this time. Her hand lifted gently, reverently, and she pressed a tender kiss to Agatha’s forehead, so soft, so full of restraint it made Agatha’s knees buckle.

 

The heat that had hung between them dimmed just slightly — not extinguished, never that — but turned into something more bittersweet.

 

“I would never force you,” Rio murmured against her skin, her lips brushing warm and careful at the edge of her hairline. “Never, Agatha.”

 

She lingered for only a second longer, then pulled away. Her hand lingered near Agatha’s cheek, fingers ghosting along the line of her jaw before tucking a lock of dark hair behind her ear.

 

“I’ll wait for you,” she said, her voice low, but steady. “What I have, more than anything else, is time.”

 

Agatha’s throat closed. The tenderness in Rio’s voice, the patience laced with quiet ache, made her chest ache worse than the dream had. She looked away, as if hiding the tears prickling at the corners of her eyes, and nodded slowly.

 

Rio’s fingers caressed her cheek again, the pad of her thumb dragging lightly beneath Agatha’s eye in a slow arc. “You need to sleep,” she said softly. “Still want me to stay?”

 

Agatha hesitated. Her pride rose like it always did, a shield she’d worn for years, forged by fear and pain — but it crumbled just as easily in the face of Rio’s unwavering presence. The part of her that still didn’t understand this connection begged her to say no. But the other part — the deeper, older part that remembered without remembering, was already answering.

 

Her voice came out fragile. Honest. “Please...”

 

Rio gave the smallest nod, something reverent flickering across her face. She leaned in, not to kiss, not to touch, but to promise.

 

“Okay,” she whispered, already moving toward the bed. “I’ll just lie here. Quiet, like I promised.”

 

She settled on top of the covers, her long body stretched out in a relaxed pose, hands resting loosely on her stomach. Her eyes remained on Agatha, not demanding anything, just being there.

 

And then, with a small, knowing smile that barely curved the edge of her lips, she added, “If you need me… you already know my name.”

 

Agatha turned away, climbing under the sheets with trembling fingers. She didn’t say anything, but her body did. The way she curled toward the warmth Rio’s presence gave off. The way her breathing, though shaky, finally began to slow. And the way, despite herself, she let her hand fall a little closer to where Rio lay.

 

Just close enough to feel her there. Not touching.

But near.

A week later, Agatha sat in the familiar warmth of Wanda’s living room, sunk deep into the soft, oversized armchair in the farthest corner she could claim. The room was a haven of cozy chaos, books piled on every surface, flickering candles throwing lazy shadows across the walls, and the scent of red wine and vanilla-scented wood polish lingering in the air.

 

Jen perched on the armrest of the couch like a lounging cat, swirling her glass and grinning over the rim. Alice and Lilia Calderu were mid-battle over the book club’s latest tragic heroine, their voices alternating between impassioned and amused. Wanda swept through the room with practiced flair, topping off glasses like a theatrical bartender at a speakeasy. She hummed to herself as she moved, too aware of everyone’s moods and sharp enough to cut through any silence with a single look.

 

But Agatha wasn’t really there. Her wine sat mostly untouched in her lap. Her fingers drummed nervously against the stem, her nails clicking lightly in a rhythm she didn’t hear. The chatter, the laughter, it all came in waves. Distant. Muted.

 

Because Rio was there. Not in the way a normal guest would be. Of course not. Rio had never done anything normally in her entire unnaturally long existence.

 

She lingered just behind Agatha’s chair, close enough that Agatha could feel the heat of her breath ghosting across her neck. Her presence was magnetic and suffocating all at once. She wasn’t touching her, she didn’t need to. Her energy wrapped around Agatha like a silk noose. Every so often, she leaned in just enough to let her lips brush the shell of Agatha’s ear.

 

“You smell like cinnamon and guilt,” she murmured softly, her voice sliding like satin against raw nerves.

 

Agatha’s fingers tightened on the glass.

 

“Are you even listening, Agatha?” Jen’s voice sliced through the haze, her perfectly manicured hand waving in front of her face.

 

Agatha blinked hard, straightening in her seat with a jolt. Her voice came out too fast, too high. “What? Yes. Totally listening.”

 

Jen gave her a skeptical look, dark eyes narrowing with that particular brand of best-friend suspicion.

 

“You’re zoning out again,” she said, folding her arms. “Let me guess, work stress? Or is it Ralph?”

 

At the sound of his name, Agatha didn’t flinch. Not even a twitch. She kept her features carefully blank.

 

Wanda threw herself dramatically onto the couch beside her, draping one leg over the other like a diva settling into an interrogation. “Please. It’s not Ralph. She doesn’t even flinch anymore when we say his name. It’s gotta be something juicier.” She sipped her wine. “Secret boyfriend?”

 

Agatha gave her a sharp glare. “I do not have a secret boyfriend.”

 

Behind her, Rio let out a quiet chuckle. Her breath danced across Agatha’s neck, smug and maddening. “That would make me your secret girlfriend, wouldn’t it?”

 

The flush that bloomed in Agatha’s cheeks wasn’t from the wine. Her jaw tensed, but she refused to react. Not here. Not in front of them.

 

Alice raised an eyebrow from across the room, cocking her head like a curious crow. “Then what’s got you so distracted, Agatha? You’ve been off all week. It’s not like you.”

 

Agatha shifted in her seat, reaching for her wine with a little more urgency this time, sipping to buy herself a second of composure. The wine was sharp, tart against her tongue. She barely tasted it.

 

“I’ve just been... busy,” she offered, tone clipped and unconvincing.

 

Wanda arched a brow, unconvinced. “Busy doing what? Meditating under waterfalls? Summoning a new man from a candle?”

 

“I’m summoning something,” Rio whispered, a smile curling around every syllable. “You. Under me.”

 

Agatha choked on the wine mid-sip, coughing into her sleeve as Wanda handed her a napkin with an overly dramatic sigh.

 

“You okay?” Jen asked, though she was already smiling like she knew Agatha was lying through her teeth.

 

“I’m fine,” Agatha said quickly, forcing the words through clenched teeth. “Just... tired.”

 

“Liar,” Rio said sweetly, now casually strolling in front of her, folding her arms, her hips swaying with that impossible confidence that made Agatha’s jaw clench. “Tell them about me. Come on, I’m dying to meet your little coven of gossip queens.”

 

Agatha’s fingers dug into the arm of the chair. Every muscle in her body screamed restraint. Her lips twitched into what she hoped resembled a polite smile.

 

Wanda gave her a long look. “Seriously, Ags. We’re your friends. Whatever’s going on — you can tell us. We’re not gonna burn you at the stake.”

 

“Speak for yourself,” Lilia muttered, sipping wine. “Depends on the scandal.”

 

Rio leaned in again, her voice a low purr. “Tell them how I make you feel. How you dream of me. How your body still remembers mine.”

 

Agatha stood up so fast her glass nearly toppled. “I need air.”

 

Everyone paused. Jen blinked. Wanda sat up straighter. Alice raised both brows now.

 

“You sure you’re okay?” Wanda asked gently.

 

Agatha couldn’t take it anymore. The noise, the wine, the constant brush of Rio’s presence like a shadow against her skin — too close, too aware. Her chair scraped against the hardwood as she stood abruptly, drawing the eyes of every woman in the room.

 

“Bathroom,” she muttered, her voice too tight, too rushed.

 

She didn’t wait for a reply. Her heels clicked sharply against the floor as she exited, pulse hammering beneath her skin. The hallway felt too narrow, the walls too close, and when she finally shut the bathroom door behind her, she leaned against it as though it might hold her together. The cool surface pressed against her spine, grounding her for only a moment.

 

Her breathing was uneven, her chest rising and falling in quick bursts. Her hands trembled at her sides. Then, like silk sliding across stone, Rio’s voice emerged beside her.

 

“You’re going to blow your cover, darling.”

 

Agatha jumped, eyes snapping open as Rio appeared in the mirror, casual, poised, lounging against the edge of the sink like she belonged there.

 

She wore the smirk of someone who didn’t need permission to exist. Her hair tumbled in dark waves over her shoulder, her clothes as immaculate as ever. She looked like the embodiment of midnight: sleek, sharp, predatory. The low light glinted in her eyes like slivers of onyx, giving her a feline gleam — dangerous and darkly playful, like a black cat curled on a windowsill, daring you to try and tame it.

 

Agatha’s glare was immediate, but the heat in her face betrayed her restraint. “You’re making this unbearable.”

 

Rio tilted her head, her tone rich with mock innocence. “You’re the one who invited me into your life, remember?” She began to circle Agatha slowly, like a cat eyeing something warm and restless. “Called me. Craved me. Welcomed me in.”

 

“I didn’t invite you to haunt me,” Agatha hissed, turning her body to follow Rio’s movements. Her own reflection in the mirror looked flushed and wrecked, like someone running from a fire.

 

“Haunting?” Rio clutched at her chest, lips parting in an exaggerated pout. “No, no. I prefer the term devoted companion.” She said the words like a purr, dragging out the syllables just long enough to make them feel intimate.

 

Agatha groaned, fingers pressing into her temples. Her body felt too hot for such a small room. Her palms were damp, her breathing quick again. “You’re a insufferable bitch!”

 

“And yet…” Rio’s voice dropped to a murmur as she stepped in front of her again, the proximity enough to steal Agatha’s air. “You haven’t told me to leave.” Her fingertips hovered just above Agatha’s arm, not touching, just whispering heat between them. “Not for good, really.”

 

Agatha’s entire body went still. The silence between them stretched thick and electric, laced with all the things Agatha wouldn’t let herself say. Her mouth opened — but no words came. She didn’t move.

 

Rio’s smirk deepened. “That’s what I thought. Good girl.”

 

And just like that, with the softest rustle of her coat and a flick of energy that felt like the brush of velvet against skin, Rio vanished. No dramatic exit. Just absence. Like smoke curling out of a candle’s flame.

 

A beat later, Wanda’s voice floated faintly from the hallway. “Agatha? You okay in there?”

 

Agatha pressed a hand to her chest, willing her heartbeat to settle. “Yeah… just a minute!”

 

She stared at her reflection for a long moment, jaw tight, cheeks flushed, the ghost of Rio’s presence still tingling across her skin. And somewhere deep inside her — beneath the fear, beneath the anger — was the terrifying truth she couldn’t escape: she didn’t want Rio to leave. Not really.

Taking a deep breath that did nothing to calm the thundering of her heart, Agatha straightened her shoulders, wiped her palms against her skirt, and forced herself back into the living room. The sound of laughter, clinking glasses, and light chatter greeted her as she stepped in — comforting noises that didn’t quite reach her this time.

 

She moved like someone heading to war and not a couch full of friends, her heels silent on the rug, her posture too perfect. Her fingers tightened around the stem of her wine glass as she lowered herself into the seat, eyes darting toward the far end of the room.

Rio was still there, of course, leaning against the wall like a smug secret, arms crossed and eyes gleaming like midnight. She looked almost bored, but the twitch at the corner of her mouth betrayed her amusement.

 

Wanda tilted her head, her wine swirling lazily in her glass. “Alright, spill. What’s going on? You’ve been acting like you’ve seen a ghost.”

 

Agatha’s fingers curled tighter around the glass, the coolness of the wine doing little to soothe the heat crawling up her neck. Her eyes flicked back to Rio, who wiggled her fingers in a silent wave, brows raised as if to say, Go on, sweetheart. Tell them.

 

She turned back to her friends. Her throat was dry. Her voice, when it came, sounded far too calm.

 

“Hypothetically speaking,” she said, “what if I told you I’ve been seeing the personification of Death herself?”

 

Silence fell like a dropped pin.

 

Then—

 

Jen burst out laughing, snorting into her glass and nearly tipping it over. “Oh my God, Agatha. What are you on, and where can I get some? Seriously, is this a shroom thing?”

 

Wanda squinted. “Wait, you’re not joking?” Agatha just looked at her, unsmiling. Wanda blinked. “You’re not joking.”

 

Alice leaned forward, her eyes narrowing in suspicious curiosity. “Is this some kind of dark metaphor? Like… Death is your toxic ex? Your taxes? Your skincare routine after forty?”

 

"Yes", she thought, "she is my toxic ex".

 

Rio’s chuckle filled the room, smooth and smug like melted chocolate. “Oh, they’re way more fun in this life. I like them. Can we keep them?”

 

Agatha shot her a death glare — ironically — then turned back to her friends. “I’m not on drugs, and it’s not a metaphor. Just imagine it for a second. A literal being. Not a hallucination. Not a dream. A real, physical embodiment of Death.”

 

Jen’s grin stretched even wider. “Okay, okay, let’s run with this. What does she look like? Classic Grim Reaper? Cloak and bones? Floaty and ominous?”

 

Agatha glanced at Rio, who spread her arms in a mock theatrical gesture, lips curled in pure mischief. She was barefoot now, her black slacks hugging long legs, shirt unbuttoned just low enough to show the suggestion of a tattoo near her collarbone. Her hair spilled wild and loose over her shoulders, her eyes catching the firelight and turning molten.

 

Agatha looked back at her friends and muttered, “Not exactly. More like someone who would annoy you into your grave.”

 

Rio gasped, clutching at her chest like she’d been wounded. “Rude,” she said, tone light and playful, “but fair.”

 

Wanda’s eyes flicked between Agatha’s expression and her tightly gripped glass. “Okay, now I am concerned. Are you sleeping at all? Eating? You look like you’re about to explode.”

 

Agatha exhaled slowly, her fingers flexing as she released the glass and pressed the pads of her fingers to her temples. “I’m sleeping. Barely. Eating. Sort of. Exploding? Absolutely.”

 

Rio drifted behind the couch now, her fingertips brushing lightly along the back of it as if she were petting something alive. “Just tell them, baby. I don’t bite. Well. Not unless asked.”

 

Agatha’s head snapped up, her voice sharp. “0

 

“I lied,” Rio replied sweetly. “It’s kind of in the job description.”

 

“You said you could lie!”

 

Jen leaned forward again, brows furrowed. “Agatha. Are you hearing voices? Because if you’re in danger or having a breakdown, we can help you. Seriously.”

 

Agatha looked at Jen, then Wanda, then Alice, and then Lilia, her oldest, most reliable circle, and something twisted painfully in her gut. The fear of sounding insane, of losing their trust. But worse than that was the fear of telling the truth and still losing them anyway.

 

Wanda leaned in closer, the flame of curiosity flickering behind her eyes, her wine glass cradled loosely in her hand. “So, hypothetically... why is this Death-person following you?”

 

Agatha shifted uncomfortably, crossing one leg over the other, her gaze pointedly avoiding the sultry shadow lounging just within her peripheral vision. The room was warm from candlelight and laughter, but under her skin, there was a chill, one she’d come to associate with Rio’s presence. “I don’t know,” she said stiffly, fingers tightening around the glass. “She says I called her, but I don’t remember doing anything like that.”

 

Alice cocked an eyebrow and exchanged a glance with Jen, amusement twitching at the corners of her mouth. “So, you summoned Death, and now she’s... what? Stalking you?”

 

“Exactly,” Agatha muttered, taking a long sip of her wine as if it could drown out Rio’s grin pressing against her awareness.

 

Jen snorted, slouching back into the couch, her legs draped casually over the armrest. “Agatha, if this is your way of saying you’re stressed out, just say so. No need to invent some hot goth Death chick haunting you.”

 

“Hot goth Death chick?” Rio repeated from behind Agatha’s shoulder, the delight in her voice unmistakable. “Oh, I love her. Please invite her over more often.”

 

Agatha felt her cheeks burn. Her grip on the glass faltered slightly, and she turned with narrowed eyes, pointing at the space Rio occupied, though her finger passed through air as far as her friends were concerned. “You’re not helping!”

 

Wanda’s eyebrows shot up, slow and suspicious. “Uh... who are you talking to?”

 

Agatha froze. Her mouth opened, then closed again. She quickly looked away, her face coloring deeper. “No one,” she snapped, the lie hanging awkwardly in the air.

 

Jen took a slow sip of wine, her grin wide. “You’re making this way too easy to tease, you know. But seriously, Agatha, maybe take a break. Get some rest. You’ve been... off lately.”

 

“‘Off’ is one way to put it,” Rio whispered in her ear, her lips brushing the air like silk. “I prefer... deliciously unhinged.”

 

Agatha’s nails dug into the side of her thigh, her other hand white-knuckled around the glass. She inhaled slowly, trying to keep her voice level. “I’m fine. Really. It’s just been a long week.”

 

Wanda reached out and patted her arm, her tone softening. “Alright, alright, we’ll drop it. But if you start naming this invisible Death person, we’re staging an intervention.”

 

“Too late,” Rio purred, practically vibrating with amusement now. “I already have a name. Want me to introduce myself?”

 

Agatha groaned and sank further into the couch, the wine glass tilted back in surrender. She didn’t dare respond.

 

Jen leaned forward, reaching for the bottle, and handed it to her. “Here. You need something stronger, but wine will do for now. To hypothetical Death stalking you!”

 

“To hot goth Death chicks!” Alice added, raising her glass high, her bracelets jingling.

 

Rio brought an invisible glass to her lips, her smirk lazy and pleased. “Cheers, darling.”

 

Agatha pressed the rim of her glass to her lips but didn’t drink. Instead, she closed her eyes, pinched the bridge of her nose, and muttered, “It’s going to be a long night.”

 

She could feel Rio grinning beside her. Smug. Warm. Unshakably there.

The lecture hall buzzed with the soft hum of laptop keys and the scratch of pens on paper, the murmur of bored students settling into routine. Dust particles danced in the golden slant of afternoon light bleeding through the tall windows, catching against the edges of Agatha’s coat sleeve as she gripped the podium. Her fingers were pale against the wood, her knuckles taut.

She tried to focus. Tried to keep her voice even. But her throat was dry. Too dry. Her heart thudded hard beneath her blouse, the echo of it throbbing behind her eyes.

 

“Today,” she began, voice smooth but clipped, “we’re discussing pivotal moments in history where death, disease, and survival shaped civilizations, particularly during the Black Plague.”

 

A soft click from the remote in her hand triggered the projector, and the grim image of a medieval woodcut flashed to life behind her, gaunt bodies sprawled in agony, a skeletal rider drifting in the corner like an afterthought.

 

“The Black Plague, also known as the Bubonic Plague, decimated Europe in the 14th century. It was said to have claimed the lives of up to sixty percent of the population.”

 

“Closer to fifty-two percent,” Rio corrected, casually perched on the edge of the projector cart like a feline who knew she was not meant to be there and reveled in it. Her legs were crossed, and her boots, scuffed, laced up to her thighs, swung lazily in the air.

 

Agatha didn’t flinch. But her nails pressed harder into the wood. Her tongue moved behind her teeth like she was grinding down fury, not words.

 

“During this time,” she continued, “many turned to religion or superstition to explain the horrors around them. Some even blamed witches—”

 

“Witches, yes,” Rio interrupted again, lips curling. “But it wasn’t nearly as dramatic as these books claim. They were more scared of their own shadows than actual witches. Believe me, I was there.”

 

Agatha’s jaw tensed. She kept her eyes forward, away from Rio’s silhouette looming behind the beam of projected history. “The Church played a significant role in framing the Plague as divine punishment, which led to widespread fear and persecution.”

 

“Divine punishment,” Rio scoffed, inspecting her nails like she wasn’t talking about centuries of suffering. “Please. It was rats. Fleas. Filthy water and the kind of hygiene that would make your skin crawl. But fear is easier to sell than science. And they sold it.”

 

A quiet ripple of laughter passed through the students, at something whispered, or perhaps at her expression. Agatha wasn’t sure.

 

“One common belief,” she said, pressing forward, her voice cool, “was that Death itself walked the streets. A skeletal figure. Cloaked. Hooded.”

 

Rio sighed dramatically, swinging her legs. “Such a cliché. I wore black, yes, but a skeleton? Really? I looked amazing, Agatha. You should’ve seen it, red lips, waist like a dream, the cloak was velvet. Velvet. I still have the dress.”

 

Agatha’s eye twitched, her lips twitching too, though not in amusement. Her fingers adjusted her glasses in a tight, practiced motion. She clicked to the next slide.

 

“Mass graves became common,” she said. “Rites were abandoned. Bodies burned in heaps outside the cities.”

 

Rio’s voice dropped. Softer. “That part is true.” She stood from the projector, stepping out of the shadows and toward the aisle, her form flickering through the projector light like smoke. “Even for me, it was... unpleasant. There was no reverence. Just fear. And rot. But what they never write down...” She turned to Agatha, her voice laced with something heavier now. “...is how hard they fought to live.”

 

Agatha’s breath caught.

 

“They prayed,” Rio went on, her tone almost reverent. “Even when their hands were blistered from shoveling the dead. Mothers held their babies with skin peeling from fever. Lovers kissed over corpses. Hope—” her voice hitched faintly, just once, “—hope is stubborn. You wouldn’t believe how much it hurts to watch it break.”

 

Agatha’s throat tightened. Her hand trembled at her side, the clicker slipping just slightly. She looked straight ahead, but her voice dipped low, barely above the whisper of the projector’s hum.

 

“And what would you know about resilience?” she murmured, unable to stop the ache behind the question.

 

“I watched it,” Rio replied, her tone hushed now, reverent, like she was confessing something sacred. “I held the hands of those who begged to live one more day. I’ve taken kings and children and monsters and martyrs. And every time... they all looked for something to hold on to. That’s what resilience is, Agatha. The refusal to let go, even when you’re already gone.”

 

Agatha’s chest rose and fell in rapid, uneven waves, as if her lungs were struggling to recalibrate around the tight, burning knot that had formed just beneath her sternum. A sheen of sweat clung to the nape of her neck, soaked into the collar of her blouse. She could feel the heat blooming across her chest, crawling up her throat, blooming high in her cheeks like some fever she hadn’t invited. Her palms were damp against the lacquered wood of the podium, fingertips gone cold despite the rush of blood just beneath her skin.

 

“Professor Harkness?”

 

The voice cut in, sharp, high-pitched, unsure.

 

Agatha blinked. The room snapped into focus.

Dozens of eyes were locked on her now, some confused, some curious, a few wide with concern. The low hum of the projector buzzed in her ear, nearly drowned out by the pounding of her own pulse.

 

She adjusted her glasses with fingers that didn’t quite want to obey. “Yes, sorry,” she said, her voice sounding distant even to herself. “Does anyone have questions about this period?”

 

The air was thick with tension for a heartbeat. Then, slowly, a forest of hands rose. Eager students. Innocent ones. Ones who hadn’t been alive when she had, if that memory had even been real.

 

Agatha barely saw them. Her eyes slid, almost involuntarily, toward the shadow lounging at the edge of her vision.

 

Rio.

 

Leaning against the back wall now, arms crossed over her chest, her black blazer open over a charcoal silk blouse that shimmered like stormclouds. She looked devastatingly calm, like a cat watching mice discuss the meaning of traps. Her eyes, dark and unrelenting, were fixed solely on Agatha. Not mocking now. Not playful.

 

Calculating. Possessive.

 

Agatha turned slightly, keeping her tone low, her voice sharpened by the tremor running just beneath it. “This isn’t over,” she muttered through gritted teeth, not trusting herself to look directly at her.

 

Rio’s lips curved. A slow, knowing smile that spread with the grace of poured ink. She lifted two fingers to her temple and offered a theatrical, mocking bow, her voice brushing against Agatha’s mind like silk through thorns.

 

“I wouldn’t dream of it, darling.”

 

Something in that last word made Agatha’s spine straighten, her entire body reacting as though Rio had touched her without lifting a finger. The sound of it was too familiar, too intimate, like the taste of a name whispered in the dark.

 

Agatha inhaled sharply, snapping her attention back to the students. “You,” she said, pointing to the front row with a steadier voice than she felt. “You had a question?”

 

A girl with bright eyes and a thick notebook sat up straighter. “Yes, Professor. Do you think the personification of Death during the Black Plague was a way for people to process grief collectively, or more about control through fear?”

 

Agatha opened her mouth to answer, but her gaze caught Rio again, still watching her like she was the only person in the room that mattered.

She forced her eyes away.

 

“Both,” she replied, stepping around the podium, her heels clicking softly on the floor. “Death was never just an end. It was a mirror. And people feared what it might reflect back at them.”

 

As she spoke, she could feel Rio’s presence, warm, quiet, heavy, anchored to her thoughts like gravity. Even when Agatha turned her back to her, the weight of Rio’s gaze pressed between her shoulder blades like a hand that refused to let go.

And in that moment, the history she taught, the facts on the slides, the sanitized stories... they all felt pale.

 

Because something inside her whispered what she hadn’t dared admit until now. The worst part of Rio’s presence wasn’t the haunting. It was how much Agatha wanted her to stay.

 

The lecture hall was heavy with the stale scent of overused air conditioning and secondhand coffee. The overhead lights buzzed faintly, too bright for how exhausted Agatha felt. Her fingers curled tighter around the black pointer, knuckles whitening as she gestured toward the projection of a rotting city street lined with the dead. Her voice tried to remain authoritative, clear. She tried to stay in control.

 

“Many accounts from the time describe scenes of devastation,” she said, clicking to the next slide. “Entire families wiped out, cities abandoned—”

 

“Not entirely,” Rio’s voice slithered through the room, smooth and insolent. She was perched at the back now, leaning lazily against the edge of a tall bookshelf, arms folded over her chest like a queen overseeing a court of fools. “Plenty of people stayed, Agatha. Some out of fear, some out of stubbornness. I remember one merchant who swore garlic kept the Plague away. Died three weeks later. Smelled terrible the whole time.”

 

Agatha’s shoulders stiffened. She didn’t look at her. Wouldn’t. Her fingernails pressed into her palm through the pointer’s grip.

 

Her voice rose an octave, tight with tension. “... and even the medical community was overwhelmed, offering ineffective remedies from herbal concoctions to bloodletting—”

 

“Ah, the good old leeches,” Rio interrupted, mock-dramatic as she placed a hand over her heart. “They always thought I was responsible when their treatments didn’t work. Like I was personally hand-delivering the Plague in a velvet cloak.”

 

Agatha’s breath stuttered in her throat. Her hands were trembling now, barely visible beneath the podium. Her eyes flicked over her students, trying to keep her composure, but she could feel the heat crawling up her neck, embarrassment, irritation, and something more volatile rising in her.

 

She forced herself to continue. “The bird-like masks of Plague Doctors have become iconic. They believed the herbs packed into the beak would purify the air—”

 

“Ridiculous,” Rio muttered again, stepping off the wall and sauntering closer, her heels silent on the linoleum. “They looked like cursed scarecrows. I almost felt sorry for them. Almost.”

 

Agatha clenched her jaw so hard it ached. Her head snapped toward the specter only she could see. Her voice was a knife’s whisper, slicing through clenched teeth. “Will you stop it? I’m trying to teach.”

 

A few students turned, startled by her sudden motion, their brows furrowing. She blinked and forced a smile, flipping through her notes like she’d simply forgotten something.

 

Rio, entirely unbothered, arched a brow, her voice a low purr that curled under Agatha’s skin. “I am helping. This is called... context.”

 

“You’re giving me a migraine,” Agatha hissed, her lips barely moving, her smile frozen and forced.

 

“You’re adorable when you’re flustered,” Rio murmured, leaning in just close enough for Agatha to feel the ghost of her breath against her cheek. “Did you know that, darling?”

 

Agatha turned back toward the students, clenching her thighs together under the desk without thinking. Her pulse throbbed at her throat, and she hated, hated, how deeply Rio’s presence unraveled her. How it felt like she was unraveling and being stitched back together all at once.

 

“Now,” she managed, her voice louder than it needed to be, “let’s examine how the Plague altered economic structures—”

 

“Don’t forget the cats,” Rio interrupted again, circling behind her. “They blamed them. Massacred them. Which, predictably, made the rat problem worse. Brilliant logic, really. Kill the rat-catchers and then wonder why the rats flourish.”

 

And that was it.

 

“That’s it!” Agatha snapped, turning with so much force the pointer clattered to the floor, the sound echoing through the room like a gunshot.

 

Silence. Every student froze. Conversations dropped mid-sentence. The entire lecture hall stared at her in stunned confusion.

 

Agatha’s eyes widened. She inhaled sharply, heart pounding like it was trying to rip out of her chest. Her cheeks flushed with heat and humiliation. She straightened her spine and tugged at the collar of her blouse, her voice suddenly too bright, too calm.

 

“I meant,” she said, clearing her throat, “that’s it for this section. Let’s take five.”

 

A beat. Then the room stirred. Chairs squeaked. Bags rustled. The low buzz of idle chatter returned as the students filed out or stretched in place.

 

The second the room thinned out, backpacks slung over shoulders, murmured conversations drifting toward the hallway, Agatha turned on her heel. Her heels clicked sharply against the floor, her body coiled like a drawn bowstring. Her eyes, usually cool and composed, now burned with a wild heat.

 

“You’re gotta be fucking with me” she hissed, stepping down from the podium and rounding on Rio. Her chest rose and fell in quick bursts, her voice strained with the effort to stay quiet. “Do you have any idea how hard it is to teach with you constantly interrupting me?”

 

Rio stood with one hip cocked, hands in the pockets of her trousers, the picture of unbothered arrogance. Her smile was slow and indulgent, like she was watching a kitten try to claw down a lion.

 

“Oh, I have every idea,” she purred, her voice syrupy smooth, thick with amusement. “But it’s just so delicious watching you try to stay professional. All that restraint. The control. The way your voice tightens when you’re trying not to snap...” She leaned in slightly, eyes gleaming. “You’re very sexy when you’re frustrated.”

 

Agatha groaned, dragging a hand through her dark waves, the movement exasperated and sensuous all at once. “You’re enjoying this way too much.”

 

“Of course I am,” Rio replied without missing a beat, her tone light but edged with something more intimate, something dangerous. “But in all seriousness,” she added, straightening slightly, her expression shifting, “you’re doing a great job, darling. Even if your sources are, how shall I say, adorably incomplete.”

 

Agatha narrowed her eyes, her brow furrowed. “This is history, Rio. Primary sources. Scholarly research. You don’t just get to rewrite it because you were... there.”

 

Rio took a lazy step closer, her boots making no sound, her presence brushing against Agatha’s like static. Her voice dropped to a low hum. “I’m not rewriting it,” she said softly. “I’m telling you the parts they left out. The fear in a midwife’s eyes when she wrapped her baby in rags and prayed he’d see the next sunrise. The sound of someone singing — badly — while they carried bodies to the river. The hope. The desperation. The beauty in how stubbornly they tried to live.” She paused. “Isn’t that why you’re here, Professor? To teach the truth, not just the dates?”

 

Agatha’s lips parted slightly, her breath hitching. Her throat worked around words she wasn’t sure how to form. She looked away, jaw tightening, and folded her arms in front of her chest like armor.

She hated that Rio could say things that made sense. That sounded like care. That felt like something deeper.

 

“Fine,” she muttered, voice low, almost reluctant. “But if you’re going to ‘help,’ could you at least do it after class?”

 

Rio’s smile curved like a blade. “As you wish,” she murmured, stepping back with a slight bow, the movement theatrical, mocking — and somehow respectful all at once. “Professor.”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes and turned back toward the podium, her blouse sticking faintly to her back where her body had heated under the stress. Her fingers wrapped around the edge of the lectern again, this time with a different kind of tension, something more pulsing, more alive.

From the corner of her eye, she could still see Rio lounging by the wall like a cat who’d just pawed open a cage and was waiting to see what her prey would do with the freedom.

Students began trickling back in, filling the seats one by one. Agatha cleared her throat, adjusted her notes, and let the carefully arranged mask of control slip back over her face.

But deep beneath it, her pulse was still racing, and she knew Rio could feel every beat of it.

The café smelled of roasted beans and cinnamon, the hum of quiet conversation and clinking cups creating a soft, familiar noise around them. Outside, gray clouds pressed low against the windows, casting a silver filter across the worn wood of the table between them.

Agatha sat rigidly in the booth, fingers wrapped tight around the ceramic mug, as if the heat might ground her. The faint steam curled toward her face, but she barely felt it. Her knuckles were pale, her jaw clenched so tightly the muscles near her ear twitched. A headache pulsed behind her eyes.

 

Across from her, Wanda sat with one arm draped casually over the booth, her coffee cooling in her other hand. She watched Agatha carefully — too carefully, eyes sharp with intuition. She always saw too much. “You’re not going to tell me, are you?”

 

Agatha didn’t look up. Her thumb traced the rim of her mug. “I already told you.”

 

“ And I laughed,” Wanda said, setting her cup down with a soft clink. “Because what you said is absurd. Completely and totally absurd.” Her voice lowered, conspiratorial and teasing. “But hey, if this ‘Death’ thing is real, ask her to show herself to me. Then I’ll believe you.”

 

Agatha finally looked up. Her eyes were tired. Not puffy or red, just hollow. Empty in a way that made Wanda’s smile falter. “It doesn’t work like that,” she murmured.

 

“Then how does it work?”

 

“I don’t know.” Her voice cracked slightly. She hated that.

 

Wanda leaned back, her fingers tapping against her cup. “So... hypothetically... Death is following you around, just casually haunting you while you go to work, do laundry, pick up the kids?”

 

“Yes.”

 

Wanda arched a brow. “And you have no idea why.”

 

Agatha’s jaw flexed. “No.”

 

Wanda stared at her. “Agatha.”

 

Agatha’s grip on the mug tightened. Her nails dug into the ceramic, and the heat burned her palms, but she didn’t let go. It was something to feel. Something real.

 

“Agatha,” Wanda said again, quieter now. “Are you sure this isn’t something else? Stress? Guilt? Ralph?”

 

At that name, Agatha blinked. Her mouth opened slightly, but no sound came. She could still hear his voice sometimes, loud, sharp, blaming. Could still feel the cold pit in her stomach from the night he vanished. She could still hear Nicole’s voice calling Rio Mama like it meant something true.

 

“It’s not that,” she said, finally, the words pushed through clenched teeth.

 

Wanda’s voice softened. “Then what is it? Because you look like you’re walking around with a bomb inside your chest.”

 

Agatha’s throat tightened. Her shoulders pulled in slightly. Like she was trying to make herself smaller. “It’s complicated.”

 

Wanda leaned forward again, her hand brushing Agatha’s across the table. “I’m not trying to pry, Aggie. I just… I hate seeing you like this. You’re disappearing in front of me.”

 

Agatha met her gaze. Wanda’s eyes were kind. Steady. Trusting. A thread of warmth tugged in her chest, dangerously close to unraveling something.

 

For a moment, she thought about saying it all. Telling Wanda about the forest in her dreams, about Rio’s voice in her head, about Nick whispering to someone she couldn't see. About how her body still remembered hands on her hips, breath on her throat, lips that tasted like the end of everything. About how terrified she was that she wanted it all back.

 

Her lips parted. And then, she felt it.

 

A shift in the air brushed the nape of Agatha’s neck like a breath too close, unseen fingers trailing along her spine. The temperature dropped just slightly, enough to make the fine hairs on her arms rise. The café buzzed on around her, warm and harmless, but that familiar pressure curled in beside her like a storm tightening its grip.

 

Before she could brace herself, a voice, velvet and venom, sliced through her thoughts. “Tell her. I’m sure she’d love to hear about me.”

 

Agatha’s stomach twisted. Her eyes slid to the seat beside her, now occupied by Rio, who lounged like the booth belonged to her. One arm draped across the backrest, legs elegantly crossed, the very image of arrogance in tailored black and a glint of wicked amusement in her eyes. Her presence was magnetic and suffocating all at once, like desire laced with danger.

 

Agatha’s jaw clenched so hard it ached. Her pulse thudded against her throat as she forced herself to look back at Wanda, whose gaze was pinned on her with quiet concern. “It’s fine. I’ll figure it out,” Agatha said tightly, her tone clipped, raw at the edges.

 

Wanda’s brows pulled together. “You’re deflecting.”

 

“No, I’m not.” The words came too fast, too sharp. She shot Rio a side-glare, venom in her eyes. Then she grabbed her mug, taking a long, scalding sip just to avoid saying anything else.

 

Across the booth, Rio’s expression curled into one of mock delight. “Wow. You’re really holding it together, aren’t you?” she purred, voice syrupy and smug.

 

“Shut up,” Agatha hissed under her breath, fingers tightening around the ceramic until her knuckles blanched.

 

Wanda blinked. “Excuse me?”

 

“Nothing,” Agatha muttered quickly, too quickly. “I just... look, can we talk about something else?”

 

Wanda didn’t move for a beat. Her gaze searched Agatha’s face, as if trying to pry the truth out by will alone. Then, with a quiet sigh, she nodded. “Sure. But this isn’t over.”

 

“It’s never over,” Rio whispered like a kiss to her ear, leaning in close enough for Agatha to feel her presence against her skin, warm, intimate, invasive.

 

Agatha didn’t respond. She forced her mouth into a tight smile, nodding along as Wanda launched into a story about a chaotic faculty meeting, something about someone stealing someone’s mug again.

But her coffee tasted like ash now. Her skin prickled under her sweater, Rio’s gaze crawling over her like silk sliding over bare skin, like claws tracing her pulse. Every breath was a balancing act. Every heartbeat a reminder that Death wasn’t just near, she was watching. Waiting. Teasing.

 

And Agatha was already unraveling thread by thread.

 

The warmth of the café wrapped around Agatha like a heavy blanket she couldn’t shake off. The aroma of roasted coffee beans, cinnamon pastries, and worn books should have calmed her nerves. Instead, her fingers gripped the ceramic mug like it was a weapon. Across the table, Wanda chatted animatedly about her twins, completely unaware of the storm unraveling inside Agatha.

But the real weight pressing against Agatha’s chest wasn’t the coffee or the conversation. It was the cold breath at her neck, the whisper curling through her ribs like smoke.

 

"Wanda Maximoff," Rio drawled, voice low and sharp, laced with venomous delight. "Of all the people to get chummy with in this life, it had to be her. You really do have a taste for irony, Agatha."

 

Agatha stiffened, her nails digging crescents into her palm beneath the table. "Not now," she hissed under her breath, not daring to look at Rio.

 

Wanda paused mid-sentence. "What was that?"

 

"Nothing," Agatha said with forced calm, flashing a tense smile. "You were talking about Tommy, right?"

 

Wanda hesitated, brows drawing together, but continued. Rio didn’t. She never did.

 

"Did you tell her?" Rio purred, drifting to the seat beside Agatha, one leg crossed over the other. Her body language was playful, but her eyes were cold. "Does she know you lied to her? That you tried to take her powers? That you sunk your claws into her grief, fed her illusions, then tried to strip her bare?"

 

Agatha’s throat tightened, her pulse skittering. "Stop," she murmured, barely audible.

 

"Oh, but darling," Rio mocked, leaning in until her breath brushed the shell of Agatha’s ear. "It gets better. You failed. She tricked you. Trapped you. Left you to rot in your own little mind-prison for three. Whole. Years. And now? You’re here playing house with her in this soft little world like it never happened. Like she didn’t try to kill you."

 

Agatha flinched, her hand tightening around her mug. Her heart pounded behind her ribs, a sick drumbeat of confusion and fear.

 

Wanda glanced at her, concern flaring. "Are you okay? You look kind of pale."

 

"I’m fine," Agatha replied quickly, but her voice cracked.

 

Rio shifted, her posture feline, her grin cruel. "Oh, you should see your face. You really don’t remember, do you? That look in her eyes when she hexed you into the ground? When she smiled as she walked away, sealing your fate?"

 

Agatha’s breath stuttered.

 

"You’re lying," she whispered harshly, barely moving her lips.

 

"Am I?" Rio leaned back, draping an arm over the backrest. "She called you a monster, Agatha. She left you broken in Westview. And now you sip lattes with her like she didn’t gut you. It’s pathetic."

 

Agatha shook her head, jaw clenched. "She’s not like that. Not this Wanda."

 

"No," Rio agreed, her voice dripping with mock sweetness. "This version is so kind. So helpful. So naive. She doesn’t remember either. How convenient for both of you."

 

Wanda reached across the table, her hand brushing Agatha’s. "Hey. Seriously, what’s going on? You’re scaring me."

 

Agatha pulled her hand back as though burned. She stood abruptly, knocking her chair slightly off balance. "I — I need to go."

 

"Agatha? Wait—"

 

She didn’t. She bolted from the café, the doorbell jingling as she escaped into the street.

 

But Rio followed. Always.

 

"You can run, darling," she said, voice a phantom brushing the back of Agatha’s mind. "But you’re the one who summoned me. And you don’t get to forget. Not forever."

 

Agatha’s steps quickened, her breath ragged, but deep down, under the panic and the ache — she felt something else too.

 

Guilt. Because part of her believed every word.

 

Agatha slammed the car door shut with a violent thud that rattled the frame. The cold echo of it reverberated through the interior, bouncing off the windows, pressing into her ribs. She gripped the steering wheel with both hands, knuckles whitening, fingertips aching from the force.

Outside, the city’s muffled hum carried on, cars, distant horns, the occasional burst of laughter, but inside the vehicle, a tempest brewed. Her breathing came in shallow bursts, heat prickling under her collar, sweat beading at her temple. The scent of her lavender hand lotion clashed with the sharp scent of leather and old coffee in the cupholder.

 

Then the voices started.

 

“You’re a danger to everyone, Agatha. You always have been.”

 

Wanda’s voice. Not this Wanda. Another. That Wanda. The one who wore grief like armor and magic like vengeance.

 

“You don’t get to make excuses,” that voice growled, biting. “You did this.”

 

Another flash — Wanda standing over her, eyes glowing red, power vibrating in the air like thunderclouds caught in her bones.

 

“You don’t get to tell me who I am.”

 

Agatha curled forward, her forehead pressed against the steering wheel, the hard plastic digging into her skin. “Stop it,” she whispered, the tremor in her voice betraying the crumbling wall of her resolve. Her palms lifted, pressing against her temples as if pressure could silence memory.

 

“You have no idea what you’ve unleashed,” Wanda’s voice echoed again. “You don’t get to make it right. You don’t deserve to.”

 

Images tore through her: hex-bound towns, her own magic snarling back at her, Wanda’s eyes blazing with wrath and heartbreak.

 

“I’ll give you the role you chose... and you’ll play it well.”

 

“No,” Agatha rasped, panic rising. “No, I didn’t... I didn’t mean to—”

 

“You’re cruel,” Wanda hissed, “and you have no idea what you've done.”

 

“STOP!” Agatha screamed, her voice ripping from her throat as she slammed her palm against the dashboard. Her body shook. Tears slid hot and sharp down her cheeks.

 

The storm didn’t ease. It cracked open further.

 

“You don't get to win,” the echo came, colder now, distant and suffocating.

 

Her own voice joined the haunting: frantic, pleading, furious.

 

“RIO!” Agatha cried, her voice breaking on the name like it was torn from somewhere primal. “MAKE IT STOP!”

 

Silence fell.

 

The air in the car shifted. Not cooled, no, it thickened. Like velvet pressed to skin. Every sound outside dulled to a whisper. Her pulse thundered in her ears.

 

"Was that so hard?" Rio's voice slithered into the quiet, honey-warm but edged like a blade.

 

Agatha lifted her head slowly, breath ragged, her eyes red and glistening. Her gaze found Rio in the rearview mirror, lounging in the backseat like a cat with blood on its paws, calm, indulgent.

 

"Get out of my car," Agatha hissed, though the tremble in her voice betrayed her lack of bite.

 

Rio leaned forward, resting her arms on the headrest of the passenger seat, her eyes gleaming with something between affection and amusement. "You called me, darling. Quite theatrically, might I add. You practically begged."

 

Agatha turned toward her fully, her voice breaking around the edges. "You said you’d make it stop. So do it. Make it all stop."

 

Rio’s gaze softened, not warm, but aware. Sharpened with memory. "It’s not that simple, Agatha. Those aren’t just nightmares. They’re echoes. Wounds that never closed. I can dull them, sure... but they’ll claw their way back. They always do."

 

Agatha’s hands clenched in her lap, her nails biting crescents into her skin. "I didn’t ask for this. For you. For any of it."

 

Rio’s smile faded, just a fraction. Her voice dropped into something lower, something real. "But you did. You called me. Just like always. And when you do... I come."

 

Agatha’s breath caught. “Why me? Why now? Why can’t you just leave me alone?”

 

"Because you’re not ready to let me go," Rio said, her tone velvet-smooth, eyes unwavering. "And you know it."

 

Agatha looked away, jaw tight, the sting of truth cutting deeper than she'd admit.

 

Rio leaned in, her breath brushing Agatha’s cheek. "You tried to take her power. You lied to her. You manipulated the grief she could barely contain. And she punished you for it. Three years, stuck inside your own spell. Playing a role."

 

Agatha flinched, eyes darting to Rio. "You’re lying."

 

"Oh, sweet thing," Rio whispered, her lips brushing the shell of her ear. "She cursed you. Left you hollow and docile in a house you couldn’t escape. And you never even saw it coming. You begged her to let you help, and she caged you instead."

 

"I don’t remember," Agatha rasped.

 

"No," Rio said. "But your soul does."

 

Agatha’s eyes filled again, her throat closing. Her chest felt too small to hold everything pressing against it.

 

Rio leaned back into the seat with a languid sigh, her voice a purr now. "And now you play her friend. Sit across from her in cafés, listening to stories about her children. Does she even know what she did to you?"

 

“She’s my friend.”

 

“Now. Not before.”

 

Agatha’s knuckles whitened on the steering wheel, her body stiff as a drawn bowstring. The sharp scent of city rain clung to her coat, the faint hum of traffic beyond the windshield barely cutting through the pressure in her chest. Her jaw tightened. Then, slowly, she turned to face Rio, her glare burning hotter than the flush in her cheeks.

 

“You don’t understand, Rio!” she snapped, her voice cracking. “The past doesn’t matter! What we were before doesn’t matter!”

 

Rio’s smirk faltered — not all at once, but like something precious fracturing behind her eyes. Her lips parted slightly, the beginnings of some clever retort curling on her tongue, but nothing came. She just... watched. Studied Agatha’s face as though it hurt to do so, and still, she couldn't look away.

 

“Doesn’t it?” she asked, her voice low, but stripped of its usual mocking lilt. “Can you really ignore it, Agatha? Pretend it doesn’t exist?”

 

Agatha scoffed, the sound bitter and wet with something unspoken. “What do you want from me?” Her voice trembled, teeth clenched, eyes shining. “You want me to go back to what I was? To feel for you what I felt before?”

 

Silence.

 

Rio didn’t flinch. Didn’t smirk. She sat perfectly still, like a shadow that had lost its anchor to the body. Her gaze didn’t soften — but it didn’t harden either. She wasn’t teasing her. Not now.

Because in that past life, Agatha had hated her. Had cursed her name. Had damned her across lifetimes. And Rio didn’t want that version of Agatha back.

 

She didn’t speak. Not because she didn’t have words, but because there were none that could carry the weight of what she felt. She simply stared, as if trying to memorize the exact shape of Agatha’s voice when she pushed her away.

Then, without a whisper, she began to fade, first her outline, then the curve of her mouth, the shadow of her collarbone, the echo of her presence peeling away like mist.

 

She didn’t argue. Didn’t beg. Because Rio never begged.

 

And because Agatha had told her to leave. “Leave me alone, Rio.” And so she did.

 

The temperature in the car shifted as if someone had opened a window, though nothing moved. The air grew less charged, but heavier in the heart. Agatha’s shoulders slumped as the pressure released, only to be replaced by something quieter. Lonelier.

She stared down at her hands, trembling now, her breath catching in her throat.

Rio sat outside on the steps of Agatha’s house, a cold beer in her hand, staring up at the stars. The bottle dangled loosely between her fingers as she replayed Agatha’s words in her mind, the pain in her voice, the anger, the frustration.

 

“The past doesn’t matter. What we were doesn’t matter.”

 

Rio tilted her head back, taking a long sip of the beer. Maybe Agatha was right. Maybe dragging her through those memories was the wrong approach. It wasn’t helping, if anything, it was only making Agatha hate her more.

 

She stared down at the bottle in her hand, her grip tightening. “Even after I gave her Nick back. After I gave her another daughter. She still can’t stand me.”

 

The words left her lips in a whisper, and for the first time in a long while, Rio felt uncertain about her choices.

What’s the point? she thought bitterly. Even if she remembers everything, she’ll still hate me. She always has.

 

Rio sighed, setting the empty bottle beside her. She needed to do something different, something to remind Agatha of the good, not just the pain.

She stood abruptly and walked back into the house, finding Nicole sitting on the couch with her legs tucked under her.

 

“Nicole,” Rio said, her voice calm but firm.

 

Nicole looked up from her phone. “What is it?”

 

“Call one of your mom’s friends,” Rio said.

 

“Why?”

 

Rio crossed her arms. “Just do it. Your mom needs someone right now, and I’m not it.”

 

Nicole hesitated, frowning. “Are you sure that’s a good idea?”

 

“Trust me,” Rio said, her voice softening. “She’ll listen to them.”

 

After a moment, Nicole nodded and picked up her phone, scrolling through the contacts. Less than half an hour later, the doorbell rang, and Nicole answered it to find Lilia Calderu standing on the porch.

 

“What’s going on, dear?” Lilia asked, her brow furrowing as she looked at Nicole.

 

Nicole bit her lip, her eyes darting to the stairs. “Mom’s... sad. I didn’t know what to do, so... someone told me to call you.”

 

Lilia frowned. “Someone?”

 

Nicole shrugged, avoiding the question. “Just... go talk to her. Please.”

 

Lilia nodded, stepping inside and heading up the stairs. Nicole let out a breath and turned to see Rio leaning against the kitchen counter, her arms crossed.

 

“Was that hard?” Rio asked, her tone light but with a hint of teasing.

 

Nicole shot her a look. “I still don’t get what you’re trying to do.”

 

Rio gave her a small, tired smile. “I’m trying a new strategy, kid. Your mom’s been through enough for one night.”

 

Nicole nodded slowly, her expression softening. “I hope it works.”

 

Rio’s gaze flickered toward the stairs, where Lilia had disappeared, and she murmured under her breath, “So do I.”

Lilia sat gently on the edge of Agatha’s bed, her movements calm and deliberate. She reached out, brushing a strand of Agatha’s hair away from her face and letting her hand linger there, stroking softly.

 

“What’s troubling you, child?” Lilia asked, her voice low and comforting, like a mother speaking to her child.

 

Agatha sniffled, turning her head slightly to meet Lilia’s gaze, her eyes red and puffy. “It doesn’t matter,” she muttered. “You wouldn’t believe me. And even if you did, there’s no way I could prove it.”

 

Lilia tilted her head, studying Agatha with that knowing look she always had—the one that made Agatha feel like she was a teenager again, caught in some lie or emotional whirlwind.

 

“Try me,” Lilia said simply.

 

Agatha hesitated, her lips trembling. She wanted to push Lilia away, to tell her it was pointless, but there was something about the way Lilia sat there, unyielding and patient, that broke her defenses.

 

After a long moment, Agatha sighed and rolled onto her back, staring at the ceiling. “Do you believe in... spirits?”

 

Lilia raised an eyebrow, clearly intrigued. “Depends on the spirit. Are we talking restless ghosts, mischievous poltergeists, or something else entirely?”

 

Agatha let out a bitter laugh, covering her face with her hands. “Something else. Something much worse. Or better. I don’t even know anymore.”

 

“Go on,” Lilia urged, her tone gentle but firm.

 

Agatha dropped her hands and looked at Lilia, her voice trembling. “I’ve been... seeing someone. A spirit. No, not a spirit. Something bigger. More powerful.”

 

Lilia’s expression didn’t falter. She nodded, her hand still resting on Agatha’s hair. “And what does this... ‘someone’ want?”

 

“That’s just it,” Agatha said, sitting up abruptly, her voice rising with frustration. “I don’t know! She says I called her, but I don’t remember doing anything like that. She keeps talking about the past, about things I can’t even remember. And she won’t leave me alone.”

 

Lilia’s brow furrowed slightly, but she stayed silent, letting Agatha vent.

 

“She says she’s... Death,” Agatha continued, her voice dropping to a whisper. “The literal personification of it. And the worst part is... I think she’s telling the truth.”

 

For a moment, the room was silent. Lilia’s hand stilled in Agatha’s hair, but her expression remained calm, thoughtful.

 

“Well,” Lilia said finally, her voice steady, “that would explain why you look like you haven’t slept in weeks.”

 

Agatha blinked, caught off guard by the remark. “You’re not... freaking out?”

 

Lilia smiled faintly, leaning back slightly. “I’ve been around long enough to know that the world is full of things we can’t explain. If you say you’re seeing Death, who am I to doubt you?”

 

Agatha stared at her, her chest tightening with relief and disbelief. “You’re... serious?”

 

Lilia nodded. “Of course. The real question is, what are you going to do about it?”

 

Agatha’s shoulders sagged, and she shook her head. “I don’t know. She’s everywhere. She knows things about me I don’t even know about myself. I just... I feel like I’m losing my mind.”

 

Lilia reached out, taking Agatha’s hands in hers. “You’re not losing your mind, child. But if she’s here, there’s a reason for it. Spirits, especially ones like this — don’t just show up for nothing. You need to figure out what she wants and why. And what you want. This isn't a one way road.”

 

Agatha hesitated, her hands trembling slightly in Lilia’s grip. “What if I don’t want to know? What if it’s something I can’t handle?”

 

Lilia squeezed her hands gently, her voice soft but firm. “Then you lean on those who care about you. You’re not alone in this, Agatha. Whatever it is, we’ll face it together, okay, honey?”

 

Agatha’s eyes filled with tears again, but this time, they weren’t just from sadness. For the first time in days, she felt a glimmer of hope.

 

“Thank you,” she whispered.

 

Lilia smiled, brushing a tear from Agatha’s cheek. “Now, get some rest. Whatever this is, it can wait until morning.”

 

Agatha nodded, lying back down as Lilia stood. As the older woman left the room, Agatha stared at the ceiling, her mind still racing but her heart feeling just a little lighter.

From the shadows of the room, Rio watched silently, her expression unreadable. For once, she said nothing, simply fading back into the darkness, leaving Agatha to her thoughts.

 

 

Chapter End Notes

Another day another chapter! Our beautiful baby plaza is coming back little by little! I'm so happy for her 😍❤️

Chapter 5: Chapter 5

Agatha nearly dropped her coffee when Wanda and Jen’s expressions froze mid-conversation, their gazes locked on something — or rather, someone — behind her.

 

A creeping chill slid down her spine.

 

"What is it?" she asked, her voice tight as she followed their stares, already knowing.

 

Wanda’s lips parted slightly, her cheeks flushing with something between shock and intrigue. “Who’s...?”

 

"Hi, darling," Rio’s voice purred directly into Agatha’s ear, the whisper hot and intimate, like a breath stolen too close. Her words brushed Agatha’s skin like silk and static all at once, and it sent a full-body shiver through her.

 

Agatha’s reaction was instant and catastrophic. She gasped, choked, and sputtered coffee back into her cup, slamming it down on the table. Heat rose violently to her face as she spun around.

Rio stood there in black leather and the kind of confidence that filled every inch of the room. One hip cocked against the table, arms crossed, her grin a weapon.

 

“You,” Agatha hissed, pulse slamming in her throat.

 

Before she could form another word, Jen leaned forward, brow arched with interest. “Wait... you two know each other?”

 

Agatha’s stomach dropped. Her gaze darted between Rio and her friends. “Hold on now! You can see her?” she asked, voice rising like a snapped string.

 

“Fortunately,” Jen replied, eyes raking Rio with bold curiosity. “Very fortunately.”

 

Wanda didn’t speak. She was staring at Rio with something like recognition in her eyes. Her fingers clenched lightly around her glass, as if grounding herself.

 

Rio, of course, was loving every second of it. She tilted her head toward Agatha, murmuring with a feline grin, “Oh, they’re delightful. You really do have excellent taste in companions.”

 

Without giving her friends a chance to ask more, Agatha stood so quickly her chair scraped against the floor. She grabbed Rio by the wrist, flesh meeting flesh with a jolt of heat, and yanked her toward the back of the bar.

 

“Excuse us,” she barked, ignoring the startled looks.

 

The door to the balcony slammed shut behind them. Cold night air met her skin like a slap. Agatha shoved Rio against the railing with both hands, furious.

 

“What the hell was that?” she snapped, her breath a mix of panic and fury. “What are you doing, showing yourself now? Why can they see you?!”

 

Rio didn’t resist. She just leaned casually back against the iron railing, as if it were a chaise lounge, not a boundary. Her expression was maddeningly serene.

 

“Nice to see you too, darling,” she said.

 

Agatha’s fingers twitched. “Don’t ‘darling’ me! You’ve been invisible for weeks. What changed? Why now?"

 

Rio gave a languid shrug, her black hair catching silver moonlight. “The veil’s thinning. You're remembering more. Your grip on reality? A little looser than before. Perfect time for a grand entrance.”

 

Agatha stepped back like she’d been slapped. “This isn’t a fucking game, Rio. You can’t just play with my life like it’s a stage.”

 

The smirk faded, just a breath. Rio's eyes darkened with something older, deeper. “You called me. You brought me back. I didn’t force my way in. You tore open the door.”

 

Agatha’s voice wavered. “I didn’t ask for this. For you.”

 

“Maybe not in words,” Rio replied softly, stepping forward, slow, deliberate, until there was only breath between them. Her voice dropped, velvet and razor. “But you wanted me. Somewhere deep. You wanted truth. Power. Me.”

 

Agatha trembled, her anger fractured by something molten crawling up her spine. She hated this, the way Rio could undo her with a look. “This isn’t fair,” she whispered. "It isn't fucking fair!"

 

Rio tilted her head, eyes glinting. “Life isn’t fair. Love certainly isn’t.” She paused, voice softening. “But I’m not here to ruin you, Agatha. I’m here because you’re changing. And whether you admit it or not, I’m part of that.”

 

Agatha stared at her, heart drumming like thunder in a glass jar. “You’re a terrible thing,” she whispered.

 

Rio smiled gently, her lashes dropping. “I'll take it as a compliment.”

 

Agatha let out a ragged breath, stepped around her, and reached for the balcony door. “Don’t,” she said, not looking back. 

 

As she rejoined Wanda and Jen, Agatha’s pulse was still thudding in her ears. She tried to suppress the flush creeping up her neck, but Rio’s presence lingered behind her like the imprint of a too-hot hand. Even out of sight, that aura — warm and sharp as a blade — brushed against the edge of her senses.

Jen and Wanda weren’t looking at her anymore. Their attention was fixed behind her, eyes wide, expressions flickering with a mixture of curiosity and disbelief.

 

“What is it?” Agatha asked, trying to sound casual, but her voice came out tighter than intended. She turned.

 

Rio was already seated at the table, legs crossed elegantly, as if she had always belonged there. The sunlight caught in her dark hair, her smirk slow and lethal. She looked like a woman who owned the room, and the people in it.

 

Jen was the first to recover, cocking her head. “Who are you?”

 

Rio gave them a look so smooth, it felt like silk sliding over skin. “Oh, I’m just a humble researcher in history,” she said sweetly. “I came here from Puerto Rico to intern with Professor Harkness.”

 

Agatha’s stomach dropped. Her mouth opened slightly, words caught behind her teeth. She glanced at Wanda, then Jen, trying to assess just how much damage Rio intended to cause.

 

Rio’s gaze flicked to Agatha for half a second, just enough for her to see the flicker of challenge in those eyes — before she turned back to the others. “I had the privilege of studying under her some time ago. She was brilliant. So inspiring. I knew I had to follow her here to learn more about... well, humans.”

 

“Humans?” Wanda asked, her brow arching high.

 

Agatha groaned and buried her face in one hand. She didn’t even have the energy to pretend anymore.

 

Rio leaned forward slightly, her voice rich with faux innocence. “Oh, yes. Humans are endlessly fascinating. Their histories, their little rituals, their mortality. So textured. Don’t you agree, Professor?”

 

Agatha’s spine locked straight. The word sent a jolt through her every time Rio said it, like being tugged backward by a leash. The way Rio wrapped that title in honey and poison made her skin crawl.

 

She dropped her hand and shot Rio a venomous look. “Oh, I absolutely agree. Nothing more fascinating than humans.”

 

Jen gave a low, impressed whistle. “You’re definitely enthusiastic.”

 

Wanda was more cautious. “And you studied together... where?”

 

Rio smiled without missing a beat. “In Europe. Briefly. The details are rather foggy now, you know how it is.”

 

Agatha could practically feel the smoke Rio was blowing into the room. Every word was like a calculated little spark.

 

“And Professor Harkness has been an incredible mentor,” Rio added, her gaze sliding to Agatha. “So patient. So... commanding.”

 

Agatha shoved back her chair with a sharp screech, standing fast. Her entire body buzzed with heat. “Alright. That’s enough. We need to get back to the classroom.”

 

Jen blinked. “Wait, already?”

 

“Now,” Agatha said, her voice brittle.

 

Rio rose too, calm and collected, brushing invisible lint from her coat. “Of course. Lead the way, Professor.”

 

As they stepped into the hallway, the moment they were alone, Agatha spun around, eyes blazing. “You are unbelievable.”

 

Rio’s expression was mild, but there was mischief flickering behind it. “I take that as a compliment.”

 

“You just sat down like you belonged there,” Agatha snapped. “You made up some fake internship, and then you—”

 

“Gave them what they wanted to hear?” Rio interrupted, tilting her head. “It’s not like the truth would go over any better, darling. Would you rather I told them I’m Death and you’ve been having midnight conversations with me between grading papers and existential dread?”

 

“You gave me the idea to tell them!”

 

“I never said it was a good one.”

 

Agatha exhaled sharply, dragging a hand through her hair. Her skin still burned from the way Rio had looked at her. Had spoken to her.

 

“I can’t do this right now. Just stay quiet. Stay invisible. And for the love of everything, don’t talk to my friends again.”

 

Rio lifted one perfectly arched brow, her smile slow and dangerous. “As you wish, Professor.”

 

That word again. It slithered down her spine, coiled around her thoughts. There was something about the way Rio said it — playful, reverent, mocking — that made it impossible to ignore.

Agatha turned her back and walked, fast, trying not to feel the way Rio’s gaze burned into her as surely as sunlight through glass.

She didn’t have to look back to know the smirk was still there.
