Rio sat comfortably in Agatha’s chair, one leg draped languidly over the other, her fingers tapping lazily on the wooden armrest. Her body was reclined, completely relaxed, like a queen overseeing a court of unwitting students. Her dark eyes glinted with mischief, and that maddening smirk curved her lips — one Agatha had come to recognize as a warning more than a smile. She didn’t look like she belonged in a classroom. She looked like a sin dressed in black silk.

Agatha stood at the front, shoulders stiff, doing her best to ignore the chaos lounging at her desk. The air in the classroom was thick with tension, not just hers, but something deeper, darker, humming in her blood. A slow burn beneath her skin. She pressed her pointer against the whiteboard like it could anchor her to the moment.

 

“For many historians,” she said, her voice even but tight, “the transition from feudalism to centralized monarchies marked a pivotal moment in the shaping of Europe’s political structure.”

 

Behind her, Rio twirled a pen between her fingers. The click of it echoed louder than it should have in the quiet room.

 

“That’s true,” Rio chimed in, her voice silky and low, curling around Agatha’s nerves like smoke. “But don’t forget the famine that wiped out half the population just a few decades earlier. They don’t like to talk about that part, do they?”

 

Agatha’s spine straightened. She turned slowly, her gaze sharp. Her knuckles whitened around the pointer.

 

“Thank you for the insight,” she said through clenched teeth, her tone saccharine and deadly, “but I think the students are fine with the content from the syllabus.”

 

Rio didn’t flinch. She leaned forward, propping her chin on one hand, her grin lazy and infuriating. “Oh, I’m sure they’d love to hear about the real causes behind the Hundred Years’ War. It wasn’t just about a vacant throne, Professor.”

 

The way Rio said "Professor", with that slow, mocking affection, sent a shiver up Agatha’s spine. The word no longer sounded like a title. It sounded like a collar.

 

“Rio,” Agatha snapped.

 

A few students chuckled, leaning in like this was part of the show. One even raised his hand, intrigued. “Wait, is she right? Wasn’t it also about land disputes and stuff?”

 

Rio didn’t miss a beat. “It was about all that and more. You should’ve seen the royal tantrums, grown men pouting like children over fields and borders.”

 

Agatha exhaled through her nose, her fingers tightening around the pointer like it was the only thing keeping her from throwing it across the room.

 

“Yes, thank you, Rio,” she said, her voice laced with restraint. “Let’s stick to the curriculum for now.”

 

But Rio didn’t stop. She offered corrections, commentary, anecdotes that sounded too vivid to be hypothetical. Every word dripped with condescension, and yet the students seemed utterly charmed.

 

By the time class neared its end, one student raised a hand, looking both confused and amused. “How do you know all this stuff? Like... you talk like you were actually there.”

 

Rio’s lips curved with pleasure. Her eyes met Agatha’s, daring her to stop her.

 

“I was there, kiddo,” she said.

 

Laughter rippled through the room. Agatha’s stomach dropped.

 

“Rio!” she hissed, stepping between her and the students. “What she means,” she said quickly, trying to keep her voice steady, “is that she’s traveled extensively. Research. Fieldwork. You know, immersion.”

 

Rio leaned back in the chair, arms stretched out like a queen bored with ceremony. “That’s one way to put it.”

 

The bell rang, and students began filing out, whispering among themselves. A few shot Rio curious glances, clearly intrigued.

As the last of them disappeared, Rio stood and stretched with a satisfied sigh, her shirt riding up slightly to reveal a strip of skin that made Agatha’s jaw tighten.

 

“Do you enjoy making my life harder?” Agatha asked, her voice low and furious as she walked up to her desk.

 

Rio turned slowly, meeting her gaze with that infuriating, predatory calm. “Immensely, Professor.”

 

Agatha’s breath hitched — just a fraction — but Rio caught it. She always caught it.

 

“Stop calling me that,” Agatha growled.

 

Rio’s eyes gleamed. She leaned in close, her breath brushing the shell of Agatha’s ear. “But you wear the title so well. It makes me want to misbehave.”

 

Agatha stepped back, pulse spiking, her face flushed with frustration and something else she refused to name.

 

She turned away, grabbing her notes with sharp, angry movements. “We’re done here.”

 

“But darling,” Rio said sweetly, already moving to the door, “we’ve only just begun.”

 

“You’re a bitch,” Agatha muttered, her voice low and bitter as she slammed her notebook closed with a sharp snap that echoed through the now-empty classroom. Her hands trembled slightly, not from fear, but from pressure, from restraint. From the sheer effort of not throttling Rio where she stood.

 

Rio didn’t flinch. She leaned against the corner of Agatha’s desk with feline ease, her hip cocked just so, one arm draped over a stack of books like she was posing for a Renaissance painting. “What?” she replied smoothly, brushing an invisible speck of dust from her dark slacks. “I was just trying to help. They seemed to enjoy it.” Her grin curled like smoke, slow and smug, eyes glittering with a dangerous kind of amusement.

 

Agatha groaned under her breath, the sound low and almost guttural, like it clawed its way from her throat. She shoved papers into her leather satchel with more force than necessary, the crisp rustle of pages harsh in the silence. “I don’t need your ‘help.’ And stop telling them you were there. Do you want them to think I’ve completely lost my mind?”

 

Rio tilted her head, the movement slow and deliberate, her black curls sliding over her shoulder like velvet. “They don’t think you’ve lost anything, darling.” Her tone softened into something sultry, something that slipped under Agatha’s skin like silk and nettles. “If anything, they probably think you’re even cooler now. Having me as your... assistant.”

 

Agatha froze mid-motion, a pen still in her hand. She turned, slowly, her stare sharp enough to cut glass. “Assistant?” she echoed, voice cold with disbelief.

 

Rio’s grin widened, baring teeth. “It has a certain charm, don’t you think?”

 

“You’re not my assistant,” Agatha snapped, slinging the bag over her shoulder, the strap biting into her skin. She took a step closer, close enough to smell Rio’s perfume, warm amber and something old, like incense and thunderclouds. “You’re my—”

 

“Companion?” Rio offered sweetly, her voice feigning innocence while her eyes told another story. “Confidante? Emotional support apparition? Lover?”

 

“Annoyance,” Agatha snapped, cutting through the tease like a whip. Her tone was sharp, but her pulse betrayed her, beating hard against her ribs, her breath short.

 

Rio laughed softly, the sound curling low and warm in the air like smoke. “Oh, I’ve been called worse. But if I’m an annoyance, why do you keep me around?”

 

Agatha didn’t answer. She just turned on her heel and stormed toward the door, her heels clicking angrily against the tiled floor.

 

Rio fell into step beside her, walking leisurely, like a cat pacing its prey. “You know,” she said conversationally, “I could teach your students a thing or two about the Black Death next time. Maybe the part about how nobles tried bathing in rosewater to stay alive. Very poetic. Very stupid.”

 

“Don’t you dare,” Agatha muttered, gripping the strap of her bag like it was the only thing tethering her sanity to the earth.

 

Behind her, Rio’s laughter followed, warm and rich and maddening. Like honey poured over razors.

Agatha didn’t look back. She didn’t have to. She could feel Rio’s eyes on her, sharp and possessive, like a storm that had already chosen its lightning rod.

Agatha decided to clean the house while the kids were still at school. The sun poured in through the windows, catching motes of dust dancing in the air. The hum of the vacuum filled the halls, giving her a rare moment of solitude, one she intended to enjoy without interruption.

 

Rio had offered to help, emphasis on offered. After folding and refolding the same t-shirt with all the enthusiasm of a cat watching paint dry, she finally tossed it aside and proclaimed, “This fabric is inherently flawed. I refuse to wrestle with factory crookedness.” She’d vanished into the bedroom with a theatrical sigh, claiming “mental exhaustion.”

 

Agatha didn’t mind. As long as Rio stayed out of her way, she could enjoy a few blessed hours of order.

 

Or so she thought.

 

Halfway down the stairs, her foot caught on the vacuum cord. In an instant, she was falling. Her heart jumped into her throat, eyes clenching shut, her stomach twisting. She braced for the sharp bite of wood against bone.

 

But the impact never came.

Instead: arms. Strong, steady, catching her mid-fall like she weighed nothing at all.

 

Gasping, Agatha opened her eyes to find Rio crouched beneath her, one arm around her back, the other supporting behind her knees. The world tilted. The vacuum hose slithered across the floor beside them like a lazy serpent.

 

“How did you get here? You were in the bedroom!” Agatha’s voice was a rasp, her breath shallow, adrenaline crackling beneath her skin.

 

Rio looked down at her with a smirk that curved slow and deliberate. “Which part of ‘cosmic, universal, all-powerful being’ in my résumé haven’t you figured out yet?” Her voice dripped with mischief, as casual as if they were discussing grocery lists.

 

Agatha wanted to argue, to shove her away and bark something scathing. But her body betrayed her. Her heart was racing too fast. Her skin burned where Rio touched her, the heat of her body seeping through fabric like something elemental.

Gently, Rio set her down at the foot of the stairs. She knelt beside her, fingers undoing the vacuum cord with surprising tenderness — slow, focused, like undoing a knot of ribbon instead of electrical cable.

 

The moment stretched.

 

When she stood again, Rio didn’t move back. She stayed close, too close. Their breath mingled in the narrow space between them, and Agatha suddenly became acutely aware of everything. The tension coiling in her core. The ache just beneath her ribs. The scent that clung to Rio like a spell: petrichor, pine, and something darker, like wild magic in the middle of the night.

Rio’s hand lifted, slow and deliberate, like she was afraid Agatha might disappear if she moved too fast. Her fingers brushed a lock of hair away from Agatha’s cheek. The touch was featherlight but deliberate, trailing down to the curve of her jaw. Then lower, into her hair, slipping through it with maddening care. Not teasing. Not demanding.

 

Savoring.

 

Agatha didn’t speak. She didn’t dare. Her eyes fluttered shut without permission, and her breath caught when her body responded before her mind did, tilting her head just slightly, unconsciously, exposing her throat in a silent offering.

 

Rio didn’t pounce. She didn’t rush.

 

She simply leaned in, brushing her lips, not her mouth, not yet, but the barest edge of them, against the curve of Agatha’s neck. The touch was a whisper of heat. Barely there. Maddening.

 

And Agatha felt it everywhere.

 

A tremble rolled down her spine. Her lips parted. A sound slipped out, soft, unguarded, something between a gasp and a moan. The kind of sound she hadn’t let herself make in years. The kind born from a memory her body still carried, even if her mind refused to name it.

Rio didn’t gloat. She didn’t speak. She just let it linger. That weightless intimacy. That pressure that wasn’t pressure at all.

 

Then her lips hovered there, just near Agatha’s ear, and in a voice so low it barely existed, she whispered, “I’d catch you again, you know. Every time. Every life.”

 

Agatha opened her eyes slowly, her breath shallow. “Stop playing with me,” she murmured.

 

Rio’s lips curved near her skin. “Who said I was playing, my love?”

 

Encouraged, Rio leaned in further, her breath brushing hot and slow along the delicate curve of Agatha’s neck. The warmth of it sent a flush up Agatha’s spine, her breath catching mid-exhale. She stood perfectly still, as if any movement might unravel her completely.

Rio's lips hovered, not in haste but with reverence, tasting the silence between them. Then, deliberate, slow, she pressed a kiss just below Agatha’s jaw. Not rushed, not demanding. It was intimate, almost devotional. The contact ignited something low in Agatha’s belly, something she hadn’t let herself feel in years.

The sound that escaped her lips, deep, unguarded, sinful, cut through the quiet like a secret. She felt it vibrate in her throat before she even realized she’d made it. And Rio, gods, Rio, smiled against her skin, savoring it like a victory she hadn’t needed to chase.

The world outside faded. The vacuum cord. The mess. The silence of the house. All of it dissolved into the charged air between them.

Rio lingered. Not just with her body but with her presence, so heavy and commanding it made Agatha dizzy. Her breath still ghosted over Agatha’s pulse, her fingers brushing lightly at the nape of her neck, playing with a strand of hair, winding it slowly between two fingers like a binding spell.

Agatha’s pulse fluttered under Rio’s mouth, frantic, traitorous. She hated how Rio made her feel seen. How she could turn her bones to fire with a whisper.

Rio drew back only slightly, just enough to meet her eyes, dark, bottomless, hungry, but patient. Her expression had shifted. Gone was the smug grin, replaced with something deeper. Something that made Agatha’s knees weaken.

 

“Say the word, Agatha,” Rio murmured, the words spoken in that low, devastating voice that coiled around the base of Agatha’s spine. “Tell me to stop, and I will.”

 

Her name had never sounded so much like a command and a promise at once. Agatha swallowed hard, her lips parted to answer, but no sound came. She leaned forward instead, imperceptible, involuntary, drawn in by the gravity between them.

 

Rio didn’t move. She simply watched. Waited. Her fingertips grazed Agatha’s cheek, a reverent touch that made her tremble. “You don’t have to fight it,” she whispered. “You never did.”

 

Something broke loose in Agatha then, guilt or fear or something raw she didn’t have the language for. She stumbled backward, nearly tripping on the baseboard. Her chest rose and fell in quick, shallow bursts, like she couldn’t get enough air.

 

“This isn’t, this can’t ...” she stammered. Her voice was hoarse, cracking under the pressure of wanting and not wanting. “You can’t just show up and… and do this. You don’t get to have this much power over me.”

 

Rio stood still, framed by golden light pouring in through the window behind her. She didn’t argue. She didn’t deny it. Her gaze was steady, her voice softer now, no trace of teasing. “I didn’t do anything you didn’t want.”

 

Agatha’s fists clenched at her sides. “That’s not—” She stopped herself. The words died on her tongue. Her voice dropped to a whisper. “I don’t know what I want.”

 

Rio exhaled slowly, her hands sliding into the pockets of her slacks. She didn’t look disappointed. She didn’t gloat. She simply nodded, the gesture small and grounded. “Then figure it out,” she said. “Because I’m not going anywhere. Not until you do.”

 

Agatha turned her back to her, pressing her palm to the wall like it might anchor her. Her whole body vibrated with tension, her senses still flooded with Rio, her scent, her voice, the ghost of her mouth on her skin.

 

“Just…” Her voice cracked. She closed her eyes. “Just give me space. Please.”

 

There was a pause. Then the sound of quiet steps. Rio moving away.

 

Agatha didn’t look. She couldn’t. But she felt the shift in the air, the absence of heat, the way the room seemed colder the moment Rio left it.

 

When she finally moved, it was to slump down onto the bottom step, her spine curving with the weight she couldn’t name. The wood creaked softly beneath her, cool against her thighs through the fabric of her jeans. Her hands rose to cradle her face, fingertips pressing into her temples like she could knead away the storm brewing beneath her skin.

 

The silence in the house pressed in on her, but inside her head, everything screamed.

 

She had leaned in. She hadn’t pulled away. And worst of all, she wasn’t sure she ever wanted to.

 

Her breath caught as she let her head fall back against the railing. The bannister felt solid, grounding, but it didn’t stop the flickering memories from bleeding in, the drag of Rio’s fingers through her hair, the heat of her breath against her skin, the exact point on her neck where her lips had touched.

 

God, she could still feel it.

 

Agatha’s eyes fluttered shut. The phantom pressure of Rio’s mouth played on a loop, and the sound she’d made, raw, involuntary, humiliating, echoed like a confession. The way her body had tilted toward Rio’s without thought, without permission. As if it remembered something her mind had buried.

 

She sucked in a breath, trying to steady herself, to wrestle her traitorous heart back into submission.

 

“Is everything okay, Mom?” he asked, his voice soft, like he wasn’t sure if he was interrupting something private. His head tilted slightly, studying her face with that uncanny, too-perceptive gaze of his.

 

Agatha sat up so quickly she nearly knocked her own knees. Her hand shot to the banister, steadying herself.

 

“Oh my God!” she gasped, voice shrill with surprise. “Sweetheart! I ... I was just...” She blinked rapidly, searching for something, anything, to say. “I was just resting my eyes.”

 

Nick stood a few feet away, backpack still slung over one shoulder, his small brows drawn together with concern. His sneakers were muddy from the walk home, one shoelace untied.

 

Nick squinted at her. “On the stairs?”

 

Before she could embarrass herself further, Rio’s voice slid in like silk, smooth and smug and far too pleased. “She’s just tired, champ,” she purred, stepping into view behind him, one arm resting lazily against the wall. Her expression was a picture of relaxed dominance, comfortable, confident, utterly in control.

 

Agatha’s entire body tensed. She could already hear the wicked amusement in Rio’s tone. That knowing glint in her eye set her nerves on fire.

 

Rio leaned in slightly, her voice dropping as she looked between mother and son. “What do you say we go upstairs, change into something a little more comfortable, and hit the garden? Maybe play a game or two?”

 

Nick’s face lit up like a sunrise. “Really? Can we?”

 

Agatha raised her hand, fingers cutting the air like a blade. “Not before he finishes his schoolwork,” she said, her tone clipped, sharp, pointed. She was reclaiming control, or at least trying to.

 

Rio crouched to Nick’s level, her hand tousling his hair, her grin all teeth. “Cut the kid some slack, my love. One little break, then he can drown in homework. Deal?” She turned her full attention to Nick, ignoring Agatha entirely. “Race you to the stairs?”

 

“Yeah!” Nick took off running, laughing as his backpack bounced wildly behind him.

 

Agatha’s mouth opened, ready to yell something else, but Rio was already gliding after him, barefoot and effortless, like a shadow with hips.

 

“Rio!” she snapped, dragging herself to her feet and glaring toward the second floor. “Don’t you dare let him skip his homework!”

 

“Don’t worry, Professor!” Rio’s voice echoed down the stairs, all singsong and dripping with smugness. “I’ll make sure he learns... something.”

 

Agatha groaned aloud, dragging her hands down her face. Her entire body felt hot, too hot. Not just from the physical tension, but from the weight of everything Rio stirred in her.

 

And now the teasing nickname again. That infuriating, devastatingly seductive “Professor” that always left a bloom of heat in the pit of her stomach and crawled under her skin like silk and nails.

 

“She’s going to drive me insane,” Agatha muttered, but even she could hear how breathless she sounded. And worse — how fond.

 

Despite her frustration, Agatha couldn’t stop the lingering warmth coiling through her chest, the phantom press of Rio’s lips still ghosting her skin like a fever dream. She shook her head sharply, trying to shake it off, but as she bent to coil the vacuum cord and tidy the mess left on the stairs, the memory clung to her like smoke.

Nicole stood at the base of the staircase, one hip cocked, arms folded with casual defiance. Her brow was arched in that signature way that Agatha had come to dread — so reminiscent of Rio it made her teeth grind. The teen’s expression danced between amused mockery and cool judgment, and her silence said everything before her mouth even opened.

 

“Wow,” Nicole finally said, her voice dry, laced with the kind of disdain only a teenage daughter could master. “You’re absolutely wrecked in your self-pity, Mom. It’s almost impressive.”

 

Agatha snapped her eyes up, heat rushing to her cheeks. “Go bother someone else, Nicky.”

 

But Nicole didn’t budge. She leaned casually against the banister, and the dim light caught the curve of a smirk curling her lips. “What did she do to you this time?”

 

Agatha turned away, stalking toward the kitchen. “It’s none of your business,” she snapped. “Go upstairs, change, and make your brother a snack.”

 

Nicole padded after her, the sound of her socks whispering against the floor. “Uh-uh. Not happening. You’re acting weird, weirder than usual. Spill.”

 

Agatha let out a tight breath, opening the fridge as a distraction. The cold air kissed her flushed skin, but it did nothing to cool the heat that had taken residence inside her. “Nicole, not now.”

 

Nicole didn’t miss a beat. She perched on a kitchen stool, folding her arms again with dramatic flair. “You’re deflecting. That means something happened. So what was it? Did she trip you with one of her cryptic metaphors? Did she kiss you and blow your mind? Or,” her grin widened “was it both?”

 

Agatha slammed the fridge shut. “Nicole. Upstairs. Now.”

 

Nicole laughed. “Come on, Mom. You’re practically humming with it. Whatever happened, it got under your skin. Admit it.”

 

Agatha collapsed into a kitchen chair, dragging a hand down her face. “I tripped on the vacuum cord. She caught me. That’s it.”

 

Nicole narrowed her eyes. “That’s not it.”

 

“Why do you care?” Agatha muttered, barely above a growl.

 

“Because you’re being cagey,” Nicole said, resting her chin on her palm. “And because I’ve never seen you look like this. Like you’re trying not to panic and melt into the floor at the same time.”

 

Agatha looked away, jaw clenched. Silence stretched.

 

“She got... too close,” she said finally, her voice low, raw.

 

Nicole’s brow lifted, but her voice softened. “And you didn’t stop her.”

 

Agatha didn’t answer.

 

Nicole sat back, the weight of realization blooming across her face. “Oh my God. Mama got to you.”

 

Agatha shot her a deadly look. “Nicole. Not another word.”

 

But Nicole was already grinning. “I knew there was something. You’re constantly fighting with her, but it’s not just that. You like the fire. You like her.”

 

Agatha groaned into her palms. “Why are you like this?”

 

Nicole hopped off the stool, snagging an apple from the fruit bowl. “Because I live here. I'm your daughter. And because, honestly, this is better than TV.”

 

She headed for the hallway, her voice floating back over her shoulder. “But you better figure out what you want, because she already has. And she’s not backing down.”

 

Agatha watched her go, the silence that followed almost worse than the teasing. She let out a groan, slumping in her chair.

 

“Of course she’s not giving up,” she muttered, staring at the tile beneath her feet. “She’s Death.”

The golden afternoon light spilled across the garden, casting soft, dappled shadows over the wooden table. Warm sun clung to their skin, and the scent of jasmine from the trellis wound its way through the breeze. Agatha sat with her back rigid, her teacup balanced between careful fingers, trying to pretend that this was normal. That Rio, sitting across from her with legs crossed and a plate of untouched sandwiches, wasn’t slowly, artfully unraveling her nerves.

 

Nick, oblivious to the tension, bit into a cookie with the kind of innocent joy only children possessed. Crumbs clung to his cheeks. "Mama Rio," he asked, blinking up at her with wide eyes, "where do you come from?"

 

Agatha nearly choked on her tea, a strangled cough escaping her lips as she turned toward her son. Rio, on the other hand, leaned back with feline grace, her fingers languidly brushing a stray curl from her face. She grinned, sharp, sweet, dangerous.

 

"Where do I come from?" she echoed, tasting the question on her tongue like dark chocolate. Her eyes flicked toward Agatha, catching the tight line of her mouth. It only made her smile deepen. "That's a very interesting question, little one."

 

Nick beamed, rocking slightly in his chair with excitement. Beside him, Nicole watched in silence, arms folded, her dark gaze unreadable. She always watched Rio like she was waiting for her to slip, or waiting to see more.

 

Rio cradled her teacup in both hands, the porcelain warm against her palms. "I come from everywhere... and nowhere," she said, her voice soft, laced with old shadows and quiet wonder. "I’ve walked through deserts so hot the air shimmered like water, cities that breathed smoke and steel, forests where the wind spoke in forgotten tongues."

 

Nick's eyes sparkled. "Everywhere? Really?"

 

"Really," Rio said, her tone reverent. Her gaze lifted, distant for a moment. "I’ve seen dawn rise over stone temples swallowed by jungle. I’ve seen stars fall into oceans so deep they swallowed light."

 

Nicole raised an eyebrow, skeptical. "That’s poetic. But... are you just saying you travel a lot?"

 

Rio met Nicole’s stare, lips twitching. "You could say that. But my travels —" her voice dipped, slow, measured, "have lasted a bit longer than most."

 

Agatha shifted uncomfortably in her seat. "Don’t tell them too much," she said, voice clipped, her hand gripping her teacup too tightly.

 

"Don’t worry, darling," Rio murmured, without looking at her. "I know where to draw the line."

 

Nick leaned in, elbows on the table. "What’s the coolest thing you’ve ever seen?"

 

Rio smiled, the expression softening something in her usually sharp face. She set her cup down, fingers lingering on the rim. "Once," she began, "there was a valley, hidden between two mountains. The flowers there only bloomed at night. They glowed, not from magic, but from the way they absorbed the moonlight. The people believed the stars had kissed them. Every evening they sang to the sky. The air shimmered with their voices. It felt like standing inside a prayer."

 

Nick gasped. "That sounds magical!"

 

"It was," Rio said, her voice hushed. "But it’s gone now. Time changes everything."

 

Nicole frowned, leaning her chin on her hand. "You talk like you were there a hundred years ago."

 

Rio turned her gaze to her, her smile returning with a spark. "Maybe I was."

 

Nick, still enchanted, asked, "Did you have friends there?"

 

The question seemed to land somewhere deeper. Rio hesitated, her gaze dropping to the center of the table. "A few," she said finally. "But when you’re... different, staying is hard. People leave. Or you do. They are afraid of you."

 

Agatha's heart clenched. There was something raw in Rio’s tone, unguarded for once. She didn’t like it. It made her feel too much.

 

"Alright," she said sharply, standing and beginning to collect plates. "Storytime's over. Nick, you still have homework."

 

"Aww," Nick whined, but he slid off his chair. Nicole rose slowly, her eyes lingering on Rio with an expression Agatha couldn’t quite place.

 

Left alone, Rio lounged in her seat like she belonged there, like she was already woven into the bones of the house. Her eyes followed Agatha with quiet amusement. "You didn’t like my story?" she asked, voice smooth as velvet.

 

Agatha set the plates down harder than she meant to. "It’s not about liking it. It’s about boundaries. They don’t need to know... everything."

 

Rio's smirk was gentle now, her fingers tracing the rim of her teacup. "Don’t worry, Agatha," she said softly. "I only tell them what they’re ready to hear. Sometimes I'm a responsible adult."

 

Agatha didn’t respond. She stood in the doorway for a moment longer, watching Rio in the light-drenched garden, the soft wind tousling her hair like it belonged there. Like she belonged there.

 

Under the fading gold of the afternoon light, Agatha huffed and turned toward the house, the soft crunch of her boots pressing into the garden path. The breeze was warm against her skin, but the chill that clung to her chest came from somewhere deeper. Each step away from the table felt heavier than it should have. As she carried the last of the plates inside, she couldn’t stop the nagging pull in her gut — Rio hadn’t told that story just for the children.

When she returned, Agatha dropped into the chair with a sigh, her movements slower now. She rested her elbows on the table, one hand propping up her chin, the other listlessly brushing a crumb off the tabletop. The air between them held weight — not tense, not hostile, just... thick. Like a silence that remembered too much.

 

“You’re quiet,” Rio said at last, her voice a velvet murmur. “That’s new.”

 

Agatha didn’t respond right away. She tilted her head just enough to glance at her, the gesture sharp but weary. “I’m tired, Rio. Tired of... this.” Her hand gestured vaguely in the space between them, as if the shape of their mess was too large to name.

 

Rio watched her, her fingers still idly stroking the porcelain of her teacup. “Tired of me,” she said, voice dipped in low amusement, “or tired of everything else?”

 

Agatha opened her mouth, then closed it again. Her eyes dropped to her lap, and for a moment, her thumb rubbed circles into the fabric of her jeans. “I don’t know,” she said, softer now. “Both. Maybe.”

 

Rio leaned in, the movement slow and feline, her posture lazy but precise. Her eyes, impossibly dark, glittered in the light as she studied Agatha’s face. “I don’t think it’s me you’re tired of,” she murmured. “I think you’re tired of fighting.”

 

Agatha’s fingers twitched at the edge of the tablecloth. She tried to scoff, to summon some cutting response. But the effort fizzled under the truth of it. “I’m not fighting anything,” she muttered instead.

 

“You’re fighting yourself, Agatha,” Rio replied, not cruel, not smug, just certain. “You’re clinging to this version of yourself that you think you’re supposed to be. Strong. Controlled. Unshakable. But I see the real you. The one buried under all that armor. The one who remembers what it’s like to burn.”

 

Agatha’s eyes snapped to her, sharp and wounded. “Don’t act like you know me.”

 

The words landed between them like a blade, but Rio didn’t flinch. Her smirk softened, almost vanishing. “I don’t have to act,” she said, her voice stripped bare. “I do know you, Agatha. I’ve known every version of you. In every life, in every world. I’ve loved you through your rage, through your brilliance, through your ruin.”

 

“That’s the problem,” Agatha said, her arms folding tight across her chest, as if trying to keep herself from splintering open. “You keep talking about this past I don’t even remember. You speak like it’s gospel, like it should mean something. But it doesn’t feel real to me. None of it does.”

 

Rio’s eyes didn’t leave her. Her voice was quiet now, low and slow, the kind of softness that demanded attention. “Do you feel it now?”

 

Agatha’s throat tightened. “Feel what?”

 

Rio didn’t smile this time. She simply looked at her, really looked. “This,” she said, gesturing between them with a single movement of her hand. Her fingers were long and elegant, and Agatha couldn’t help but track the motion with her eyes. “This pull. This current between us. You try to dismiss it, to rationalize it away. But it’s here. It’s always been here. And it scares the hell out of you.”

 

Agatha’s pulse jumped, too quick beneath her skin. She swallowed hard, her mouth dry. Her fingers gripped the edge of her seat like she might fly apart if she didn’t anchor herself. The wind brushed against the back of her neck, raising goosebumps she wished she could blame on the weather.

 

“I’m not scared,” she said, but her voice didn’t hold. It cracked, thin and strained.

 

Rio leaned back, one arm draping lazily over the back of her chair, the other toying with the hem of her sleeve. “You’re terrified,” she said, not unkindly. “And that’s alright. But stop lying to yourself.”

 

Agatha’s chest rose and fell unevenly, her arms crossed tight over her middle like she was bracing for a storm that had already landed. The fading light painted gold across the table and warmed her skin, but inside, everything felt tight and cold.

 

“That doesn’t mean anything,” she said, her voice hollow. She meant for it to sting, but it slipped out softer, uncertain.

 

Rio leaned back in her chair with a grace that was almost feline, her body relaxed, but her eyes never leaving Agatha. Her smile was small, private. “Doesn’t it?”

 

Agatha let out a sharp breath and dragged her fingers through her hair, tugging a little too hard at the roots. The pressure grounded her for a moment, but it did nothing to silence the echo of Rio’s voice under her skin. “You’re impossible.”

 

“I’ve been called worse,” Rio murmured, her tone light but her gaze unwavering.

 

The silence that followed wasn't empty, it pulsed between them like a living thing. Agatha could feel it in her throat, thick and heavy, like all the words she couldn’t say were pressing upward and refusing to be swallowed.

 

She shifted in her seat, fingers drumming against the edge of the table. Her eyes stayed fixed on her lap, on the patterns her hands made against the fabric of her jeans. “Why do you care so much?” she asked finally, her voice low. “Why not just... leave me alone? You clearly have better things to do with your cosmic, all-powerful existence.”

 

Rio didn’t laugh this time. She watched Agatha carefully, her expression softening in a way that stripped her of every mask. “Because you called me, Agatha. And because I love you, whether you believe it or not.”

 

The words were simple. But they sank like stones in Agatha’s chest.

She blinked hard, staring down at her hands, at the slight tremble in her fingers, the tiny scar on her knuckle, the chipped nail polish. Anything to avoid the weight of Rio’s gaze. Her throat tightened, aching with all the things she didn’t know how to say.

 

“I’m not asking for anything from you,” Rio continued, her voice quieter now, edged with something deeper. Not sadness. Not pity. Patience. “I just want you to stop running from yourself.”

 

“I don’t know how to stop,” Agatha whispered, her voice cracking around the edges.

 

Rio stood slowly, the movement fluid and unhurried. She circled the table and knelt beside Agatha, one hand rising, not forceful, not demanding, just there. She placed it gently on Agatha’s shoulder, the warmth of it blooming through fabric and muscle like a pulse.

 

“You don’t have to figure it out all at once,” she said, her breath brushing against Agatha’s jaw. “Just... let yourself feel. Start there.”

 

Agatha didn’t move. She couldn’t. Her heart pounded so violently it echoed in her ears, drowning out the quiet rustle of leaves around them. Her eyes closed. Just for a second.

 

She didn’t lean into Rio, but she didn’t pull away either.

 

Rio let Agatha take the lead, her dark eyes steady and unyielding as Agatha leaned in. The kiss was cautious but laced with tension, a slow, tentative meeting of mouths that carried the weight of lifetimes and the promise of something dangerous. Agatha's lips trembled against Rio's, a soft exhale escaping her as her fingers brushed the edge of Rio's jaw. The kiss was brief, a flicker of heat, not a fire, but it left Agatha breathless.

 

She pulled back, blinking hard, her cheeks burning. The air between them buzzed with static. Before either could speak, the sharp sound of the doorbell rang out, cutting through the silence like a blade.

 

Rio didn’t flinch. She remained perfectly still, her posture loose and feline, head tilted, eyes gleaming with amusement. “Expecting someone, darling?” she asked, her voice a low hum, soaked in velvet.

 

Agatha stepped away, her body flushed with the aftershock of the kiss. Her lips still tingled. She ran a hand through her hair, trying to compose herself. “No,” she muttered. “Not... really.”

 

Her steps to the front door were measured but fast, her breath unsteady, the soft creak of the hardwood under her bare feet the only sound besides her heartbeat thudding in her ears. Behind her, Rio leaned against the hallway wall like a shadow that refused to let go, cool, unreadable, but humming with the thrill of proximity.

 

Agatha opened the door and met the calm, stoic faces of Officer Daniel and his partner. The weight of reality settled hard over her shoulders, snuffing out the warmth that lingered behind her.

 

“Officer Daniel,” she greeted, her voice carefully even, though her pulse fluttered with apprehension. “What can I do for you?”

 

“Mrs. Harkness,” Daniel replied with a curt nod, his tone as firm as always. “We have an update regarding your husband’s case.”

 

The knot in Agatha’s stomach twisted tighter, like barbed wire pulling through soft flesh. She held the door wider, her fingers briefly slipping on the handle from the sheen of nervous sweat. “Of course,” she said, stepping aside. “Come in.”

 

The officers entered with quiet authority, their presence dragging cold air in with them. Rio remained in the hallway, her form still and attentive, her eyes never leaving Agatha.

As Daniel and his partner stepped into the living room, the familiar scent of chamomile and cinnamon lingered in the air from the abandoned teacups. The light through the window had softened, casting golden edges over everything it touched, except for the tension that tightened Agatha’s spine the moment Rio’s name almost slipped free.

Daniel’s sharp eyes landed on Rio first. She was draped over the armrest of the couch like a cat in the sun, legs crossed, posture loose, but her gaze sharp. She didn’t stand. She didn’t flinch. Her dark eyes met his, calm and assessing.

 

“And you are?” Daniel asked, his voice clipped and precise, the question more accusation than inquiry.

 

Rio tilted her head slowly, a corner of her mouth curving upward. “Rio Vidal,” she began, voice slow and rich, like warm honey laced with venom. “The Deat—”

 

“Friend!” Agatha’s voice snapped through the room like a breaking glass. She stepped in front of Rio so fast her tea nearly sloshed over. Her pulse pounded in her throat, every muscle in her body tensed. “She’s my friend. A close friend.”

 

Daniel’s eyebrows lifted slightly, and though he nodded, the skepticism in his eyes stayed rooted. “I see.”

 

Rio offered nothing but a feline smile in response, folding her hands neatly in her lap. “Don’t worry, officer. I’m just here to support Agatha. Harmless, I assure you.”

 

Her tone was playful, but Agatha caught the subtle gleam behind her words, the deliberate needle meant to unnerve. She shot Rio a look that could’ve flayed lesser beings.

 

Daniel turned away with a slight, skeptical grunt. “You mentioned an update?” Agatha prompted, her voice calm but taut.

 

Daniel pulled a folder from under his arm, the rustle of paper loud in the quiet room. He flipped to a page and held up a photo. “We’ve spoken to a witness. A neighbor. They claim they saw your husband the night he disappeared. Leaving alone.”

 

Agatha frowned, her throat tightening. She folded her arms as if shielding herself. “Alone? Are you sure?”

 

“They were adamant. He got into a car down the street. Unfortunately, the vehicle description is vague, but it’s progress.”

 

As Daniel spoke, Agatha could feel Rio’s gaze on her, calm and steady like a hand pressed to the center of her chest. She could see it out of the corner of her eye, Rio’s amused smirk as if she already knew how this story ended.

 

“And how long have you been staying here?” Daniel shifted his tone, suddenly addressing Rio again.

 

Rio’s smile never faded. She turned slightly toward him, her profile catching the light, elegant and unreadable. “Not long. Just helping Agatha... through her grief.”

 

There was a cool finality in her voice. Daniel’s jaw tensed. “Well. If either of you remembers something else,” he said, eyes locked on Rio now, “call us.”

 

“Of course,” Agatha answered, too quickly. Her fingers tightened around the hem of her sweater, knuckles pale. “Thank you.”

 

As the officers turned to leave, Daniel glanced back one last time. Rio raised her hand in a slow, mock-sincere wave, the glint in her eye making Agatha’s stomach twist.

 

The door clicked shut.

 

Agatha spun around the second they were out of sight. “What the hell was that?” she hissed.

 

Rio stretched luxuriously, like a predator who’d just finished toying with prey. “I was charming.”

 

“You were provoking him.”

 

“I’m always provoking someone. It’s part of my charm.”

 

Agatha’s jaw clenched. “You nearly said it. Your name.”

 

Rio rose and moved toward her, slow and deliberate. “And you stopped me. That’s progress. You're reading me already!”

 

Agatha stared up at her, her jaw tight, lips parted, breath shallow. The silence between them pulsed, hot, taut, unforgiving. Her hands were fists at her sides, nails biting into her palms to keep her grounded, to stop the tremble that threatened to betray her. The air between them felt too thick, too charged, like it might snap and spark if either of them moved too fast.

 

Rio didn’t move. She didn’t need to. Her words alone were an earthquake.

 

“You’re mine, Agatha” she said softly, each syllable brushing over Agatha’s skin like velvet-lined steel. “And I don’t like being forgotten.”

 

The sentence struck low, just beneath Agatha’s sternum, where her pulse lived. It wasn’t just the words. It was the way Rio said them, the ownership wrapped in intimacy, the quiet fury in the softness. No raised voice. No demand. Just truth, delivered like a secret promise and a threat all in one.

Agatha opened her mouth, but nothing came. Her throat had gone dry. There was too much heat in her chest, and not nearly enough breath to hold it.

 

So she turned, sharply, the movement too fast, too defensive. “I need a drink,” she muttered, her voice lower than intended, edged with something raw. Her heels clicked against the floor as she stormed toward the kitchen, not to escape Rio, she told herself, but to drown her in silence.

 

Behind her, Rio’s laughter curled through the air like smoke. Low, knowing. Sinful.

 

“I’ll take one too, darling,” she called, the nickname sliding off her tongue like a touch against bare skin.

 

Agatha’s steps faltered, just once. She hated that word from Rio’s mouth, hated how it sounded like possession and worship all at once. Hated that it made her thighs clench and her mouth dry.

 

In the kitchen, she yanked open the cabinet and grabbed a glass. Her fingers trembled slightly as she poured the whiskey, just one finger more than usual. She didn’t pour Rio’s. Not yet. That would be a surrender.

The sound of approaching footsteps was soft, but her body knew. She felt Rio before she saw her, felt her heat like a hand at her back, felt the air shift with her presence. The kitchen lights cast a golden glow, and when Agatha turned to face her, Rio was already leaning lazily against the counter, arms crossed, eyes dark and fixed on her.

 

Predatory. Patient.

 

“You’re not going to win, Rio,”

 

Agatha said quietly, her voice low but taut, knuckles white against the marble counter behind her. She didn’t look at her—refused to. Her breath was tight, her spine straight, but her pulse betrayed her, beating too fast, too loud.

 

“You think you can get under my skin,” she continued, voice trembling just enough to betray the war inside her. “Twist me into knots until I give in. But I’m not the same woman I was in whatever life you think we shared.”

 

Behind her, footsteps moved slowly over the kitchen tiles, bare, deliberate. A quiet click of boot against floor. Then silence.

 

Then warmth.

 

Rio’s voice came next, smooth as poured whiskey, low as a whisper at midnight. “Oh, Agatha…” she purred, stepping close enough for her breath to ghost against the shell of Agatha’s ear, “you’re exactly who you were. You just don’t remember how good it felt to stop pretending.”

 

Agatha’s breath hitched. Her fingers dug into the edge of the counter.

Rio circled her like smoke, her presence like silk and threat all at once. Her fingers brushed lightly across the small of Agatha’s back, so faint it could’ve been a breeze, but the shiver it left was electric.

 

“Let me make you another drink,” she murmured, now behind her. Her lips brushed the curve of Agatha’s ear, her breath warm and laced with mint and liquor. “Or…” she said, dragging the syllable out like a promise, “you can keep pretending that glass in your hand is the only thing shaking.”

 

Agatha’s hand trembled. The glass wobbled. She set it down too hard, the sound sharp and brittle in the stillness between them.

 

She didn’t respond. She didn’t have to.

 

Rio smiled behind her, slow and self-assured, and when she moved again, her touch was no longer subtle. She pressed a hand against Agatha’s hip, her thumb anchoring into the bone just enough to claim. Then another touch, fingers gliding up her spine, dragging fire in their wake.

 

Agatha’s head tilted back when Rio’s lips found her neck, just below the ear. A gasp tore from her lips before she could catch it. “Rio… baby, don't...” she breathed, warning or plea, it didn’t matter. It was already too late.

 

Rio grinned against her skin.

 

Her arms slid around Agatha’s thighs in one fluid movement, lifting her effortlessly. Agatha let out a surprised sound, half moan, half disbelief — as her body was settled onto the counter, cool marble kissing the back of her thighs.

 

The heat between them was immediate. Hungry.

 

Agatha’s legs wrapped instinctively around Rio’s waist, her heels pressing into the small of her back. Her arms curled around Rio’s shoulders, her fingers tangled in her dark hair as she pulled her in, mouth crashing into hers.

 

The kiss wasn’t gentle. It was molten. Teeth, tongue, breath shared like sin and air.

 

Rio tasted of whiskey and mint and something wild, something not of this world. Agatha’s hips rolled forward on instinct, seeking friction, contact, something, anything, because her skin was burning, her body pulsing in places she hadn’t remembered feeling in years.

Her moan was swallowed into Rio’s mouth. Desperate. Embarrassed by how much she needed this. How badly her body betrayed her control.

She ground her hips against Rio’s stomach, greedy, frantic. The heat between her legs was maddening, soaked in want, in shame, in something that felt like surrender.

 

God, it was wrong. It was so wrong.

 

Rio was Death.

 

But it didn’t feel wrong. It felt like gravity. Like home.

 

“Rio… please…” Agatha gasped, her voice broken against Rio’s mouth as her lips trailed along her jaw, then lower, until they found her neck.

 

The plea was layered. Tension and permission. Yes and not yet.

 

Rio heard it all. She always did.

 

Her mouth stilled against Agatha’s pulse, lips parted against her skin. Then slowly, she pulled back. Her hands cupped Agatha’s face gently, reverently, thumbs brushing against her flushed cheeks.Their foreheads met. Breath to breath. Heartbeat to heartbeat.

 

Rio’s voice was soft now, deep and warm, curling like smoke between them. “See, baby?” she whispered, her gaze locked on Agatha’s parted lips. “I already have you.”

 

A pause. A cruel, tender smile.

 

“I won.”

 

Agatha’s eyes fluttered closed, her body still aching, still trembling against Rio’s. And for a moment — just a moment — she stopped pretending it wasn’t true.

 

"Yeah, you did"

 

Chapter 6: Chapter 6

Chapter Summary

Hi gays, how are you? Hope you're okay! Another chapter for you 😍

Agatha sat stiffly in the principal’s office, the edge of her seat digging into the back of her knees. Her hands gripped the armrests like anchors, her knuckles blanched from pressure, nails half-mooned into her palms. The room was too bright, sterile. The overhead light buzzed faintly, like it knew tension was thick enough to slice.

Next to her, Nicole sat coiled like a spring, arms locked across her chest, legs tucked under her chair as if daring anyone to look at her wrong. Her jaw was clenched, her foot tapping a silent rhythm that betrayed the storm beneath her silence.

 

Principal Lively adjusted her glasses slowly, deliberately, as though the pause might defuse the room’s charge. “Mrs. Harkness, while we understand that children sometimes have disagreements… physical violence cannot be tolerated.”

 

Agatha inhaled through her nose, steadying her pulse. “I understand,” she said, voice tight, formal.

 

Before she could elaborate, the office door opened with a gust of cold air and something wilder. Rio entered like a storm cloud — heels clicking, coat open, dark hair swept back from her face with casual arrogance. Her eyes locked immediately on Nicole, scanning her with a mix of protectiveness and fire. She looked like she was ready to gut someone with a smile.

 

Agatha stood so quickly her chair screeched. “Rio,” she hissed, eyes wide with alarm. “Not now.”

 

Rio ignored her. She always did when her blood was hot. She walked with a predator’s ease to the center of the room, her voice sharp and smooth. “Now is exactly the time.”

 

Principal Lively blinked, visibly caught off guard. “And you are?”

 

Rio cocked her head slightly, lips curving in a way that could only be described as dangerous. “I’m her mother,” she said without hesitation, nodding toward Nicole. “Obviously.”

 

The principal’s eyes darted toward Agatha, brows drawn tight. “I’m sorry, what?”

 

Agatha groaned under her breath and rubbed her temples, the beginnings of a headache thrumming behind her eyes. “She’s not wrong,” she muttered through clenched teeth. “Rio Vidal donated the eggs for both of my children. She is their biological mother, in some way. But she is not here in any official capacity.”

 

Rio flashed Agatha a look that said yet.

 

Principal Lively blinked again, clearly unsure what to make of the dynamic now unfolding in her office. “I see,” she said slowly.

 

“I’m just here for my daughter,” Rio added, voice softer now, though it still carried an undercurrent of steel. “And because she’s clearly not being protected properly.”

 

“Rio, stop,” Agatha snapped, her voice dropping lower in warning. “You’re not helping.”

 

Rio’s eyes slid back to Nicole, who hadn’t looked up once. “Nicole,” she said, gentler now. “What happened?”

 

Nicole still didn’t lift her gaze, her shoulders rigid. “I don’t want to talk about it.”

 

“Then don’t,” Agatha cut in, stepping between them. “She doesn’t have to explain herself here.”

 

“She deserves to be heard,” Rio countered, gaze unwavering, jaw tense. “Even if she’s angry. Especially if she’s angry.”

 

"Dad..." Nicole’s fists trembled where they rested on her lap. Her voice, when it came, was quiet but raw. “She said you killed him.”

 

Agatha’s stomach dropped like a stone. “What?”

 

Nicole’s head finally rose, and her eyes shimmered — not just with tears, but with rage, betrayal, and a confusion that made Agatha’s heart twist. “She said the police think you did it. That you killed Dad and lied. But you didn’t, right? He left us. I know he left.”

 

The words slammed into Agatha like a blow to the chest. She stumbled backward a step, her mouth open, but nothing came out.

Rio was already moving.

 

Her whole body stilled, then turned to steel. Her hands clenched at her sides, knuckles cracking. “Who said that to you?” she asked, voice like ice over fire.

 

“Rio,” Agatha warned, trying to regain control of the spiraling conversation, but Rio didn’t even glance at her.

 

“Nicole,” she said again, softer but firmer, crouching slightly so they were eye to eye. “Tell me.”

 

Nicole sniffed and wiped at her nose with the sleeve of her hoodie. “Morgan Stark.”

 

Rio stood straight. “Morgan Stark?” Her lips curled. “Give me five minutes.”

 

Agatha lunged forward, grabbing Rio’s wrist before she could make it to the door. “Don’t you dare.”

 

Rio turned sharply, her pupils blown wide, voice razor-sharp. “That little brat humiliated my daughter. She made her cry. She made her doubt you. And I’m supposed to do nothing?”

 

“Yes!” Agatha hissed. “You are supposed to not threaten a child, Rio! You’re supposed to be better than this. We are adults. She’s a kid.”

 

“I don’t give a fuck about her age,” Rio growled. “Words like that don’t come from nowhere. Someone taught her to say it. And I’m going to find out who.”

 

“And then what?” Agatha challenged. “You’re going to scare her into silence? You’re going to threaten her family? Because that’s not justice, Rio. That’s revenge. And that’s not what Nicole needs right now.”

 

Nicole had gone silent again, her eyes darting between them like she was watching a match lit too close to dry grass.

 

Rio’s breathing was heavy, her chest rising and falling, her fists still clenched. “You think I’m wrong?”

 

Agatha shook her head, her voice quieter but firm. “I think you’re hurt. So am I. And I think you’re scaring her.”

 

Rio looked at Nicole — really looked — and something in her face cracked. She exhaled, shoulders sinking as the fury bled into exhaustion.

 

“I just want her to feel safe,” she said, almost to herself.

 

Agatha stepped closer and touched her arm, not as a command this time, but as an anchor. “Then let’s do that. Together. The right way.”

 

Rio didn’t speak again. She simply nodded once, jaw tight, then turned back toward Nicole. Her hand reached out slowly, resting gently on Nicole’s shoulder.

The principal, clearly overwhelmed, held up her hands with a firm but tired grace, her fingers trembling just slightly as she adjusted the glasses perched at the tip of her nose.

 

“Let’s all take a moment to calm down. Mrs. Vidal, was it?”

 

“Yes,” Rio said, her voice clipped and tight, though it simmered with restrained fury just beneath the surface.

 

The principal offered a strained smile, trying to restore authority. “Mrs. Vidal, please take a seat so we can address this appropriately. We can contact the Starks and arrange a meeting to discuss these allegations.”

 

Rio moved slowly to the chair, every motion deliberate, a storm barely leashed beneath the surface. She sat down with an air of reluctant compliance, her spine rigid, one leg crossed tightly over the other as her knuckles whitened where they gripped the armrest.

 

“Fine,” she said, each syllable cool and sharpened like glass. “But let me be clear — no one spreads lies about my daughter’s family. No one.”

 

“Rio, stop,” Agatha said softly, her voice trembling with exasperation and something else — fear, maybe, or the overwhelming need to maintain composure before it shattered entirely. Her eyes briefly met Rio’s, pleading in a language they had never agreed upon but both understood instinctively.

 

Rio didn’t speak again. Her jaw tensed, her lips pressing into a thin line, but she leaned back in her seat with a quiet, tight nod.

 

The principal cleared her throat, reclaiming the silence with effort. “Mrs. Harkness, Mrs. Vidal, we will handle this matter professionally. Nicole, I trust you understand that violence is not the answer, no matter what’s said?”

 

Nicole, still curled in on herself like a blade drawn too tight, nodded without raising her eyes. Her voice had dried up entirely, replaced by the cold press of shame and the heat of still-bubbling fury. Her nails dug crescent moons into her sleeves.

 

“Good,” the principal said, standing with finality. “I’ll reach out to the Starks and we’ll resolve this matter together. In the meantime, I expect Nicole to avoid further contact with Morgan until a meeting has taken place.”

 

Agatha stood slowly, her movements precise, her breaths long and even like she was counting each one to keep from unraveling. Nicole followed without a word, and Rio stood last, her heels clicking with sharp finality against the polished tile.

Once outside the office, away from the polished politeness and tightly wound tension of administration, Agatha rounded on Rio.

 

Her voice was low, but furious. “You cannot keep barging in and making things worse.”

 

Rio’s expression didn’t flinch. If anything, her brow arched in amusement. “Worse? I just defended you and our daughter.”

 

“You escalated it,” Agatha spat, her voice catching in her throat, her face flushed — not with embarrassment, but with the heat of helplessness. “You always escalate.”

 

Rio’s smirk shifted into something softer, subtler — no less dangerous, but laced with a tenderness that only infuriated Agatha more. Her gaze flicked to Nicole walking ahead of them, her small shoulders square with anger she hadn’t been taught to carry.

 

“I didn’t escalate anything,” Rio said smoothly. “I protected my family.”

 

Agatha stopped walking, planting her heels against the polished hallway floor. “Stop saying that.” Her voice was hushed but sharp enough to cut. “Stop saying things like that.”

 

“Like what?” Rio asked, her voice low, all velvet and edges. “The truth?”

 

Agatha stared at her, something unreadable in her eyes — wounded, shaken, pulled in too many directions. Her lips parted, then closed again as if any word she tried would be the wrong one. The moment stretched.

And then Nicole turned to glance back at them, her expression unreadable, watching them both like she was waiting to see who would blink first.

 

Rio stepped forward, not closing the space between them, just brushing the edge of Agatha’s personal gravity. Her voice was quiet now, barely above a whisper. “Let’s just go home. We’ll deal with this together.”

 

Agatha stared at her for a second longer before her shoulders slumped. The air left her lungs in a slow, weary exhale.

 

“Fine,” she muttered. “But no more drama, Rio.”

 

Rio’s grin was small, almost tender — too knowing. Her eyes gleamed with something that looked like a promise and a warning.

 

“No promises, Professor.”

 

Agatha groaned, pressing two fingers to her temple as she turned toward the door. Behind her, Rio fell into step, her presence like a second shadow — laced in fire, cloaked in chaos, and far too close to Agatha’s heart for her to admit out loud.

Nicole sat in the car with her arms crossed, her brows drawn together in a permanent scowl, the weight of exclusion pressing hard against her chest. Through the tinted window, she tracked every step her mothers took up the Starks’ pristine driveway. Rio’s posture was relaxed, almost feline, all fluid grace and coiled restraint. Agatha, in contrast, was rigid with tension, her heels striking the pavement with purposeful, clipped clicks.

 

“I don’t know why they won’t let me be there,” Nicole muttered, her nails tapping irritably against the car door.

 

“Probably because they know you’d make it worse,” Nick answered from the backseat, not even glancing up from his tablet. His fingers moved rapidly across the screen, the game’s sound muted but its glow illuminating his young face.

 

Nicole twisted in her seat to glare at him. “She deserved it.”

 

“Whatever,” Nick mumbled, clearly more invested in leveling up than in sibling drama.

 

Up the path, Agatha inhaled sharply as her finger hovered over the doorbell.

 

“Rio,” she said, her voice tight and low. “Let me do the talking. Please.”

 

Rio gave her a slow, indulgent smile, her hands tucked neatly behind her back. "Of course, darling. I’ll be as silent as your conscience." Agatha didn’t bother hiding her eye roll.

 

The door opened before she could reply, revealing Pepper Stark in a crisp cream blouse and tailored slacks. Her gaze was cool, precise. Her smile, if it could be called that, didn’t reach her eyes.

 

“Mrs. Harkness,” she said, each syllable clipped. Her eyes shifted to Rio. “And...?”

 

“Rio Vidal,” Rio purred smoothly, stepping forward, hand extended in mock politeness. "A pleasure."

 

Pepper didn’t take it. Her gaze returned to Agatha like Rio hadn’t spoken at all. “I assume this is about Morgan.”

 

“Yes,” Agatha answered, voice level but tight. “May we come in to discuss it?”

 

There was a heartbeat of pause before Pepper stepped aside, allowing them into a living room so spotless it felt untouched by life. The scent of polished wood and subtle citrus cleaner hung in the air. Everything — from the pristine cushions to the gleaming surfaces — screamed order, control, and curated appearances.

 

“Please, have a seat,” Pepper said, gesturing to the white couch with all the warmth of a museum tour guide.

 

Agatha lowered herself carefully, smoothing her skirt as she sat. Rio remained standing, pacing slowly around the room like a cat let loose in someone else’s territory. Her eyes moved from photo to photo, her lip curling slightly at the sight of Morgan’s framed cheerleading portrait.

 

“I understand Nicole had an altercation with your daughter,” Agatha began, tone measured. “She told us some things were said that were... troubling.”

 

Pepper raised one elegant brow, arms folded. “Troubling? Your daughter struck mine. That’s more than troubling — it’s aggressive.”

 

Agatha’s fingers curled slightly on her lap. “She reacted because Morgan said something deeply inappropriate.”

 

“About Agatha,” Rio interjected, her voice suddenly like velvet over steel.

 

Pepper’s mouth twitched. “And what, exactly, does that mean?”

 

Agatha opened her mouth, but Rio beat her to it.

 

“It means your daughter accused Agatha of killing her husband,” she said, voice calm but with a venomous edge. “A baseless, revolting thing to say, especially considering the source.”

 

Pepper stiffened visibly, her mask faltering. “I—I don’t know where she would’ve heard that.”

 

Rio gave a slow blink. “Don’t you?”

 

“Rio,” Agatha snapped under her breath, reaching to still her with a hand.

 

But Rio stepped forward, her gaze fixed. “Let’s not pretend kids make up things like that without help. So tell me, Pepper, what exactly have you been whispering about my family?”

 

Pepper’s cheeks flushed. “I beg your pardon?”

 

“You heard me,” Rio said, folding her arms. “Rumors like that don’t just appear. So unless Morgan’s been reading police reports on her own, someone planted that thought.”

 

“Rio. Enough,” Agatha said firmly, rising to her feet and placing a restraining hand on Rio’s arm. Her grip was tight. “We are here to resolve this, not start a war in someone’s marble foyer.”

 

The air between them vibrated with tension. Pepper looked between the two of them — Agatha, visibly trying to keep the situation from boiling over, and Rio, who exuded unshakable menace beneath the calm of her voice.

 

Mrs. Stark straightened, her composure beginning to crack beneath Rio’s unrelenting stare. Her polished exterior — perfectly tailored blouse, flawless hair, that poised smile — strained at the edges. "I assure you, I’ve said no such thing," she insisted, though her voice carried the tiniest tremor. "If Morgan said that, it’s because she misunderstood something."

 

Rio tilted her head slowly, her expression sharp, amused in that dangerous way she had. Like a lion entertaining the idea of play but always two seconds from a bite. "Misunderstood, huh? How convenient."

 

Agatha stepped in then, sliding between them like a barrier made of tense muscle and restraint. The heat radiating off Rio made her skin prickle. "Mrs. Stark," Agatha said, tight-lipped but polite, her voice coated in ice. "Whatever the source of this misunderstanding, it’s caused a lot of hurt. I think it would be best if you had a conversation with Morgan about the importance of being mindful of what she says."

 

Mrs. Stark’s jaw twitched. She nodded curtly, clearly itching to usher them out of her pristine home. "Of course. I’ll speak with her."

 

"Good," Agatha replied, her words clipped as she stepped toward the door, signaling the end of the conversation. "And I hope we can put this behind us."

 

The sun was low on the horizon as they walked back to the car, staining the driveway gold. Agatha’s heels tapped briskly on the pavement, but Rio’s footfalls were silent, predatory. She stayed quiet, but her energy buzzed — dark, unreadable, like a coiled storm held barely in check.

Agatha could feel the burn of her gaze without even turning. Her own jaw ached from clenching it too tightly.

 

Inside the car, the air was thick with unspoken tension. Nicole leaned forward between the seats, her voice quick and sharp. "Well?"

 

"Handled," Agatha muttered, jamming the key into the ignition. Her fingers trembled slightly as she gripped the wheel. "Barely. And if you ever, EVER, interrupt me like that again, I'll—"

 

Rio let out a low chuckle from the passenger seat, all sin and silk. "I'll take the punishment happily, like the good girl I am."

 

The words dropped like a spark into kindling. Agatha’s breath caught, her knuckles whitening on the wheel. She turned her head slowly, narrowing her eyes. "You think this is funny?"

 

Rio leaned in just enough for her breath to ghost along Agatha’s neck, her voice a low purr. "No. I think you trying to control me is funny. You know you love it when I misbehave."

 

Nicole groaned in the backseat. "Oh my God, can you two not flirt while I'm trapped back here like a hostage?" Agatha exhaled sharply through her nose, biting back the urge to throttle both of them. 

Agatha sat on the couch with Nicole nestled close, her arm around the girl's slender shoulders, thumb tracing slow, soothing circles over the fabric of her shirt. Her voice was calm, measured, like a spell laced with comfort, pulling the anxiety out of the air one word at a time. Nicole didn’t speak much, just nodded, her eyes still a little too wide, too glossy. The tension of the day clung to her like a second skin.

Across the room, Rio moved like a storm barely held together — her boots hitting the hardwood with impatient, clipped steps. Her hands curled and uncurled at her sides, and the sharp line of her jaw flexed every time her mouth tightened. Her eyes, dark as obsidian and twice as sharp, flicked across the room like she was searching for something to break.

 

"Rio, can you stop for a second?" Agatha asked, her voice holding both exhaustion and edge as she looked over her shoulder.

 

Rio froze mid-stride, then turned toward her with fire sparking behind her lashes. "No, I can’t," she snapped, tone laced with a simmering fury that made the room feel warmer. Her hands gestured sharply, slicing the air. "That Stark woman is infuriating. And her kid — Morgan — entitled, cruel, and clearly learning it at home. I should’ve done more."

 

"You’ve done enough," Agatha replied, voice low but unwavering. There was no venom in her tone, only weariness. The kind that settles into your bones. "Let me handle the rest."

 

Rio barked out a dry, humorless laugh, pacing again. "Handle it? Right. That’s what Ralph used to say, wasn’t it? 'Let me handle it.' And what did he ever handle, Agatha? Nothing but his ego. Nothing but silence and lies."

 

Agatha flinched, her hand instinctively tightening on Nicole’s shoulder for a heartbeat before she consciously loosened her grip. Her lips thinned. She didn’t respond. Didn’t take the bait.

 

"Nicky," she said softly, turning to her daughter, brushing a few strands of hair back from her face. "Why don’t you go upstairs, sweetheart? Run a bath. Light one of the lavender candles, the one you like. I’ll come up soon."

 

Nicole hesitated, her gaze moving warily from her mother to Rio. Her voice was small but firm. "You sure you’ll be okay?"

 

Agatha nodded, offering her a gentle smile that didn’t quite reach her eyes. "I promise. Go on."

 

Nicole pushed herself up from the couch, still tense, and started toward the stairs. She paused, glanced back over her shoulder at Rio — whose entire posture screamed agitation — then disappeared up the steps. The quiet thump of her bedroom door echoed faintly in the silence that followed.

Agatha exhaled through her nose, rising slowly, smoothing her skirt down as if to shake off the lingering static of the moment. She turned to face Rio fully. The way Rio looked at her — like she was starving, like she was tethered to Agatha by something invisible and unyielding — made Agatha’s pulse stutter.

Some small flowers sprouted and died immediately where Rio stepped. As if the traces of her anger left behind a trail of uncontrolled power.

 

"You're spiraling," she said, voice tight. "You need to calm down."

 

"I am calm," Rio snapped, then immediately dragged a hand through her hair in frustration. The flowers that were in the room all rose with a little more life. It took a lot out of Agatha to simply not laugh.

 

Her body said otherwise, too — chest heaving subtly, jaw tight, shoulders set with that almost predatory tension she wore when she was seconds from doing something reckless. 

 

"You scared Pepper Stark," Agatha continued, stepping in close, lowering her voice but not her strength. "You nearly lit her house on fire with your glare. You don’t get to bulldoze people just because you feel righteous. And you're filling my living room with flowers like it's the Amazon rainforest."

 

"I protected our daughter," Rio hissed, eyes flashing. Her voice dropped, silk over steel. "And I would do it again."

 

Rio moved her hands impatiently and the flowers disappeared and the plants in the room took on their natural shape.

 

Agatha stood firm, breathing in slowly, letting it fill her lungs, force her to think. "You don’t get to walk into my life, claim territory like you’re entitled to it, and drag fire in your wake."

 

Rio stepped forward, invading her space, the air between them crackling. Her voice dipped into something dark, something possessive. "I don’t need to claim what’s already mine."

 

Agatha’s breath caught. She hated the way her body reacted — heat coiling low, a traitorous ache curling in her belly. Her fingers twitched at her sides.

 

"You don’t own me," she said, though her voice faltered at the end.

 

Rio leaned in close enough that Agatha could feel the heat of her breath ghost across her jaw. Her next words were barely a whisper. "Don’t I, though?"

 

Agatha’s lips parted, but the words never came. The room buzzed with tension. And beneath the fury, beneath the exhaustion and unspoken history, was the pull — gravity between stars destined to crash or burn.

 

"Come with me," Agatha said, her voice low but commanding, each syllable carrying the weight of something unspoken.

 

Rio stopped mid-step at the edge of the hallway, brow arching, lips parting into a lazy smirk. "Why? You’re not planning to lecture me again, are you?"

 

"Just follow me," Agatha replied, already turning on her heel, the click of her boots muffled on the carpeted hallway as she made her way toward her bedroom.

 

The air between them was thick with tension, but not the kind that demanded distance — no, this was heat. Something coiled, tight and waiting to snap. Rio’s curiosity piqued, and she followed, her gait slow and fluid, feline in its grace.

They stepped into Agatha’s room, the door closing behind them with a muted thud. The soft scent of lavender clung to the sheets, mingling with something uniquely Agatha — warm spice, aged books, and something sharp like ozone. The dim golden light from the bedside lamp bathed the room in a soft, sensual glow.

 

Rio leaned her shoulder against the closed door, arms crossed, her tone mocking but her eyes sharply alert. "So," she drawled, voice low and velvety, "what’s the plan? You going to tell me how much of a burden I am again? How I’ve ruined your life?"

 

Agatha didn’t speak. She crossed the room slowly, the soft rustle of fabric brushing between them as she stopped in front of Rio.

Then, without a single warning, she reached out and grabbed Rio by the lapels of her coat, pulling her forward with purpose. Her mouth crashed against Rio’s, fierce and hot. It wasn’t soft or uncertain, Agatha kissed like someone claiming territory she was tired of pretending didn’t belong to her.

Rio stilled for a moment, startled. Her body tensed before she melted into it, hands finally rising to rest on Agatha’s hips, fingers digging just enough to make it felt. When Agatha pulled back, breath ragged and lips flushed, Rio stared at her, speechless, pupils blown wide, her smugness utterly erased for the first time in what felt like forever.

 

"Okay," Rio whispered, a rare flicker of vulnerability threading her voice. "What... what was that?"

 

Agatha’s hands slid from Rio’s chest but didn’t retreat. They settled at her collarbones instead, fingers still curled slightly. "That was me realizing something," she murmured.

 

Rio blinked, trying to ground herself. "Realizing what?"

 

Agatha licked her lips, her voice hoarse and honest. "That was hot. You defending us. Defending me. Ralph never did that. Not once. He never made me feel like someone was in my corner."

 

Rio’s smirk returned slowly, but it was different this time — less arrogant, more predatory. "Ralph," she said, the name like a curse on her tongue, "doesn’t mean anything to you. Or to this family. And you know it."

 

Agatha nodded, jaw tight, emotion simmering behind her eyes. "I know. And that’s what makes this so... confusing."

 

Rio stepped forward, her hands now brushing up Agatha’s arms in slow, deliberate motions. Her voice dropped into that husky register that always made Agatha’s knees weaken. "It’s not confusing, Agatha. You’re just scared. You’re not used to wanting something this badly and having it want you back."

 

Agatha’s breath caught in her throat. The words landed like fire on bare skin. She looked away, but Rio’s fingers tilted her chin gently back.

 

"I hate that you’re always right," Agatha muttered, barely above a whisper.

 

Rio smiled, her mouth ghosting near Agatha’s ear, lips brushing just close enough to feel heat but not touch. "I’ll take that as a compliment, baby."

 

Agatha shivered, her hands unconsciously gripping Rio’s arms tighter. Her body was betraying her mouth again — leaning in when she meant to push away. Rio didn’t move to deepen the moment further. She just held her there, close, steady. Waiting. A predator who knew she didn’t have to chase anymore.

 

She’d already been chosen.

 

Agatha’s chest heaved with shallow, uneven breaths, her pulse hammering against her throat like a war drum. Her fingers twitched at her sides as she stared into Rio’s dark, patient eyes — eyes that shimmered like obsidian, calm on the surface but betraying a coiled hunger just beneath. There was no teasing grin now, no clever remark waiting on her tongue. Just silence. Tension. An invitation.

The air between them was thick with heat, alive with everything they hadn’t said. And Agatha hated it — how much she felt it. How much Rio made her feel, damn her. She clenched her jaw, nails digging into her palms, fury and want tangled too tightly to tell apart.

 

“Damn you,” she growled under her breath, her voice hoarse. And then she moved.

 

In one breathless moment, she closed the space between them, grabbed the front of Rio’s shirt with both hands, and yanked her forward. The kiss landed hard — desperate, greedy, tasting of frustration and fire. No prelude, no hesitation. Just lips on lips, teeth grazing, heat meeting heat.

 

A little pain... So little, so uncomfortable.

 

“It feels wrong,” Agatha heard her own voice in her mind. But it wasn’t her — not the her of now. Her voice was young. Innocent. Afraid. Warm. Hopeful.

 

Rio inhaled sharply against her mouth, startled — but it melted away in an instant. She groaned low in her throat, hands flying to Agatha’s waist, fingers tightening as if she meant to hold her there forever. Her body curved into Agatha’s like it belonged there, like it had always belonged there. Agatha ignored the voice, the pain, the flashes, the past that she didn't remember.

 

"Is it bad?" Rio asked... Not this Rio — the one in her mind.

 

The kiss deepened, messy and hungry, Rio’s mouth parting willingly beneath Agatha’s. Agatha moaned softly when Rio’s tongue brushed hers, the sound embarrassingly raw, too honest. She didn’t care. She couldn’t care. 

Her head hurt. It hurt so much. Her eyes were filling with tears, but she didn’t stop, she didn’t break the kiss. Not when Rio was responding with that perfect blend of control and reverence, like she was taking her apart cell by cell and savoring every second of it.

Agatha pressed closer, crushing their bodies together, her thigh slotted between Rio’s legs, her fingers fisting the collar of Rio’s shirt like she needed it to breathe. 

 

"No... it’s not bad... You’re not bad, Rio." The flash of her — young, fifteen, dressed in a white dress, old, a little stained with mud, forest, the sound of running water — appeared in her head. 

 

Her senses were drowning in her — Rio’s scent (earthy, electric, pine and leather), her heat, the way she tasted (like red wine and rebellion). Her hands burned where they touched. Her whole body trembled with the effort not to fall too far.

Rio’s hands slid upward slowly, possessively, until they cupped Agatha’s jaw with aching tenderness. 

 

"I am Death, Agatha."

 

Her thumbs brushed along Agatha’s cheeks, soft and reverent in contrast to the fire in the kiss. 

 

"Then why do I feel so alive beside you?”

 

When they finally broke apart, gasping, their foreheads pressed together, lips red and swollen, Rio let out a low breathless chuckle.

 

“That,” she murmured, her voice rasping like velvet over stone, “was unexpected.”

 

Agatha’s eyes were dazed, her lashes fluttering, a single tear insisting on appearing. Her fingers were still twisted in Rio’s shirt, trembling slightly. “Don’t act like you didn’t want it,” she whispered, her voice unsteady but defiant.

 

Rio’s lips curled slowly, darkly. Her voice dropped to a purr. “Oh, I wanted it, mi amor. I’ve wanted that for centuries.”

 

That word — mine — sent a tremor straight down Agatha’s spine. Her stomach twisted, not from shame, but from the terrifying truth of it. Because she had wanted it. And she hated how much she wanted it again.

 

“I am Death, Agatha.” 

 

Still, she pulled back slightly, trying to collect herself, to build up some sort of barrier again. Her fingers smoothed Rio’s shirt almost absentmindedly, brushing the place where her lips had just been. “This doesn’t mean anything,” she said flatly. Or tried to.

 

“It feels wrong.” 

 

Rio leaned in again, brushing her lips just shy of Agatha’s ear, her breath warm against skin too sensitive.
