Her voice was a sinful whisper, dangerous and teasing. “You say that, Professor,” — and Agatha shivered, damn her, damn that title — “but you’re still holding onto me like you’re afraid I’ll vanish.”

 

Agatha’s hands jerked back like she’d been burned. She turned sharply, pacing a few steps toward the door, needing space, needing oxygen that didn’t smell like Rio.

 

“Don’t make this a thing,” she snapped over her shoulder, but her voice cracked.

 

Behind her, Rio leaned back against the wooden beam like a queen on her throne, arms crossed lazily, eyes devouring. “Oh, my love,” she drawled, her voice like liquid smoke, “That's what you said the first, the second, the third time... And counting..”

 

Agatha closed her eyes, groaning softly, dragging a hand through her hair. Her skin still tingled where Rio had touched her. Her lips ached. Her heart wouldn’t calm down.

She didn’t know what this was. She didn’t know what to do with it. But she knew one thing: she wasn’t ready to let go.

 

Not yet.

 

"Then why do I feel so alive beside you?”

The television flickered dimly in the room, casting cold flashes of artificial light over the tense silence. The news anchor’s solemn voice crawled into every corner of the house like smoke, the words “Ralph O’Connor: Missing Seven Months” burning into the bottom of the screen like an accusation. Agatha sat upright, her spine rigid as steel, her fingers white-knuckled around the glass in her hand. Each breath she took felt like swallowing glass — sharp, acidic, punishing.

Her eyes were locked on the screen, but they didn’t really see the footage — blurry security cam stills, reporters outside a courthouse, an old photo of Ralph smiling tightly beside her. It all felt like someone else’s life, someone else’s mess.

Nick and Nicole sat flanking the couch like silent witnesses. They weren’t speaking, but their bodies were coiled in the kind of tension only children pick up on — the unspoken weight hanging in the air, pressing into their small chests, making everything feel a little colder than it should.

Rio moved with the quiet certainty of someone who was never unsure of herself. She didn’t ask — she didn’t need to. She stepped forward, slipped between the children, and sat down, pulling both of them into the curve of her arms like she’d done it every day of their lives. Her fingertips combed gently through Nick’s curls, then over Nicole’s sleek ponytail, the touch as intimate as it was grounding.

 

But her eyes never left Agatha.

 

Her voice was low, coaxing, intimate. “Sit down, my love,” she murmured, like she was trying to reel Agatha back from a ledge only she could see. Her thumb traced soothing circles on Nick’s shoulder as she added, “Nick, change the channel, would you?”

 

Agatha didn’t move. She was a portrait of control barely holding together at the seams. “This isn’t right,” she whispered, the words rasping out as if they hurt to speak. Her throat bobbed with the effort of keeping her composure. “He’s out there. Lost or... or dead.”

 

Rio’s voice was soft, but it carried like a whisper cutting through glass. “Not dead,” she said under her breath, the corners of her mouth twitching into a wry smirk.

 

Nick giggled, the sound small but piercing in the thick quiet. “Mama Rio’s funny,” he said, nudging Nicole, who gave a reluctant, shy smile in response.

 

Agatha snapped her head toward Rio, her expression cracking open. “Rio!” she hissed, her voice sharp and raw. “This isn’t a joke.”

 

Rio held up her hands in exaggerated surrender, her eyes glinting with something unreadable — half amusement, half caution. “What? I’m sorry.”

 

“Sorry?” Agatha echoed, her voice pitching higher, trembling. “I’m sitting here choking on guilt, wondering if I should’ve done more, called more, been more — wondering if he’s suffering somewhere — and I... I—” Her voice broke. She bit her bottom lip hard, trying to swallow down what came next.

 

Rio finished the sentence for her, her voice low and loaded. “And you kissed me.”

 

The words landed between them like a slap, intimate and explosive. The room seemed to tilt.

Agatha froze. Her hand trembled as she set her glass down with a shaky clink on the table. Her lips parted, but nothing came out. She looked like she’d just realized the floor beneath her was made of glass, and it had started to crack.

 

“I kissed the personification of death,” she said finally, her voice bitter and broken. “While my husband is—”

 

“Not dead,” Rio said again, cutting her off. This time, her tone was different — firmer, with an edge of something darker underneath. “And I’d know.”

 

Agatha looked at her then, really looked at her. The shadow in Rio’s eyes was real, ancient, but so was the fire. She looked impossibly calm — unbothered, but not unfeeling. The kind of calm that came with knowing too much and saying too little.

 

“And I’m just supposed to take your word for it?” Agatha asked, her voice cracking, her arms crossed protectively over her chest.

 

“Yes.” Rio’s answer was instant. Steady. Certain. “Because I’m the one who would know if he were gone. And he’s not. Not yet.”

 

The silence that followed was taut, drawn like a bowstring. The only sound was the quiet rustle of Nick’s hand against his blanket, the low hum of the TV now turned to a nature documentary — distant and irrelevant.

 

Then, Nick’s small voice broke through the tension. “You’re funny, Mama,” he said again, his tone sweet and oblivious, curling closer to her.

 

Rio smiled, soft and real this time, pressing a kiss to the top of his head. “I try, champ.”

 

Agatha stared at the scene — Rio cradling her son like she belonged there, like she had always belonged. The weight of it hit her chest with something like grief, or maybe longing. She wanted to be angry. She should have been angry. But all she could feel was this aching warmth curling behind her ribs, fragile and infuriating.

 

She rubbed her forehead, muttering, “You’re going to ruin everything.”

 

Rio didn’t look at her. Just kept stroking Nick’s hair with that maddening gentleness. “Or maybe,” she said quietly, “I’ll finally make it mean something.”

 

Agatha didn’t answer. Couldn’t. The words stuck somewhere in her throat, tangled in the tangle of guilt, desire, and something that felt a lot like fear.

 

And still — still — she didn’t look away.

 

“I need some air,” Agatha said abruptly, standing and heading for the back door.

 

Rio didn’t follow immediately. She stayed with the children, her hands still resting on their heads as she watched Agatha disappear into the night.

 

“You okay, Mama?” Nick asked, looking up at her with wide, trusting eyes.

 

Rio smiled faintly, her gaze softening. “I’m fine, champ. But your mom... she’s got a lot on her mind.”

 

“You’ll make her better,” Nicky said matter-of-factly, her voice carrying a surprising amount of confidence.

 

Rio chuckled, though there was a hint of sadness in her tone. “I’ll try, kiddo. I’ll try.”

 

She stayed with them a moment longer, ensuring they were at ease, before excusing herself to find Agatha. Whatever storm was raging inside her, Rio wasn’t about to let her weather it alone.

The din of the cafeteria felt like a dull roar in Agatha’s ears, the clatter of trays and clinking of cutlery serving as background noise to her slow, calculated chewing. She sat stiffly at the table, spine straight, eyes locked on her plate like it held the answers to every possible escape route.

 

But nothing could save her from what was coming.

 

Rio returned from the food line like she owned the entire damn building — hips swaying, chin lifted, her tray balanced easily in one hand. Her dark hair was pulled back in a loose, elegant twist, and the slinky black blouse she wore did nothing to minimize the way half the cafeteria turned to look. Including Alice.

 

“God! Your intern is a whole delici—” Alice began, her voice a low purr, eyes tracking Rio’s every step like a cat sizing up a meal.

 

“Alice!” Agatha snapped, her voice sharp as broken glass, low but slicing. Her cheeks flushed crimson, and she refused to look up from her chicken and rice like it might swallow her instead.

 

But Rio didn’t falter. She slid into the seat beside Agatha like she belonged there — which she absolutely didn’t — and set her tray down with maddening poise. Her scent hit first: something earthy and magnetic, like warm amber, wet stone, and trouble.

 

She leaned in, her arm brushing deliberately against Agatha’s as she whispered, “Don’t stifle her creativity, darling. Let her express herself.” Her voice was all silk and teeth.

 

Agatha whipped her head toward her, eyes narrow slits. “I will end you.”

 

Rio’s only response was a slow, knowing smile.

 

Wanda, ever the instigator, lifted her fork and gestured lazily. “Why does she call you pet names? Did I miss the wedding?”

 

“Because she’s annoying,” Agatha muttered, stabbing at her rice like it had insulted her personally. She still hadn’t made eye contact with anyone, least of all Rio, whose presence was a furnace against her side. “That's why.”

 

But Rio wasn’t done. She leaned back, arm draping over the back of Agatha’s chair, fingers brushing the fabric of her jacket. Her voice dropped — low, confident, utterly unbothered. “I’m in love with Agatha. Have been since the first day I saw her teaching.”

 

The table fell silent. Agatha choked. A bit of chicken flew from her lips and hit her plate with a wet plop.

 

She stared at Rio like she’d just announced she was the Queen of England. “What?!” Her voice cracked with disbelief.

 

Rio looked at her, eyes dark and steady, lips curved in that same maddening smirk. “What?” she repeated, all faux innocence. “You know I don’t lie. It’s not allowed.”

 

Agatha’s mouth opened, then closed again. Her face was blazing with heat, and her brain was tripping over itself, refusing to string together any sentence that didn’t end with her screaming.

 

She groaned and pinched the bridge of her nose, her voice a strangled hiss. “Okay! Just... just eat your food, Rio.”

 

Rio plucked a piece of arugula from her salad with dainty fingers and smiled. “Anything for you, my love.”

 

Wanda leaned across the table, resting her chin on her hand, eyes gleaming like a woman who’d just found her new favorite soap opera. “Hold on. Are you sleeping with my best friend?”

 

“WANDA,” Agatha snarled, whirling to face her, eyes blazing.

 

Rio didn’t blink. “Not yet,” she said easily, popping the arugula in her mouth and chewing slowly. “But I’m trying. Very hard.”

 

Jen, who’d been sipping her coffee with forced detachment, immediately sputtered, nearly choking. She grabbed her napkin, coughing into it while Alice burst out laughing so hard she had to clutch the edge of the table for balance.

 

“Fuck you!” Agatha slammed her napkin down, her voice nearing a growl. “You’re all unbearable.”

 

Wanda leaned in with a wicked grin. “So, you’re not denying it?”

 

Agatha glared at her, her lips trembling with the effort not to explode. “There’s nothing to deny. And for the love of everything, can we drop this topic?”

 

The room buzzed with background noise — cutlery scraping against plastic trays, the soft hum of conversations layered over each other — but at their table, time felt narrowed down to one simmering point of focus. Agatha.

Rio’s touch was featherlight, barely there, but it lit up Agatha’s nerves like a fuse. Her fingers slipped beneath the stiff collar of Agatha’s blouse, slow and deliberate, grazing the sensitive skin at the nape of her neck. It was a ghost of a touch, but it made Agatha’s entire body tense. A spark of heat shot down her spine, blooming beneath her skin in a way that was both infuriating and dizzying.

 

“You’re blushing, Professor,” Rio murmured into her ear, the word Professor rolling off her tongue with a familiar teasing reverence that curled under Agatha’s skin. Her voice was smoke and silk, designed to unravel. “Should I take that as a yes?”

 

Agatha jerked back just slightly, jaw tightening as she hissed, “Fuck off!” The curse fell from her lips sharp and breathless, more defense than denial.

 

Rio didn’t flinch. Instead, she took another measured bite of her food, her lips curving around the fork like a slow promise. The sharp edge of her smirk dulled into something softer — still dangerous, but touched with fondness. “You know they’re just jealous, darling,” she said, her tone lazy, her eyes half-lidded as she looked Agatha over like something decadent. “I mean, look at you.”

 

Agatha groaned, dragging her hands down her face and letting her elbows clatter loudly on the table. “I hate all of you. I hate you, Rio!”

 

“You don’t,” Rio said easily, confidence oozing from every syllable as if it were gospel. “You just want to.”

 

Another glare. Another skip in Agatha’s pulse.

 

Jen, having finally recovered from her earlier coughing fit, raised her coffee cup in Rio’s direction like it was a weapon. “You’re trouble, aren’t you?”

 

Rio raised her own glass of water, the gesture elegant and laced with irony. “The best kind.”

 

The table burst into laughter — Alice practically wheezing beside Wanda, who had tears of amusement in her eyes, and Jen shaking her head as she sipped her drink. The tension in the air dissolved, the group sliding easily back into their rhythm, though with an added charge — like someone had flipped the current on.

Agatha muttered something incoherent under her breath, her face hidden in her hands, but a tiny smile tugged traitorously at the corners of her mouth.

 

Rio saw it. She always did. And she leaned in once more, voice a hush meant for Agatha’s ears alone. “You can keep pretending, my love,” she whispered, her fingers lightly tracing the curve of Agatha’s spine beneath the table. “But your body always tells the truth.” Agatha didn’t look at her. Didn’t respond, but she didn’t move away either.

 

The air around the lunch table shimmered with tension barely masked by the forced clatter of cutlery and the occasional dry laugh. Agatha sat rigid, her jaw tight, stabbing at the wilted greens on her plate like they’d insulted her. Every inch of her posture screamed restraint — shoulders tight, lips thin, eyes flickering toward Rio with murderous restraint. The fork in her hand trembled once, betraying the weight of her composure.

Across from her, Rio lounged like she owned the table — and perhaps Agatha too, in spirit if not in fact. Her long fingers toyed with the rim of her glass, idle, predatory. The smug tilt of her smirk hadn’t moved since she sat down, like it was stitched into her very bones. Every so often, she’d glance sidelong at Agatha — not to speak, not to push, but simply to look. Watch. Wait. Daring her to crack.

Wanda, arms folded and coffee in hand, studied the pair with the precision of someone used to sniffing out secrets. Her brow furrowed as she slowly stirred her drink, the silence stretching around the table like a slow-building spell. Then she spoke, voice laced with suspicion.

 

“You know,” she mused aloud, eyes never leaving Agatha, “I’ve known Aggie for years. And I’ve never seen her let someone get away with this much... nonsense.”

 

The fork slipped from Agatha’s hand and hit the plate with a sharp clink. Her eyes snapped to Wanda like flint to steel. “Wanda, I swear—”

 

“No, no,” Wanda said, waving a dismissive hand, “I mean it. You don’t just let people call you darling. Or touch you. Or breathe within five feet of you without vaporizing them with a look. And now she’s dropping the ‘I’m in love with Agatha’ thing?” She leaned forward. “It’s weird, Aggie.”

 

“Don’t call me Aggie,” Agatha snapped, her cheeks blooming red like fire pressed under porcelain. Her voice was low, taut, and ready to shatter.

 

Rio raised one elegant hand, as if asking for the stage. “If I may,” she purred, her voice drenched in amusement, “it’s not weird. It’s destiny.”

 

Jen, leaning on her elbow, arched a skeptical brow. “Destiny,” she repeated flatly.

 

“Absolutely,” Rio said without hesitation. She leaned forward like a lover reciting a vow, her eyes locked on Agatha’s. “How else would you explain this magnetic pull between us? A love that transcends time and logic and reason—”

 

Agatha slammed her palm down on the table with a loud bang, her breath catching like fire in her lungs. “Oh my God, stop talking! Too much, Rio, too much!”

 

Alice spat her drink back into her cup, coughing through a burst of laughter. Wanda chuckled into her hand, and even Jen cracked a crooked smile.

 

Agatha could barely look at any of them. Her skin was hot, her chest tight, and her whole body pulsing with a blend of embarrassment and something that felt suspiciously like desire. She grabbed her tray with jerky motions and stood, her chair scraping loudly against the floor. “I’m going back to my office.”

 

Rio stood too, fluid and graceful, her movements a complete contrast to Agatha’s storm. “Need company?” she asked, voice silken with just the right amount of insolence.

 

“No,” Agatha barked over her shoulder, not slowing down.

 

“That’s cute. You think I was asking.” Rio’s grin spread, lazy and indulgent, as she followed like a shadow too confident to hide.

 

Behind them, laughter rang out again, louder this time — Alice howling, Wanda wiping tears from her eyes. But Agatha didn’t turn back. Her heels clicked hard against the floor, Rio’s steps echoing lightly behind her, perfectly in rhythm.

And though Agatha didn’t speak again until they were down the hall, her flushed cheeks and clenched fists betrayed her. So did the small, involuntary glance over her shoulder. And Rio saw it. Every flicker, every flick of longing buried beneath fury. She always did.

The office door clicked shut behind Rio with a gentle finality, sealing them off from the chaotic noise of the cafeteria. The moment felt heavier than it should have, weighed down by silence, by tension so thick it clung to the walls like heat after a storm.

Agatha dropped her tray on the desk with a loud thud, the metal rattling as if echoing her frustration. She turned sharply, her brows drawn in a glare already forming on her face — but it faltered the moment she caught Rio’s gaze.

 

Rio wasn’t smirking this time. Not at first.

 

She stood against the doorframe with one hand casually braced above her head, her body language relaxed but eyes... intense. Dark and unreadable, they traced over Agatha like a slow tide, savoring the stillness between them. Her mouth curved just slightly — an expression that held amusement, yes, but also something far more dangerous. Hungry. Focused. Agatha’s throat tightened.

 

“What?” she snapped, folding her arms tightly across her chest like armor. Her voice was firm, but her heartbeat betrayed her, thudding erratically behind her ribs.

 

Rio’s eyes dipped, deliberately slow, from Agatha’s eyes to her lips, then lower. She shrugged with a casual grace that somehow felt like it had teeth. “Nothing,” she said, her voice velvet-lined. “You’re just... fun to watch when you’re all fired up.”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes hard enough to anchor herself back in reality. “Well, stop watching. Don’t you have something better to do?”

 

“Not really,” Rio said, her voice a little softer now, and she took a single step forward. “Unless you’re suggesting I find something else to focus on.”

 

The change in her tone was subtle but devastating. That teasing cadence gave way to something thicker, lower. Like a secret shared under candlelight. Agatha’s breath hitched despite herself, her fingers twitching where they gripped her sleeves.

 

“You’re insufferable,” she muttered, averting her gaze, pretending the floor was suddenly fascinating.

 

“And yet…” Rio moved closer — too close now. She reached up, not to touch Agatha’s face this time, but to gently gather a handful of her hair. “You keep me around. Like a loyal poppy.” 

 

Her fingers slid through the silky strands at the nape of Agatha’s neck with calculated slowness, making Agatha’s breath catch.

 

Rio leaned in, close enough for Agatha to feel the whisper of her breath at her ear. “Why is that, I wonder?”

 

Agatha stood frozen, the scent of Rio suddenly enveloping her — dark spices, rain-soaked wood, and something floral buried deep beneath it all. She felt the ghost of Rio’s lips near her jawline, the warmth of her breath skating over her skin. And then — softly, purposefully — Rio tugged her hair, just enough to tilt her head, baring the curve of her throat.

 

“Rio,” Agatha warned, though the edge in her voice was thin, barely there. “Don't…”

 

But Rio didn’t stop. She leaned in fully now, her mouth brushing against Agatha’s pulse point with the lightest kiss — just enough pressure to stir the blood underneath. Then her lips parted and she sucked gently, enough to leave behind a faint, blooming mark. Agatha gasped, her hands gripping the edge of the desk behind her for support. Her knees felt loose, heat pulsing low in her stomach like a spark had been struck.

 

Rio pulled back slowly, her lips still close enough to graze the mark she’d just left. Her voice was a satisfied murmur, smug and intimate. “Just wanted to leave something for you to think about.”

 

Agatha’s eyes flew open, her face flushed with shock and fury and something far too dangerous to name. “You—”

 

But Rio was already stepping away, her smirk fully returned now, glittering with wicked delight. “I’ll be around,” she said lightly, like she hadn’t just unraveled Agatha’s self-control with a single touch.

 

And with that, she turned and exited the office without looking back, her departure quiet, calculated, and entirely triumphant — leaving Agatha standing there, breathless and burning, with a fresh mark blooming red on her neck and a storm gathering behind her eyes.

The door clicked shut behind Rio, and only then did Agatha allow herself to move. She reached up slowly, her fingers brushing the side of her neck where her skin still tingled. Her fingertips met the mark — warm, sensitive, unmistakable. A flush bloomed under her skin as reality hit her like a crashing wave.

 

“Oh my God,” she whispered, stumbling to the mirror on the far wall of her office. “That bitch!”

 

Under the harsh overhead lights, the evidence was impossible to ignore: a red, blooming mark just above her collarbone, stark against her pale skin. She stared at it, wide-eyed, her heart galloping in her chest.

 

“I have class. I have a room full of undergrads in ten minutes—” Her voice spiraled as she paced. “I kissed Death. I let her bite me. I let her mark me. What the hell is wrong with me?”

 

The door creaked open again.

 

“Hey, I brought you the notes for — oh.”

 

Lilia.

 

She stepped inside with a cup of tea in one hand and a file in the other, then paused, blinking once, then twice, her eyes landing right where Agatha’s hand hovered near her neck.

 

A slow grin spread across her face. “Well, well,” she said, shutting the door with her foot. “Looks like somebody had an... extracurricular activity over lunch.”

 

Agatha whipped around, mortified. “Don’t start.”

 

“Oh, sweetie. I don’t have to start anything. That mark’s already giving a whole TED Talk.”

 

“Lilia, I’m serious!” Agatha barked, her voice cracking slightly. “This isn’t funny! I—I just lost my husband. He’s still missing, and I’m walking around with a mark from someone else on my neck! I can’t—” She broke off, her hands fluttering uselessly as panic took over. “What if someone sees? What are the students going to think? What if the faculty—?”

 

Lilia’s smile softened, her teasing expression falling away as she crossed the room. “Okay, okay,” she said gently, setting the tea aside and placing both hands on Agatha’s arms. “Breathe. Deep breath in, hold, and out, honey. Come on. You’re going to pass out if you keep spinning like this.”

 

Agatha did as she was told, her chest heaving as she fought to calm herself. Lilia tilted her head to get a better look at the mark and clucked her tongue.

 

“Alright. Let’s get you some concealer before someone decides your ‘ghost girlfriend’ is tattooing hickeys on you.”

 

Agatha groaned, dragging a hand down her face. “It’s not a hickey.”

 

“Honey,” Lilia said, pulling a compact from her oversized purse, “It’s exactly a hickey. And you didn't deny the ‘ghost girlfriend’ either.”

 

Agatha sank into the chair beside her desk while Lilia crouched in front of her, dabbing expertly at the mark with a practiced hand. The makeup was cool against her skin, the scent of Lilia’s citrus-scented lotion grounding her slightly.

 

Lilia glanced up with a mischievous smile. “So… was it the tall, dark, and terrifying Death you’ve been seeing or the one who is ‘in love with you’?”

 

Agatha didn’t answer at first. Her lips parted slightly, eyes flickering with guilt and something she hated admitting to herself, something dangerously close to joy.

 

“Yes,” she said finally, barely above a whisper.

 

Lilia leaned back, cocking a brow. “Well. Doesn’t seem like she’s all that dead to me.”

 

Lilia wasn't specific. Something in her tone seemed to connect the dots. Agatha decided not to question it for now. It would raise too many questions, questions she didn't have the head or time to answer. 

 

Agatha shot her a dry look. “It’s not funny, Lilia.”

 

“It’s a little funny.”

 

Agatha sighed, rubbing her temples. “She just… gets under my skin. She says things, and I know I should tell her to leave, but she doesn’t listen. And then... she’s kind to the kids. And she makes me laugh. And she defends me. And then I’m kissing her in my room, my office, like a damn teenager.”

 

Lilia stood and smoothed Agatha’s collar gently over the now-concealed mark, her touch light. “That sounds like someone you care about. You look... lighter when you talk about her. Happier.”

 

Agatha frowned. “I’m not supposed to be happy. Not right now.”

 

“That’s not how grief works, Agatha, my child.” Lilia smiled softly. “It comes in waves. So does healing. Sometimes they crash into each other, and sometimes they give you a little room to breathe.”

 

Agatha stared at her reflection in the mirror, at the carefully hidden mark, the faint pink still warming her cheeks, the quiet tremble in her hands. She didn’t know what to do with any of it.

 

"How does she make you feel? Be honest, Agatha." Lilia asked, looking into Agatha's blue eyes.

 

Agatha's eyes filled with tears as a phrase, a memory came into her head:

 

"Then why do I feel so alive beside you?”

 

“She makes me feel... alive. I feel alive next to her." Agatha bit the inside of her cheek to swallow a tear. Her throat was tight, red, sore. "Death's kiss brings me life, Lilia... That shouldn't happen, should it?”

 

“Uhm... Well, Death's kiss and The Kiss of Death have a big difference, Agatha. You don't kiss her expecting to surrender to Death, you kiss her expecting to surrender to that feeling. The feeling that she, her soul gives you. This feeling, Agatha, has a simple name. And you already know what it is, don't you?

 

Agatha swallowed hard and looked away. Yes, she knew. She knew what it was about. But she wouldn't accept it, couldn't accept it. 

 

“Love”

 

Rio couldn't be right about this madness from another life. What was so bad that happened in that other life for Rio to come to her in this life? And why after another life did she still feel this way about none other than Death herself?

 

No, she didn't believe it. If she didn't say it out loud, it wouldn't be real. 

 

“Love. It is not love.”

Chapter 7: Chapter 7

Chapter Notes

Sesbian Lex

See the end of the chapter for more notes

The past month had stretched like silk over wire — soft in some places, taut in others. Agatha moved through her days as though rehearsing a life that wasn’t entirely hers, and yet, somehow, it had begun to fit. Morning routines bled together: the warm scent of fresh toast in the air, the scuffle of Nick’s socks sliding over wooden floors, the groan of Nicole's teenage moods behind slammed doors. And then, always, Rio, silent and smirking in the doorway, a mug of untouched coffee cradled in her hands, her gaze heavy with meaning that never needed words.

Rio had woven herself into the rhythm of the house without resistance, like ink blooming in water — impossible to undo, and strangely beautiful. She moved barefoot through the kitchen, humming tunes from centuries past. She left fresh, fragrant flowers on Agatha’s nightstand each morning, their scent clinging to the sheets long after Rio had slipped away. She sat cross-legged on the floor helping Nick untangle puberty and first heartbreaks, as if she’d ever been human enough to live through them. She played basketball with the kids in the yard, her laughter echoing under dusk light, and when Agatha curled up with cramps and exhaustion, Rio didn’t ask — she simply pressed a heating pad to her stomach, rubbed her back with strong, steady hands, and whispered, “Breathe, baby. Just breathe.”

 

It was terrifying how right it felt.

 

There was a softness blooming in the spaces Rio touched — domestic, easy, real — and Agatha hated how much she welcomed it. She’d stopped questioning the surreal normalcy of having Death lounging on her couch. The boundaries blurred faster than she could rebuild them. One day Rio was the shadow at her back. The next, she was folding Nicky’s laundry and fixing a cabinet door that hadn’t closed properly in years. It was unsettling. Perfect. Unnatural. And somehow, exactly what they needed.

 

But despite it all, Agatha couldn't find rest.

 

While Rio lay sprawled across the couch, reading one of her grimoires upside-down — of course — and the kids dozed in front of a flickering cartoon, Agatha sat hunched at the kitchen table, candlelight painting her skin in shades of bronze and fatigue. The air was thick with wax and ink. Her fingers, stained from hours of scribbling, clenched her pen too tight. Her eyes flicked toward the tangled mess of a board she’d created on the wall — maps pinned at odd angles, red string stretching between blurry photographs of Ralph, half-buried police reports, and symbols she didn’t recognize but somehow felt.

 

Nothing fit. Nothing answered the hollow in her chest or quieted the hum beneath her skin. The leads had frozen. Her memories were like fogged glass — she could feel the shapes behind them, the weight of something she was meant to remember. But when she reached, there was only silence. Even Ralph’s voice had faded from her mind, hollow and distant, like a dream that never really belonged to her.

 

The pen trembled in her hand. Agatha closed her eyes.

 

She didn’t trust this stillness. Not the quiet house, not the scent of pine and night that lingered in the doorway, not the woman made of shadow and stars curled comfortably on her couch like she belonged. Because maybe she did. And maybe that was the most dangerous thing of all.

 

“Staring at that wall won’t bring him back,” Rio said, not bothering to look up from her book. Her voice was that familiar blend of velvet and blade — soothing to the ear, but every syllable pricked. It slid under Agatha’s skin like silk over a wound.

 

Agatha didn’t respond. Her eyes remained fixed on the wall of files and strings, her spine rigid, fingers digging into the arms of the chair. She could feel Rio’s words curling around her like smoke, intentionally low, intentionally provoking. She refused to meet her gaze. Nicole had already teased her enough that morning — little smirks and knowing looks about how Rio seemed to orbit around her mother like a woman who had already claimed the house and everyone in it. She would not give either of them the satisfaction.

 

Behind her, the leather of the couch shifted as Rio sighed and placed the book aside. The rustle of pages was followed by the slow stretch of limbs, long and unhurried, the kind of movement that belonged to someone completely unbothered by time. Rio arched her back like a cat, her ribs rising with a deep breath that pulled her shirt up just enough to show a sliver of tattooed skin along her hip. Agatha saw it from the corner of her eye — and hated the way her throat tightened.

 

“You haven’t slept properly in a week, sweetheart.” Rio’s voice grew softer, almost concerned — but still laced with heat. “Your energy is starting to taste... burnt.”

 

Agatha turned her head slowly, the muscles in her neck tight from holding tension. Her eyes locked onto Rio, hard. “I would be sleeping if you were actually talking about what you know about all this. He is the father of my children!” Her voice cracked at the end, sharper than she meant, betraying her exhaustion.

 

Rio didn’t blink. She stepped forward, her expression unreadable. “No. He’s not.” Her words were quiet, but they hit like thunder. “And you know that.”

 

The room thickened. Something dangerous coiled beneath Rio’s skin, quiet and patient and utterly untouchable. The dim lighting deepened the shadows around her eyes, made the lines of her jaw sharper, her gaze more animal than human.

 

Agatha stood halfway, jaw clenched, eyes burning. “Then tell me something, Rio. Where is he?”

 

Rio moved.

 

She rose with that impossible grace — bare feet silent on the hardwood, every motion intentional, practiced, powerful. She circled the room slowly, the way a predator might test the edge of a trap it didn’t fear. Her fingers dragged along the edge of Agatha’s desk, grazing parchment and wood like they were hers to touch. Her nails, black and chipped, whispered across the pages like ink itself. The scent of her wrapped around Agatha in waves: smoke, jasmine, earth after lightning. It made her chest tighten.

 

“I’m not the one who answers that question, Agatha,” she murmured, stopping just behind her. Her voice brushed against the shell of Agatha’s ear, so low it vibrated through her bones. “All you have to do is remember.”

 

Agatha’s breath hitched in her throat. Her hands trembled slightly against the edge of the table. “I don’t want to remember,” she rasped. “I’m tired!”

 

“You want to,” Rio whispered, “and you will. Because it’s already unraveling. You feel it. When I touch you. When I say your name.” She dragged the syllables of it out like worship. “It hums under your skin.”

 

“Stop it,” Agatha said, but it came out breathless. Weak. Her hands clenched the desk like an anchor. “You don’t know what I feel.”

 

Rio’s smile — when it came — was slow, deliberate, dangerous. She stepped closer still, until her lips grazed the skin just beneath Agatha’s jaw. A shiver erupted down Agatha’s spine. Rio didn’t kiss her — just exhaled there, warm whiskey and mint spilling across sensitive skin.

 

Agatha nearly dropped her glass. Her body surged forward in instinct, her eyes fluttering shut. A soft gasp escaped her lips — too honest, too telling.

 

Rio pulled back, not out of mercy, but because she wanted to see the damage. “Oh, I do,” she said darkly. “And soon, you’ll admit it.”

 

Agatha stood frozen, every nerve frayed, every cell screaming. She hated this. She hated her. She hated how much she wanted her.

Then Rio’s voice turned to something harder, colder.

 

“You want answers?” she said, circling back to the front of her. “You’re looking in the wrong places, Professor. Ralph’s disappearance isn’t the beginning of your story. It’s the consequence of your hiding.” Agatha opened her mouth to ask what the hell that meant, but Rio was already walking away, the hem of her loose shirt whispering along her thighs. “Now, go to bed,” she called over her shoulder. “Or don’t. But either way... stop trying to bury what already clawed its way to the surface.”

 

Agatha stared after her, the ache in her chest matched only by the buzzing in her fingertips.

The soft flicker of the television bathed the room in warm, golden hues, casting dancing shadows across the walls. The animated ballroom scene glowed on screen, but the real magic sat right in the living room — Rio, her body relaxed but her presence always electric, gently threading her fingers through Nick’s dark curls as he dozed, his head nestled on her lap. Nicole lay curled on the other side of the couch, her face half-buried in a pillow, pretending not to watch but quietly mouthing the lyrics to “Tale as Old as Time.”

Agatha, however, was anything but calm. The wine had dulled her nerves only slightly. Her fingers were stained with ink, nails chipped, her pajama top slipping off one shoulder as she sat cross-legged in the center of an organized chaos of old leather-bound volumes. Pages filled with elegant script were scattered around her like relics, and she hunched over her open journal, writing in bursts, as if her thoughts might vanish if she didn’t capture them fast enough. Candlelight flickered beside her, illuminating the furrow of her brow and the determined tightness in her jaw.

 

Then came the knock. Three short, clipped taps, too polite to be casual, too familiar to be friendly.

Agatha froze mid-sentence, her pen hovering in the air. Her breath caught in her throat. Cold dread slid down her spine like ice water.

 

Nick stirred slightly, mumbling something against Rio’s leg.

 

Nicole lifted her head. “That better not be the cops again.”

 

“It is,” Agatha muttered, setting her pen down. Her hand reached blindly for the wine glass, but it was empty.

 

“I’ll get it, my love,” Rio purred, rising with feline grace from the couch, gently lowering Nick’s head to a throw pillow without disturbing him. She smoothed the blanket over him and cast a glance at Nicole that was both reassuring and commanding. “Keep your brother calm.”

 

Nicole narrowed her eyes. “Don’t start anything.”

 

Rio gave her a wink, then turned to Agatha, who had already started to rise. “Rio—” Agatha began, her voice low and tight.

 

But Rio was already moving, barefoot across the hardwood floor, the hem of her loose shirt brushing her thighs, posture relaxed but coiled with power. She glanced back once, her voice laced with something warmer than teasing this time. “Relax. I’ll play nice.”

 

Agatha pressed her knuckles against her lips, watching the sway of Rio’s hips as she disappeared toward the entryway. Her heart was pounding, not with fear, but with that familiar dread that came every time the door knocked. Every time the past tried to creep back in.

From the front hallway, the low murmur of voices began. A male voice, firm, measured, was met with Rio’s velvet tone, smooth and unsettling. Agatha couldn’t hear the words, but she could feel the shift in the air: something electric, something sharp.

 

She closed her eyes, exhaling through her nose, whispering under her breath, “Please don’t provoke them…” But she already knew that was asking the moon not to pull the tides.

 

The moment Agatha saw Daniel’s silhouette at the door, something cold settled in her stomach. It was always him — always the same unreadable expression, always the same stiff stance like he didn’t quite believe her, like he was waiting for her to slip. And now he was looking at Rio with that same edge of polite condescension he wore like a badge.

 

“Good evening,” Daniel began, but his voice lacked any warmth. His eyes flicked down to the way Rio leaned against the frame, bare feet on the tile, arms crossed loosely, a smirk tugging at her mouth like she was playing with him. It made him visibly uncomfortable. “We’re here to speak with Mrs. Harkness.”

 

“And you’re speaking with me,” Rio purred, her tone smooth as velvet, but there was a current under it, something slow-burning, like a lit fuse.

 

Daniel’s jaw twitched slightly. “Mrs. Vidal, is it?” He flipped a page in his notebook, pen tapping the edge. “Are you her... legal counsel or something?”

 

Rio tilted her head, eyes dark and unreadable. “Or something,” she murmured, lifting a single brow. “But don’t worry, Officer. Whatever you need, I can handle it.”

 

That one sentence sent a ripple down Agatha’s spine from across the room, her breath catching before she even knew why. Rio had said it lightly, but she knew that tone. It was a warning wrapped in silk.

 

Daniel, however, wasn’t amused. “We need to speak with Mrs. Harkness directly,” he said, this time with steel beneath his civility.

 

“Of course you do,” Rio said, voice syrupy sweet as she stepped aside with a mockingly graceful gesture. “She’s right in the living room. Don’t let the candlelight intimidate you.”

 

The officers stepped past her, but not before Daniel gave Rio one last glance, a mix of distrust and irritation. Agatha rose from the floor slowly, her joints stiff from sitting too long, her mind trying to click into something sharper than panic.

 

She brushed her hair out of her face, tucked it behind her ear, and offered them a polite, tight-lipped smile. “Officers,” she said evenly, her voice smooth but taut like a bowstring. “What can I do for you this time?”

 

“We’re following up on Ralph’s case,” Daniel replied, his partner nodding like a silent echo behind him. “It’s been seven months. We’re reviewing all aspects of the investigation.”

 

The word “seven” hit harder than Agatha expected, a pressure that bloomed behind her ribs. Seven months of silence. Of stares. Of waiting.

 

Her arms crossed automatically, her fingers digging slightly into the sleeves of her cardigan. “And that requires asking the same questions over and over again?”

 

Daniel didn’t flinch. “We just want to ensure we haven’t missed anything.” His gaze shifted downward to the scattered books: the cracked leather bindings, the curling parchment pages covered in Latin, symbols, and underlined passages. “You’ve been doing some... reading?”

 

Agatha’s jaw tightened. “Just research. Nothing relevant to Ralph. I'm a historian and a teacher.”

 

She hated how defensive it sounded. As if she had something to hide. As if the books weren’t her last desperate attempt to make sense of the woman lounging now behind the officers, arms crossed, watching everything like a panther ready to pounce.

 

Rio let out a soft chuckle, and though it was barely audible, it dripped with amusement. “I’m sure your time is better spent chasing actual leads, Officer,” she said without looking up, her voice a weapon dressed in silk gloves.

 

Daniel’s eyes flicked to her for half a second but returned to Agatha like she hadn’t spoken at all. “Have you remembered anything new? Anything unusual about Ralph’s behavior before he disappeared?”

 

Agatha took a slow, measured breath, the scent of wine and candlewax lingering in her nose. She could feel the warmth of the fire at her back, and the weight of Rio’s stare like a palm pressed to her lower spine.

 

“No,” she said flatly. “And I’ve told you everything I know. Repeatedly.” Her voice cracked slightly at the end, but it was still sharp. Controlled. Barely.

 

Rio stepped forward just enough to make her presence known again, not touching Agatha, but close enough to cast her shadow beside her. “She’s not hiding anything, Officer. But I have to say, your fixation is starting to look more like harassment.”

 

Daniel’s eyes narrowed, his lips twitching toward something like a warning, but he kept his tone even. “We’re doing our job, Mrs. Vidal.”

 

The tension in the room shifted the air like pressure before a storm. Agatha’s arms remained locked across her chest, her nails digging into her sleeves. She felt caged between the weight of protocol and the raw protectiveness clawing in her chest. Her breathing was shallow, lips pressed in a thin line, but her gaze was unwavering as she looked at the officers.

 

Daniel’s voice broke the silence, deceptively calm. “Mrs. Harkness,” he said carefully, like each word had been weighed, “we’d like to speak with your children before we leave.”

 

Agatha’s posture changed immediately, spine snapping straighter, her chin tilting slightly as though daring him to repeat himself. Her fingers twitched against her biceps, the only crack in her otherwise statuesque control.

 

“Why?” she asked, her voice low, almost too quiet, dangerous in its restraint.

 

Daniel’s partner stepped forward, his voice smoother, trying to diffuse. “Sometimes children notice things adults might not. Even something small, someone at the door, a sound, a car. We just want to talk.”

 

Before Agatha could gather a response, Rio’s presence surged forward like a silent wave crashing into the conversation. Her bare feet padded across the floor with feline grace, and when she stopped beside Agatha, her eyes bore into the officers with something fierce, something ancient.

 

“No,” she said, the word slicing the air like a blade. “Absolutely not.”

 

Daniel blinked, his brow furrowing. “Excuse me?”

 

“You’re not dragging my kids into this,” Rio snapped, stepping slightly in front of Agatha. Her body was relaxed, but her stance was protective, possessive. “They don’t know anything, and even if they did, they’re not your fucking leverage.”

 

The smirk that Daniel usually wore was gone. He exchanged a glance with his partner, both men suddenly more cautious. “We’re not accusing them of anything, ma’am. Just routine.”

 

Rio’s mouth curled in disdain. “Don’t ‘ma’am’ me. I’ve seen what your ‘routine’ looks like. You want a confession from a child to justify your stagnation. Not today.”

 

“Rio, honey,” Agatha said, her voice quiet but firm. She laid a hand on Rio’s forearm, fingers curling lightly, grounding her. “Let them ask. If either of the kids feels uncomfortable, I’ll end it. Right then.”

 

The fire in Rio’s eyes flickered as she looked down at the hand on her arm. Agatha’s touch was always soft, too soft, and it disarmed her in ways nothing else could. Still, she didn’t move, didn’t pull away. Her jaw clenched, lips parting to argue, then sealing again as she studied Agatha’s face.

 

“You’re sure?” Rio asked, voice low, almost growled. Her fingers brushed briefly against Agatha’s wrist like she was reading her pulse.

 

Agatha nodded. “I’m sure.”

 

Rio stepped back slowly, the gesture deliberate. She didn’t remove her gaze from the officers, didn’t soften. “Fine,” she said finally. “But I’ll be listening. And if I think for a second you’re pushing them, this stops.”

 

Daniel nodded once, professionally. “Understood.”

 

“Good,” Rio murmured, her arms folding again across her chest, her body now a silent wall between them and the hallway.

 

As Agatha turned to call for the children, she felt Rio’s presence still close — tension in the air, in the heat rolling off her skin. And as much as it unnerved her, it also steadied her.

The weight of the room seemed to shift as Nicole and Nick stepped closer, their sock-covered feet making no sound against the floorboards. The muted glow of the television flickered across their faces, casting soft shadows that made them look even smaller, even more guarded. Nick’s little hand remained knotted in Nicole’s sleeve, his thumb brushing the fabric like it gave him courage. Nicole’s jaw was set tight, her chin lifted defiantly despite the unease in her eyes.

 

Agatha’s voice was gentle, but behind it trembled a mother’s dread. “These officers have a few questions about your dad,” she said, her tone carefully measured. “You don’t have to answer if you don’t want to, but it might help.”

 

The children exchanged a glance. Nick’s brows knit together, his small mouth pressing into a line before he finally gave a reluctant nod. Nicole didn’t move, but her stance shifted forward slightly — like a shield.

Daniel knelt on the rug in the living room, lowering himself to the children’s level with a gentle smile. His badge glinted faintly in the late afternoon light pouring through the blinds. His voice was warm, not overly sweet, but inviting — like a teacher who knew how to reach even the shyest student.

 

“Hi, Nicole. Nick,” he said softly. “I know this is all a little weird, but I just wanted to ask if either of you noticed anything unusual before your dad left. Anything you remember. It can be small.”

 

Nicole sat slouched on the arm of the couch, arms crossed, her face unreadable. Nick perched beside her, shoulders hunched, eyes on the floor. Nick spoke first, voice quiet but steady. “He wasn’t a good dad.”

 

The words made Agatha’s stomach tighten. She didn’t interrupt — she couldn’t. Her eyes flicked between her children, but mostly, they lingered on Nick’s small hands twisting in his lap.

 

“He always came home late,” the boy continued. “He didn’t go to school events or help with homework. He forgot my birthday one time. He never remembered wedding anniversaries, it made Mom sad.”

 

Agatha’s heart ached, but she said nothing.

 

Daniel tilted his head slightly, staying kind. “That sounds really hard, buddy. Did anything feel different before he disappeared?”

 

Nick nodded slowly. “Yeah. He was acting weird. Like… more than usual. He kept muttering stuff. Said he was trapped. That he didn’t want to be in another spell again.”

 

Daniel frowned. “Spell?”

 

Nick shrugged. “That’s what he said. Said he was stuck. That he needed to get out. That someone was watching him.”

 

A shadow passed over Rio’s face where she stood behind the children. Agatha’s eyes caught the change — her stance straightening, head tilted ever so slightly. Her lips were pressed in a line, the amber in her eyes dimming to a mossy, unnatural green. Her attention wasn’t on the children anymore. It was fixed — sharp and calculating — on Daniel.

 

Agatha swallowed. “What is she doing…?”

 

Nick went on, oblivious. “He met with a woman. She always wore red. Blood red. He said she was like a therapist. But he only saw her at night.”

 

Nicole scoffed. “More like the slut he was screwing. He thought we didn’t notice.”

 

“Nicole! Language!” Agatha warned.

 

Daniel shifted his weight, noting that down quietly. “Did he ever say her name?”

 

Nick shook his head. “No. He just said she helped him ‘see clearly.’ Said Mom made him sick. But he never said why.”

 

Agatha flinched. It felt like the floor was slipping beneath her feet.

 

“She was a jerk.”, Nicky said angrily.

 

“He stopped letting us call him Dad,” Nick added softly. “When we were alone. Said it didn’t feel right.”

 

“Right how?” Daniel echoed.

 

Nick nodded. “Like he wasn’t supposed to be here. Like someone had put him in the wrong place.”

 

Nicole finally spoke again, her voice flat and cold. “He didn’t matter. Not to me. Not to Nicky either. Not to mom.”

 

Daniel looked up. “What do you mean, Nicole?”

 

She didn’t answer. Just glanced briefly — deliberately — toward Rio. And Rio… smiled. Not warm. Not cold. Just knowing.

Agatha’s heart twisted. She was torn between watching her children open wounds she hadn’t realized were still bleeding… and watching the eerie stillness blooming in Rio. Her body so still it didn’t even seem to breathe. Shadows clung to her cheekbones like fingers. Her pupils dilated, almost fully black, and that green in her irises shimmered like moss on wet stone. Not human. Not hiding.

 

“For him it was all about the chains.” Nick said.

 

“What chains?” Daniel asked gently.

 

Nick blinked. “I don’t know. He didn’t say. But… after that, Mom got really sick. And then he left.”

 

His face softened, but he didn’t cry. Just looked up with a sadness far too grown for his age.

“Nick, brush your teeth properly this time,” she said, her voice low and pointed, stern enough to suggest authority, but not enough to stop him from humming through the bubbles.

“Can you two stop flirting?” she asked flatly, glancing between them with theatrical disgust. “It’s weird. And disgusting.”

“We are,” Rio said at the exact same time, her tone smooth and completely unapologetic, her eyes never leaving Agatha’s. "And you should be happy, little demon, that means you moms love each other."

 

"I do not-"

 

Nicole snorted. “Whatever. Just keep it down. I’m trying to sleep and you’re embarrassing.”

“And what a life it is, darling,” she murmured, her voice low and velvety, hand grazing lightly along Agatha’s back as she passed behind her. “Tragic, chaotic... delicious.”

“Go put him to bed,” Agatha finally muttered, half under her breath.

 

Rio tossed a grin over her shoulder. “Only if you’re next.”

 

Agatha didn’t respond. She just stood in the hallway, heart thudding a little too hard for her own comfort, biting the inside of her cheek to fight the smile that was already rising, unwanted but undeniable.

The dim light from the hallway poured in behind her, casting a long shadow across the wooden floor. Her body ached. Every muscle begged for rest. She tugged the tie from her hair, letting it fall messily around her face as she moved toward the bed.

And then she froze. A familiar weight shifted on the mattress behind her.

 

“Why are you still here?” she asked, her voice sharp, but laced with exhaustion rather than surprise.

 

Rio lay sprawled across the bed like she owned it, limbs stretched, one foot hanging off the edge, her tousled hair a halo of rebellion against Agatha’s otherwise structured world. Her dark eyes glinted in the low light.

 

“Where else would I be?” she said lazily. “The couch? Dreadful upholstery. I like it here. I like watching you unravel. It's... delicious.”

"You don't die" Agatha yanked open a drawer and pulled out her pajamas with more force than necessary. “And I don’t have the energy for your theatrics tonight.”

 

“You’d have more energy,” Rio said, sitting up fully, her legs folded beneath her, “if you let go of that tight little leash you keep on yourself. All this brooding, this... control… it’s exhausting, but sometimes fun, just watching you.”

 

Agatha turned on her heel, eyes flashing, her fingers clenching around the fabric in her hands. “Fun? You think today was fun? The cops sniffing around again, the kids talking about how useless their dad is, me finding out he was cheating on me with a whore?! Was that funny?

 

Rio tilted her head, one brow raised as she stood from the bed. Her voice dipped into something sultrier, lower. “No,” she said. “But watching you flustered? That was fun.”

 

“Rio,” Agatha warned, her tone clipped. Her skin prickled with awareness as Rio crossed the room with lazy, predatory grace — bare feet silent on the wood, the scent of pine, rain, and dark earth trailing in her wake.

 

“What?” Rio murmured, stepping into Agatha’s space. “You’re cute when you’re mad. And irresistible when you’re trying not to be.”

 

Agatha swallowed, her throat tight, every nerve in her body suddenly hyperaware of the closeness, the heat, the magnetic pull that made her knees feel unreliable. She stepped back — just a little — but Rio followed, slow and deliberate.

 

“You could just admit you like having me around,” Rio said softly, brushing an imaginary strand of hair from Agatha’s shoulder with a feather-light touch. “Wouldn’t kill you.”

 

Agatha’s cheeks were already flushed, her breathing uneven. “I like having you around as much as I like migraines,” she muttered, voice thick.

 

Rio hummed, amused. “You didn’t seem to hate me earlier,” she whispered, dipping her head just enough that her lips hovered by Agatha’s ear, breath warm against her skin. “When you melted into me. When I kissed your neck like it belonged to me.”

 

Agatha stiffened, the heat in her belly flaring, but she masked it with a glare. “That was a mistake.”

 

Rio’s smirk didn’t falter. “Mistakes aren’t usually so... repeated. Are you still counting?”

 

“You’re pushing it,” Agatha growled, backing toward the dresser until her spine met wood.

Her other hand rose — slowly, teasingly — to catch a lock of Agatha’s hair between her fingers. She twisted it gently, tugging just enough to tilt Agatha’s head and bare her throat. Then she leaned in, lips brushing just beneath Agatha’s ear before trailing lower, letting the heat of her mouth hover over the delicate curve of Agatha’s neck.

 

“I want to mark you again,” she whispered, her breath like sin. “But not out of punishment this time. Out of promise. All your body now.”

 

Agatha’s lips parted in a silent gasp, her eyes fluttering shut for the briefest second.

Then she felt it — Rio’s mouth, soft and deliberate, kissing the hollow of her throat. A slow, languid suck of skin that sent a ripple down Agatha’s spine, hot and possessive. Her breath caught. The sensation was maddening — a blend of heat and ownership that left her trembling. Her fingers dug into the dresser behind her, nails scraping against the wood as her knees threatened to give out. The sting was subtle but deliberate, and when Rio pulled away, licking the mark like a signature, Agatha gasped.

Rio stepped back just enough to let her gaze linger on the fresh bloom of red beginning to form. The curve of her mouth turned up into a slow, satisfied smile.

 

"You'll feel that every time you move tomorrow, every time you see yourself in a mirror." she murmured with a wink, her voice dripping with satisfaction.

 

Agatha's hand flew to her neck, her fingers brushing the still-warm spot. "Rio!" she hissed, her voice shaking with a mix of fury and something far more dangerous. “Seriously! Are you twelve? A fucking bat?”

 

Her heart pounded wildly in her chest, breath hitching as Rio leaned in again — closer now. Close enough that Agatha could feel the warm exhale of her breath on her lips. That wild scent of pine and rain, smoke and spice, curled into her nose, grounding her and setting her ablaze all at once.

Agatha’s eyes flickered shut for a second. Her body screamed at her to move, to step away, but she stayed rooted in place. Frozen. Waiting.

 

"Tell me to stop," Rio whispered. Her voice was a husky breath, barely audible, her lips hovering just inches away. “I'll be good  for you and stop if you say so.”

 

Agatha didn’t answer. Couldn’t. Rio searched her eyes, something raw and serious flickering beneath the mischief. She didn’t move. She didn’t push. She waited.

 

"Just say the magic words, my love," Rio whispered, her voice now softer, almost reverent.

 

The words sank deep into Agatha’s chest, wrapping around her ribs and pulling tight. She could feel the heat coiling low in her belly, the ache building with every second of that charged silence. She wanted to scream. She wanted to give in. She wanted to be touched again, to be ruined and rebuilt by the very creature she’d been resisting for weeks. But she couldn’t speak. She couldn’t find the words. Rio didn’t push. She stayed. Perfectly still. Eyes locked on hers. A quiet storm, waiting for permission.

Agatha’s fists clenched at her sides, her whole body tight with restraint. Her throat worked as she tried to speak, to form the one word she wasn’t sure she meant.

 

Instead, a breath escaped — ragged, helpless.

 

Rio's gaze softened. Her smirk melted into something quieter. Something close to love. "Take your time," she whispered. "I'm not going anywhere."

 

And she didn’t.  She waited, patient and still, until Agatha whispered, almost brokenly, "Fuck you!." Then she moved.

Agatha clung to Rio like she was afraid she’d disappear. Rio groaned softly against her lips, pressing back with just as much hunger, her hands sliding over Agatha’s waist, gripping her tight. Marking the skin with the squeeze she gave, eliciting a tearful moan from Agatha. 

Their bodies met like puzzle pieces snapping into place — the heat between them instant and blinding. Agatha tilted her head, deepening the kiss, and Rio followed eagerly, her mouth hot and possessive, her kiss aching with all the things she hadn’t said. Agatha felt her chest rise and fall, her heart threatening to punch through her ribs. Her skin buzzed with sensation. Rio tasted like wild honey and thunder.

Rio pulled Agatha's hips against her, placing a thigh between Agatha's legs just to tease her and when she tried to rub herself, Rio just pull her knee away. Only to repeat it again.

Rio's eyes shone with something primal. Something ancient. "That," she whispered, her voice hoarse, "was fucking worth the wait. So worthy... every millennia."

 

Agatha laughed, breathless and shaky. "You’re a devil."

 

Rio smiled, brushing a strand of hair behind Agatha's ear. Her fingers lingered. "No, my love. I made the devil myself."

 

Agatha’s breath hitched as Rio’s lips met hers again, slower this time — so deliberate, it felt like a question and a promise all at once. The fire hadn’t dimmed, but it had shifted into something molten, deeper. Rio’s mouth moved over Agatha’s with reverence now, not hunger. As though she were rediscovering a temple long abandoned.

Rio’s hands didn’t roam. They stayed anchored — one resting lightly on the curve of Agatha’s waist, the other sliding up her back with aching patience, fingertips grazing the slope of her spine. She wasn’t pulling Agatha closer anymore. She was holding her there, steady and still, like she might disappear if she let go too fast.

Agatha felt her knees give slightly, her hands bunching in the soft fabric of Rio’s shirt. Her chest rose and fell against Rio’s with every uneven breath. Her body trembled — not from fear, but from the overwhelming intimacy of it. There was no performance in this touch. No teasing. Just Rio.

"Slow," she murmured, eyes half-lidded and dark with heat. "I want to feel you. All of you. After everything... after how long it’s been."

“Making me stop thinking”

"Still with me, amor?" she asked, voice like velvet, with the faintest edge of dominance threading through it.

"Good girl," Rio whispered, her lips brushing the shell of Agatha's ear. Her hands cradled her gently, reverently, like holding something both powerful and breakable. “My good Agatha.”

"I remember this," Rio murmured into the hollow beneath her collarbone. "You always made me beg first. You were a crazy control freak."

The fabric was soft between her fingers, but not as soft as Agatha’s skin beneath it. Her movements slowed, reverent, deliberate — as though she were touching something sacred. As Nicole busied herself making tea, her quiet movements grounding the moment, Agatha began to speak, her voice trembling.

 

“I was giving birth,” she started, her fingers clutching the edge of the counter. “Leaning against a tree, terrified, in so much pain, and... alone. Completely alone.”

 

Nicole paused, listening intently but letting her mother continue.

 

“And then I saw her,” Agatha said, her throat tightening. “Rio. She was standing in the distance, holding a flower in her hand. I remember feeling so much fear, so much anger. Agatha shook her head, her hands trembling slightly as she held the mug. “She didn’t give me a chance. She left before I could. And, Nicky... I’ve never seen her like that before. She was—” Her voice broke. “She was desperate.”

 

Nicole tilted her head, a small, knowing smile playing on her lips. “You have seen her like that before, Mom. You just don’t remember yet.”

 

Agatha blinked at her, confused. “What do you mean? How do you know about all of this?”

 

Nicole leaned back in her chair, her expression calm. “She told just enough” she said simply. “She used to tell me stories when I was still inside you.”

 

Agatha let out a shaky laugh, disbelief flickering in her eyes. “She told you stories? Inside me? Really?”

 

Nicole nodded seriously, her tone unwavering. “She’s a great storyteller. And, for the record, she’s a good mom too.”

 

Agatha’s throat tightened as she looked down at her tea, her face flushing. “She’s not—”

 

“She is,” Nicole interrupted gently, smiling softly. “She’s a good mom. And she’s a good wife, too.”

 

Agatha’s face turned crimson as she averted her gaze. “Nicole, stop.”

 

Nicole chuckled, taking another sip of her tea. “Don’t worry, Mom. She’ll come back. She always does. Like she loves to remind you, she’s stuck with you.”

 

"She's hiding things from me, Nicky... Did you see the way she looked at that police officer today?"

 

"She has her reasons, Mom. She was protecting us." Nicky touched his mother's hand, trying to calm her down.

 

"Do you know what she is, Nicole?"

 

Nicole paused, looking straight to her mother eyes and Agatha could swear that her eyes changed. "Do you?"
