Chapter 8: Chapter 8

Chapter Notes

🔞
This chapter has a little explanation about Ralph's disappearance but not completely yet.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Rio didn't know how much time had passed for Agatha since she'd fled.

The memory — that damn memory — gnawed at her, hollowing out a space inside her chest that even her cosmic power couldn't fill. It hurt. It burned. And worst of all, it scared her.

Goddamn it, she thought bitterly. She was Death. She was the fucking Death. A cosmic entity, omnipresent, omniscient, unstoppable. No creature, no god, no time-worn king could escape her. And yet here she was — curled in the corner of her own house in the Death Realm — feeling small. Feeling cold. Feeling something that tasted dangerously close to grief.

Her nails were bitten to the quick, chewed away in her endless cycle of self-recrimination. They had already grown back — small obsidian points — but still she sat there, unmoving, staring into nothing.

Tiny black flowers had bloomed beneath her bare feet, curling through the warped floorboards, fed by her spiraling emotions. The scent of them was rich, almost sweet, cloying in the still, damp air. Outside, the wind howled against the rickety walls of the little cabin, rattling the windows so fiercely they sounded like sobs.

It had been so long since she'd come back here, her own home felt alien. Like a haunted house abandoned by time.

 

And Rio hated haunted houses. They reminded her of ghosts — and there was nothing in existence she despised more than ghosts. Ghosts meant regrets. Ghosts meant unfinished business. 

 

And she had so, so many.

 

The Death Realm itself, usually a lush, eerie paradise of overgrown vines and ageless creatures, now looked sickly.

 

The green-black mist hung heavier than normal. The plants drooped, shriveled, pressing against the broken glass. Even the creatures lurking outside — things from ancient worlds, prehistoric beasts, spirits too stubborn to pass on — seemed to slink in the shadows, hiding from the weight of her despair.

The door creaked — no, clicked — delicately open, like it refused to offend the silence inside.

 

And into the gloom stepped a figure so luminous it almost hurt to look at her. Eva… or Life, your middle twin sister of triplets. Rio's twin. Older by mere seconds. Yet she always made it seem like centuries.

Where the room was dark, moldy, and desolate, Eva strode in like a burst of gold — her heels clicking smartly against the rotting floorboards, scattering black petals wherever she stepped. She wore a dress spun from starlight itself, golden and extravagant, clinging to her statuesque figure with effortless grace.

Her long, silver-white hair cascaded down her back like a waterfall, almost glowing in the dimness. Her lips were curved in that same familiar smirk that always made Rio want to punch something — and maybe also cry.

 

She looked like a goddess or a very expensive cosplay model from a cheesy video game. Rio didn’t lift her head. She barely blinked.

 

Eva’s voice, rich and melodic, carried easily through the thick, dead air. “Well, this place has certainly seen better days. Honestly, Rio, it’s giving... late-stage Plague Era realness. But for that we had reasons… now?”

 

Her heels crunched over the vines as she stalked closer, her presence filling the cabin with an unsettling light.

 

Rio barely muttered, voice dead. “Go fuck yourself, Eva. I'm not in the mood for you and I don't have time.”

 

Eva tsked loudly, the sound somehow both affectionate and insufferable.

 

“Oh, darling, what else do we have but time? It's practically our third sibling.” She spun on her heel theatrically, letting her dress flare around her like a sunburst. “Now, tell me... what did you do?”

 

At that, Rio finally lifted her head. Her black hair clung to her cheeks, her black eyes duller than usual. There were bruises under her eyes — emotional bruises, soul-deep.

 

Eva’s grin widened, sharp as a blade and twice as dangerous. “Ohhh, let me guess. Starts with an ‘A’, ends with ‘-gatha’?”

 

Rio's jaw clenched.

 

Eva took a delicate step closer, crouching in front of her like a cat stalking wounded prey. “You’re miserable. And that’s saying something, considering you’re always this close to existential misery. But today? Today’s a new record, little sister. Bravo.” She clapped once, slow and mocking.

 

Rio's hand twitched like she might actually punch her. I want to punch her so badly… Instead, she dug her fingers into the flowers blooming underfoot, crushing the petals in her palm, staining her skin black.

 

Eva’s smirk faltered slightly at the sight. “What happened, Rio? Talk to me. ” she asked, softer now. “What did she remember?”

 

Rio swallowed hard, the lump in her throat so tight it hurt. “It wasn’t me, I didn't do it.,” she whispered, voice raw, almost childish in its brokenness. “I didn’t want her to remember. Not yet. Not that.”

 

Eva’s head tilted, hair sliding forward like liquid metal. “But she did,” she said, almost gently. “Didn’t she?”

 

Rio nodded, a single, miserable jerk of her chin. The storm outside raged louder. The windows trembled. Eva reached out, brushing a thumb against Rio’s cheek, almost motherly.

 

“My poor little Death,” she murmured. “You can’t control everything, you know. Not even her heart. Especially not her memories. I've told that, baby sis, so many times.”

 

Rio shivered under her touch. She hated how right Eva was. Hated it with everything she had left. And yet, for the first time in longer than she could remember, Rio didn’t shove her sister’s hand away. She just sat there, broken and silent, while the storm howled around them.

 

"I tried to stay away... I swear," Rio whispered, voice shaking, the weight of her confession heavy between them. Her hands trembled slightly as she buried them in the fabric of her black jeans. "But I can't, Eva. You—you, of all our siblings, you understand... Reia—"

 

Eva’s face darkened slightly. Her bright golden glow dimmed, as if the very thought soured the air around them. She moved, the rustle of her starlight dress brushing softly against the rotting floor, and sat beside Rio with an elegance so natural it made the dilapidated house feel even more haunted.

 

"We're not here to talk about my past, sister," Eva cut her off, her voice as smooth and cold as polished marble. "We’re here to talk about your present."

 

She didn’t look at Rio when she spoke. She couldn’t. Because no matter how poised Eva appeared, deep inside, she hated this conversation. Hated hurting her baby sister more than anything. Of all of them — Death, Life, Fate, Time — Rio was the most human. The only one who had ever managed to revive her own heart. For love.

 

Eva inhaled slowly, steadying herself. Her crystal heels clicked faintly against the warped wood as she shifted. "Fate and I made it clear, Rio," she continued. "No matter how much you love Agatha… your relationship with her is a risk. A danger. Not just to you. Not just to her. But to the balance of the universe itself."

Outside, the storm raged louder, the wind slicing against the shutters like knives. The scent of decay and wet earth saturated the air.

 

Rio gave a dry, humorless laugh — sharp and broken. Black petals fell from her palms as she clenched her fists. "So the risk isn't us," she spat, "it’s our creators. Because if what you're saying is true, then it means for the first time since the dawn of the goddamn universe — since the birth of Space and Void — we’re not playing by their stupid, fucking rules anymore!"

 

Her voice cracked under the weight of her fury, reverberating off the broken walls.

 

Eva remained silent, her golden lashes lowered. "The rules exist for a reason, Rio," she said quietly.

 

"Stupid fucking reasons, Eva!" Rio exploded, springing to her feet.

 

The floor groaned under her bare soles. Dark vines coiled higher up the walls like angry serpents.

 

"Why can’t I have her?" Rio demanded, her voice breaking into a hoarse cry. "Why can’t I love her? If love is forbidden, why was I given the capacity to love her? Why wake me up with this beating thing in my chest just to punish me for feeling it?"

 

Her chest heaved violently. Her arms wrapped around herself, trying to contain the raging tide boiling inside. Tears welled in her eyes — fat, burning tears that blurred the edges of the golden glow her sister radiated. Rio didn't know how to cry properly. She didn't know how to distinguish rage from sorrow, or fear from grief.

All she knew was that in that moment — She felt everything.

 

"I don't know, baby sis," Eva finally said, standing so gracefully it was almost like she floated.

 

Her voice, for once, was stripped of all sarcasm, all games.

 

"I don’t make the rules," she whispered, stepping closer. "I don't know the limits of what we are. None of us do.”

 

Rio’s lips trembled with unshed rage. Eva’s eyes softened. She reached out, brushing a silver strand of hair from Rio’s damp forehead.

 

"I only know what Fate told me. And I’m the only one you still listen to."

 

Rio barked a bitter laugh, wiping her face roughly with the back of her hand. "Tell Dália to go fuck herself," she snapped. "Tell her to shove her 'fate' right up her self-righteous, omniscient ass!"

 

Her powers pulsed outward again. The vines on the floor creaked and twisted violently. The walls trembled.

 

Eva sighed, folding her arms elegantly under her chest, the picture of patience. "You told Agatha yet?" she asked, voice even. "Have you shown her everything?"

 

Rio’s whole body sagged, the fight bleeding out of her all at once. 

 

She shook her head miserably. "No," she rasped. "She… she’s remembering it on her own."

 

A beat of silence.

 

Eva’s lips curved into a slow, sad smile. "Good," she said softly. "That's better. It means she’ll see it from your side. She'll understand the truth if she finds it herself."

 

She stepped forward, closing the last inches between them, and pressed a hand against Rio’s trembling shoulder.

 

"Now breathe, little one," she murmured. "Because your emotions? They're wrecking this place."

 

At first, Rio didn't understand, but when she looked — really looked — she saw.

 

Thick, black vines bristling with jagged thorns had erupted all around the room. Snaking up the beams. Splitting the cracked windows. Creatures from ancient, forgotten worlds cowered in the shadows, hissing at her grief made manifest.

 

Rio gasped sharply. Her hands flew to her mouth.

 

Eva smiled faintly, almost proudly. "See?" she whispered. "You're powerful when you love. Cute."

 

Rio closed her eyes, focusing inward, gathering the shards of herself that had scattered. She inhaled deep — pulling the cold, heavy air into her burning lungs. And slowly — inch by inch — the vines withered. The black flowers curled into themselves. The angry mist thinned.

By the time Rio opened her eyes again, the house was still ruined — but no longer hostile. Only heartbreak remained, hanging in the silence like the fading echo of a scream.

 

"Look, I didn’t just come here for you or Agatha," Eva said, voice dropping lower, threading through the heavy, crackling air. Her golden glow flickered faintly as she moved to lean against the battered window frame. "You know damn well I don't give a shit about who you love. I’m not here to judge you."

 

She crossed her arms, one delicate brow arching sharply.

 

"I’m here for Ralph, Rio," she said, firmer. "We need to find him — find his soul — before he does something stupid."

 

Rio scoffed under her breath, shifting her weight, black vines still slithering uneasily under her bare feet. "I don't give a fuck about him," she muttered.

 

"You should." Eva’s tone sharpened, cutting through the gloom like a blade. The room seemed to contract around them, thickening. "I know you triggered his memories," Eva continued, every word measured, "woke them all up at once — and he broke. Why you did it, I still don’t know. Yet. But that’s not the focus of my question right now."

 

She stepped closer, heels clicking with merciless precision.

 

"Your time to fix this is running out."

 

Rio narrowed her eyes, arms folding defensively across her chest. "What are you talking about?"

 

Eva's expression hardened, the glimmer in her golden eyes fading into something almost mournful. "Ralph was going to kill Agatha."

 

The words hit like a slap, making Rio stiffen visibly, her mouth parting in silent shock. Eva didn’t stop. She couldn’t.

 

"The food poisoning?" she said coldly. "It wasn’t some bad chicken salad, Rio. It was an attempted poisoning. Ralph remembered everything. He wanted revenge. He wanted her dead."

 

The old wood under Rio’s feet groaned as her powers flared without her permission, a low rumble vibrating through the house.

 

"And I—" Eva pressed a hand to her own chest, voice breaking just slightly, "I made him disappear before he could. I had to. And because he was so... Broken, I can't find his soul anymore. All his lives, all the suffering in his soul, especially the one under Agatha's hands, broke him. Because if Agatha died in your arms..." she stepped closer, grabbing Rio's chin in a firm grip, forcing her to look up, "you would’ve broken the only rule you cannot break."

 

Her grip was firm, her fingers cold but grounding.

 

"You would've killed him in retaliation," Eva whispered. "And you know what happens if you kill, Rio. You don’t get to come back from that."

 

Rio’s chest heaved as her mind spun. She knew Eva wasn’t lying. She could feel the truth crawling over her skin, thick and suffocating. "I would’ve torn him apart," Rio admitted, her voice hollow.

 

"You still might," Eva said, letting go of her roughly. "If you don't find him before it's too late."

 

Eva stepped back, crossing her arms tightly, as if trying to contain her own emotions.

 

"Benny — Time — he told me Ralph is slipping. His time is fracturing. His mind is almost gone.”

 

“I'm Death. I'll know when his time it's close.”

 

“Not if he kills himself before his time. If he falls completely, if he snaps and dies by his own hand..." She turned slowly, golden dress dragging slightly across the rotted floor. "You will be the one who takes responsibility for his death, Rio. Not because you killed him — but because you were meant to guard the line. And you failed."

 

Rio swore under her breath, her hands clawing through her hair. Her heart slammed painfully against her ribs — a sensation she hated.

 

"Fuck!" she hissed, almost spitting the word. Her silver eyes burned hot with rage and guilt and fear. "Fucking hell!"

 

"Yes. Fuck," Eva echoed, voice cold and merciless.  She stared at Rio, her lips a grim, sharp line. "Have you found Benito's hiding place yet?" Eva demanded. "Or are you still wandering around like a lovesick mortal?"

 

Rio growled low in her throat, fists clenching at her sides. "The cop..." she muttered. "Daniels."

 

Eva’s smile was quick and razor-sharp. "Smart little Reaper," she said. "We planted him inside the police force. It would be easier. Less obvious."

 

Rio snorted, rolling her eyes despite herself. "He looks like shit blonde."

 

Eva actually laughed — a short, musical sound, brittle at the edges. "Desperate times, darling. Benny hated the look too. Said he felt like a sacrificial lamb on a bad soap opera set. But we had to make sure you wouldn’t smell a trap the moment you got near."

 

The humor vanished from Rio’s face instantly, replaced with a cold, broken mask. "The last time you and your fucking plans came near my family," she said, voice low and venomous, "my son was born dead. My wife died in my arms."

 

The air snapped with cold. The house seemed to shudder. Eva stood silent for a long moment, her golden lashes lowering. "I know," she said, so quietly Rio barely heard it over the roar of blood in her ears. "I know. I'm sorry"

 

And for the first time, the great, shining embodiment of Life looked... old. Tired. Haunted.

But neither of them said anything more.

The wounds were too deep. The storm between them too vast.

 

For now, they only had one path forward: Find Ralph. Fix what had been broken.

 

Before Death herself had to pay the ultimate price.

The library was hollow with silence, the kind that pressed against skin and made every breath feel like a trespass. Fluorescent lights flickered overhead, but most of the room was swallowed in shadows, books lining the shelves like silent witnesses to Agatha’s desperation. The air held the weight of dust, old ink, and something colder — something ancient.

Agatha sat at one of the long oak tables, hunched forward with elbows braced against its scratched surface. Her eyes were rimmed with exhaustion, the dark circles beneath them sinking deeper with each passing night. The Ouija board in front of her was worn and smooth, its letters faded from years of hands too curious for their own good. At its center, the planchette lay still, untouched by spirit or breeze. The seven-day candle burned low, the scent of wax and lavender clinging to the air like a whisper of false calm.

 

"You’re stuck with me, Rio," she muttered, voice tight and low. "So stop playing hide and seek and show yourself already."

 

Nothing. Not a flicker of air. Not a single shift in energy.

 

Agatha clenched her jaw and growled, dragging her hand down her face. “Where the hell are you?”

 

Two weeks. Two entire weeks without a trace. No flowers. No teasing smirks. No hovering shadow by the door, coffee in hand and mischief in her eyes. Agatha would never say it aloud, but the silence had become unbearable. Her bones ached for Rio’s presence. Her breath was wrong without it.

 

She pressed her fingers to the planchette. “Hello, death,” she whispered. “Get out of whatever limbo you’re sulking in and come to me… Death.”

 

At first, there was only stillness. But then, a drop in temperature — subtle, then sudden. Like the room itself exhaled. The warmth leeched from her fingertips. The candle flickered violently.

 

Agatha stilled. No. It wasn’t Rio. It couldn’t be. The cold in the room wasn’t her. It was suffocating, invasive. There was no rhythm to it, no teasing edge or quiet protectiveness.

 

Something else had come.

 

The hair on the back of Agatha’s neck stood on end. Her fingers went rigid around the planchette. But just as her lungs began to seize with panic—

 

Heat. Blazing, furious, familiar. The candle flared. Outside, lightning split the sky despite its clear blue canvas, thunder rumbling a second later like an ancient snarl. Agatha’s head whipped around toward the shelves behind her — and there, cloaked in shadow, Rio stood.

Her death mantle clung to her body like ink made flesh. Her skin glowed pale in the candlelight, her face half-lit, half-devoured by darkness. Her eyes were voids, so black they swallowed the space around them.

 

“I warned you,” Rio said. Her voice wasn’t angry — it was deeper than that. Disappointed. It cracked through the room like thunder.

 

Her fist was clenched tightly, as if holding a leash, and when Agatha followed the invisible line down, her stomach lurched. At Rio’s feet, something writhed. A soul — no, a specter — contorted in hatred, snarling and lashing in silent agony. Black veins ran along its translucent form, its face twisted in pure malice. A collar of gleaming thorns was wrapped around its neck, each movement pulling them deeper into its flesh.

 

Rio gave the leash a tug. The entity howled soundlessly. Flames erupted from the collar, swallowing the form in a plume of smoke and ash.

 

Agatha could barely breathe. That wasn’t Rio. That was Death. And Death had come for more than just a warning.

 

“Many times, it won’t be me who answers, Agatha.” Her voice was calm now, level, but under it burned something feral.

 

“You gave me no choice!” Agatha snapped, rising to her feet. Her chair scraped backward against the marble floor. “You left! You didn’t answer! You gave me nothing but silence and ghosts and then you think you have the right to barge in here and scold me?”

 

Rio inhaled slowly, her eyes never leaving her. Then, without a word, she let go of the leash. The remnants of the tortured soul fell apart like paper turning to ash. The candle’s flame flickered, then extinguished with a breath of wind that wasn’t there.

 

And then Rio stepped forward. With every step, the transformation began. The deathly aura receded like a tide. The black of her cloak faded into the familiar leather jacket. Her eyes shifted — from abyssal void to dark amber. Softer. Quieter.

 

Agatha’s chest rose and fell like she’d run miles. “Where were you?” she whispered. “Purgatory? Hell? Limbo?”

 

Rio’s smirk was faint but there. “The Realm of Death. My home,” she said casually. “I was away too long. The place was a mess. Infernal weeds. Hell-beetles. Rotting timelines. You know how it is.”

 

“Liar.”

 

Rio closed the distance, their noses nearly touching now. The smell of smoke and night-blooming flowers clung to her like second skin.

 

“I can’t lie, my love,” she whispered. Her voice was intimate now — velvet and heat, laced with dark amusement and something more dangerous.

 

She reached out, slow and deliberate, and extinguished the candle with the pads of her fingers. Smoke curled upward like breath from parted lips. And then she stepped into Agatha’s space like she belonged there.

 

“Why did you disappear? Why didn’t you answer me when I called?” Agatha hissed between clenched teeth, her voice low and threatening, almost feral. Her fists were tight at her sides, trembling with the urge to lunge at Rio, to shake answers out of her, to make her feel what she'd been feeling in her absence — rage, confusion, a sick, gnawing grief. Her heart beat violently against her ribs like it wanted out, like it wanted revenge.

 

Rio sat on the edge of the table with a slow, deliberate grace, legs slightly parted, hands braced beside her. Her dark eyes held Agatha’s with a teasing glint, head tilted in mock curiosity. The air around her was thick, still, and charged — like the silence right before a storm tears the sky in two.

 

“Missed me?” she asked with a crooked smirk, her voice sultry but edged with something dangerous. She looked up at Agatha from under her lashes, her tone a seductive drawl wrapped in old wounds. “I thought you hated me. There was a time you begged never to see me again.”

 

Agatha let out a sharp, furious laugh that barely masked her disbelief. Her nails dug into her palms, leaving crescent-shaped wounds. What game was Rio playing now? What mask was this? Did she want Agatha to admit it — to admit she hated her? Wanted to hate her?

 

“Don’t you dare throw a life I can’t remember in my face, Rio,” she snapped, stepping closer, her boots echoing sharply on the floor. “I told you — the things I did in that past? I don’t care. They don’t matter to me.”

 

Rio's eyes flickered, her jaw tightening almost imperceptibly.

 

“Oh, but they do,” she said, quieter now, almost intimate, as if confessing a sin in the dark.

 

Agatha tilted her head slowly, her eyes narrowing. A shift rippled through her — an old, dangerous presence stirring behind her gaze. Rio recognized it instantly. It was her again — the witch from before. The one who stole power with a kiss, who bent others to her will with a glance. The look she gave now said: You don't get to challenge me. You may be Death, but I do not fear you.

 

“How much do they matter?” Agatha asked, voice low, venomous. “Do they matter up until the moment I found out Nick, our son, was going to die before he even took a breath? That you were going to take him? That I hated every piece of you for it?” Her voice cracked, her composure fracturing. “Is that where they start to matter, Rio? And then what — then you run?”

 

Rio clenched her jaw so tight her teeth ached. Her tongue slid along the inside of her cheek as she stared at Agatha, trying to swallow the rising scream in her chest. Her fingers curled into the wood of the table, splinters stabbing under her nails, and the ancient surface cracked beneath her hand.

 

She hadn’t thought they'd reach that memory so soon. Hadn’t prepared for this confrontation — not like this. And Agatha… she still didn’t remember everything. “Agatha…” she said carefully, her voice suddenly small.

 

“Tell me,” Agatha cut her off, stepping in until their knees nearly touched. Her breath was shaky, hot with pain. “What did you think? That only the beautiful, sweet, fucking intoxicating moments would come back to me? That I’d remember the feel of your mouth on my skin, your hands, the way you made me beg — but not this part? The part where you ripped my son from me?” Her voice cracked, and the fury broke into raw grief. “Because in this life, you gave me both of them — Nick, Nicole — as if that would make it okay.”

 

“I wasn’t trying to make up for anything!” Rio snapped, standing now, facing her, eyes wide and wet with emotion. “You asked me for them, Agatha! You begged me for them! I didn’t just show up and shove two children into your life like some twisted gift!”

 

Agatha closed her eyes, her breath coming fast, her chest rising and falling beneath the leather of her jacket. She was trying to hold herself together, but she was unraveling — thread by thread.

 

“What happened to Nicole in that life?” she asked, voice almost a whisper. “Why didn’t I see her in that memory?”

 

Rio froze. “I can’t tell you that,” she said, voice suddenly flat. “Because it’ll—”

 

“Break me?” Agatha growled. “Tear me apart?” Her voice went shrill, choked by the sob buried in her throat. “And what the hell do you think I am right now?”

 

Rio’s breath caught. Her mouth opened, but no words came. Her lips trembled. A single tear slipped from her eye, and she cursed under her breath. “Shit… you hate me again, don’t you?” Her voice cracked, and her shoulders sagged as the words left her. “Fuck. I lost you again, fuck. Goddamn it!”

 

Something inside her snapped. It had been dormant for centuries — this ancient, brutal ache she had sealed away. Her heart pounded like it wanted to claw through her ribcage. Her hands went cold. Her stomach twisted, a sharp cramp of panic pulsing through her entire body. She pressed a trembling hand to her chest, desperate to feel something, anything.

 

“I’m sorry, Agatha. Please, please forgive me,” she whispered, her voice broken now, ragged with pain. “I didn’t mean to. I swear to you… I didn’t mean to.” She was hyperventilating, eyes wild, pupils blown wide like prey caught in a trap.

 

And for the first time, Agatha saw it: Death, reduced to trembling panic. Vulnerable. Human. And utterly shattered.

 

“Rio?” Agatha stepped forward, the heat of her fury cooling in the face of Rio’s collapse. She dropped to her knees beside her, her voice low, urgent. “Rio, honey, look at me. I'm sorry, baby.”

 

Rio didn’t respond. Her gaze was distant, unfocused, as if trapped in a memory she couldn’t escape.

 

“Rio,” Agatha whispered again, more firmly this time, her fingers reaching to cradle her face. Rio’s skin was cold. “Baby, look at me. Please.”

 

Rio blinked, finally meeting her eyes, and in them — raw agony. “He was my son too, Agatha,” she said hoarsely. “I lost him too. I loved him. I loved him so much.”

 

“I know,” Agatha breathed, tears spilling freely down her cheeks. “Baby, I know. I know now, okay?” She pulled her close, wrapping her arms around her, holding her like she was made of glass and fire at once. “I’m not blaming you. I just want to understand. I want us to understand this — us — you.”

 

Rio buried her face in Agatha’s neck, her body trembling with silent sobs. Her arms clung to her tightly, like she was terrified to let go again.

Agatha held her there on the floor, their bodies pressed together, two broken things trying to fuse back into something whole. The scent of Rio’s skin, earthy and electric, filled her lungs. Her grip tightened.

 

“You’re not losing me again,” she whispered. “Not this time.”

 

Rio collapsed into Agatha’s arms, her breath shaky, uneven, ragged like torn silk. Her body trembled, not from cold, but from the weight of a thousand memories pressing against her ribs. She buried her face in the crook of Agatha’s neck, her voice cracked and desperate as she inhaled her scent — a mix of lavender, old paper, and something uniquely Agatha. 

 

“Forgive me,” she whispered, her voice muffled against skin. “Please, my love, don’t leave me alone again. It was dark. Cold. Everything was cold.”

 

Agatha’s breath hitched. She felt the heat of Rio’s tears seeping into her skin, the tremor in her voice twisting something deep in her chest. She tilted Rio’s face up gently, cupping her cheeks in both hands, her thumbs brushing against the wet tracks on her lover’s skin. Then she leaned in, slowly, reverently, and pressed a kiss where the last tear had fallen. Her lips lingered there like a promise.

 

“Rio, sweetheart,” she murmured, voice low, velvet-soft, but weighted with gravity. “There’s nothing to forgive in you. Nothing.” Her eyes, stormy with emotion, searched Rio’s for understanding. “I don’t remember everything yet, but that Agatha… she’s not me. Maybe she chased love through power. Maybe she thought control was the only way to be wanted. Maybe she was good at it. I don’t know. But I’m not her.”

 

Her fingers traced the edge of Rio’s jaw, firm, grounding, a silent reassurance. “I already have love now. Nicole, Nick…” her voice softened, almost breaking, “And yours.” At that, she held Rio’s gaze fully. Her tone deepened, no longer fragile, but commanding. “It’s your work, Rio. It’s what you were born for. To guide, to carry, to end and begin again. I should’ve never hated you for simply doing what you had to do. For being who you are.”

 

Rio blinked slowly, jaw tightening, emotion flickering in the clench of her throat. She looked down for a second before meeting Agatha’s eyes again, this time with guilt simmering under the surface. 

 

“You say that now,” she said, voice hoarse, “but there’s still so much you don’t remember. You won’t like it when you do. But you have to remember.”

 

Agatha nodded slowly, her grip never leaving Rio’s skin. “Okay,” she whispered. “That’s okay. You can’t tell me why?”

 

Rio shook her head, the movement subtle but filled with tension. “No… I can’t. Because I don’t know.” She bit her bottom lip, hard enough to leave a mark. “Fate, my sister, said only your memory returning could restore what was lost between us. That only your soul, finding its voice again, could stop it from screaming after me.”

 

Agatha frowned slightly. Her voice dropped, low and curious. “And what exactly is it screaming for?”

 

“I don’t know,” Rio replied, more quiet now. She was trembling again, but with restraint. “It’s not my job to know that. My work is to guide souls, to let endings bloom into something new. To teach them what it means to surrender and survive. And…” she looked down, a flush blooming across her pale cheeks, “apparently… to get you pregnant.”

 

Agatha let out a startled, breathy laugh, head falling back for a moment. “You did a damn good job at that.”

 

Rio looked up at her through her lashes, something sly, something wicked dancing in her eyes even in the middle of heartbreak. “Three times.”

 

“Don’t brag, big boy,” Agatha purred, one brow arched as she leaned in closer. Her fingers slid through the hair at the nape of Rio’s neck, gripping just enough to tilt her head back and expose her throat. Her voice dipped into something huskier, but gentle. “That mouth of yours is gonna get you in trouble, you know that.”

 

Rio exhaled, her breath catching. “Promise?”

 

Agatha’s lips hovered just above hers, a faint smirk tugging at the corner of her mouth. “I don’t make promises I don’t intend to keep.”

 

Their breaths mingled, heavy with grief and longing, but beneath it — an old hunger reawakened. Agatha could feel it in the way Rio’s hand gripped her waist, in the way her pulse quickened under her skin. And Rio, despite the ache still raw inside her, welcomed it. Welcomed the pull, the surrender, the invitation to be punished and forgiven all at once.

 

“I missed you,” Rio murmured, her voice low and reverent like a prayer, like a confession under candlelight. “Even when you hated me… I missed this. You. Us.”

 

Agatha’s voice was a command wrapped in velvet. “Then prove it. No more running, Rio. I don’t care what’s coming. We face it together. You hear me?”

 

Rio nodded slowly, her lips brushing against Agatha’s. “Yes, ma’am.”

The clatter of forks against ceramic filled the university cafeteria, along with bursts of laughter from the surrounding tables. The usual scent of over-salted fries and weak coffee lingered in the air, but at the corner booth, where Agatha sat with her colleagues, the tension was palpable. She pushed at her bland salad with the tip of her fork, wishing, desperately, to become invisible.

 

"Where’s that hot friend of yours?" Jen asked, her voice muffled through a mouthful of fries, ketchup glistening on her lower lip.

 

Agatha winced. "First, swallow your food. We’re not scavenging in a warzone. Second, she’s not my friend, and she’s not—"

 

"If you’re about to say she’s not hot," Jen interrupted, wiping her mouth lazily, "you’d be lying. We all have eyes, Aggie."

 

Agatha’s jaw flexed. She kept her eyes on the lettuce, stabbing it a little harder than necessary.

 

Wanda, lounging across from her with an iced coffee in hand, cocked her head. "What’s going on between you two?"

 

"Nothing," Agatha said quickly, too quickly. Her voice clipped, defensive. She still didn’t look up.

 

Wanda gave her a slow, calculating look. "You’re different this week. You’ve been... glowing. And you’ve been dressing a little more... sensual."

 

Agatha narrowed her eyes. "I am not."

 

"You are," Lilia chimed in smoothly, swirling her spoon through her yogurt like she was stirring a cauldron.

 

Agatha groaned. "Even you, Lilia?"

 

Lilia smirked. "Sweetheart, the evidence is right in front of us. I haven’t seen you this flushed since your sabbatical in Paris. And back then, you swore it was the red wine."

 

Agatha opened her mouth to deny it, the heat rising rapidly up her neck.

 

"We had sex." The voice was smooth. Velvet-wrapped steel. Every syllable curved like smoke. And it came from right behind Agatha.

 

She went rigid. The sip of water she’d just taken erupted from her mouth in a violent spray, right across Jen’s shocked, open-mouthed face.

 

"AGATHA!" Jen shrieked, leaping back, reaching for napkins as Lilia sputtered her drink across the table and Wanda stared in open-mouthed horror.

 

Agatha didn’t move. She didn’t need to look. She knew. And there she was. Leaning languidly against the back of Wanda’s chair, dressed in black slacks and a sleeveless button-down that showed far too much collarbone, was Rio. Her lips curled into a slow, smug smile, and her dark eyes glittered with unapologetic mischief.

 

Agatha gritted her teeth. "Rio."

 

"Yes, darling?" Rio answered, all honey and thorns.

 

Agatha lowered her voice to a hiss. "You're invisible again."

 

"And still stealing the spotlight. It's a talent," Rio murmured, her voice intimate, as if they were sharing secrets under the covers instead of in a crowded cafeteria.

 

Jen was fuming. "What the actual hell is going on with you, Agatha? I am soaked!"

 

"She’s doing that ghost thing again," Alice muttered from beside Wanda, sipping her drink without looking up.

 

"I’m not—!" Agatha snapped, pointing toward Rio. "She’s right there! You seriously don’t see her?"

 

Wanda turned, then blinked at the empty space. "See who?"

 

Agatha’s frustration boiled over. She pushed her chair back, her whole body tense. "You can’t just show up like that!"

 

Rio, unbothered, prowled closer. She circled behind Agatha like a predator teasing prey, dragging a single fingertip, cold as riverwater, down the back of Agatha’s neck. Agatha shivered violently.

 

Lilia’s eyes widened. "Oh my god. You’re blushing."

 

Agatha slapped her palms to her cheeks. "I am not."

 

"That’s not a blush," Wanda said dryly. "That’s a post-orgasm glow."

 

Agatha’s voice cracked. "Would you all just shut the fuck up?!"

 

Rio leaned down, lips nearly brushing her ear. Her voice was lower now, molten. "They’re not wrong, love. You were glowing. And loud. My poor back is still recovering from the scratches."

 

Agatha stood up so fast her chair screeched across the floor. "I need air."

 

"You need a girlfriend," Jen muttered darkly, still blotting her shirt.

 

"You need a muzzle," Agatha growled.

 

"And you," Lilia added, lifting her glass in a mock toast, "need to get better at lying."

 

Without another word, Agatha stormed out, the air crackling around her. Her hands were trembling. Her face burned. Behind her, Rio followed like a well-dressed storm, that insufferable grin carved across her face.

 

"Well," she whispered, brushing imaginary dust from her shoulder, "that went better than expected.”

 

The classroom was dim and quiet, lit only by the lazy spill of afternoon sunlight slanting through the tall windows. Dust motes floated in the golden beams, drifting like restless spirits. Agatha stood at her desk, her hands flat against the wood, knuckles white with pressure. Her jaw was clenched, her pulse drumming in her ears. The echo of her students' laughter from the hallway felt far away, distant, like a world she no longer belonged to.

 

“I thought we had resolved this,” Agatha snapped, her voice low but laced with venom. Her hand slammed against the desk with a crack that echoed through the empty room. “I am not going back to being the schizophrenic professor, Rio!”

 

Rio appeared in a soft shimmer by the chalkboard, reclining against it like a shadow come to life. Her posture was casual, but her eyes — those amber eyes — were sharp, amused, and entirely too satisfied. “We did resolve it. Of course we did. But really, darling, what would your life be without me to stir a little chaos into your day?”

 

Agatha shot her a glare so sharp it could’ve flayed flesh. “I don’t know. Peaceful? Predictable?”

 

Rio smirked as she prowled forward, slow and deliberate. Her boots made no sound on the floor, but her presence pressed in like thunderclouds before a summer storm. “Boring,” she said simply. “Utterly dull.” She reached out and tugged playfully at the edge of Agatha’s high collar, her fingers like ice, like silk. “Excellent choice of attire, by the way.”

 

Agatha’s breath hitched. “Why?”

 

Rio’s grin widened as she leaned in, her lips brushing the shell of Agatha’s ear as she whispered, “Because I can spend the whole day kissing your neck while invisible, and no one will notice a thing. You’ll have to sit through your lectures with flushed cheeks and your legs clenched, trying not to moan like the needy little thing you are. All while maintaining your ‘professional’ face. If you even can.”

 

Agatha’s throat tightened. She swallowed hard, the scent of Rio’s skin — a mix of cold stone, spice, and something darker, older — filling her lungs like a spell. Then, in a sudden flare of dominance, Agatha shoved Rio back with both hands, hard enough to make the taller woman stumble against the desk with a loud thud. Papers fluttered to the floor. Rio blinked in surprise, her expression flickering between shock and something dangerously turned on.

 

“Do not forget your place,” Agatha hissed, stepping in until their bodies almost touched again. She gripped the front of Rio’s shirt and yanked her forward just enough to make her bend slightly over the desk. Agatha loomed over her now, power humming in her spine, breath warm and steady against Rio’s lips. “The same way you like teasing me, I can make you regret it. You’re invisible, sure, but I know your limits. You have rules about using your powers in front of mortals, don’t you?”

 

Rio’s breath caught, and for a moment, the smugness bled from her face. Her pupils dilated. “How do you know about that?”

 

Agatha’s voice dropped to a low purr, velvet and steel. “Somewhere… in a massive estate, in the center of Salem… on a summer night when I was fifteen… you told me. Ring any bells?”

 

Rio’s eyes widened. She stiffened, blinking as that memory — that night — flooded her senses. She hadn’t realized Agatha had remembered it. Not that detail. Not that night. The look in her eyes was different now. Focused. In control.

 

Agatha tilted her head, reading her reaction. “Judging by your face… you do remember.”

 

That night had been the first time Rio saw Agatha cry. Evanora had bruised her pride — and her skin. Rio had wanted to tear the woman to pieces, but Agatha had asked her to scare her instead. Just scare. No deaths. No chaos. Just... help. And Rio, despite everything, even though she is forbidden from using her powers in front of living humans, had obeyed. For Agatha. That was the night she first laid her lips on Agatha’s trembling ones. The first night she had broken the rules for Agatha.

 

“You remember more than you admit,” Rio murmured, barely above a whisper.

 

“I remember just enough,” Agatha said, voice softer now, but no less dangerous. Her lips were so close, her breath traced the edge of Rio’s mouth like a lover’s touch. “And I’m curious to remember more. Maybe if I left the kids with you tonight and went somewhere… alone… to relax… the rest would come back.”

 

Rio’s hand twitched on the desk. Her eyes darkened instantly, like a storm rolling in. “Relax, how?”

 

Agatha’s smirk was slow, teasing. She reached for Rio’s hand where it clutched the table edge, her touch soft but firm as she eased the growing pressure before Rio shattered the wood. “I’m a grown woman, baby. There are many ways to have fun.”

 

A sharp, threatening hiss left Rio’s throat as she bared her teeth like a feral cat. Her shoulders tensed, and her other hand curled into a fist. “You’re not insane yet, Agatha,” she warned, her voice low, trembling on the edge of rage and desperation.

 

“Jealousy doesn’t suit you, kitten,” Agatha whispered, stepping back with deliberate slowness, her eyes never leaving Rio’s. “Now make yourself visible or sit in that chair and behave. Because if you don’t… I will go out tonight. And if I do, you won’t be able to touch me or do anything if someone touches me. Because your rules won’t allow it. Understood?”

 

Rio didn’t respond at first. Her jaw was tight, her chest rising and falling too fast for someone who was supposed to be in control. Finally, she straightened, brushing imaginary dust off her shirt, and offered Agatha a thin, tight smile. “You drive me insane,” she muttered.

 

Agatha’s eyes gleamed. “Good. Then we’re even.”

Agatha ended the class fifteen minutes early, her voice trailing off as her mind shifted abruptly, snagged by the jarring memory of the school meeting. The Parent-Teacher Conference.

 

Nick. Shit.

 

She gathered her things quickly, stuffing papers into her leather satchel with one hand and rubbing her temple with the other. A headache was starting to build at the base of her skull — stress or guilt, she wasn’t sure which. As she slipped her coat on, she could feel it — that chill that wasn’t cold. That brush of presence.

 

She was being followed. Again.

 

Outside, the air was thick with spring warmth, the scent of jasmine riding on the breeze. As Agatha approached her car, she didn’t need to turn around to know Rio was there. She felt it — like the way the room always shifted when Rio entered, as if the world itself inhaled.

 

Sliding into the driver’s seat, she didn’t check the mirrors or even glance toward the passenger side. She simply exhaled, long and controlled, and said flatly, “Are you coming with me, or will you keep pretending only I can see you?”

 

There was a pause — silent, but heavy. Then leather creaked softly under shifting weight, and when Agatha turned her head, Rio was already there. Sitting coolly in the passenger seat, she looked unbothered, legs crossed, hands in her lap. Her face was tilted toward the window, and sunlight streamed in, casting a golden halo over her skin. But it was the shadow — her shadow — that gave it away. For once, it wasn’t invisible. It curved softly across the dash and over Agatha’s arm. Real. Tangible. Visible.

 

A muscle in Agatha’s jaw twitched. She smiled, slow and dry. “So you’re showing yourself now.”

 

“Happy?” Rio asked, finally turning her head. Her voice was like velvet laced with sharp edges, and the corner of her mouth curved in a smug, satisfied smile.

 

Agatha didn’t answer right away. She let her gaze drag down Rio’s form — how she sat like she owned not just the car, but gravity itself. The seat seemed to mold around her. Her presence always did that — made everything feel smaller, charged, like static before lightning struck.

 

“Very,” Agatha said finally, shifting in her seat and starting the engine. “Nick’s going to be pleased to know that the other mom of his decided to show up.” Her tone was teasing, but her eyes flicked over Rio with something heavier than humor.

 

Rio's smile deepened, pleased with herself. “Well… it’s not exactly the first time I’ve been there. I’ve attended a few of these little human rituals — just... invisibly.”

 

Agatha’s brow lifted, one hand on the gearshift. “So you were just looming in the corner while I tried to explain why our son built a trebuchet out of cafeteria trays?”

 

“Technically,” Rio said, lifting a finger, “he built it out of discarded trays, chairs, and one mop handle. Very resourceful. You should’ve seen the trajectory.”

 

Agatha huffed a laugh, biting the inside of her cheek to keep from smiling. She pulled out of the parking lot, the scent of Rio’s presence — smoke, snow, and the faintest trace of iron — curling in the small space between them like a secret.

 

“This time,” Agatha said, voice firmer now, “you can be there as his mother too. Officially. Just… try not to terrify the principal.”

 

“I always behave,” Rio purred, dragging out the words as she leaned in closer. Her fingers danced over Agatha’s thigh with calculated slowness, the pressure feather-light but charged. “Unless you want me to misbehave. In which case…”

 

Agatha turned her head sharply, eyes narrowing. “Don’t you dare start.”

 

“Start what?” Rio asked, the picture of innocence, though her smirk betrayed her. She leaned back with a satisfied sigh, buckling her seatbelt with exaggerated politeness. “Lead the way, mama bear.”

 

Agatha shook her head, but her lips curled despite herself. She kept her eyes on the road, though every nerve in her body was acutely aware of the woman beside her. Every shift of fabric. Every glance. Every inhale. It wasn’t going to be a normal parent-teacher meeting. Not when Death decided to come along — visible, smug, and with the smirk of a woman who knew exactly how to unmake her with one word.

They sat side by side on the narrow bench lining the school hallway, waiting for their turn to speak with Nick’s teacher. The buzz of voices, the distant squeal of sneakers on polished linoleum, and the low murmur of casual parent chatter filled the corridor. The walls were a washed-out yellow, the fluorescent lights above flickering every few seconds like they were struggling to stay awake. A clock ticked too loudly, and the air was thick — not hot enough to sweat, but warm enough to make clothes cling where they shouldn’t.

Agatha crossed her legs, one foot bouncing with restrained impatience. She looked straight ahead, jaw tight, her fingers gripping her purse like it had insulted her. Rio, on the other hand, looked completely relaxed — one arm draped lazily behind Agatha on the back of the bench, the other twirling a chipped plastic dinosaur she'd found abandoned under a seat. Her long legs were stretched out like she owned the place, black jeans tight enough to be sinful, boots untied like always. The open buttons of her navy shirt gave an unapologetic peek of bare skin and the sharp line of her collarbone, and the edges of a tattoo, glowing softly under the hallway lights.

 

Across from them sat Susan Storm, pristine as always in her pearl earrings, icy smile and form-fitting blazer that screamed "perfect wife of a genius". She crossed her legs delicately and didn’t even pretend not to stare.

 

Agatha noticed. Oh, she definitely noticed.

 

She let out a slow, sharp breath through her nose, like a dragon just before the flames. Her head turned toward Rio, eyes smoldering with something between fury and desire. Her voice dropped, a low warning wrapped in velvet and steel. “Button your shirt.”

 

Rio didn’t even look up. “It’s fucking hot in here, Agatha,” she murmured, still distracted by the dinosaur, tapping its tiny head against her thigh with childlike amusement. She smirked to herself. She knew exactly what she was doing.

 

Agatha narrowed her eyes. Her fingers twitched. “This is a school. Not a goddamn strip club.”

 

Finally, Rio looked up. Her dark eyes were half-lidded, amused, amused and predatory. She dropped the dinosaur on her thigh and tilted her head, letting her eyes lazily wander down Agatha’s body before flicking back to her face. Then she followed Agatha’s gaze toward Susan and immediately understood.

 

Ah.

 

The blonde was looking at her like a wolf in a cocktail dress. That was the problem. And Agatha was simmering in it. Something wicked unfurled in Rio’s grin. The kind of grin that pulled confessions from lips and made sinners out of saints.

 

“I think I’ll leave it open,” she said, stretching slowly as she straightened her back, making sure the motion pulled her shirt further apart, the hint of a tattoo curling under her ribs now in full view. “It really is hot.” Her voice dropped on the last word, just enough to make Agatha’s spine stiffen.

 

Agatha leaned in slightly, her fingers curling tight around the strap of her bag. “Close. It. Or I will.”

 

Rio’s gaze slid back to her. “Mmm. You threatening me in front of PTA moms now?” Her lips barely moved, but her voice dripped with something dark, teasing, deliciously taunting. “What do you think they'll say if they see you tugging at my shirt like that, baby?”

 

She bit her lower lip, just lightly, watching the storm rise behind Agatha’s eyes.

 

“‘Cause from where I’m sitting,” she added, voice slow and honeyed, “you look very interested in what’s underneath.”

 

Agatha’s cheeks flushed, not from embarrassment, but from a heat deeper, older, more territorial. Her fingers twitched again — itching to grab, to control, to put Rio exactly where she wanted her. The tension between them was so thick it buzzed in the air like static before a lightning strike. The hallway noise seemed to fade under it, swallowed by the unspoken things vibrating between them.

Susan stood up then, brushing invisible lint from her thigh. She gave one last not-so-subtle glance at Rio’s exposed skin and clicked her heels as she walked away, probably off to seduce another married physicist.

 

Agatha leaned over, close enough that her breath brushed Rio’s ear, her tone satin-smooth but sharp as a blade. “You like making me jealous?”

 

Rio didn’t hesitate. “I thought it was our game now... and I love it.”

 

Agatha smiled without warmth. Her hand drifted toward Rio’s chest, thumb just grazing the edge of the open shirt. Her voice was so quiet it could’ve been a prayer or a threat. “I’m going to make you regret it later.”

 

Rio’s pulse jumped under Agatha’s touch. Her smile faltered for a split second. “Promise?”

 

Before Agatha could answer, the classroom door creaked open and a teacher’s voice called out, “Agatha Harkness? You can come in now.”

 

Agatha stood, smoothing down her skirt with a graceful flick of her fingers. She didn’t look back.

Rio, still seated, watched her walk into the room with a dark gleam in her eyes and a wicked grin tugging at her mouth. She adjusted her shirt, finally buttoning it — only because Agatha wasn’t watching.

 

Rio followed Agatha immediately, her presence gliding behind her like a shadow dressed in silk. Silent, elegant, unseen. The door to Nick’s classroom creaked faintly as she stepped inside and pushed it closed with a soft click, the sound precise and deliberate, like a secret being sealed. The room was a burst of childish joy — walls covered in crayon drawings, alphabet banners swaying slightly in the breeze from a barely functioning ceiling fan, and tiny chairs arranged like a tea party waiting to start. Everything was miniature. Everything was warm. Too warm.

 

Rio stood there, momentarily disarmed. Cute, she thought, eyeing the toy kitchen set in the corner. Her pale fingers curled slightly around the back of one of the child-sized chairs. Tiny little humans. Ridiculously adorable. She smiled, just a little.

 

The teacher — Miss Carter — lifted her gaze from the papers on her desk. Her eyes swept Rio up and down, taking in the dark clothing, the composed posture, the undeniable charisma curling off her like perfume. Confusion settled behind her polite expression.

 

“Mrs. Harkness... It’s good to see you again. How have you been?” Miss Carter’s voice was calm, but her eyes flicked back to Rio, visibly uncertain. “And you are...?”

 

“Rio Vidal,” Rio answered smoothly, stepping forward and extending her hand with a practiced grace. Her smile was slow and disarming, almost too charming for a school setting. “Nick’s other mom.”

 

Agatha’s head snapped around so fast it made an audible crack. Her eyes flared with disbelief, lips parting in a sharp breath that never fully escaped. She had expected Rio to pull something bold — but not that bold. Not that blunt. No build-up, no softening. Just straight to the point, like always. Her heartbeat stuttered once in her throat, and her cheeks flushed with a mix of irritation and something dangerously close to... amusement.

 

Miss Carter hesitated but gestured to the chairs across from her desk, professionalism outweighing curiosity. “Alright then… please, sit. We have quite a bit to discuss.”

 

Without missing a beat, Rio circled behind Agatha and pulled the chair out for her with a low, respectful murmur near her ear, “After you, ma’am.”

 

Agatha narrowed her eyes at her but sat anyway, spine straight. The sound of the chair’s legs dragging across the floor was oddly sharp in the room’s quiet. Rio sat beside her, brushing her fingers lightly across Agatha’s shoulder as she did. The touch was fleeting but calculated — soft pressure, just enough to feel the warmth of skin beneath fabric. Agatha turned her head slowly, suspicion tightening her jaw. She knew that touch. Rio was up to something. She was always up to something.

 

Miss Carter launched into her overview of Nick’s performance. Academic excellence, musical aptitude, creativity with drawings, unexpected skill in sports. Rio nodded politely, but her focus was drifting. One hand was already in her coat pocket, fingers fiddling with the tiny green plastic dinosaur. She placed it delicately on her knee, tilting it back and forth, making its stubby arms “dance.”

A childish grin bloomed on her lips. She looked like a grown woman pretending to be innocent. Or maybe she wasn’t pretending.

Agatha’s irritation simmered beside her like a covered pot on a high flame. The click-click of the plastic against Rio’s ring echoed like a countdown in her ears. Without warning, she reached out, snatched the toy from Rio’s hand, and shoved it into her purse with a hard zip.

 

“Ah!” Rio gasped, betrayal written across her face like a child who’d just lost her ice cream.

 

“Rio,” Agatha growled under her breath.

 

“What?” Rio leaned closer, pout full, lashes low. “I already know everything she’s saying. You forgot I’m the one doing homework patrol while you survive Nicole’s teenage angst and hormonal rage.”

 

Miss Carter cleared her throat, arching a brow as she looked between them. The dynamic was... unconventional. “Ladies,” she said, tone sharp but patient. “Despite Nick’s strengths, there’s something I am concerned about.”

 

She opened his file, sliding out two colorful drawings from the folder. The first showed a happy family: Agatha with Nicole, hand-in-hand with Nick, and beside him, a hooded woman dressed in green-black. The second was more unsettling — Nick alone with the same cloaked figure, her face replaced with a skull, hollow eyes and all.

Agatha’s blood ran cold. Her eyes widened, throat suddenly too dry to swallow.

 

Holy. Shit.

 

Meanwhile, Rio’s reaction was the opposite. Her eyes lit up like it was Christmas morning. “Oh! That’s me!” she exclaimed, delighted. She pointed proudly to the skeletal face. “Damn, he really nailed the jawline.”

 

Agatha turned to her, shooting daggers so sharp they could peel skin. Miss Carter, meanwhile, blinked at Rio, then at Agatha — her face caught between concern and incredulity.

 

“Your son sees you as a specter, Ms. Vidal?” Miss Carter asked delicately. “That isn’t... normal for a seven-year-old. The way a child depicts their parents says a lot about their inner world. I’ve also noticed that Nick has gradually stopped mentioning Mr. O’Connor altogether. That, too, is something we find worrying for a child who — presumably — lost his father.”

 

She glanced at Agatha, then back to Rio, who was still admiring the drawing. “I’m not a negative influence for my son if it's what you are implying,” Rio said flatly, her smile gone, replaced with a dark edge in her voice.

 

Agatha straightened her posture and raised a hand slightly, her voice calm but assertive, cutting in before Rio could spiral. “I understand your concern, Peggy. But Nick’s fine. He’s healthy, happy, emotionally responsive. Rio...” She exhaled, choosing her words carefully. “Rio dressed up as Death for no reason one day, very dramatic makeup, and, well, Nick saw it. He wasn’t scared. Actually, he’s obsessed with the video Nicole took of me screaming like a banshee. It’s been on replay for two weeks now.”

 

Rio arched a brow toward Agatha, lips twitching into a smirk. Liar, that expression said. A familiar look. It was the face Rio made when the witch in Agatha resurfaced — smooth, manipulative, unapologetically clever.

 

God, she loved that side of her.

 

“She’s... eccentric,” Agatha added. “Hyper, strange, a little unfiltered, yes. But the kids love her. And so do I.” Her voice dropped slightly, turning soft at the end. “Ralph is... complicated. But let’s just say he was never the father they needed. And they know that.”

 

Miss Carter gave a slow nod, though the tension in her shoulders didn’t quite ease. “Still. Last week, when Franklin Richards teased Nick, he told him he’d send his mom to haunt his dreams... and take his dog.” She turned her gaze to Rio.

 

Rio blinked, blinking twice like she didn’t see the issue. “What? I’m not a ghost. I don’t haunt people. And I never mess with dogs. Pure souls. Sacred beings. I haunt Agatha, sure — but that’s consensual. Nick doesn’t fully understand my powers ye—”

 

“Okay!” Agatha cut in, raising both hands quickly. “What she means is that we’ll have a conversation with Nick about not threatening his classmates with supernatural retribution only our child can claim.” She glanced sideways. “Because... most mothers can not do that.”

 

Rio hummed beside her, quiet but undeniably amused, leaning in with a whisper just low enough to send a shiver up Agatha’s spine. “That went well, don’t you think?”

 

Agatha shot her a side glance filled with fire, her hand gripping Rio’s thigh under the table in warning. 

 

As they stepped out of the classroom, Rio collided shoulder-first into a woman rounding the corner too fast, nearly knocking the phone from her hand. It would’ve hit the floor and shattered if Rio’s inhuman reflexes hadn’t snatched it midair, catching it with two fingers like it was nothing more than a falling leaf.

Behind her, Agatha was still smiling politely at the teacher, murmuring a final thank you, but her eyes locked immediately on the scene — on Susan’s hands resting far too casually on Rio’s shoulders. The diamond ring on Susan’s finger sparkled like it had a soul of its own, catching the hallway light with arrogant brilliance. But it didn’t stop her from touching what didn’t belong to her.

Rio didn’t seem to register the shift in the atmosphere behind her — or she simply chose to ignore it. Which, for Rio, was entirely on brand.

 

"I'm so sorry," Susan said with a practiced smile, smoothing down Rio’s shoulder like she was erasing the contact. Her fingers lingered just enough to feel the tension under the leather jacket. "I was so distracted, I didn’t even see you..."

 

“It’s fine,” Rio replied, her tone light, handing the phone back without skipping a beat. “Here.”

 

“Oh! You have amazing reflexes... You must be really athletic. Strong. You didn’t even let me or the phone hit the floor.”

 

“Has nothing to do with sports. I was built this way. A long time ago,” Rio said with a sly glint in her eye.

 

Susan chuckled, a little confused by the phrasing, but Rio saw the flick of her gaze — to behind her. She felt the air grow colder. Agatha had stopped walking. And now, she was watching. Burning. Rio didn’t turn. She didn’t have to. Her skin prickled with it. The kind of attention that reached inside your ribs and gripped your spine. That territorial stillness before a storm.

Part of her knew she should stop. The other part — the part currently biting her inner cheek to hold back a grin — was enjoying every second of this.

 

“Oh, but you must work out, right? Which gym do you go to?” Susan’s fingers tightened around Rio’s upper arms now, sliding down in a slow, clearly intentional press. “There’s one close by. I go often. Never seen you there.”

 

The moment Susan’s hand made the slightest movement lower — toward Rio’s back — Agatha’s fingers closed around her wrist. The grip was strong. Controlled. But barely.

 

“She works out at home. With me. Watching,” Agatha said, her voice sharp and even, like a scalpel cutting through silk. She didn’t blink. Didn’t flinch. Her eyes locked on Susan’s like a hunter who’d just chosen her prey.

 

In another life, she could’ve incinerated her with a thought.

 

“Agatha,” Susan said sweetly, though her tone faltered as she tried to pull her hand back. Agatha didn’t move. Not yet. “It’s been a long time.”

 

“Not long enough.” Agatha stepped forward until she was in front of Rio, shielding her completely, standing so close that Rio could smell the faint vanilla-and-smoke scent she always wore.

 

Possessive. Commanding. Delicious.

 

Susan smiled, sharp and sugary. But when her eyes slid to Rio again, there was hunger there. A challenge.

 

“You moved on fast, huh? And upgraded, by the looks of it.” Her gaze raked over Rio like she was peeling her clothes off molecule by molecule.

 

Rio could practically hear Agatha’s knuckles tightening. She knew that look. She’d seen what came after, too. If Agatha still had her powers, Susan would be a smear on the hallway floor.

 

“How’s your husband?” Susan asked with venomous sweetness.

 

“Probably doing better than yours,” Agatha answered coolly, her hand now resting on Rio’s hip like a mark of ownership. “Seeing as his ex-wife isn’t rubbing her ring on someone else's bicep in public.”

 

Rio coughed, trying to swallow a laugh and not choke. She adored this version of Agatha. Not the composed mother. Not the reformed witch. This. This razor-tongued creature full of fury and pride and possessive rage.

 

Susan blinked, clearly not expecting that. “Ex?” she asked, arching a brow. “Was it a divorce? Or did they finally find his body in your basement and call it?”

 

Agatha’s lips curled into something feral. “The second one. I used his corpse to summon Death. It's not working — she won’t listen to me.” Her nails pressed into Rio’s arm, deep enough to leave a mark, grounding herself through her. “But I guess I’ll have to summon a way to educate her, right? I'm gonna need another body... Want to take a wild guess at who I’m thinking of?”

 

The color drained from Susan’s face. Her confident smirk evaporated. All the years of taunting, of passive-aggressive jabs — this was the first time Agatha spoke like that. With that voice. The one that echoed from something ancient, something dangerous.

 

“It was a pleasure meeting you... even though I never caught your name.” She looked at Rio, clearly waiting for her to say something. But Rio stayed silent, feeling Agatha’s pulse thrum through her grip. Agatha wasn’t playing anymore. “And it’s always... a pleasure to see you, Agatha.”

 

“I can’t say the same,” Agatha said flatly. “Come.”

 

She didn’t wait for Rio to respond. She wrapped her fingers around her wrist and pulled her out of the hallway, past the gawking parents, past the staff, straight toward the car. The cold air hit them as they exited the school building, but Rio barely noticed. Her wrist was still in Agatha’s grip — tight, firm, tingling. Possessive.

 

It feels so good.

The car door slammed with more force than necessary, the echo reverberating through the parking lot like a warning shot. Agatha gripped the steering wheel with white-knuckled restraint, the leather creaking beneath her fingers. Her jaw was locked, lips a thin line, and her eyes — still lit with that cold fire — were fixed dead ahead as if driving faster would silence the fury bubbling inside her.

Rio settled into the passenger seat with a little too much comfort, tossing her hair over her shoulder and exhaling a soft, amused sigh. She crossed her legs slowly, deliberately, and leaned her head back against the seat, watching Agatha from the corner of her eye like a cat toying with prey.

The silence was sharp. Dense. Like the moment before a storm snaps open the sky. Agatha turned onto the road with a jerk of the wheel, her movements controlled but barely. The heat of her anger radiated in waves, the air in the car thick with it — spiced with the scent of her perfume, her skin, and something darker, more primal: the burn of jealousy that still simmered hot under her collar.

 

Rio smirked. “You’re gripping that wheel like you want to strangle it.”

 

“I do want to strangle something,” Agatha muttered, her voice low and dangerous.

 

“Not me, I hope.”

 

Agatha didn’t answer. Her eyes stayed on the road, but her body was taut, her shoulders high, her breaths shallow.

 

Rio bit back a grin and let her fingers trail along her thigh, slow and casual. “You know, I didn’t tell her my name.”

Chapter End Notes

New names and their meanings:

Life: Eva (Eva means Life, as it is the name of the first woman according to the Bible (Eve for English speakers).

Fate: Dália (In Lithuanian culture the name Dália has the meaning of destiny or fate.)

Time: Benito "Benny" (has the meaning of blessed in Latin culture).

I chose to keep the Brazilian and Latin spelling of the names. I thought it would be prettier and more poetic too.
