Agatha bit down hard on her lip to keep from laughing. She had to be the adult here, clearly. The responsible one.

 

"Rio..." she started carefully, voice cracking with suppressed amusement. "What... did you do to my kitchen? It's 7:30 in the morning. I have to be at the college by 8."

 

Rio turned around, pouting like a guilty black cat caught mid-crime. Her nose was streaked with flour, and when her golden-brown eyes met Agatha’s, so wide and sheepish, it was all over.

Agatha snorted, laughter bubbling uncontrollably from her lips.

 

"I was trying to take care of you," Rio mumbled, pouting even harder. "You made me feel so good last night... I think I wore you out... So I thought I'd make you breakfast... And..." She gestured helplessly to the chaos around her.

 

Agatha stepped closer, heart softening into something unbearably tender. She reached out, gently wiping the tip of Rio’s nose with the sleeve of her robe. Rio leaned into the touch immediately, like a starved kitten, almost purring under her breath.

 

Agatha’s chest ached sweetly. "This is Death," she thought. "The great Reaper... acting like this?"

 

She cupped Rio’s flour-smeared face with her fingertips. "Why didn’t you just make pancakes?" she teased lightly. "You're good at pancakes."

 

Rio’s lips twitched into a small, embarrassed smile. "Because you deserve more than pancakes after giving me three orgasms in a row, Agatha," she said bluntly, without a hint of teasing, just as a simple truth.

 

Agatha choked on a laugh and covered her mouth. God help her. Rio's complete innocence in saying something so filthy would kill her one day.

Rio looked at her, so open, so bright, so... pure. Her amber eyes gleamed under the soft morning light filtering through the dusty windows. Agatha’s heart squeezed painfully in her chest.

 

"You know what I'd really love to eat right now?" Agatha said, smoothing her thumb across Rio’s cheek before kissing it tenderly.

 

Rio closed her eyes instinctively, melting into the affection. "Me?" Rio asked hopefully, voice so genuine it almost hurt.

 

"Tempting," Agatha murmured, "but I have exams to supervise today. I was thinking something lighter. Fresh fruit. Like those mornings... when I first started bleeding." She smiled faintly at the memory, voice growing soft. "You used to leave baskets outside my room... full of flowers, fruits, and—"

 

"— Grape juice," Rio finished, a fond smile lighting her face. "Because you wanted to drink wine so badly, but you were only twelve."

 

"Exactly," Agatha laughed, her chest tightening with a rush of warmth.

 

"You always wanted to be so grown up," Rio said, voice full of nostalgia. "You used to steal your mother's dresses and pretend you were leading a coven."

 

"And you..." Agatha tilted her head, studying Rio’s softened features, "you looked so different. You almost looked like Nicole. Messy freckles, wild hair... like some lost teenage boy who didn't know where he belonged."

 

Rio laughed, a genuine sound. "I had to adapt to you," she said, shrugging. "It would’ve been weird if I stayed in my adult form hanging around a kid all the time."

 

And just like that, with a casual wave of her hand, the disaster in the kitchen vanished. Flour, flowers, broken eggs, overturned bowls — all gone. The kitchen gleamed again as if nothing had ever happened. And there, waiting on the table, sat a perfect breakfast: fresh fruits of every color, a crystal pitcher of grape juice, and wildflowers arranged with surprising grace.

Agatha’s breath caught. The smile she gave Rio wasn’t forced, wasn’t measured, wasn’t cautious. It was pure, unfiltered wonder. The same look she used to give her... back when everything between them was simple and untouched by pain. Rio stared at her, eyes glowing gold and full of something too big to name. Something desperate and wild and so, so in love.

 

"Rio," Agatha said gently, noticing how awkwardly Rio twisted the corner of the tablecloth in her fingers. "Sit down. You're acting weird."

 

"Sorry..." Rio mumbled, sliding clumsily into the chair beside her. "I just... I forgot how it feels to be with you like this. No running. No fighting. Just... us."

 

Her voice cracked on the last word. Agatha reached out without thinking, threading their fingers together. She felt Rio’s heart hammering in her palm. It made her own chest tighten painfully.

 

"Rio," she breathed, voice trembling slightly, "do you want to go out with me?"

 

Rio blinked. Confused. Adorable. "I always go out with you," she said, tilting her head like a puzzled puppy.

 

Agatha chuckled, squeezing her hand. God, she was adorable. "No, baby. I mean... a real date. Like — official. Dinner. Movie. Something stupid and cheesy."

 

The silence that fell between them was heavy and sacred. Even the air seemed to shimmer. Rio’s mouth opened — and nothing came out at first.

 

"I..." she stammered, eyes wide, cheeks flushing a deep, lovely pink.

 

Death blushed. Rio Vidal, the fucking Reaper, was blushing like a teenager asked to prom.

 

"Yes," she whispered finally, voice hoarse with emotion. "Yes! I want that. I want that so much."

 

Agatha laughed — light and bright and full of something she hadn't let herself feel in a long time: hope. "Good," she said, brushing the back of Rio’s hand with her lips. "I'll plan everything. You just have to wear something comfortable. I'll take care of you."

 

Rio squeezed her hand back, so tightly it almost hurt. "But Agatha," she asked shyly, "why?"

 

Agatha smiled, tucking a stray lock of hair behind Rio’s ear.

 

"Because, my love," she said, voice shaking but sure, "it's time we do this right. You made me a mother — twice — you live in my house, I have your nudes on my phone... but we never had a first date."

 

She leaned in, their foreheads brushing gently.

 

"And judging by your face right now," Agatha whispered, smirking, "I'm guessing our first dates back then weren't very conventional, were they?"

 

Rio gave a sheepish shrug. Agatha laughed softly.

 

"So let’s start properly this time," she said, voice fierce and full of quiet devotion. "No more running, Rio. No more hiding."

 

Rio closed her eyes, breathing in the scent of Agatha’s skin — the lavender soap, the faint trace of warmth and magic clinging to her. "No more hiding," Rio whispered back.

Rio was practically glued to Agatha’s side as they walked across campus, the morning sun casting soft halos around them. Her arm brushed against Agatha’s every few steps, her hand occasionally grazing her waist as if she simply couldn’t help it. The high-collared black sweater she wore clung to her figure, but it couldn’t hide the marks blossoming beneath — marks she wore like trophies. Even if she could erase them with a thought, she wanted them there. Agatha had made them. They were proof, stamped into her skin, that she was hers.

 

And then there was the smile. God, the smile.

 

Rio practically floated as she moved, a grin so stupidly happy it made her look drunk. Her golden-brown eyes never left Agatha for long, following her like she was the sun and Rio was some helpless, desperate moth. Agatha tried to ignore it. Tried to focus on her breakfast, on the stack of papers waiting for her in her office, on literally anything but the possessive way Rio’s gaze slid over her like a touch.

 

It wasn’t working. And her friends were noticing.

 

At first, they exchanged silent looks, nudging each other beneath the table as they picked at their food in the campus café. But it didn’t take long before Jen, ever the blunt one, broke the dam.

 

"You two fucked, didn’t you?" she said, loud enough that three tables turned to stare.

 

Agatha choked violently on her juice, coughing and sputtering, while Rio just tilted her head and smiled lazily, like a satisfied cat stretching in a sunbeam. She took a deliberate sip of her coffee before answering.

 

"No!" Agatha barked, voice hoarse.

 

"Yes," Rio said at the exact same time, smirking around the rim of her mug.

 

Wanda’s brow shot up suspiciously. She leaned forward, scrutinizing Rio like a scientist examining a new, irritating specimen. "Agatha's not gay," Wanda said flatly.

 

Rio set her cup down with theatrical care, the porcelain clicking lightly against the saucer.

 

Her smile sharpened. "She was pretty gay last night. And I can’t lie, honey," she purred, tilting her head, the amber of her eyes gleaming mischievously. "It’s not allowed."

 

The way she said it sent a chill down Agatha’s spine — and not in a good way.

 

Wanda leaned back, folding her arms. "Prove it."

 

"No, Rio, don't prove it," Agatha snapped quickly, shooting her a deadly glare.

 

Rio ignored her entirely, resting her chin in her hand and batting her lashes at Wanda. "That I can’t lie," she asked sweetly, "or that I slept with Agatha?"

 

"Both," Wanda said, a wicked grin curling at the corners of her mouth.

 

Rio gave a mock sigh of defeat. "Fine." With exaggerated slowness, she reached up and tugged down the turtleneck collar of her sweater. A collective gasp rose from the table.

 

Along the elegant column of her neck, angry red and purple marks bloomed — bites, kisses, the kind of bruises you couldn’t mistake for anything else.

Agatha wanted to die. Right there. Instant cardiac arrest. Her soul probably did leave her body for a few blessed seconds.

 

"Holy shit, Harkness!" Jen choked, eyes wide as saucers. "What are you, a vampire?"

 

"Or a fucking canibal?" Alice snorted, covering her mouth to hide her explosive laughter. "You almost ripped the girl's throat out, Agatha!" she howled between giggles, thumping the table.

 

Agatha covered her face with both hands, groaning. "I am going to strangle her," she muttered behind her fingers. "I am going to fucking strangle her."

 

Rio just smiled angelically, looking way too proud of herself.

 

"Masochist, she would probably love to be strangled." Agatha thought bitterly. "Fucking adorable, self-satisfied little masochist."

 

Wanda, however, wasn’t done. She tapped her manicured nails against the table thoughtfully, eyes narrowing. "Alright," she said. "You proved you slept with her, which I have some questions… Now prove you can’t lie."

 

Rio’s smile grew sharper, hungrier. She loved a good challenge. "You sure about that, Wanda?" Rio asked, voice dropping just slightly, a warning hidden in the sweetness.

 

"Yes," Wanda said stubbornly.

 

"No," Agatha hissed across the table, shooting daggers at Rio.

 

"Yes," Wanda insisted.

 

Rio gave a mock shrug, as if to say, You asked for it. 

 

"Fine," she purred. "Here’s something you’ve never told anyone but yourself." She leaned forward slightly, lowering her voice to an intimate, lethal whisper. "You’re cheating on your husband... with the hot Russian ballet teacher from the Arts campus. Natasha-something."

 

The words hit the table like a bomb. Silence. Dead, total silence. Even Alice and Jen stopped laughing, their jaws dropping. Wanda’s face went utterly blank. For a moment, Agatha thought she might flip the table. Or murder Rio right there with her bare hands.

 

"Who told you that?" Wanda asked, her voice deadly soft, her hands curling into fists against the wood.

 

"No one," Rio said sweetly. "I don’t need anyone to tell me anything. I see things, honey. I hear things. I collect things." She smiled, all teeth. "And incidentally... I was there. The day you kissed her under the old oak tree. Remember the security guard that offed himself in Block A? The one between the Library and the Arts Building?"

 

Wanda paled. "You were spying on us?"

 

"No," Rio shrugged innocently. "I was collecting."

 

Agatha slammed her hand over Rio’s mouth, cutting her off mid-sentence. "Okay! That’s enough!" she hissed, feeling her face blaze with secondhand embarrassment. "You proved your damn point, honey."

 

Rio’s lips curved into a smug smile against Agatha’s palm, but she allowed herself to be silenced. The rest of the table sat in stunned, horrified silence. Except for Jen and Alice, who were both struggling so hard not to collapse in hysterical laughter that their faces had turned bright red.

 

Wanda just glared daggers across the table. "You," she said to Rio, voice trembling slightly, "are dangerous."

 

Rio winked, utterly unbothered. Agatha didn’t know whether to laugh, cry, or throttle her on the spot. Probably all three. She sighed heavily, running a hand through her hair.

The heavy wooden door creaked open, and Agatha stepped into the hallway, the worn soles of her boots clicking softly against the stone floor. She tugged her deep blue overcoat tighter around her, the fabric stiff from the crisp, biting air that filtered in from the cracked windows. Underneath, her white blouse was neatly tucked into fitted purple slacks — elegant, effortless — but her shoulders sagged with exhaustion after the long class.

Wanda stood by the door, leaning casually against the opposite wall, arms crossed, mouth already twitching in mischief.

 

Agatha narrowed her eyes, gripping the stack of books tighter against her chest. "If you're here to judge me," she warned flatly, balancing the weight of the largest textbook in her palm, "I swear to God, Maximoff, I will throw this book at your face."

 

Wanda raised her hands in surrender, a smirk curving her lips. "No judgment," she promised, voice light. "Just... curiosity."

 

Agatha exhaled a long, slow breath through her nose, muttering something about nosy witches under her breath, before pushing the door to her office open and stepping aside. The familiar scent of parchment, ink, and cold coffee wrapped around her as she dumped the books onto her cluttered desk. Wanda followed, shutting the door behind them with a soft click. They stood there for a moment, the silence stretching thin.

 

"Did you know?" Wanda finally asked, her voice quieter now. "About me... and Natasha?"

 

Agatha peeled off her coat, revealing the crisp white blouse underneath, and slung it over the back of her chair with a practiced flick of her wrist. She leaned against the desk, arms folded.

 

"No," she said simply. Wanda blinked, caught off guard by the bluntness. "It’s none of my business," Agatha added, voice firm but not unkind. "You’re my friend, Wanda. Not my wife. Your private life? Not my concern."

 

She gave a small, dry laugh.

 

"And given everything going on in my own love life right now, believe me," Agatha continued, rolling her sleeves up, "I’m in no position to judge anyone."

 

Wanda visibly relaxed, tension bleeding from her posture. Her smile, small but genuine, finally returned. "Thanks," she said, voice low.

 

Agatha only nodded, brushing a stray curl behind her ear. But Wanda wasn’t done. She tilted her head, narrowing her eyes slightly, studying her with the precision of a surgeon.

 

"And what about you?" she asked, smile turning sly. "Since when are you into women?"

 

Agatha shrugged, her mouth twitching into something half-defensive, half-shy — an expression Wanda had never seen on her before.

 

"I don’t know," Agatha admitted honestly, eyes flickering toward the window as if the answer might be written in the clouds. “What I do know is that I've never liked men. I... My mother taught me to never really like anyone, she said it wasn't necessary. That I should just get married and follow the rules. I never stopped to think about what I really liked.

 

She fiddled with a pen on her desk, twirling it between her fingers. 

 

"It’s not like I sat down and made a decision one day. I find women attractive, I always have. But I never cared. It’s just..." She exhaled, struggling to explain the feeling clawing inside her. "It’s like being hungry. Or thirsty. Except worse. Like... if she’s not near me, I feel like I'm suffocating."

 

Her voice cracked slightly, and she dropped the pen, embarrassed.

 

"I sound like a fucking teenager," she muttered.

 

Wanda's heart softened immediately. She had never seen Agatha like this. Not with any man. Not even once.

 

She smiled warmly. "You’re adorable," Wanda said, and laughed when Agatha shot her a mortified glare.

 

Agatha grumbled under her breath, grabbing the pen again and pretending to scribble something just to have something to do with her hands. But the light mood didn’t last. Wanda leaned in slightly, lowering her voice.

 

"Then tell me something," she said. "If Rio was with you at the library... how did she see me and Natasha? And what exactly did she mean by... 'collecting'?"

 

Agatha stilled. The playful glint in her eyes dulled instantly, replaced by a cold, heavy seriousness that filled the room like a storm rolling in. She set the pen down carefully.

 

"Whenever Rio’s with me," Agatha said quietly, "she’s almost never just with me."

 

Wanda frowned, shifting uncomfortably in her chair. "What does that mean?"

 

Agatha leaned back against the desk, crossing her arms over her chest, her expression darkening. "She's working," she said, voice flat.

 

"Working... how?" Wanda pressed.

 

Agatha hesitated, weighing the words carefully on her tongue. Finally, she locked eyes with Wanda, the weight of centuries — lives lived and lost — pouring into her stare.

 

"Collecting," she repeated, voice barely above a whisper.

 

"Collecting what, Agatha?"

 

Agatha pushed off the desk, moving to the window. She watched the students outside for a long moment, their laughter distant, faintly echoing against the cold stone buildings.

 

Then she turned back to Wanda, her face pale but steady. "Souls," she said, the word falling like a blade between them.

 

Wanda inhaled sharply, sitting up straighter, her heart beginning to pound against her ribs.

 

"Rio..." Agatha continued, her voice dropping lower, rougher, "she’s not human. What I'm about to tell you is going to sound fucking insane, Wanda, but…"

 

Agatha stepped closer, her hands trembling slightly by her sides.

 

"She’s Death, Wanda," she said. "The literal embodiment of Death itself." Wanda’s mouth opened slightly, but no sound came out. "And..." Agatha’s voice cracked now, thick with emotion she couldn’t — didn’t want to — suppress, "I’m falling in love with her."

 

The confession hung in the air, vibrating with raw, terrible honesty. Wanda could only stare, breathless, as her friend — her strong, proud, invincible friend — looked ready to shatter into a thousand pieces.

 

"Death? Rio is Death? The Death you kept saying you were seeing and everyone thought you were losing your mind?"

 

Agatha nodded silently, a tight, almost fearful movement. She knew if she ever dared to tell Wanda the full truth — about being a witch in a past life, about Rio being bound to her through those ancient memories — Wanda would have her locked away without hesitation.

 

"One thing at a time," Agatha thought grimly. "Piece by piece."

 

"Agatha, is this some kind of foreplay between you two or... I don't know, some weird sexual fetish or...?"

 

Agatha let out a low, frustrated growl. Her hand twitched at her side before she rolled her shoulders back dramatically, fingers fussing with the cuff of her crisp white button-up shirt as if preparing for a duel.

 

"Wanda, what I'm about to do... Please, don't scream. And don't tell anyone."

 

"What the hell are you talking about?" Wanda narrowed her eyes, taking an instinctive step back, like she was bracing for Agatha to leap at her.

 

Agatha inhaled deeply, her chest rising and falling slowly. She closed her eyes, sinking into the chair with a weighted exhale, as though reaching deep into a part of herself long buried and dangerous.

 

Her voice came out in a whisper, soft enough that Wanda had to read her lips to understand. "Rio," Agatha breathed.

 

She knew — knew with every fiber of her being — that Rio would come. Rio always came when Agatha called.

The room shifted. The very air warmed, thick with the scent of lavender and honey, an almost overwhelming sweetness that wrapped around them like a comforting blanket. It wasn't a grim coldness, but a tangible love — a devotion so fierce it made the heart ache. And then Rio was there. Silent as a ghost, solid as stone. She appeared behind Agatha, her hands sliding gently onto Agatha's shoulders, her touch brimming with tenderness.

 

"My love?" Rio's voice was soft, almost reverent. She began massaging Agatha's tense shoulders, her entire focus locked solely on her.

 

Agatha opened her eyes and locked her gaze onto Wanda. Wanda stood frozen, mouth agape, skin bleached of all color. Her hands trembled as she stumbled backward, knocking into a bookshelf with a loud thud.

 

"Wanda?" Agatha called, her voice strained. "Are you okay?"

 

Only then did Rio seem to register Wanda's presence.

 

"Shit," Rio muttered, her affectionate demeanor slipping into sharp irritation. "Agatha, can you explain why you summoned me while a human, utterly clueless about what’s happening, is here staring at me?"

 

"I needed someone to tell me I'm not insane, Rio! I trust her."

 

“You did a terrible job, honey.”

 

Wanda finally found her voice, though it came out strangled. "Agatha, you’re out of your goddamn mind." She clutched her chest like she might faint. "I... I need water. I'm gonna be sick."

 

She stumbled sideways. Agatha bolted from her chair, rushing to catch Wanda before she collapsed.

 

"See? This is exactly why we don’t do this. We don’t tell humans," Rio said, throwing her arms up dramatically.

 

"Rio, shut up!" Agatha hissed under her breath, keeping her attention on Wanda. "Oh, come on! Stop being such a drama queen! You gave birth to twins behind your couch for Christ’s sake and—"

 

She froze mid-sentence. That memory... it wasn’t from this life. It was from before. Before everything. Panic shot through her veins. She couldn’t — mustn’t — say any more.

 

Wanda gripped Agatha’s face with both hands, frantic now. "Agatha, what the hell are you talking about?! You’re Billy's godmother! He was born in a hospital! Are you crazy?!"

 

Tears pricked at Wanda’s eyes, her nails digging slightly into Agatha’s skin in desperate fear.

 

"Tell me this is some kind of magic trick," Wanda demanded. "Tell me you didn’t summon Death herself — looking like your hot Puerto Rican girlfriend — like she’s some kind of obedient lapdog!"

 

Rio raised an eyebrow, crossing her arms. "Rude, not a lapdog" she said, voice low and dangerous. "I’m more like a loyal servant to my queen."

 

"Rio, not helping," Agatha barked. She turned to Wanda again, heart pounding. "She’s... loyal. That's it."

 

"Loyal? This has to be a joke," Wanda stammered, her hands shaking. "You’re screwing Death! You left hickeys all over Death’s neck, Agatha!"

 

Agatha turned beet red. Rio smirked with pride, tilting her head playfully. "She did an excellent job."

 

"Rio!" Agatha shot her a murderous glare. "Enough with the commentary."

 

Wanda’s knees buckled slightly as she sank back into a chair, staring at Agatha like she was a stranger. "You're dating Death," she whispered, her voice hoarse.

 

"We’re not dating," Agatha snapped, the denial sharp and desperate.

 

"Yet," Rio added with a lazy, wicked smile. "We have a date tonight."

 

Wanda's breathing began to steady, though her body remained rigid with suspicion. "Date? Agatha, you never go on dates. Not even with Ralph. What fuck is going on?!"

 

Agatha pressed her lips into a thin line, lowering her gaze. She could feel Wanda's judgment like a physical weight. "Ralph was a mistake, Wanda. You know I never loved him. My mother pushed me into that marriage."

 

"I'm not accusing you, motherfucker!" Wanda said gently, though concern furrowed her brow as she sat heavily in the nearest chair. "But do you have any idea how all of this looks to the outside world, Aggie?" Her voice cracked slightly with worry. "He's missing. Vanished. And you're... you're going on dates with Death."

 

Agatha winced, reaching for the bottled water Rio had retrieved from the small fridge. She knelt in front of Wanda, offering it with both hands like a peace offering.

 

"No one knows she's Death except you," Agatha said softly, trying to soothe her. "Maybe Lilia suspects something, but... that's it."

 

Rio kept her distance, sensing Wanda's fragile state. She closed her eyes and, without a word, released a subtle wave of calming scent — a gentle blend of wildflowers and the crisp bite of fresh snow. It filled the room quietly, weaving into the atmosphere and coaxing Wanda's panic into something slower, softer.

 

Wanda took a long sip of the water, her fingers trembling slightly around the plastic bottle. After a few moments, she asked, voice hoarse, "And the children? Your kids… do they know?"

 

Agatha hesitated, chewing on her lower lip until it reddened.

 

"It's complicated. They know Rio's not human. That she's... something. But not what she truly is." Agatha's voice cracked a little with emotion. "They — Nicky and Nick — they’re... they're biologically Rio’s too. They’re not Ralph's children. They never were. They're mine and Rio's."

 

Wanda choked on her sip of water, coughing hard. Her green eyes widened in stunned disbelief. "How, Agatha? That's impossible!"

 

Agatha glanced over her shoulder at Rio, who bit down on her lip to keep from making some smug or mischievous comment. She knew if she opened her mouth, Agatha would not hesitate to throw the water bottle at her head.

 

"Like I said," Agatha murmured, "it's complicated."

 

Rio shifted slightly, her fingers brushing over the edge of a nearby table absentmindedly, eyes never leaving Agatha. Her whole being ached to touch her — to reassure her — but she stayed put, unwilling to make Wanda’s recovery harder.

 

"But she’s not here to hurt anyone," Agatha said firmly, squeezing Wanda’s knee for emphasis.

 

Wanda set the water down with a small clunk, rubbing her face with both hands. "Then why is she here?"

 

Agatha's eyes softened, and her shoulders slumped as if the confession weighed more than she could bear. "Apparently... I summoned her. That day we were joking around with the Ouija board, asking about Ralph. My soul — without realizing — called her to me."

 

Wanda blinked, slow and stunned. "Why?"

 

"I'm still figuring that out, Wanda," Agatha admitted, her voice barely above a whisper. Shame and uncertainty tangled inside her, making her stomach twist. "And... I don't even know if I want to send her away." The words escaped before she could stop them. Her cheeks flushed instantly with embarrassment.

 

Across the room, Rio's heart thundered against her ribs. Agatha doesn't want me to leave, she thought, giddy enough to nearly float. She had to grip the table harder to keep herself grounded.

 

"But I promise you, Wanda," Agatha said, meeting her friend's eyes with a fierce determination, "Rio won't hurt anyone. It's not allowed."

The house had fallen into a rare, peaceful quiet — the kind that only happened when both kids were home, fed, and content. The late afternoon sunlight slanted through the windows, throwing warm golden patches across the hardwood floor. Agatha sat on the couch, twisting a strand of hair around her finger, her stomach flipping nervously. She had barely gotten the words out when Nicole’s head snapped up from her sketchbook.

 

"You want my help planning a date?" Nicole blinked slowly, like she was staring at some unknown species. Then, slowly, a grin split her face. "Holy crap, who are you and what have you done with my mom?"

 

Agatha flushed, flicking a throw pillow at her. "Don’t make me regret asking, Nicky."

 

Nicole giggled, dodging the pillow easily, her dark curls bouncing. She chewed her lip for a second, thinking hard, and then her face lit up.

 

"A museum," she said brightly, eyes sparkling. "Take Mama to a museum!"

 

Agatha tilted her head, surprised. "A museum?"

 

Nicole nodded enthusiastically, scooting closer. Her voice dropped into a more tender tone, almost reverent. "Mama's lived through so many millennia, Mom. She knows all the stories. She used to tell them to me... when I was still in your belly."

 

Agatha's breath caught. She didn’t remember Rio ever doing that. Not physically. Not consciously. But she did remember those nights — nights when Nicole had been kicking and restless, only to suddenly calm, warmth and serenity wrapping around them both like a blanket. The memory filled her chest with something sweet and aching.

 

"She would tell me stories of stars being born," Nicole continued, her voice soft and dreamy, "and of oceans carving out mountains. She would hum old songs, too. I couldn't understand the words back then, but it made me feel... safe."

 

Agatha swallowed around the sudden tightness in her throat. She reached out and tucked a loose strand of hair behind Nicole's ear.

 

"And for dinner," Nicole said, brightening again, "take her somewhere Mexican! Just... not too spicy. Mama's a total baby when it comes to hot peppers."

 

Agatha chuckled "Seriously?"

 

"Oh yeah," Nicole said with a knowing nod. "I saw her once cry trying a jalapeño popper. Total meltdown."

 

Agatha laughed, the sound bubbling out of her without permission, and Nicole grinned proudly.

 

"Just," Nicole said, her voice turning serious, "don't get all weird about it. Mama loved you. Loves you more than anything."

 

Nicole flopped sideways, curling into Agatha's lap like a cat, resting her head against her mother's stomach.

 

"If you took her to a parking lot and gave her a sandwich and orange juice, she'd still think it was perfect."

 

Agatha smiled, smoothing a hand over her daughter's hair, savoring the simple, grounding warmth of the moment.

 

"One rule, though," Nicole said, her voice muffled against Agatha's sweater. "Never take her to a cemetery."

 

Agatha stiffened slightly. Her fingers paused mid-stroke.

 

"Why?" she asked, a faint edge of unease in her voice. "She’s…" Agatha cut herself off quickly. Nicole still didn't know the full truth about Rio — who, and what, she truly was.

 

Nicole shrugged, unconcerned. "She hates ghosts. Says they’re annoying. If you take her there, she’ll spend the whole night arguing with them and forget you’re even there."

 

Agatha let out a breathless laugh, shaking her head. "Okay, no cemeteries. Got it."

 

Nicole tilted her head up, her big, wise eyes locking onto Agatha’s with startling clarity.

 

"I'm glad you're happy, Mom," she said softly. "It makes me happy too." She pointed a small finger at Agatha’s heart. "I can feel it, you know. Here. It's warm. Calm."

 

Agatha’s heart squeezed painfully at the sincerity in her daughter's face. "You’re only twelve, baby," she said, stroking Nicole’s cheek. "What do you know about love?"

 

Nicole smiled up at her, a little sadly, like she knew more than she should.

 

"Mama used to tell me," she whispered. "I was born from your love. That’s why she found you."

 

Agatha blinked back sudden tears.

 

"She used to call me 'Agape' when I was still inside you," Nicole said, her voice full of wonder. "It means 'love' in Greek." Nicole’s tiny fingers traced a small circle over Agatha’s heart. "She would whisper to me: ftiagmeno apó agápi. Made of love."

 

Agatha bent down, pressing a kiss to Nicole’s forehead, her hand trembling slightly against her daughter's skin.

 

"She wasn’t wrong, sweetheart," Agatha whispered.

.

.

.

The room was filled with golden light, the kind that only comes at the very end of the day, when everything feels softer, slower, almost sacred. And for the first time in a long time, Agatha allowed herself to believe that maybe — just maybe — there was still a future worth reaching for.

The evening of the date arrived faster than Agatha anticipated. She stood in front of her open closet, glaring at the array of clothing as if the right outfit might magically leap into her arms. The air in her bedroom was thick with the scent of lavender detergent and a faint trace of anxiety.

 

"Okay, Agatha," she muttered to herself, flipping through hangers. "You’re not interviewing for a job. You’re not going to war. You’re going on a date. With your..." She paused, the word catching in her throat. "Your maybe-future-girlfriend-who-also-happens-to-be-Death."

 

Her hands shook slightly as she yanked out a few options, holding them up to herself in the mirror. A black dress — too funeral. A red blouse — too aggressive. A soft cream sweater — too casual?

 

Nicole peered around the doorframe, chewing on a cookie. She watched silently for a moment before giggling. "You’re being so extra, Mom."

 

Agatha scowled playfully at her reflection. "Help me or leave me to die."

 

"You’re dramatic," Nicole said, hopping onto the bed and crossing her legs. "Wear the green one. It matches your blue eyes. Mama always said you had 'eyes like spring after a storm'."

 

Agatha stared at the green dress — a soft, flowing thing she rarely wore because it made her feel... vulnerable. Seen.

Perfect.

She slipped it on carefully, smoothing the fabric over her hips, her heartbeat drumming in her ears.

 

Nicole gave a thumbs-up. "Beautiful."

 

Agatha took a shaky breath, forcing a smile. She turned to grab her shoes, the room tilting slightly with nerves.

 

"You’re going to be fine," Nicole said firmly, hopping off the bed to hug her from behind. "She's gonna look at you like you hung the stars."

 

Agatha squeezed her daughter's small hands and smiled at their reflection in the mirror. "Thanks, baby."

 

She just hoped she could survive the night without making a complete fool of herself. Because somehow, deep down, Agatha knew — this night was the beginning of everything.

 

While Agatha struggled upstairs, Rio was busy descending into a full-blown panic attack in Nick's bedroom.

Nick, perched casually on his bed, kicked his legs back and forth, sipping from a juice box, watching the chaos unfold with mild amusement. His room smelled faintly of crayons, soap, and the sweet artificial tang of apple juice.

Rio, in stark contrast, looked like a tornado trapped in human form. She snapped her fingers — again — and another outfit materialized on her body.

 

"When I grow up, will I have cool powers like that?" Nick asked between sips, his tone completely casual.

 

Rio grunted, tugging at the hem of a black, sparkly dress that clung a little too desperately to her curves. "Not up to me, kiddo. I don't make the rules." She spun around dramatically, holding her arms out. "Okay. This one?"

 

Nick squinted, wrinkling his nose. "Is Mom taking you to one of those places with the flashing lights and bad music?"

 

Rio blinked. "A clubhouse?"

 

"That's the word!" Nick snapped his fingers in triumph.

 

Rio muttered a curse under her breath. Sometimes she forgot he was only seven. "Problem is," she grumbled, snapping her fingers again and changing into something even worse, "your mother didn't tell me anything."

 

"Ask her."

 

"It's supposed to be a surprise, genius." 

 

Nick shrugged like the fate of the universe was of absolutely no concern to him. "Then wear something simple. Pants, sneakers, polo shirt. Works for me every time."

 

Rio groaned, tossing a hand dramatically against her forehead. "You are seven years old, Nicholas."

 

"And you're almost late," he pointed out, tapping the face of his roaring dinosaur alarm clock. "It's nearly seven o'clock."

 

Rio let out a strangled sound — half snarl, half whimper — before throwing her arms up in defeat. "Fine! This or nothing!"

 

In a snap, her final outfit settled around her: a silky black dress that hugged her body just enough to look elegant, but not desperate. The fabric fell to her knees, slightly shorter on the right thigh, with delicate straps brushing against her shoulders. It hinted at her figure without screaming for attention. A pair of modest heels completed the look — just tall enough to be graceful, but practical enough to run if necessary. A subtle shimmer of makeup flickered into place: soft eyeliner, a kiss of color on her lips, a faint glow on her cheeks.

 

Nick gave an approving nod. "Now you look good! Less 'girl from another planet', more 'I want to marry Nick's mom,'" he said proudly, throwing both thumbs up.

 

Rio laughed despite herself, smoothing a hand over the dress. 

 

"She'll like it," Nick added, voice serious for a second. "Now stop freaking out and go wait for her downstairs. And take the flowers."

 

Rio squinted at him. "Where the hell did you get that idea?"

 

"One of Nicole's cheesy teen romance books. You should monitor what she reads, by the way."

 

Rio snorted, arching a brow at him. "Tattling on your sister now?"

 

Nick swung his little legs and slurped the last of his juice noisily, flashing a wide, mischievous grin. "Will you raise my allowance?"

 

"No."

 

"Then I'm done talking. Now go before Mom dumps you for someone with actual fashion sense."

 

Rio gasped dramatically. "She would never! No one could ever compete with me."

 

She strutted out of the room, shoulders squared, confidence forced but convincing. Nick watched her go, grinning to himself before flopping backward onto the bed with a soft whump.

 

"So cocky," he muttered under his breath, tossing the empty juice box toward the trash can with lazy precision. "She’s lucky Mom loves her."

.

.

.

Rio stood near the entrance, clutching the bouquet of flowers like a lifeline, her palms sweating slightly against the delicate wrapping. Her heart thudded painfully inside her chest, faster than any battle, any confrontation she’d ever faced. A strange, sweet anxiety coiled in her stomach, rendering her — Death herself — utterly useless.

When Agatha finally descended the stairs, Rio forgot how to breathe. The sight of her — that soft green dress clinging perfectly to her curves, the warm glow of her skin in the golden light — was enough to completely short-circuit Rio’s mind. She stood frozen, mouth slightly parted, black eyes wide, drinking in every inch of Agatha like a starved woman. She didn't even notice her grip tightening on the flowers until Agatha reached the last step, tilting her head with a small, knowing smile.

 

"Are those for me, Rio?" Agatha purred, her voice slipping around Rio like silk. She dragged out the name deliberately, a wicked tease that sent a full-body shiver through Rio.

 

Rio blinked, struggling to remember how speaking worked. "Ah... Yes!" she stammered, thrusting the bouquet forward awkwardly. "They’re — they’re for you. Totally for you."

 

Her brain scrambled for a cover as she flicked a glance upwards. Nick was perched on the staircase, vigorously shaking his head, mouthing "No!" with exaggerated movements.

 

"From Nick's..." Rio began, then faltered, catching the warning gleam in Nick’s eyes.

 

"Your idea?" Agatha asked sweetly, one brow arching, her smile growing sharper — predatory.

 

Rio coughed into her fist, her cheeks burning. "Yes. Mine."

 

Agatha leaned in slightly, close enough that Rio could smell her — hints of jasmine, vanilla, and something unmistakably Agatha. The scent made Rio’s knees nearly buckle.

 

"I thought you couldn’t lie, baby," Agatha murmured, her voice thick with amusement and command, tilting her head just enough to make Rio feel pinned in place, prey caught in the careful gaze of a queen.

 

Rio swallowed hard, fighting the desperate urge to drop to her knees right there. "It’s not a lie," she said hoarsely, "if I say that the idea to create each flower with the exact shade, fragrance, and softness to not overpower you was mine."

 

A slow, deliberate smile curled Agatha’s lips.

 

"Nuances," she murmured, accepting the bouquet, letting her fingers brush over Rio’s trembling hand longer than necessary. The electric contact burned down Rio’s spine, making her pulse roar in her ears. "You know how to play with words, don't you?" Agatha teased, voice dipped in honey, but her eyes — those stormy eyes — were sharp, dominant.

 

"It’s a gift," Rio whispered, unable to resist the smile tugging helplessly at her mouth.

 

Agatha’s gaze softened — just a fraction — before she lowered her lashes demurely and extended her free hand, palm up. "Shall we?"

 

The invitation wrapped around Rio's senses, sweet and commanding all at once. She barely managed a nod, stepping closer and slipping her hand into Agatha’s. The warmth of her skin made Rio want to fall to her knees again, to press her lips to that palm and vow herself to her forever.

 

"Yes, please," Rio said, voice rough, almost pleading. "Before your children embarrass me to death."

 

“My now, hum?” Agatha chuckled low in her throat and turned her head toward the staircase. Nicole and Nick were both there, beaming like proud, mischievous conspirators.

 

"Don’t do anything I wouldn’t do!" Nicole called out, a wicked gleam in her eye. "Be back before 10 PM, and no alcohol!"

 

Agatha rolled her eyes, squeezing Rio’s hand. "Nicole," she said in a dangerously sweet tone, "go to hell."

 

Nicole grinned even wider, victorious. "I’ve waited my whole life to throw that line back at you, Mom. Have a great date!"

 

Rio groaned under her breath, letting Agatha pull her gently toward the door. "Your kids terrify me," Rio muttered.

 

"Good," Agatha said, giving her a sidelong smile that promised far more trouble later. "They’re supposed to. Because they're also yours."

 

Outside, the evening air wrapped around them, soft and cool, carrying the faint scent of blooming flowers and fresh-cut grass. Rio inhaled deeply, trying to ground herself, trying not to show how badly she was already crumbling under Agatha's effortless dominance.

 

Tonight wasn’t just a date. It was surrender.

The car slid into a parking spot just across the street from the museum, the old building lit beautifully against the velvet night sky. Agatha killed the engine and started reaching for the door handle, but a warm, trembling hand wrapped around hers, anchoring her in place.

She turned her head, her gaze falling onto Rio. Rio’s fingers were tight around Agatha's, her skin hot, almost feverish to the touch. Her eyes — those molten amber eyes — seemed to glow under the dim light of the dashboard, filled with something raw, something vulnerable.

 

"You want something, honey?" Agatha asked, her voice teasing, yet soft, sensing the crackling nerves in the air between them.

 

Rio shifted closer, her breath hitching.

 

"Can I..." she swallowed, the words tangling in her throat. "Can I kiss you? You look so beautiful, Agatha. So perfect. It's almost sinful just sitting here, staring at you and doing nothing. Like I'm throwing a gift from God away."

 

Agatha's heart gave a painful, sweet squeeze. She smiled, slow and decadent, and reached up to cup Rio's face. Her thumb traced lightly along Rio’s cheekbone, feeling the subtle tremble under her skin. Rio instinctively leaned into the touch, a soft, nearly inaudible whimper escaping her. She nuzzled Agatha's palm like a starving kitten, her golden eyes fluttering closed for a moment.

 

"Uhm..." Agatha hummed, her tone playful as she dragged a teasing finger over Rio's lips, feeling them part slightly under her touch. "You always lean in like such a needy little thing. Like a stray kitten who hasn't been fed."

 

Rio opened her eyes, heavy-lidded and filled with desperate affection.

 

"But usually," Agatha continued, her smirk deepening, "the kiss comes at the end of the date."

 

Rio gave a low, frustrated growl in her throat, a sound so soft and broken it sent a delicious shiver down Agatha's spine.

 

"I still have your lip prints and teeth marks on my neck from last night. Just because the public can't see it, it doesn't mean that is gone! So don't play coy now, Agatha Harkness," Rio muttered, her voice rough with longing.

 

Agatha threw her head back and laughed — a rich, glorious sound that filled the small car and made Rio's heart ache with want. Without giving herself time to think, Agatha bent down and captured Rio's mouth in a quick, hot kiss. It was a tease, a wicked promise. The moment Rio tried to deepen it, Agatha pulled away, a wicked gleam in her eye.

 

"I'm a respectable woman, you know," Agatha said, voice thick with mock innocence. "You'll have to work harder if you want more tonight."

 

Rio let out a strangled groan, slumping against the seat as Agatha stepped out of the car with feline grace. The door slammed shut with a satisfying thud, leaving Rio reeling inside. Moments later, Agatha appeared by her door, bowing slightly in an exaggerated, elegant gesture, her hand extended like a courtly knight.

 

"Milady?" she said, voice dripping with playful authority.

 

Rio took her hand with a huff, rising from the seat with as much dignity as she could muster.

 

"You're still the same manipulative witch," she muttered under her breath, unable to suppress the fond smile tugging at her mouth.

 

Agatha’s arms slipped easily around her waist, drawing her close. "And yet," Agatha whispered against her ear, "it didn’t stop you from crossing the multiverse for me, did it?"

 

Rio's breath hitched. Her hands fisted weakly in the fabric of Agatha's dress.

 

"No," she admitted, voice cracking just slightly. "Nothing could."

 

For a second, they just stood there, wrapped around each other in the cool New York night, the faint sounds of traffic and the rustling of distant leaves barely reaching them.

 

Then Agatha pulled back, brushing a kiss against Rio’s temple. "Come on," she said. "I'm dying to hear your stories."

 

Rio stiffened, panic flaring hot in her chest. Stories. Her mind flashed, unbidden, to Eva’s warning, to the guilt simmering inside her like a poison. For a second, she thought Agatha meant those stories — the ones soaked in blood and betrayal.

 

"About what?" Rio asked sharply, panic making her voice too high.

 

Agatha, oblivious to her turmoil, pointed across the street to the brightly lit sign: MUNICIPAL MUSEUM OF NEW YORK.

 

Rio let out a breathless laugh, her whole body sagging with relief. "Oh!" she gasped, her mouth forming a perfect 'O'.

 

Agatha raised a brow, amused. "What did you think I meant?"

 

"Nothing," Rio lied quickly, lacing their fingers together and tugging Agatha toward the entrance. "Come on! I want to introduce you to some old friends from the Jurassic."

 

Agatha allowed herself to be pulled along, her smile lingering. The night had only just begun — and beneath all the laughter, all the teasing, something darker and heavier simmered, waiting. But for now, there was only this: the warmth of their joined hands, the thrum of possibility, and the sparkling lights of the museum welcoming them inside.

.

.

.

The museum air was crisp and faintly perfumed with old stone, varnish, and time itself. Rio dragged Agatha eagerly from one exhibit to another, her fingers laced tightly with Agatha’s as she practically vibrated with excitement. Her voice was a soft, unstoppable current in the vast halls, gushing with endless stories.

 

"This," Rio said, pulling Agatha toward an ancient pottery collection, "was actually slightly different in another life. The designs were more geometric."

 

She flashed Agatha a proud, dazzling smile, like a kid showing off a prized toy.

 

"And this?" She pointed to a primitive map. "Total fabrication. It wasn't like that at all. Humans are so creative with what they don't know."

 

Her happiness was palpable — the way she glowed, the way she barely touched the ground when she walked, how her amber eyes shimmered every time she shared a piece of herself. Agatha followed silently, her heart swelling with something too big, too warm to name.

They finally stopped in front of a meteorite display, encased in shimmering glass and bathed in soft blue light. The massive, dark stone glistened like a fallen star.

Rio released Agatha's hand and approached it revently, fingertips ghosting over the barrier.

 

"This one," Rio breathed, her voice turning low and reverent, "came from a planet humans will never even imagine. A world that bloomed with creatures made of light and sound. When it shattered, those beings died screaming songs that no ear here could ever comprehend."

 

Her voice cracked just slightly, emotion bleeding into every word.

Agatha didn't hear the museum's low hum or the soft murmurs of other visitors anymore. She only saw Rio — this ancient, beautiful soul pouring herself out like a prayer. She realized, in that still moment, what made her different now from the Agatha she had once been: she would never again tell Rio to leave.

Without thinking, without caring, Agatha closed the distance between them, grasped Rio's jaw between her hands, and crushed their mouths together. Gasps erupted from a few nearby tourists, but Agatha couldn't have cared less. She only tasted Rio — the faint bitterness of her lipstick, the salt of almost-shed tears, the trembling life of her. Rio stumbled back a step, stunned. Her lips were flushed and parted when Agatha finally, reluctantly, pulled away.

 

"Ahn..." Rio murmured, her voice thick with shock and wonder. "Not that I'm complaining but—"

 

"I love you," Agatha said, the words tumbling over each other in a rush. Her hands trembled slightly where they cradled Rio's face. "Don't leave. I don't care what memories come. I don't care about the pain. I want you."

 

Tears welled in Rio's amber eyes, clinging to her lashes. "And what if there are things I need to tell you? Things that might hurt you? Things that might be... my fault?"

 

Agatha's thumb brushed a tear before it could fall, gentle and sure.

 

"What if," she whispered, tucking a strand of Rio's hair carefully behind her ear, "we live this together first... and figure the rest out after?"

 

"Agatha—"

 

"Rio," Agatha interrupted, her voice dipping into a dangerous, commanding softness that made Rio’s knees weaken. She leaned in close, almost purring against Rio's skin. "Do you want to end up like that herd of dinosaurs you told me about?"

 

"Triceratops," Rio corrected automatically, a broken little laugh escaping her.

 

"Those Triceratops," Agatha repeated, nipping lightly at Rio's earlobe, "who spent their last days worrying about the bright star in the sky and forgot to live at all."

 

Rio closed her eyes, her chest heaving.

 

"No..." she whispered, haunted by the memory of those gentle beasts dying scared and confused.

 

"Then," Agatha said firmly, pressing their foreheads together, "whatever it is you're carrying, baby, you tell me later. Tonight is ours."

 

"You're going to send me away," Rio said, her voice cracking. "Again."

 

Agatha growled low in her throat — a warning, a reprimand. "Enough," she said, pressing her face into Rio's shoulder, breathing her in. Warmth. Salt. Life.

 

She pulled back slightly, cupping Rio's chin and forcing her to meet her gaze.

 

"Rio," she said, and the tone — sharp, commanding — made Rio’s spine straighten automatically. "I didn't plan this date to play 'good Christian' and only sleep with you after marriage. I planned this because it was the only way I could show you that all your talk about reincarnation, fate, and connections? I believe it. I believe you."

 

She leaned closer, her breath hot against Rio's mouth.

 

"I wore this dress, put on the best damn lingerie I own, and yes, I even shaved everything," she hissed, between clenched teeth, her voice low and sultry. "So don't you dare mess this up for me now."

 

Rio's eyes widened slightly, her throat bobbing with a hard swallow.

 

"Now," Agatha continued, her fingers tapping lightly against Rio’s lips, "you're going to be good and behave for me tonight, you’re going to shove all those intrusive thoughts deep, deep down, and go back to rambling like the adorable nerd you are. Talk to me about — I don't know — that turtle over there."

 

Rio blinked rapidly, her mouth twitching toward a smile. "It's a tortoise."

 

"Rio," Agatha growled warningly.

 

"Okay, okay!" Rio laughed, light finally returning to her eyes. "Let's talk about the tortoise."

 

Agatha shook her head, exasperated but fond. "You're like a child sometimes!"

 

"You love it," Rio teased, bumping her shoulder against Agatha's.

 

And for the first time that night, Rio let herself believe that maybe — just maybe — they could have this.

 

They could have everything.

 

Chapter End Notes

Guys, if I don't reply to the comment, it doesn't mean I didn't read it. I'm always reading. Love you.

Chapter 10: Chapter 10

The restaurant was a hidden gem tucked away between towering buildings, its brightly colored facade glowing warmly against the evening chill. Inside, the scent of roasted peppers, cumin, and fresh lime clung thick to the air. Strings of lights crisscrossed the ceiling, casting everything in a soft, golden haze. Agatha led Rio to a cozy booth in the corner, sliding into the seat with a grace that made Rio's stomach tighten painfully. Rio followed, her hands fidgeting with the hem of her dress as she tried — and failed — to keep her eyes off Agatha. The waitress appeared quickly, dropping off menus with a bright smile. Rio barely glanced at hers. Her attention was glued, helplessly, to the woman across from her.

 

Agatha's lips curled into a slow, dangerous smile. "You're staring, baby," she murmured, voice pitched low enough to make Rio's skin pebble with heat.

 

Rio shifted, clearing her throat. "Can't help it. You look like..." She waved a hand helplessly. "Something no one should ever be allowed to touch."

 

Agatha leaned forward, resting her chin on her hand, her gaze heavy and knowing. "But you can touch." Rio's breath hitched. She gripped the edge of the table harder. "Just not here," Agatha added wickedly, dragging her tongue slowly along the edge of her bottom lip.

 

Rio groaned under her breath, slumping back against the booth. "Cruel woman," she muttered. Agatha merely smiled, the glint in her stormy eyes promising far worse to come.

 

When the food arrived — tacos, enchiladas, rice, and beans — the spicy aromas made Rio's nose twitch. She eyed the bright red salsa suspiciously.

 

Agatha caught the look and smirked. "Relax, baby. I ordered the mild one. I’d rather not watch you cry over jalapeños again."

 

Rio huffed indignantly but picked up a taco anyway, biting into it carefully. The flavors exploded on her tongue — savory, bright, a little heat dancing at the edges — but manageable. She moaned softly in approval.

 

Agatha laughed, a rich, indulgent sound. "Good?"

 

"Heavenly," Rio said around another bite. "You’re not just beautiful, you're a genius."

 

Agatha cocked her head, feigning surprise. "Was that a compliment and an admission of my superiority in one sentence?"

 

Rio wiped her mouth, licking her fingers clean with slow, deliberate strokes that made Agatha's thighs press tightly together under the table.

 

"Don't get cocky," Rio murmured, her eyes dark with mischief. "You’ve still got to survive dessert."

 

Agatha arched a brow, intrigued. "Dessert?"

 

"Mm-hmm." Rio leaned in, voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper. "I may or may not have plans for you involving something sweet, messy, and totally sinful."

 

Agatha’s mouth went dry. She sipped her margarita slowly, trying to hide the flush creeping up her neck.

 

Rio's foot brushed hers under the table, a teasing little nudge. "You okay, darling? You look a little flushed," Rio teased, her smile downright predatory now.

 

Agatha narrowed her eyes, tapping her nails lightly against her glass.

 

"Careful," she said softly, voice like velvet-wrapped steel. "If you keep teasing me, I'll make sure you regret it."

 

Rio's pupils dilated beautifully. "Promise?"

 

Agatha's answering smile was pure danger.

They ate slowly, savoring every bite, every glance, every brush of fingers over the table. Time seemed to stretch and slow between them, every sensation heightened — the spicy tang lingering on their tongues, the scratch of the rough napkin against their fingertips, the low hum of mariachi music swirling in the background.

 

Halfway through their meal, Rio wiped her mouth and leaned back, grinning. "You know," she said, "the first time I ever had tacos, it was in Mexico, obviously. But it wasn't just any tacos."

 

Agatha smiled, swirling her drink lazily. "Oh? Do tell."

 

Rio's grin widened. "There was this little old lady. Must’ve been at least ninety. Ran a taco stand in the middle of nowhere — one of those places you’d drive past if you blinked too long."

 

Agatha leaned in, intrigued.

 

"Anyway," Rio continued, laughing softly, "I showed up to... well, to collect her soul."

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow. "Romantic."

 

"Very," Rio said dryly. "Only she refused. Flat out. Told me — and I quote: 'I'm not dying until I finish feeding all these idiots properly.'"

 

Agatha snorted into her drink.

 

"And she meant it," Rio said, eyes gleaming. "She kept cooking. And cooking. And glaring at me like I was the worst inconvenience of her entire existence."

 

"Did you at least get a taco out of it?"

 

"She threw one at me," Rio said proudly. "Hit me square in the face. Best taco I ever tasted."

 

Agatha shook her head, laughing. "You got assaulted with Mexican food and called it a win."

 

"It was a spiritual experience," Rio said solemnly, placing a hand over her heart. "She finally let go three days later. But not before teaching me how to make her secret salsa."

 

Agatha wiped a tear from her eye, still laughing. "You’re unbelievable."

 

Rio leaned forward, eyes gleaming. "You love it."

 

Agatha’s answering look was soft and heated all at once. "I do."

 

The tension simmered low between them again, but it was different now — gentler, richer. Not just lust, but something warmer, something binding.

When dessert arrived — a decadent plate of churros drizzled with chocolate and caramel — Rio’s eyes lit up like a child on Christmas morning.

 

"Oh, this was worth crossing dimensions for," she said, grabbing one and taking an exaggerated bite, chocolate smearing the corner of her mouth.

 

Agatha bit her lip to suppress a laugh — and the sudden, overwhelming urge to devour her whole. Instead, she reached across the table slowly, wiping the smudge from Rio’s lip with her thumb. Rio caught her hand in hers and kissed the pad of her thumb, holding Agatha’s gaze with a hunger that made Agatha’s stomach flip.

 

"You're playing with fire," Agatha warned, her voice low and dangerous.

 

Rio smiled sweetly, the very picture of innocence — if innocence had molten gold for eyes. "Burn me."

 

Agatha laughed, a low, sinful sound that promised that when they left this restaurant, there would be no more holding back. No more teasing. Tonight, they were finally going to devour each other, heart, soul, and body.

As Agatha waited at the counter to pay for their dinner, Rio lingered behind, rocking back and forth on her heels, her hands tucked behind her back like a mischievous child. She couldn’t stay still; the energy buzzing inside her demanded to spill out. So she did what she always did when she was nervous or too full of life: she talked.

 

"Did you know," she said to no one in particular, her voice low and playful, "that chocolate was considered the food of gods long before humans made it a dessert? I met the Mayans once — very serious about their chocolate." She chuckled under her breath. "They'd be horrified by Hershey bars."

 

She wandered a few steps closer to Agatha, who was fishing through her purse, pretending not to listen but smiling to herself.

 

"And once," Rio continued, picking up a brightly colored pepper from a decorative basket near the counter, "someone challenged me to eat the hottest chili in the world. I agreed. I almost cried."

 

Behind her, a small noise — half cough, half chuckle — made Rio turn her head. An old man stood behind them in line, no taller than Rio's shoulder. His weathered skin was lined with deep, beautiful wrinkles, and his eyes — a sharp, dancing brown — held a lifetime of stories. His gray hat was tucked under one arm, and he listened, utterly baffled, to Rio’s enthusiastic ramblings.

 

"Jóvenes," he muttered in Spanish, shaking his head as if only the folly of youth could explain such nonsense.

 

Rio grinned, tilting her head mischievously toward him.

 

"La amo, señor," she said, switching effortlessly into Spanish, her voice softening. "Tengo que contarle muchas historias. No quiero que se aburra conmigo."

 

The old man’s stern face cracked into a slow, knowing smile. He responded in heavily accented English, his voice rich and gravelly.

 

"That is how I conquered Amélia, my wife. I talked. Too much." His eyes twinkled. "When I left for long trips and returned, she said I spoke even more. So..." he shrugged. "She kept me close. To make me talk less."

 

Rio laughed warmly, crossing her arms and leaning in slightly.

 

"Women are ingenious, no?" she teased, one eyebrow arching dramatically. "Always planning."

 

Behind the counter, Agatha’s head snapped up.

 

"Rio, honey," she said warningly, her voice laced with that particular brand of command that made Rio’s stomach flip.

 

Rio flashed the old man a quick smile and whispered in Spanish, "I told you so!"

 

Agatha finished paying with a practiced flick of her card, then grabbed Rio’s hand with a firm grip and tugged her outside into the cool night.

The parking lot was mostly empty, quiet except for the distant hum of passing traffic. Rio barely had time to catch her breath before Agatha spun, pinning her between the car and herself with an easy, dominant grace.

 

Agatha's palm braced against the metal near Rio's head, her body radiating heat and intent. "Ingenious, am I?" Agatha murmured, her voice like a silken whip.

 

Rio licked her lips, heart hammering. "It was a compliment," she said defensively, pressing her back against the car like it could somehow save her.

 

Agatha's mouth curved into a slow, dangerous smile. She leaned in, her breath brushing Rio's ear, making her shiver deliciously.
