The silence Eva left behind was thunderous. It rang in Agatha's ears like aftershocks, echoing louder than any slam of a door could have. Her breathing was shallow, almost forced, as if her lungs couldn’t quite decide if they belonged to her. The office was warm but her skin had gone cold. Her hands trembled slightly at her sides, curled and stiff, like she didn’t trust them to move.

 

Rio stood still, as if turned to stone. Amber eyes dimmed but alert, lips parted like she wanted to speak, but no sound came out.

Agatha turned to her slowly. The weight in her gaze was crushing. Anger. Confusion. Pain. All boiling quietly under the surface, restrained only by the force of will Agatha had spent a lifetime perfecting.

 

"You knew."

 

Rio flinched, just a little. "Agatha, I swear to you, I didn’t. Not this. Not what she said. I was told the rules, the boundaries, the expectations. I don’t remember anything from before I... woke up. My purpose was handed to me, and I never questioned it."

 

"So you never thought to ask what you were made of? What you were missing?" Her voice was sharp, slicing through the air like a knife. "That means it isn’t love, Rio. Not really. I’m just a fucking cosmic magnet. The other half of your puzzle. Something broken that made you feel whole."

 

She shook her head and took a shaky step back, her voice wobbling with the weight of what she tried not to feel.

 

"So that’s why you looked at me like that since the first moment. That’s why you couldn't leave even when I told you to. Not because you loved me. Because something inside you was screaming to take back what was yours."

 

Her lips trembled. The tears brimmed now, swimming against the fury in her stare.

 

"So all this time, all this life we built... it’s not even a choice to you. It’s a gravitational pull."

 

"No!" Rio took her face in both hands, desperate, fierce. "No, Agatha. You think I don’t know the difference? I’ve held your broken body in the past life. I’ve watched you die. I’ve guided your soul home. I know what I feel. I’d trade everything — everything I am, everything I was created to be — just to keep waking up next to you. I love you, not because I need to. But because I fucking want to."

 

Agatha didn't answer. She only stared at her, and in that silence, Rio began to move away, her hands trembling as she released Agatha's face.

 

"If this is too much," Rio whispered, her voice nearly breaking, "I understand. I can go. I just... I'm sorry. I never wanted to hurt you."

 

She turned. Agatha grabbed her wrist.

 

Hard.

 

"Don’t you dare walk out on me."

 

Rio turned, startled. Agatha pulled her into a crushing hug, burying her face in Rio’s shoulder, breathing in her scent like it would ground her. Lavender and frost. Familiar. Steadying.

 

"Stay here, you idiot. I'm just losing my shit, okay? I'm still human. Still hormonal. Still under-caffeinated."

 

Rio let out a broken laugh against her temple. "That’s something I wouldn’t trade my immortality for."

 

Agatha snorted, her lips brushing Rio’s neck. She pulled back just enough to press a kiss to the skin below her jaw.

 

"Come on," she muttered. "I need food. And I have something to tell you."

 

Rio’s eyes flickered with worry. She studied Agatha’s face, gauging every flicker of muscle.

 

"You’re not pregnant again, are you? Because if you are, we’re getting me some cosmic birth control and maybe putting a hex on my own damn fingers."

 

"Oh my God, Rio!" Agatha shoved her, mortified. Her face turned bright red. "Shut the hell up!"

 

Rio laughed, warm and loud and full of life. Agatha rolled her eyes, but the weight in her chest loosened just a bit.

There were still worlds to burn. Truths to face. Ralph to find. But for now, they had each other. And lunch.

 

 

Rio hadn’t realized just how ravenous she was until the scent of roasted herbs and garlic butter hit her as they stepped into the quiet restaurant tucked away on a cobbled corner. The place was all warm wood and golden light, the air thick with the scent of sizzling fat, fresh bread, and sweet wine. Her stomach growled like an ancient beast, and she didn’t even hesitate to order everything: starters, mains, dessert — the works. Now, she was slumped back in her chair, spooning strawberry shortcake into her mouth like it was a divine offering.

 

Agatha watched her with both amusement and mild horror. Her brow furrowed as she tilted her head.

 

“In what celestial cage were you locked up?” she asked dryly, watching Rio demolish the dessert.

 

Without missing a beat, Rio lifted the hem of her shirt slightly and revealed the thin tattooed vines curling along her ribs. One of the tiny etched leaves had turned brittle gray and was already flaking at the edge.

 

“One reality is dying as we speak,” she said matter-of-factly, her voice tinged with fatigue. “It’s exhausting. Even for me.”

 

Agatha’s smirk faded as she leaned in, eyes tracing the fading mark. “Oh,” she breathed, the sound more an ache than a word. She watched the leaf crumple inward, like time had crushed it. Then Rio dropped the hem and picked her spoon back up.

 

“I can wait to talk,” Agatha offered softly, but Rio shook her head.

 

“No, my love,” she said, dabbing sugar from her lips with the corner of her napkin. “I’m yours. I’m listening.”

 

Agatha hesitated, then exhaled. “I remembered something.”

 

Rio froze. Her spoon clattered to the plate.

 

“What?”

 

“White beetles,” Agatha said, trying to sound casual but failing. “Ring any bells?”

 

Rio released a breath she didn’t know she’d been holding. “Oh, you mean the time you called me a filthy street boy?” she laughed. “Truly romantic.”

 

Agatha smiled. “And our first kiss. You froze like a damn statue.”

 

“Oh, I’m sorry,” Rio said, rolling her eyes. “It’s not like the Creators offered French kissing classes to cosmic entities.”

 

Agatha arched a brow. “You’ve lived for eons and knew nothing?”

 

“Why would I?” Rio gestured, exasperated. “I’m not human. Where in my eternal, soul-reaping journey would I ever need to kiss a mortal?”

 

She leaned forward, eyes glinting. “Everything I know, you taught me. Every detail. And judging by the way your body reacts when I touch you, I’d say you’re a damn good teacher.”

 

Agatha’s cheeks flushed violently.

 

“Of the two of us,” Rio added with a playful smirk, “you’ve always been the more creative one. I can’t wait until you remember our first time.”

 

Agatha sputtered, nearly choking on her water. “Stop saying things like that!”

 

“What?” Rio feigned innocence. “I was pure. Practically a saint.”

 

“Yeah, a hollow saint,” Agatha grumbled.

 

Rio grinned, clearly entertained. She took another bite of her dessert, then licked her spoon with deliberately slow satisfaction.

 

“But,” she said, her voice softening, “I do have a question.”

 

“If it’s about what I taught you, I swear to—”

 

“It’s not,” Rio laughed, lifting her hands. “You taught me plenty. I wanted to ask… When you sang that song this morning — did it bring anything back?”

 

Agatha frowned, gaze drifting. “Is there something I’m supposed to remember?”

 

“There’s always something.”

 

She was quiet a beat too long. Then, softly: “No. Just the song. Playing over and over. Does that mean something bad?”

 

Rio hesitated. Her fork lowered slightly. “The song itself? No. But the last time you sang it... maybe.”

 

Agatha met her gaze. “Did I die afterward?”

 

The silence between them said enough. Agatha reached across the table, placing her fingers over Rio’s.

 

“I’m not afraid to die, Rio,” she said softly. “Because I know who will be waiting at the end. Whatever happened before, it doesn’t matter. I’m alive now. And I'm here with you.” 

.

.

.

The bathroom lights buzzed faintly overhead, humming in sync with the low rumble of the restaurant just beyond the door. Agatha stood at the large mirror, fingers deftly reapplying a swipe of berry-toned lipstick, her expression mildly annoyed as she mumbled to herself.

 

"I still have to prep the next class. And I swear, if one more of those insufferable first-years tries to mansplain the Cold War to me..."

 

Her muttering was cut short by the soft sound of boots on tile. She barely had time to glance up before familiar arms slid around her waist from behind. Rio’s scent hit her immediately—earthy and wild, like night rain falling over stone and smoke. The sensation of her body pressing close, warm and fluid against Agatha's back, made her breath hitch.

 

"Rio," Agatha warned, trying to sound stern, but her voice betrayed her with that slight lilt of amusement and arousal. "Stop. One of us has to work."

 

"Why?" Rio murmured into her neck, voice low and almost sing-song. "I can afford you, the kids, and all your impulsive candle hoarding."

 

She raised a hand and with a slow, casual flick, manifested a crisp $100 bill between her fingers like sleight-of-hand magic. Agatha’s eyes darted to the note, narrowing despite the smirk tugging at her lips. Rio’s fingers were warm as she tucked the bill gently between Agatha’s breasts, slipping it down through the opening in her blouse with deliberate slowness. Agatha’s breath caught. Not from surprise — Rio pulled stunts like this often — but from the intentional intimacy behind the act.

 

"Buy something nice for yourself, sugar lips," Rio whispered, her tone playfully husky.

 

Agatha rolled her eyes, though her cheeks flushed with color. "You are impossible."

 

"And you are insanely hot." Rio’s mouth found her ear, teeth grazing it gently, and Agatha felt the goosebumps ripple down her spine. "And I just want to remind you that everything I know... every delicious, filthy thing I do to you... was taught by you. Down to the last exquisite detail."

 

Agatha gasped softly when Rio’s hand palmed her ass and squeezed. The gesture was bold, possessive, and somehow still reverent. The lipstick in Agatha’s hand trembled, forgotten. Her knuckles went white around it.

 

"Rio," she growled under her breath, voice ragged, but not angry.

 

"Hmm?"

 

"Not here."

 

"Where then?"

 

"At home. Tonight."

 

"That’s so far away," Rio murmured with mock despair. "Just a kiss, then. You wouldn’t deny me that, would you, honey?"

 

She looked up into the mirror, meeting Agatha’s eyes with a pleading expression so dramatic it made her look like a starlet in a tragic play. Agatha tried—truly tried—not to react. But the flush in her neck betrayed her, the soft rise and fall of her chest giving away just how much Rio still got under her skin.

 

"I know you, love," Agatha said softly. "If I kiss you, you'll melt. And if you melt, we’re not making it out of here without at least one broken sink."

 

Agatha turned then, slow and deliberate, until they were face to face. She grabbed the lapels of Rio’s jacket and tugged her down into a kiss that silenced every excuse she’d just made. It started soft, but deepened quickly — hungry, full of tension neither of them could name. Rio’s hands slid down Agatha’s hips, grounding them both. Her fingers didn’t roam further, though Agatha knew she wanted to. She could feel the restraint in every muscle pressed against her, the way Rio groaned softly against her mouth but didn’t push.

When they finally pulled apart, breathless and flushed, Agatha rested her forehead against Rio’s.

 

"You know I’ll make you pay for this tonight, right?"

 

Rio grinned, that wicked glint back in her eyes. "That’s the goal, baby."

 

Agatha shook her head, laughing under her breath, before turning back to the mirror.

 

"Now go wait outside before I give in and destroy my career."

 

"With pleasure," Rio purred, sauntering to the door with a sway that was entirely intentional.

 

Agatha, alone again in the soft buzz of bathroom light, pressed a hand to her chest where the money still sat, then sighed, the corners of her mouth curving in surrender.

 

Damn her.

.

.

.

It whispered against the wide windows of the living room like a secret trying to get in. The fire crackled low in the hearth, shadows dancing over bookshelves and the dark wood floor. Agatha stood barefoot on the rug, still wearing her work trousers and blouse, though she’d long since undone the top two buttons. Her sleeves were rolled to her elbows, a pen still tucked behind her ear — an unintentional symbol of how hard she tried to stay grounded in this life. Rio, on the other hand, was sprawled on the couch like a woman born of silk and storms. She wore nothing but one of Agatha’s black button-downs, too large and far too sinful on her long limbs. Her damp curls spilled over the pillow as she scrolled lazily through a book of poetry she clearly wasn’t reading. Her gaze, half-lidded and amber, had been following Agatha for minutes now.

 

“I can feel you watching me,” Agatha murmured without looking, still focused on the papers in her hand. “You’re practically breathing down my spine.”

 

“You love when I do that,” Rio replied, her voice thick with satisfaction. “You go tense every time. Like a bowstring.”

 

Agatha’s lips twitched despite herself. “Some of us have self-control.”

 

“And some of us know exactly how to undo it.”

 

The rustle of pages stilled in her hands as Rio stood. Agatha heard her approach — not the sound of feet, but the shift in pressure. The heat of her body like a warm shadow curling toward her. Fingers brushed her hip first, featherlight, then curled possessively at her waist. Agatha exhaled slowly as Rio pressed against her back, slipping an arm around her torso and dragging her knuckles across the exposed skin at the base of her throat.

 

"You're not working anymore," Rio murmured against her ear, her lips grazing the edge of it. "You're winding yourself too tight again, querida."

 

“I have a lecture to finish for tomorrow,” Agatha replied, but her voice had softened. She tilted her head slightly, betraying herself.

 

“I don’t care about your lecture,” Rio said, tongue brushing the shell of her ear before she tugged lightly on the lobe with her teeth. “I care about how your pulse is racing. I care that your body is begging to be touched and you keep denying it.”

 

Agatha swallowed. Her pen fell from behind her ear without her noticing. Rio’s hand moved slowly — dangerously — up her stomach beneath the blouse, the back of her fingers trailing up the skin until they brushed just below her bra. She didn’t push. She didn’t grab. She waited.

 

Agatha’s breath hitched. "Rio..." Her voice was a warning. A plea. A threat wrapped in want.

 

“Mmm. There it is,” Rio purred. “That edge. Right between giving in and keeping control. I live for that in you.”

 

She pressed a kiss just behind Agatha’s jaw, hot and open-mouthed, while her other hand slid between Agatha’s thighs from behind—still over the fabric, but enough to make her gasp and tense forward.

 

“Let me take care of you, baby girl,” she whispered. “Let me make you forget why you needed to be strong tonight.”

 

Agatha turned in her arms then, finally facing her, eyes burning with that mix of defiance and need that always undid them both.

 

“You don’t get to call me that right now,” she breathed.

 

Rio smirked and leaned in, brushing her lips over Agatha’s but not kissing her. “Then stop acting like one.”

 

Agatha’s hand shot up, gripping Rio’s jaw with the same force she used when wielding magic—firm, commanding, electric. But her kiss when it came was slow. Hungry. A surrender that felt like a threat. She devoured Rio’s smirk, swallowed her arrogance, and pulled her in tighter.

 

“I’m still in control,” Agatha hissed against her lips.

 

Rio smiled against her mouth, eyes glinting. “Of course you are, baby.”

 

But neither of them believed that.

 

Agatha’s chest rose and fell in a deliberate, strained rhythm, her breath heavy with a mix of restraint and surrender as Rio leaned in closer. The fire behind them had burned down to glowing embers, casting low amber light across the room, shadows stretching long like the reach of something primal. The silence was thick, broken only by the soft patter of rain against the windows, a steady, intimate sound that made everything inside feel more secret, more charged. She still had her hand on Rio’s jaw — assertive, stubborn — but her grip was slipping. Not from weakness, but from the war inside her. Her fingers trembled, not in fear, but in anticipation, in the quiet ache of knowing she wanted to let go and not knowing what it would cost.

Rio kissed the corner of her mouth again, letting her lips linger without claiming more. She didn’t need to. Not yet. Agatha’s silence was permission enough.

 

Agatha exhaled softly. “Where are the kids?”

 

Rio didn’t step back. She nuzzled down, grazing her lips along Agatha’s chin, then kissing the hollow beneath her ear — her voice low and sultry, like velvet pulled slow across bare skin.

 

“Exhausted,” she murmured. “I took them to the park for hours. Ran them like wolves. Swings, trees, hide and seek. Let Nick bury me in leaves. Nicole lectured me on structural integrity. We came home soaked and muddy. I fed them, bathed them, tucked them in. They’re out cold, Agatha. I planned this.”

 

She said it like a confession — dark, sweet, deliberate.

 

“I need you.”

 

Agatha’s hands tightened on Rio’s shoulders, fingers curling into her shirt like claws trying not to drag her closer. There was guilt. Of course there was guilt. She was a mother. But it warred with desire so sharp her teeth clenched. Her jaw ached with restraint. Her thighs pressed together reflexively. Rio sensed it — she always did — and bit down gently on Agatha’s earlobe, tugging just enough to derail the train of maternal worry.

 

“They’re safe. Dreaming. Warm in their beds,” Rio whispered against her skin. “I wanted to make time for you.”

 

Agatha swallowed hard. Her throat bobbed, tight with the weight of control slipping. Rio’s voice wound down her spine like silk soaked in heat, and her magic — gods, her magic — stirred beneath her skin, wild, eager, humming.

 

“And if I say no?” she asked, pushing, testing, needing to know.

 

Rio stepped in, their bodies fully aligned now. The firmness of her palm flattened against Agatha’s stomach, just beneath the soft curve of her ribcage. Her breath brushed hot over Agatha’s neck where her pulse betrayed her, frantic and pleading.

 

“Then I’ll say goodnight, mi reina. A no is a no” Rio murmured. She dragged her nose along the line of Agatha’s jaw, her hands unmoving now — just heat and weight and promise. “I never take what you don’t offer. I’m not here to own you. I’m here to serve you.”

 

Agatha’s knees  threatened to give. That wasn’t seduction — it was devotion. And it scared her, maybe more than anything ever had. Because it was real.

 

She pulled back just enough to meet Rio’s gaze, her voice shaky. “You wore them out… just to have me?”

 

Rio tilted her head, soft curls brushing Agatha’s collarbone.

 

“Not just to have you. To make room for you. For us. You’re tired, baby. End of semester, Nick begging for vacation, the whole damn situation with Ralph tightening around your throat. You’re burning out and I can see it. I just wanted to be the one who holds you through it.”

 

Agatha didn’t answer. Not with words. The rain deepened outside, drumming a lazy lullaby against the glass. The fire crackled low behind them, casting flickers of orange across Rio’s cheekbones, across Agatha’s trembling hands.

 

Then, softly — barely a breath — Agatha whispered, “Take me upstairs.”

 

Something shifted in Rio. Her body straightened, energy surging through her frame like lightning finding its charge. That smirk reappeared, slow and hungry, all wolf and worship. She slid her hands under Agatha’s thighs and lifted her, cradling her like something sacred. Agatha gasped quietly, arms looping around her neck, their mouths so close now, so warm, so aching.

 

Rio didn’t move yet. She needed to hear it again.

 

“Say it,” she whispered, her voice like velvet steel. “again.”

 

Agatha’s lashes fluttered. Her body trembled against Rio’s, tension and need coiled like a storm inside her.

 

“Take me upstairs, baby.”

 

Rio groaned, deep and guttural, and then kissed her — hard and slow and claiming. It was a kiss that said mine without apology. She didn’t ask for surrender. She took it, because Agatha had given it willingly. Then she turned, carried her toward the stairs, one step at a time, their bodies molded together—heat, history, and hunger. Behind them, the house was quiet. The fire burned low. The storm began to scream against the windows. But they heard nothing but each other.

The stairs creaked softly under Rio’s boots, but her hold on Agatha was unwavering — firm, possessive, but gentle. As if she were carrying a flame too precious to risk dimming. Agatha clung to her with one hand curled behind Rio’s neck, the other tangled in the fabric at her shoulder, fingers bunching reflexively as the heat between them deepened. Her breath brushed against Rio’s cheek, uneven and hot. The upstairs hallway was dimly lit by the wall sconces — flickering gold light playing over old framed photographs, shadows slanting across the wood panels. But Rio didn’t pause. Her steps were slow, measured, intentional. Like she was savoring each footfall. Each second closer to where she could finally let go. When they reached the bedroom, Rio nudged the door open with her hip. The room greeted them with silence and softness. The bed was neatly made, the covers a pale gray, the lamps casting soft pools of amber over the sheets. Rain tapped steadily on the windows. The storm had not let up.

Rio didn’t speak as she crossed the room. She placed Agatha on the bed like she was glass — not fragile, but sacred. She hovered there for a moment, standing over her, eyes trailing down Agatha’s body with reverence and heat. Agatha looked up, chest rising, flushed and silent. Her hair spilled over the pillows, and her lips were parted just slightly. She was still dressed, but barely holding onto her composure.

 

Rio leaned down, brushing her knuckles along Agatha’s jaw. "Take off your blouse for me, my love. Slowly. I want to watch you."

 

Agatha’s breath hitched, her eyes searching Rio’s for a beat — and what she found there undid her. She sat up, unbuttoning one clasp at a time. The fabric slipped from her shoulders, revealing the swell of her collarbones, the curve of her chest in black lace. Rio’s eyes darkened as she knelt onto the bed, kneeling between Agatha’s thighs, fingers tracing her hips, reverent.

 

"You taught me everything," she whispered, voice ragged with awe. "So tonight, I’m going to prove how well I learned."

 

Agatha opened her mouth to respond, but Rio caught it in a kiss — deep and dragging, like she meant to taste every word Agatha didn’t say. Her tongue was slow, dominant, coaxing. Her hands roamed without hesitation. One gripped Agatha’s thigh, pulling her closer by the waist, the other slipped into her hair and tugged lightly until Agatha gasped. That sound — raw, surprised — was Rio’s favorite symphony.

 

Agatha broke the kiss only to whisper, voice hoarse: "You’re being greedy."

 

Rio smirked, her lips brushing Agatha’s collarbone as she spoke. "Of course I am. You’re mine."

 

She kissed down her chest, slow and possessive, biting lightly just above the curve of her breast. Agatha arched into her, moaning low. Her hands finally let go, clutching Rio’s back now instead of resisting. The edge of control was gone. Only surrender remained.

And Rio? She worshipped. With hands, with lips, with every whispered praise against fevered skin. She stripped Agatha of doubt before she stripped her of anything else.

 

"Let go," she murmured. "Tonight, you don’t carry anything but me."

 

And Agatha obeyed.

 

The room held a reverent silence, broken only by the quiet sigh of the rain brushing the windows. Rio set Agatha down gently on the edge of the bed, her hands warm and steady as they skimmed down her sides, grounding her — not just in the moment, but in the body that trembled slightly under her touch. Agatha leaned back on her elbows, breath shallow, her blouse hanging loosely over her frame, collarbone exposed and glowing softly in the firelight. Her eyes searched Rio’s face—not with fear, but with a growing ache she couldn't suppress any longer. An ache that had built over lifetimes.

Rio knelt between her thighs. It was an act done without flourish or fanfare, but there was something sacred in the movement. A reverence. Her hands found Agatha’s knees and gently parted them, thumbs pressing softly into the sensitive skin of her inner thighs, coaxing, never demanding.

 

“You’re sure?” Rio asked, voice low and velvet-rich, brushing like a hush across Agatha’s skin. Her breath, warm and steady, ghosted over the hem of the sleep shorts, and Agatha’s stomach fluttered in response.

 

Agatha nodded slowly, her lips parting but no words forming just yet. Her breath caught when Rio leaned in and pressed a single kiss against the inside of her knee, like a vow. Then another — closer. Then another. Rio’s fingers slipped beneath the waistband of the shorts, her touch slow, unhurried. She wasn’t tearing anything away. She was unveiling something precious. Her eyes flicked upward, locking with Agatha’s, asking again in silence.

 

“Take them off,” Agatha whispered, her voice hoarse, eyes glassy with both desire and trust. “Please.”

 

Rio exhaled a breath she didn’t realize she was holding, then gently tugged the fabric down, inch by inch, as if the moment demanded patience. The shorts slid away easily, and then, just as delicately, Rio traced her thumbs along the curve of Agatha’s hips, hooking the edge of her underwear with barely-there pressure. Agatha’s hands found the bedsheets, gripping them as her breath shivered out of her. Not from fear. From anticipation. From being seen. As the last fabric slipped away, Rio didn’t immediately touch her. She simply looked—drinking her in with an expression soft with awe, yet laced with something darker and deeper. Worship. Possession. Hunger carefully leashed.

 

“You’re unreal,” Rio murmured, voice thick. “Every time I see you like this, I think maybe I imagined it all. That no one could be this beautiful. This powerful.”

 

Agatha let out a quiet laugh, shaky and breathless. “I’m sweaty and tired, Rio. That’s all.”

 

“No,” Rio said, rising slightly to press a kiss to the hollow just below her navel, her hands still warm on Agatha’s thighs. “You’re perfect. My beautiful woman.”

 

Agatha's legs tensed gently around her waist at that, breath catching. Rio looked up, sensing the shift — the slight tilt of Agatha’s chin, the widening of her pupils, the quick flutter in her chest.

 

Control. Challenge. Need.

 

“Say it again,” Agatha said, her voice no longer breathless — it was low.  

 

Rio’s smile curved slow and reverent. She pressed her lips just above Agatha’s hipbone and whispered against her skin:

 

“My beautiful woman.” And the look in Agatha’s eyes when their gazes met again — dark, burning, already undone — was all the permission Rio needed to worship her like a goddess born from flame.

Chapter 12: Attention Lesbians

Chapter Summary

This isn't a chapter. I just need to let you know a few things about this week's posts.

OKAY! 

Just a heads-up, everyone! This week I’ll be posting all three chapters on Sunday.

 

They’re already written, but still raw. They need editing (which I won’t have time for until Saturday). I’ll be doing a training program in Paraguay to work as a translator there. So I’ll be super busy traveling from my tiny town in the middle of nowhere in Paraná all the way to Foz do Iguaçu and crossing the border — which, as any Brazilian who's been on the Friendship Bridge knows, is pure chaos.

 

Anyway, I’m really, really sorry and I promise to make it up to you.

 

In one of the chapters, they’re going to find Ralph — but it’s going to cost Agatha her memories. That’s my spoiler of the week to make up for the delay.

 

Again, I’m truly sorry. But mama’s about to start earning in dollars, so it’s totally worth it!

 

See you on Sunday!

 

Any other questions my twitter DM is open @godnessoflie, my number to contact is +55 45 99138-0189 WhatsApp and SMS. Love you.

Chapter 13: Chapter 12

The chalk scraped softly across the blackboard, each stroke deliberate as Agatha wrote a date above the phrase “ Ritual Symbolism in Early European Settlements .” Her voice had been calm and steady just moments before, carrying the same confidence she always did when talking history. But something inside her had shifted — so subtly at first she thought it was just exhaustion. A flicker. A hum. A pressure rising at the back of her skull like storm clouds gathering.

The heat in the room changed. A sudden wave surged through her — violent, unseen. Like being pulled underwater mid-breath. The piece of chalk slipped from her fingers, hit the board with a clack, and shattered. She staggered back, her chest heaving, vision going sideways. Books slipped from her arm and scattered across the floor with a thud that echoed in the quiet room.

A gasp left her lips.

Rio, seated beside the desk — legs crossed, spinning a pen between her fingers and barely pretending to take notes — snapped to attention. The pen dropped from her hand. She was moving before she even knew why, fast and fluid like smoke pulled by instinct. In two strides, she was kneeling beside Agatha, her fingers already cradling her face.

 

"Hey, hey, love, look at me," she murmured, her voice a careful blend of alarm and calm. Her thumb brushed over Agatha’s cheek. “ Agatha . You’re okay. You’re safe.”

 

But Agatha’s gaze was distant, unfocused, as if staring through dimensions only she could see. Her lips parted, breath shallow. Sweat gleamed at her hairline.

 

“Agatha, mi amor,” Rio said again, firmer now, both palms cupping her cheeks. “Stay with me. Look at me, please .”

 

Agatha blinked rapidly, confusion etched across her expression. Her pupils were dilated, her lips trembling.

 

“Where... where am I?” she whispered, eyes darting around as if expecting to see someone — or something — else. “Where’s... where’s the road ?”

 

Rio stiffened. “What road, baby? You’re in your classroom. You’re with me.”

 

“A classroom?” Agatha looked down at herself, then around at the students who now stared in awkward silence, shifting uneasily in their seats.

 

A red-haired girl raised a tentative hand. “Professor Harkness…?”

 

Rio didn’t hesitate. She turned her head over her shoulder, her voice like velvet wrapped around steel. “Class dismissed. Now .”

 

There was no protest. Chairs scraped back, bags slung over shoulders. The students filed out quickly, heads low, whispering as they passed. A door clicked shut behind them, leaving only the hum of the overhead lights and Agatha’s rapid breaths.

 

Agatha wrapped her arms around herself as if suddenly cold. “Rio... it’s coming back too fast. Flashes. Fire. You — your eyes glowing green. My magic bursting. There was... a path. A long one. And five people. I couldn’t see their faces, but I knew them. I knew them like I knew my own blood.”

 

Rio pressed her forehead to Agatha’s and closed her eyes, her own heart thudding against her ribs. She hated this — hated not knowing, not being able to shield her.

 

“I can stop it. Just breathe, okay? Stay with me,” she whispered.

 

Then she kissed her forehead softly, reverently, and murmured something ancient and sacred in Latin — Oblivio levare. Dolorem quietare. Memoriam domare.

Agatha gasped, her back arching slightly, and then the sharp current within her dulled. The storm passed. She slumped into Rio’s arms with a sigh that sounded like surrender and relief all at once.

 

Her hand trembled uncontrollably as she reached for Rio’s arm. “What’s happening to me, honey?”

 

Rio held her tighter, as though she could physically bind her together. “I don’t know. And I hate not knowing. But I swear to you — I will find out. I’ll fix this. I’ll burn down every law of time and soul and god if I have to. But no one’s touching you again, not while I’m breathing.”

 

Agatha nodded weakly, the effort making her head spin. “Don’t leave me.”

 

“I wouldn’t even if the universe begged me to,” Rio whispered fiercely, brushing damp strands from her lover’s forehead. “I'll call someone to be with you. You want Lilia? Or Wanda?”

 

“Lilia…” Agatha mumbled. “Wanda asks too many questions.”

 

Rio huffed a quiet laugh, kissed her temple. “Smart choice.”

 

She helped her up slowly, guiding her gently to sit in the chair behind her desk. The grip of Agatha’s fingers around Rio’s hand didn’t weaken, and Rio didn’t try to pull away.

 

“I’ll call her. I’ll take care of everything. You just rest, minha sombra.” Rio cupped Agatha’s jaw one more time and pressed a kiss to her knuckles. “Whatever this is… I’ve got you, my love.”

 

And as she turned to call Lilia, her mind was already running — through spells, protections, archives, and names buried deep in time. Whatever had been set into motion… she would break it before it took Agatha from her again.

 

 

The hallway outside the classroom was dim, lit only by the soft, flickering glow of the old overhead fixtures. The quiet tick of a distant clock echoed like a heartbeat in the hush between them. Lilia stood near the window, arms folded, her shawl slipping slightly off one shoulder like it always did, but she never seemed to mind. Her silver-streaked hair was pinned with care, but her eyes — sharp, dark, knowing — were wholly unamused. Rio leaned against the wall opposite her, arms crossed in imitation, though the restlessness in her stance betrayed her stillness. She looked like she belonged to another world entirely — because she did. Her shirt sleeves were rolled just above her wrists, revealing the faint glint of the tattooed leaves running along her forearm. One of them was curling at the edge — fading. Decaying. She didn’t bother hiding it.

 

“You’re avoiding the real conversation,” Lilia said, finally breaking the silence with the kind of measured calm only a woman who’s raised both children and spirits could wield. Her gaze didn’t waver. “You keep circling, but you’re not saying what you need to say.”

 

Rio’s mouth twitched, but it wasn’t quite a smile. “I don’t need your insight tonight, Lilia.”

 

“I’m not offering it. I’m demanding honesty.”

 

Rio pushed off the wall, walking a slow, deliberate line closer. The air around her seemed to ripple with something old — weightless, but impossible to ignore. She wasn’t trying to intimidate. She didn’t need to.

 

“You know more than you’re pretending to hide, witch ,” Rio said, stopping just close enough for the chill she carried to clash with Lilia’s warmth.

 

Lilia raised an eyebrow, unshaken. “You’re the one talking in circles, Death . Not me.”

 

The word landed between them like a blade — not sharp, but heavy. Certain. Undeniable.

 

“She knows.”

 

Rio blinked, her mask slipping just a hair. But Lilia didn’t gloat. She simply looked at her the way mothers do when they catch a child lying — not with anger, but with tired affection. Disappointment layered under knowing.

 

“You knew?” Rio asked, the question low and quiet.

 

“I’ve always known,” Lilia replied. “The way you watch her. The way the shadows shift when you breathe. The way time stills around you, even when you try to look human.”

 

Rio swallowed hard and looked away for a moment, jaw tight. “Then why didn’t you say anything?”

 

“Because it wasn’t my place,” Lilia said. “But you are running out of time to keep pretending you’re not part of this.”

 

Rio’s throat worked, her pulse ticking visibly at her neck. She hated this . She hated not having answers, hated even more being the source of pain she couldn’t control. Her voice softened when she finally spoke again.

 

“I didn’t come here to play at being human. I came to protect her.” She looked up, locking eyes with Lilia now. “I’ve failed before. But not this time.”

 

There was something raw in her voice — stripped down and real. Not divine. Not eternal. Just... Rio .

 

Lilia’s features eased, though her arms didn’t uncross. “Have you hurt her?”

 

“No.” Rio’s answer was immediate. “I wouldn’t. Not even by accident.”

 

“Good,” Lilia replied. “Because if you had... I’d find a way to make even you regret it.”

 

There was no malice in her tone — only love . Fierce, protective, maternal. And Rio nodded like she respected it.

 

“Just stay with her,” she said softly. “She trusts you. She needs a voice that won’t lie. And if something changes... if she gets worse... call me first.”

 

Lilia studied her for a long moment, then let her arms fall to her sides. “You know I will. But this mess — this storm building around her — it has your signature on it.”

 

Rio didn’t flinch. She only said, with a tremble barely audible under her words, “Just take care of her for me. I swear, this time I’ll fix everything. I won’t lose her again.”

 

Lilia stepped closer, reaching out to gently touch Rio’s arm — not for comfort, but to ground her. “Then stop trying to fix the past ,” she said. “And be here when she needs you in the present . You got a big knew chance, Rio, don't waste it”

 

Rio closed her eyes. And for a moment, Death let herself feel fear.

 

 

The classroom was hollow. Silent. Lifeless . The walls that once echoed laughter and questions now stood heavy with dread. The overhead lights had gone out, leaving only the cold gleam of moonlight filtering through the windows in fractured slants. Dust floated in the air, catching the silver glow like ghosts suspended mid-breath.

Agatha stood frozen in place, her chest rising in panicked stutters. Her books were still scattered across the floor where she had fallen. The silence cracked.

 

And then — Laughter . Low at first. Male . Sharp. Then higher — feminine , cruel, like wind catching broken glass and twisting it into something that sounded almost like Evanora. But it wasn’t. She knew it wasn’t.

 

“Agatha, Agatha, Agatha,” the voice sang mockingly through the dark.

 

Ralph emerged from the back of the room, strolling between the student desks like a serpent weaving through tall grass. His footsteps echoed too loud, his palms clapping slowly and deliberately with each step. That mocking grin — too wide, too calm — split his face as though it had been carved into him.

 

“Finally alone,” he murmured, tilting his head to watch her. “Uncomfortable, isn’t it? The voices. The fragments. The memories crawling under your skin. You look just like she did, you know. Right before she left you.”

 

His voice was venomous, but it wasn’t just his. Agatha’s eyes snapped downward — to the floor where the light of the moon tried to catch his shadow. But it wasn’t his. Ralph’s body moved freely, but the shape trailing him, mimicking his movements, was taller, more angular. Feminine . With a cruel tilt to the shoulders and hair too stiff to be real. A shadow with her mother’s figure — Evanora’s — yet Agatha could feel, down to her marrow, that whatever it was… it was worse.

 

“Ralph…” she breathed, her voice trembling, barely audible.

 

She wanted to move. To run. To scream. But her legs wouldn’t obey. Her fingers wouldn’t unclench. Her heartbeat was thundering in her ears, drowning out all rational thought.

 

And Rio — where was Rio?

 

Agatha’s throat tightened. “ Death ,” she called out. “ Rio !”

 

Ralph grinned wider. “Ah, no. She won’t be hearing you today, wife.”

 

He took another step forward, arms spread like a stage actor. The sick glee on his face made her stomach churn.

 

“She can’t feel you right now. My friend — Vengeance — she’s playing with her senses. Like a harp. And she’s very good with strings.”

 

His hand went to his waist, drawing something that gleamed under the dim moonlight. A gun. No spell. No curse. Just a weapon. Brutal. Human . Real.

 

“I begged to die! I begged for her to come when you tore my mind apart,” he hissed. “When you pulled myself from me like skin. But she didn’t . She let me rot. So now she’ll watch you die. And after you — your children .”

 

Agatha flinched, a sob catching in her throat. Her knees almost gave, but her will stiffened, fueled by rage and fear.

 

“ Rio !” she shouted again, stumbling toward the door, hand outstretched. Her voice cracked under the strain. “ Please !”

 

No answer. Just silence.

 

And Ralph’s breath — shallow and fast, like an addict near euphoria. He followed her with a slow pace, the barrel of the gun casually swinging by his side.

 

“She let you die, Agatha. Did she tell you that? The way it really happened?” His voice began to shift — warping — until it wasn’t his anymore. The edges frayed and softened into something honeyed and cruelly sweet.

 

The voice of her mother.

 

“You died in her arms,” it said. “ Begging . Stealing her power with your mouth on hers. And she let you finish. Let you fade. Like every man and woman in your cursed life — she abandoned you.”

 

Agatha’s lips trembled, her back pressing against the cold wood of the classroom door. “ You’re lying .”

 

“Oh no,” the voice answered in that mock-Evanora lilt. “I was your mother. I know you. I saw it in your eyes the first time you realized no one would love you the way you loved them. Especially her.”

 

The air had grown colder. Her breath fogged faintly, but the fire in her limbs burned now with raw panic.

 

“Where is your son?” the voice cooed. “Where’s Nicholas, Agatha? Oh, that’s right. She took ‘im. She keeps him in her world. Her realm. Where you don’t belong.”

 

“ Enough !” Agatha snapped, her voice breaking. “ Enough !”

 

She clutched at her wrist — her left wrist — where the connection always buzzed when Rio was near. It wasn’t buzzing. Not yet. But Agatha had never needed it more. She dug her fingers into her own skin, squeezing until she could feel her pulse racing beneath her thumb. She closed her eyes, trembling, trying to focus.

 

“Rio… baby, please . I need you .” A sob escaped her. And for a second, just a second, the air shifted. Only slightly. Barely enough to feel.

 

“She can’t hear you,” Ralph sneered. “And when she does come… it’ll be too late. Because she can’t kill me. And if she doesn’t… I’ll tear you apart piece by piece until she breaks.”

 

He aimed the gun now, arm steady. The silver barrel caught the moonlight like a blade.

 

“But maybe I’ll let her watch.” Agatha didn’t answer. She looked him straight in the eye, even as tears slipped down her cheeks.

 

“ She’s coming ,” she whispered. Her voice shook, but it was resolute. “She’s always come for me.”

 

Then, through her clenched teeth — soft but sharp like a blade beneath silk — Agatha spoke the words that cut through dimensions:

 

“ Death , come to me, my love.”

 

The classroom was no longer just a classroom. The air felt warped — thicker, heavy with something ancient and foul. The shadows had deepened unnaturally, bleeding down the walls like ink in water. Agatha’s heartbeat thrummed behind her ears, loud and erratic. Each breath she took was shallow, sharp, burning against her lungs.

Ralph was advancing slowly. But it wasn’t really Ralph anymore. His gait was stiffer, head cocked at a wrong, puppet-like angle, as though the bones underneath didn’t belong to the flesh. And behind him, that shadow — her mother’s outline — twitched unnaturally, like smoke caught in a wind Agatha couldn’t feel.

 

“I want to touch you,” Ralph’s voice rasped, or rather, her voice through him. “Just a finger to your mind, dear Agatha. Just one caress, and you’ll forget all about her. You’ll be mine . Ours. Forever.”

 

His hand rose — slow, almost tender — as if to bless, not to hurt. But Agatha felt the dread rise in her like a tsunami. Her whole body screamed no. If that thing touched her, it would break something. Twist something. Something she wouldn’t be able to come back from.

 

“No!” she choked, stumbling backward, knocking into the edge of a desk, her palm scraping against the metal as she shoved it between them. She kept moving, faster now, darting toward the tall windows at the side of the classroom. “ Rio !”

 

But nothing. Only the sound of her own breath and his footsteps. Tap. Tap. Tap. Outside, it was night. How had it become night so quickly? The world beyond the window was painted in deep blue and bruised black, the sky thick with clouds that looked like they were holding their breath.

 

Ralph’s face twisted into a grin too wide for his skull. “I want to see her fall to her knees for you, Agatha,” he hissed. “ Begging. Screaming . Because when she breaks her sacred rule, when she kills me in this form… she becomes mine.”

 

The female voice — the thing wearing her mother’s cadence — echoed around the room like wind through a crypt.

 

“She will burn the rules for you. Burn the order. And when she does, I will take her . Every inch. Every shard of her broken loyalty. Vengeance will own her, and the stars will bleed for it.”

 

“No!” Agatha gasped.

 

She didn’t want Rio to come now. Not like this. Not when she was cornered and scared and outmatched. Not when breaking that rule might twist her beloved into something else. Something monstrous. Something lost.

She turned — just in time to see Ralph raise the gun again, the metal glinting under the classroom’s artificial lights like the grin of a beast that had waited too long for blood.

 

“Don’t worry,” he purred, his voice dripping with venomous calm. “Just a little wound, darling. Just enough to make you stay still .”

 

There was a flash of steel, a sound that cracked time in two. The shot fired.

Agatha’s breath caught in her chest. Her body reacted before her mind could. Her knees buckled. She shut her eyes tight, bracing for the impact — sharp, burning, the kind of pain that came with the certainty of ending.

 

But nothing came.

 

No pain.

 

No fire.

 

No darkness swallowing her whole.

 

Just… silence.

 

A silence too still. Too wrong . It was the kind of silence that felt like the air had turned solid. That something ancient had awoken and everything around it had instinctively stopped to kneel.

Agatha opened her eyes slowly, unsure if she was dead. Expecting, maybe, the sterile white of some imagined afterlife or the crimson haze of bleeding out. But what she saw froze every cell in her body.

There, standing between her and Ralph, was a figure that did not belong to the human world.

Tall. Impossibly still. Cloaked in shadow and presence so dense it seemed to eat the light around it. The air rippled around her like heat rising off black stone, though the cold that emanated from her made Agatha’s skin break out in goosebumps. Even without seeing her face, Agatha knew — knew — that this wasn’t the Rio she kissed before sleep. This wasn’t the Rio who whispered soft things against her throat in the morning or kissed her fingertips while cooking.

 

This… was Death.

 

The gunshot’s echo had long since died, and yet the world hadn’t moved forward. Everything remained frozen — held in suspense as if creation itself waited to see what this being would do. And then Agatha saw it. The bullet. It hovered mid-air like an afterthought, suspended as if even gravity didn’t dare interfere. Rio reached out — slow, graceful, sovereign — and took it between two fingers, inspecting it with cold detachment. The bullet seemed to resist at first, trembling in her grip, but then she squeezed, and it crumpled like paper between her fingers. The sound of its collapse was deafening, a crack of finality that echoed through Agatha’s bones.

She couldn’t move. Her legs had gone weak, her arms hung at her sides. Her heart pounded against her ribcage with the force of a caged thing. She should’ve felt safe. But instead, she felt everything. Awe. Terror. Grief. Love. Reverence. All of it tangled and burning just beneath her skin.

Her gaze lifted — slowly — scanning the figure’s silhouette. A long coat, dark as space, wrapped around a body that defied reason. Part armor, part shadow, part bone. Leather wrapped around her midsection like armor, stretched over a ribcage that shimmered between flesh and nothing. Her shoulders broad, inhuman. Her presence overwhelming. The place where her face should be was… almost familiar. Almost hers . Almost Rio.

 

Except it wasn’t .

 

And yet when Agatha found the eyes — those brilliant, golden, mournful eyes — her heart clenched so tight she could barely breathe. Because they were Rio’s. Undeniably . And despite the monstrous silhouette, despite the darkness clinging to her like smoke, those eyes looked at her with the same quiet desperation Agatha had seen every time Rio had whispered please be safe .

 

Agatha’s lips trembled, her throat tightening, her voice a breath barely audible: “…Rio?”

 

She wasn’t sure which was worse — witnessing the raw embodiment of Death or knowing that it still loved her. Her outline pulsed with wrongness. The shadows bent toward her like gravity. The air grew heavier with every second, filled with the scent of ash, iron, and something ancient — something final.  Ralph faltered. So did the shadow. Whatever controlled him, it didn’t understand how Rio had broken through the enchantment, how she had found Agatha inside a layered illusion of fear and silence.

Rio exhaled, her voice not coming from her lips but from inside her — echoing like thunder through the marrow.

 

“ I-I sssmelled veerminn .”, Rio's voice echoed not through her mouth, but throughout her body. Like the voice of God. A metallic, cold voice.

 

She stepped forward slowly, graceful, menacing, like a predator indulging in the final moment before the kill. Her head tilted toward Ralph, eyes glowing brighter now.

 

“W-whichh of youu cockroachess iss ssniffing around… around what belongss to-to mmee?”

 

“ Rio ,” Agatha breathed, frozen at the window.

 

Rio turned her head slightly, not fully — just enough for one eye to catch her in profile. It was the only soft motion she allowed herself.

Agatha saw it. Saw her . Saw Rio’s truest self — and it stole the air from her lungs. Angled face, lips gone, jaw more bone than skin. And yet her gaze… those eyes held everything that mattered. Everything that had ever been gentle, fierce, and hers.

 

“Rio, my love…”

 

“I-I’m ssorry I-I wass late,” the voice echoed softly, rippling the shadows like a tide. “B-But thank youu forr believing I-I’d come… come… ”

 

She turned away from Ralph.

 

Agatha stepped forward hesitantly, chest rising and falling in shallow bursts. Her heart screamed both terror and relief. And when she reached for Rio’s hand, her fingers hesitated for only a moment. Rio’s hand was cold. Not like winter. Like death. Rigid, unmoving, more bone than flesh, and yet — Agatha held it. Held her. And the weight of it was undeniable. For the first time, Agatha felt what Rio truly was — not just her lover. Not just her protector. Not just the one who kissed her into peace.

 

She was Death.

 

Agatha’s voice cracked. “My love…”

 

Rio turned her face further away, trying to shield her, as if ashamed. “D-don’t lookk at me… me, baby. Not… not like this.”

 

But Agatha didn’t let go. She curled her fingers tighter around Rio’s palm, her other hand lifting gently to touch the edge of her jaw.

 

“You came for me,” Agatha whispered, tears burning in her eyes. “That’s all I see. I love you.”

 

The classroom felt like it had been uprooted from time itself. The walls pulsed faintly as if echoing a deeper heartbeat that did not belong to the earth. The shadows no longer clung to the corners — they moved. Whispered. Watched. And at the center of it all, between Agatha and the horror in Ralph’s form, stood Rio — shoulders squared, her back like a shield. She hadn’t moved since stopping the bullet, but her energy had shifted, and the air around her thickened with something raw and ancient.

Then came the voice. That feminine voice curled around them like smoke, slipping between cracks in the world.

 

“The only way to make me stop… is to kill me, Death.”

 

It echoed like a dare.

 

Rio’s hands remained clenched at her sides. Her entire form radiated tension, fury coiled tight beneath the surface. But it wasn’t just rage. There was restraint too. Discipline. Love, heavy as armor.

Behind her, Agatha stepped closer, her breath uneven, her fingers trembling as they reached for Rio’s hand again. Cold, rigid, inhuman — and wrapped her smaller fingers around it anyway.

 

“Why is she using his body?” Agatha whispered, her voice thick with fear.

 

Rio didn’t turn. Couldn’t .

 

“B-becausse Vengeancee hass no form of-of her own… own,” she said, her voice echoing from within the bones of her chest. “ S-she caan only possessss t-those consssumed by-by hatred. Ralph… Ralph… was broken. Hollowed out-out. Easy to infect. And she’s always wanted my-my body, because it’s the only one-one that could house her completely. B-but ssshe can’t have it unless I-I let her in through rage…rage.”

 

Her hand squeezed Agatha’s gently, almost apologetically.

 

“T-that’s why ssshe’s aafter you… you. S-she knows I-I’d lose myself if I-I lost you again… again. S-she can’t kill you herself — b-but Ralph can… caan”

 

The words were cold, but Agatha could feel the desperation laced between every syllable. She swallowed hard.

 

“Then how do we stop this?”

 

Rio’s silence was heavy.

 

“I-I need Eva,” she said finally. “S-she created the ward around this space… space — kept usss out. I-I only got through becaussse you’re my-my soulmatch. I-I felt your pull. You sssummoned me, A-agatha… withhh your pain… pain. With your need… Need”

 

“I didn’t mean to,” Agatha whispered. “I don't know how…”

 

“I-It doesn’t matter… matter, love. Y-You did. B-but to-to bring Eva in… you’d have to-to summon her the same way.”

 

“I don’t… I don’t know how.”

 

Rio’s voice dropped lower. Softer. “N-neither do I-I. That’s why I-I’m going to protect you with everything I-I have until we figure it-it out… out.”

 

Agatha’s eyes brimmed with tears. She lifted Rio’s hand to her lips and kissed the stiff, cold skin gently, her breath warm against her knuckles. The chill didn’t scare her. The bone didn’t scare her. The only thing that terrified her was the thought of losing this.

Rio watched the motion — silent, stunned. That someone could kiss this hand and still look at her with devotion. Still whisper her name with affection. Still love her .

 

Her soul ached.

 

“She’s not afraid of me,” she thought. “Even now… even like this.”

 

Agatha whispered, her voice uneven, urgent. “Please, look at me, Rio.”

 

Swallowing deeply, Rio turned to Agatha. Her heart, black as it was, beat beneath her ribs. If it was a contest of fear, Rio was winning.

Rio turned her head slightly, still too afraid to show her full face, but Agatha caught a glimpse of the sharp bone beneath, the ancient shadows that stitched her together. She was terrifying. Agatha didn’t care.

 

“You're beautiful . So powerful and… mine . I can believe for even one second that I have you as my soulmate. Promise me that you won't hide yourself from me again, my love.”

 

Rio's eyes filled with tears, but none fell. She just closed her eyelids and held back the tears.

 

“I-I swear it-it. But I-I need something from you too… too.”

 

“Anything.”

 

“ Y-you cannot let her words-words re-reach you. Y-you can’t let the visions in…in. Don’t let hate grow in you, Agatha… Agatha. I-if ssshe to-touches you, I-I don’t know what ssshe’ll do, but it will be bad… bad. S-she wants to turn you-you into a-a weapon. Or a key… a key.”

 

Agatha nodded, wiping her tears. “And if I fail?”

 

“Y-you won’t,” Rio said firmly. “Thi-think of the kids. Think of our-our home. Think of-of how I-I sound when-when I-I say your name… name. Use that to-to hold her out… out. Promise me… me.”

 

“I promise.”

 

Rio slowly began to pull away, readying herself, her form tightening with the quiet rage of a divine sentinel. But Agatha tugged on her hand again.

 

“I love you,” she said, her voice shaking.

 

Rio froze.

 

Agatha stepped closer. “I love every version of you. The woman. The shadow. The Death. I love all of it. All of you.”

 

Finally, Rio turned, letting her face be seen completely by a lighting that broke outside. Her expression wasn’t fully human anymore — but her eyes were. They shone with that familiar warmth, with unbearable grief and need.

 

“I-I love y-you too, A-agatha Harknessss,” she said, her voice a reverent tremble. “I-in every life-life you’ve ever lived… lived. I-in every one-one you will… will”

 

Her hand slid out of Agatha’s. Then she stepped forward. Facing Ralph — and the thing inside him. The classroom darkened further, as if Rio’s presence demanded the light to kneel.

 

“I-i ssmelled a roachh e-earlier,” Rio said coolly, her voice now heavier, carrying the weight of death and dominion. “Now-Now, againn, whichh one of-of you filthy creatures is-is creeping around what’s mine… mine?”

 

Vengeance hissed through Ralph’s mouth, his lips curling into a snarl. “You’re too late. She’s already cracking. She’s already afraid. Soon, she’ll be mine — and when she is, you’ll break. And when you break… I’ll wear you.”

 

Rio’s grin was sharp. “Try it. Try it.”

 

Then the ground beneath them shuddered as the battle began. The storm inside the classroom had taken form. The walls shivered with a magic that didn’t belong to the mortal realm, and Rio stood at its eye — dark, tall, cloaked in her true form, eyes lit like golden fire behind the skeletal angles of her face. Her voice echoed from deep inside her, reverberating through bone, brick, and blood.

Across from her stood Vengeance, still anchored inside Ralph’s body, though the thing wearing his skin was grotesquely stretched now, its shadow bubbling and twisting with limbs that didn’t exist. Behind Rio, Agatha trembled, crouched near a row of overturned desks, sweat slicking her brow as her breath came shallow and erratic. Her eyes darted wildly, tracking every movement with terrified clarity.

 

Then came the voice — not Ralph’s, but Evanora’s.

 

“Look at you,” the shadow cooed, stepping forward, taking the precise shape of Agatha’s mother. “ Frail. Pathetic. Just like always. Not even a witch anymore. You’re nothing without me.”

 

Agatha flinched as if struck. Her chest rose in short, fast breaths. The scent of old perfume — Evanora’s signature — filled the air, thick as rot. Her voice was like ice under the skin. Familiar. Cutting. Designed to shatter her.

 

“Stop…” Agatha whispered, eyes filling with tears. “You’re not her. You’re not my mother.”

 

But the creature stepped closer, a twisted smile curling on her stolen face. “She never loved you. Not truly. You were an inconvenience. And now even Death pities you.”

 

“ No .”

 

The shadow lunged to touch Agatha’s forehead, but her hand snapped up just in time, blocking the strike. Her fingers shook violently. Her mind reeled, teetering on a cliff. Pain bloomed behind her eyes.

 

And then — Agatha remembered.

 

She remembered Rio’s mouth against hers the first time. The hesitant, unsure press of lips in a dark hallway. That first kiss wasn’t fireworks — it was curiosity. Fear. Hope. It was good. Familiar. Like coming home. She remembered Rio running down the museum aisles, pointing out ancient artifacts with childlike wonder, her laughter bouncing off marble walls.

She remembered Nick’s first breath, her little hands holding her face in the hospital. His little eyes opened and revealed the greenish coloration, thick brown and tangled strands. Nick looked so much like Rio, even as a baby. 

She remembered Nicole's first birthday. How happy she was about the huge green cake.Her laughter echoing through the house and her clapping her hands when singing happy birthday.

 

Her family. Her loves. This was real. This was hers and no one would take it away. Clinging to those memories, Agatha pushed the vision of Evanora away.

 

“I’m not yours,” she hissed, standing fully now. “I was never yours.”

 

Across the room, Rio and Vengeance collided.

 

“You are nothing!” Vengeance spat, voice fracturing the air. “A ghost. A failed god. One day, she will die, Death. And then what will you be?”

 

Rio stood her ground, unmoving. Her spine was steel. Her aura wrapped around Agatha like a shield, every breath she took laced with protective rage.

 

“W-when that day comes… comes,” Rio’s voice vibrated, low and dangerous, “I-I will guide her myself… my-self. A-and I’ll find her again… again. I-in the next li-life. And the ne-next. Because sshe is-is mine… mine. And I-I am hers… her. Y-you’ll never understand that… that. Be-because you don’t exist unless you-you infect someone. You-you have no form, no-no love, no soul… soul. You are rot… rot.”

 

“I’ll possess her,” Vengeance promised, her voice turning sickeningly sweet. “And I’ll be gentle.”

 

“You won’t touch her.”, This time Rio's voice came out clearly, accompanied by the thunder that exploded outside, shaking the window. Loud, strong, and vibrant.

 

Then came Agatha’s scream.

 

Rio spun just in time to see her collapse to the floor, her limbs twisting in pain. Rage lit her body like a flare. With a single motion, she reached out, gripped the false Evanora by the throat — her hand glowing white-hot — and hurled the shadow creature across the room, smashing it into rows of chairs. Sparks flew. The walls cracked.

Vengeance reeled in Ralph’s body, unbalanced. Rio didn’t hesitate. She turned, and with the full force of her fury, drove Ralph’s possessed frame into the chalkboard. The wall exploded in a burst of plaster and splinters. Ralph hit the ground like a puppet with its strings cut.

 

The world rippled.

 

Light returned. The windows flashed with afternoon sun again. The smell of chalk, dust, and old books replaced the stench of rage and rot. The illusion shattered . The classroom was whole again. Outside, distant chatter of students carried through the open hall. Only one thing was wrong. Ralph lay unconscious on the floor. And Agatha wasn’t moving.

 

“ Agatha ! My love!” Rio’s voice cracked as she dropped to her knees beside her. Her dark form shifted, collapsing back into her human shape. Her jaw trembled as she cradled Agatha in her arms. “Baby… talk to me, please. Please .”

 

Agatha blinked slowly. Her head fell against Rio’s chest.

 

“That… was really hot… ” she mumbled weakly. “Can you throw me against a wall one day?”

 

Rio let out a breath between a sob and a laugh. “You're okay… thank all the fucking gods.”

 

“I think so. My head just… it’s pounding.”

 

Rio’s hand cupped her cheek, gently tilting her face. “Did she touch you?”

 

“No,” Agatha whispered. “But the memories… they’re flooding back. Too fast. It hurts, Rio. It really hurts.”

 

Rio’s face softened with unbearable sorrow. “Shh, I’ve got you now. I’ve got you.” She kissed Agatha’s temple. “Let me take you home. We’ll fix this. Together.”

 

Agatha nodded weakly. “Okay.”

 

Rio stood, lifting Agatha into her arms like she weighed nothing. As she carried her from the room, Ralph’s body lay still on the floor behind them. Forgotten. Unconscious. Powerless.

 

For now.

 

 

The bathroom was dim, lit only by the low amber glow of a salt lamp in the corner. Steam curled lazily into the air, carrying the soft scent of lavender and eucalyptus oil. The gentle slosh of water echoed against the tiled walls, broken only by the faint hum of Rio’s voice — singing something slow, wordless, and ancient. Her voice wasn’t perfect. It was raw, low in her throat, vibrating softly against Agatha’s spine where she knelt behind her in the tub. Agatha sat curled forward in the hot water, knees drawn to her chest, her forehead resting on her arms folded over the edge of the porcelain. Her soaked hair clung to her neck and shoulders. Her skin was flushed from heat and grief. Rio’s hands moved with care, not to seduce, not to provoke — just to hold. To remind . Her palms glided gently over Agatha’s back in slow, grounding circles, her thumbs pressing into the tense muscles beneath the skin. She felt every flinch. Every tremble. She whispered nonsense between the verses of her song — soft comforts like “I’ve got you,” and “you’re safe.”

 

"I sent my brother to take Ralph to the station," she said softly, breaking the song for a moment. "Maybe... maybe Life can undo the lock she placed. Maybe this can stop."

 

Agatha didn’t move. Her eyes were fixed on a spot on the wall. She wasn’t crying. But her stillness said everything.

 

“Agatha? Cariño... are you hearing me?”

 

Her voice was barely audible. “Lilia died…”

 

Rio’s heart stuttered. “ No, no, baby. She’s fine. She’s downstairs making something Italian and swearing in three languages because I brought her into all this.”

 

Agatha shook her head slowly. “Not that Lilia. The other one. The witch . She fell. It was slow… she screamed.”

 

Rio’s hands stilled.

 

“It’s a memory, love. Just a memory.”

 

Agatha turned her face slightly, resting her cheek on her arms. Her voice broke. “I don’t want them, Rio. I don’t feel right. I don’t know what’s real. I don’t know if the memory of Nick’s birth is ours… or hers. I don’t know which life this is. And Nicole — she never appears. Not once. Where is she, Rio?” Her breath hitched, and the tears finally fell. “ Please . Make it stop, my love. Please.”

 

Rio pressed her forehead gently to Agatha’s shoulder. She wanted to be calm, but the ache in her chest was thunderous. The desperation in Agatha’s voice clawed at her ribs. Her skin felt too tight. Her own form trembled faintly now — not from exhaustion, but from helplessness.

 

“I… Eva might be able to do it. But I…” Her voice faltered.

 

Agatha lifted her hand from the water and found Rio’s, guiding it to her lips. Her kiss was warm, trembling. “ Please ,” she whispered. “If it means losing all of them, I don’t care. Just don’t let her take you from me. Don’t let her bury you in all the noise. You’re the only thing that makes sense. ”

 

Rio looked at her. Really looked at her. Her Agatha. Shivering in hot water. Haunted by lifetimes. Fragile and still choosing her . She knew the risk. Tampering with memories was more than dangerous — it could reset everything. Erase the present. Reboot a life that had taken years to rebuild. Agatha might forget her completely.

 

But Rio also knew that watching Agatha break was no longer an option. "Okay," she whispered, her voice raw. “We’ll fix this. Together.”

 

“Promise me.”

 

Rio kissed her temple, brushing wet strands behind her ear with trembling fingers.

 

“I’ll try to make sure the last thing you forget is my smile,” she murmured. “But if you do… I’ll make you fall for me again. I swear it.”

 

Agatha turned, slowly, fragile in every movement. Her eyes were glassy, pupils blown wide. Her hand cupped Rio’s jaw.

 

“Don’t run away this time,” she whispered.

 

“Never again, my queen,” she said, kissing her softly. “Even if you forget me… I’ll be right here, waiting to be remembered.”

 

.

.

.

 

The bedroom was quiet, the sound of the rain having softened into a gentle rhythm against the windowpane. Warm light spilled from the lamp on the nightstand, wrapping the room in golden calm. The steam from the bath still clung to Agatha’s skin, trailing in invisible wisps along her shoulders and collarbone.

Rio stood behind her, slowly brushing through the strands of Agatha’s damp hair with practiced care. Each stroke of the brush was a ritual — gentle, reverent. She had already dried Agatha’s back with a towel, wrapped her in a silk robe, and was now focused entirely on this task, as if detangling hair might somehow help untangle memories too.

 

Agatha sat on the edge of the bed, her back straight, her breathing even but shallow. Her eyes were distant again, focused on nothing, until they weren’t. Until something flared behind them. Suddenly, she turned . Her fingers tangled into Rio’s hair with a kind of desperation that wasn’t panicked — it was primal. She yanked Rio down to her level, their faces crashing close, and sealed their lips together in a kiss that was more declaration than comfort.

 

It caught Rio completely off guard. Her hands froze midair, still holding the brush. For a second, she didn’t breathe. Agatha’s lips were hot and commanding, and the force behind the kiss made Rio’s knees weaken. She dropped the brush with a soft clatter on the floor and slid her arms tightly around Agatha’s waist, pulling her in, molding their bodies together as if she could anchor them both in the now.

 

Agatha pulled back just a breath, lips brushing against Rio’s, eyes dark and shining.

 

“You okay, sweetheart?” Rio asked, her voice a little hoarse, as though the air had been knocked from her lungs.

 

Agatha’s mouth curved into something wicked. “Make no mistake — I will never forget you.” Her fingers tugged gently on Rio’s hair, enough to draw a soft, involuntary sound from her. Then she bit Rio’s bottom lip and whispered against it, “I’d hate to lose these reactions of yours.”

 

Rio blinked, the sensation still lingering on her mouth.

 

“Reminds me of the day I sank the Titanic for you,” Agatha continued, her voice velvety and amused. “You were so shocked by the deaths. Your face, Rio… priceless. You don’t remember it, honey?”

 

Rio stared at her for a moment, then let out a stunned laugh, breathless and filled with disbelief. “You’re a sadist.”

 

Agatha smirked and leaned in again, catching her lips in a deeper kiss. “And you love it.”

 

Rio kissed her harder this time, all restraint abandoned. Her hands slid under the silk robe, fingers splaying against the small of Agatha’s back. She didn’t push. She simply held her there, tasting every emotion Agatha was pouring into the kiss — anger, fear, want, love, all of it wrapped in heat and memory.

 

When they pulled apart, foreheads pressed together, both of them breathing like they’d run through fire, Rio whispered, “Gods help me, I really do.”

 

Agatha’s hand brushed down her chest slowly, palm open. “Then don’t leave. No matter what memory they take.”

 

“I’m not going anywhere,” Rio said, her voice low and trembling with truth. “If I have to follow you through lifetimes again, I will . I already have .”

 

The bedroom was a sanctuary of sin — warm, dim, and thick with the scent of lavender oil and rising desire. The air itself seemed to pulse, heavy with the musk of sweat and something darker, something hungry. Agatha’s silk robe, once draped over her shoulders like a promise, now lay discarded beneath her knees, a pool of crushed fabric forgotten in the heat of the moment.

She straddled Rio’s waist, her thighs bracketing the other woman’s hips with possessive intent. Her mouth was a brand against Rio’s throat — sucking, biting, leaving behind a trail of blooming bruises that would linger for days. Teeth grazed the delicate skin just above Rio’s collarbone, and a sharp gasp escaped, followed by a breathless whimper that sent a thrill straight down Agatha’s spine.

 

Rio’s fingers were knotted in the sheets, her grip so tight the fabric threatened to tear. Her head was thrown back, lips parted in surrender, her breath coming in ragged pants. The sound of her voice — low, wrecked, dripping with submission — made Agatha’s blood burn.

 

"Gods, Aggs..." Rio groaned, her voice rough with pleasure. "You’re going to kill me before Vengeance ever gets the chance."

 

Agatha grinned against her throat, her lips slick with spit and the faint metallic tang of skin breaking under teeth. " Good ," she purred, her voice a velvet threat. "That’s the plan."

 

Agatha pulled back just enough to breathe against her skin, voice laced with that familiar danger.

 

“I’m making sure your soul remembers me. In case Eva wipes your brain next.”

 

“I’m not the one losing memories,” Rio smirked through her sharp inhale, nails digging in slightly as Agatha rolled her hips.

 

“But you're mine,” Agatha whispered, sinking her teeth again. “You need reminders.”

 

Rio was about to respond — something cocky, something sinful — but the air snapped. A sudden burst of golden light cracked in the corner of the room.

 

Ahem. The sound was deliberate. Loud. Judgmental . Agatha froze. Rio’s eyes snapped open, wide with dawning horror.

 

Agatha didn’t move. Her mouth was still latched onto Rio’s neck, her teeth barely grazing the fresh mark she’d been in the middle of claiming. A thin string of saliva connected them, glistening in the dim light.

 

Rio swallowed. "Oh no."

 

Slowly — agonizingly — Agatha lifted her head. Standing near the dresser, arms crossed, one perfectly manicured eyebrow arched in a look that could curdle milk, was Eva.

 

“OH FOR THE LOVE OF—” The voice hit them like a thunderclap. Agatha froze mid-movement. Rio didn’t even turn her head, just closed her eyes with a sigh that came from the deepest, most exhausted part of her soul.

 

Dressed in an immaculate white blouse and golden trousers that shimmered with celestial embroidery, she looked like she’d stepped straight out of a divine board meeting — only to walk in on something profoundly unholy.

Her gaze traveled from Agatha’s disheveled robe (barely clinging to her shoulders, her chest still heaving) to the rapidly darkening bruise on Rio’s neck. Then, with the slow, deliberate horror of someone who had seen too much, she blinked.

 

"Well," Eva said, her voice drier than the Sahara. " That explains why no one answered the summoning."

 

Agatha’s brain short-circuited. "You couldn’t have knocked?"

 

Eva’s expression flattened. "I’m a cosmic being, Agatha, not your delivery driver ." Then she turned her withering stare to her sister. "Rio. You’re not even wearing pants. Again .”

 

Eva stood at the edge of the room, hands on her hips, her expression a blend of scandalized horror and ancient disappointment — like she’d just walked in on two immortals breaking every celestial conduct code in the book.

 

“Do you two have no boundaries? Is there some eternal law that says I must always be scarred by your mating rituals ?”

 

“We are not mating…” Rio said defending herself. “ Yet .”

 

Agatha, still on top of Rio, blinked once. Then again. “…She teleported. Into the bedroom,” she muttered in disbelief. “This can’t be real.”

 

Rio lifted one arm lazily and waved it toward Eva like she was swatting a fly. “We’re bonding. Leave .”

 

“Bonding?!” Eva barked. “You’re half-naked and she’s biting you like a starving wolf! You’re supposed to be protecting the mortal timeline, not —” she motioned vaguely to the bed, “— testing its endurance!”

 

Agatha slowly reached for the sheets, dragging them up with royal dignity, even as she refused to move from Rio’s lap. “You’re the one who decided to pop in uninvited. This could’ve waited.”

 

Eva dropped her hands, exasperated. “Ralph is awake again. And I need you both dressed, functional.” Rio raised an eyebrow. “Define ‘functional’.”

 

“Rio!” Agatha elbowed her, biting back a laugh as she felt the tremble of Rio’s body shaking with quiet laughter beneath her.

 

Rio, still sprawled beneath Agatha, had the audacity to smirk. "In my defense, you didn’t give me time."

 

"I gave you weeks," Eva snapped. "And instead of fixing the unraveling fabric of reality, you’re here letting Agatha turn you into her personal chew toy ?"

 

"I’ll have you know," she drawled, "she was doing a fantastic job .”

 

Agatha huffed, trying — and failing — to pull her robe closed while still perched on Rio’s lap. The silk slipped, revealing far more than she intended, and she ended up clutching it to her chest like a half-hearted shield. 

 

"For the record," she muttered, "I was doing memory exercises. Sensory . Very effective."

 

Eva’s glare could have melted steel. "Rio, shut up."

 

"She’s stressed. I’m stress relief."

 

"I said shut up!”

 

Eva’s eye twitched. She looked skyward, mouthing what was either a prayer or a curse, before pinching the bridge of her nose. 

 

"This is the literal definition of ‘not the time .’ One of you is breaking from reality, the other’s being hunted by Vengeance, and you’re in here trying to turn her neck into a constellation of hickeys ?”

 

Eva pinched the bridge of her nose. 

 

“Five minutes. And if I hear even one more moan from this dimension—”

 

“You’ll what?” Rio challenged, smirking as she tilted her head, fangs barely peeking through now that her power was stirring again.

 

“I’ll banish you to the Realm of Perpetual Abstinence.”

 

Agatha gasped. “That’s a real place?”

 

Agatha finally climbed off Rio, adjusting her robe with as much dignity as she could muster.

 

"Okay, okay, I get it. Serious. Emergency. Doomsday. We’re back in goddess mode. Happy ?"

 

Eva exhaled like she was counting to ten in her head. Then, without another word, she turned toward the window, muttering something in a language that made the air hum with divine irritation.

 

"Next time," she snapped over her shoulder, "I’ll manifest in the kitchen. At least then I won’t get PTSD from your sex life."

 

Rio snorted. Agatha threw a pillow at her. Eva vanished with a sound like the universe sighing in defeat.

 

And then, silence . Agatha stared at the spot where Eva had been. Then, slowly, she turned back to Rio.

 

Agatha looked down at Rio. “We’re never living this down.”

 

Rio grinned up at her. “Wanna make it worth it?”

 

“You’re the worst.”

 

“And you love it.”

 

 

The air in the room was heavy, pulsing with something too big for the walls to hold — an invisible pressure that sat on all their shoulders. The window was cracked open, letting in a breeze that carried the smell of rain-soaked soil, but even that couldn’t cool the heat rising between them.

Eva stood near the armchair, her long coat still damp from the outside. Her arms were crossed, jaw tense, and eyes glowing faintly gold in the dim light of the room. She looked less like a divine being and more like an exhausted diplomat on the verge of breaking protocol just to get things done.

 

“I haven’t gone to the station yet,” she said flatly, eyes shifting between Agatha and Rio. “The humans are swarming around Ralph like moths to flame, trying to make sense of what he’s been saying. Talking about purple magic, you, Death, your relationship, his memory loss. It’s chaos .”

 

Agatha sat on the edge of the couch, wrapped in a robe, still visibly shaken. Her wet hair clung to her neck and temples, a towel forgotten on her lap. She stared at Eva with quiet exhaustion, her fingers twitching slightly — restless, alert.

 

“And Benny?” Rio asked, voice low, sitting close beside Agatha with one protective hand resting gently on her thigh.

 

“Disguised as Officer Daniels,” Eva replied. “He’s watching Ralph. Making sure the bitch doesn’t crawl back into him. For now, Vengeance is circling, not feeding.”

 

Agatha’s brows drew together, her voice hoarse. “Can’t you just sneak in and wipe his mind like... like clearing a hard drive ?”

 

Eva scoffed, a sharp, tired sound. “Oh sure, and then what? Everyone who saw him raving about witches and cosmic romance will just magically forget? The security footage? The phones? You people put cameras in your refrigerators now.”
