She ran a hand through her hair. “I’ll play devil’s advocate. Get him declared unstable, committed. Once he’s inside, I’ll erase everything — all his lives, all his pasts. Once he’s a ghost in his own skull, no one will care what he used to be.”

 

Silence dropped like a stone. Agatha blinked. Her eyes flicked to Rio’s hand on her leg. Then slowly, they lifted to meet Eva’s. And then she stood. Fast.

 

“ No ,” she said. Her voice was clear, shaking — but sharp like a blade unsheathed. “Wait — no. No fucking way .”

 

“Agatha —” Rio started, already rising with her.

 

Agatha backed away, hands trembling. “Is that what you’re going to do to me?” Her voice broke into something more raw, more human. “Erase everything ? Just… rip me out of myself ? Because I won’t let you. I won’t become some blank thing that doesn’t remember my kids, or you —” she pointed at Rio, her voice cracking, “—or who I am.”

 

“Agatha, no one said —” Eva began, but Agatha cut her off.

 

“ DON’T !” she shouted. “Don’t talk like I’m not here. Like I’m some magical mess to fix. This is my mind. My life . You’ll have to kill me first!”

 

Rio reached for her. “Agatha — please —”

 

“Don’t ‘Agatha’ me, Rio Vidal !” she snapped, snatching her arm away. “Don’t touch me if you’re thinking of turning me into a goddamn vegetable.”

 

Rio stepped back like she’d been slapped, her throat bobbing as she swallowed something heavy. Her hands hovered in front of her like she didn’t know whether to reach again or let her go.

 

“It’s not like that,” Rio said, her voice lower now, full of ache. “It’s not what I want. But I —” Her words faltered. “I don’t want to lose you .”

 

“Well, congratulations ,” Agatha breathed, tears clinging to her lashes. “You’re almost there.”

 

Rio’s face crumbled. She turned sharply to Eva, eyes glowing in the dim light. “ Don’t touch her. Don’t even think about touching her memories. I swear to you, if you do — I will walk away.”

 

Eva froze. Rio stepped forward, each word a knife dragged across the floor.

 

“I will walk away from the job. From the duty. From all of it. I will let the veil rot and the cycle shatter. No more souls. No more guidance . I will burn the line between realms to ash.”

 

“You can’t do that,” Eva whispered, stunned. “You know you can’t.”

 

“I will,” Rio snarled. “Let them try to stop me. Let them try to punish me. What will they do, Eva? Kill me?” She laughed, hollow and cruel. “Good fucking luck.”

 

Eva’s mouth opened — then closed. She looked away, pained. “You think I want this? You think I enjoy being the one that has to say it out loud?”

 

She stepped closer, her voice softer, strained. “Her memories are merging, Rio. Too fast . The lives are colliding — both full of grief, love, trauma. If they don’t stabilize, one life could consume the other. She could become someone else. Someone who doesn’t know you. Or worse — someone who remembers everything and hates you for it. She could break. Both of you could .”

 

Rio was shaking, chest rising and falling hard.

 

"Revenge could take advantage of this hatred and possess Agatha. Then, you know what she wants, to possess YOU , Rio. She wants your body and she knows that by taking Agatha away from you, she can achieve that.”

 

“I’ll kill Vengeance,” she said through gritted teeth. “Before she touches her. I don’t care if she’s a concept. I’ll shatter her.”

 

“You can’t kill a spirit,” Eva reminded quietly.

 

“I can’t kill the living ,” Rio corrected, eyes glowing brighter now. “No one ever said anything about cosmic parasites .”

 

Another silence. Agatha stood between them, trembling, her hand at her chest like she was trying to keep something inside from cracking. Then, quietly, she whispered:

 

“If you’re going to do it... make me forget the other life. All of it . But don’t you dare erase this one. Don’t you take Rio from me.”

 

Rio turned to her, stricken. “Agatha—”

 

Agatha’s voice trembled. “I don’t need to remember how we started to know that I love you. And if Eva takes that away, I’ll spend every life finding my way back to you. But I’d rather die than forget what we have now.”

 

Rio crossed the room in two strides and wrapped Agatha in her arms. The silence was full of breath and salt and the weight of the impossible.

 

“I won’t let them take you,” Rio whispered against her hair. “Even if I have to burn down every rule the gods ever made.”

 

And for a moment, nothing moved but their hearts. Beating in defiance. Together.

 

Agatha’s chin rested on Rio’s shoulder, her tears soaking into the skin just above the collarbone. Her body trembled, more from exhaustion than emotion now, her breath warm and uneven. The scent of lavender soap from Rio’s skin, the salt of Agatha’s tears, the faint warmth of the fire crackling in the distance — all of it mixed into a moment suspended in time, like the fragile hush before a storm breaks open.

 

“Sometimes you forget,” Agatha said, voice low and raw, “that I can do things too.”

 

Rio turned her head just enough to glance at her. “No one said otherwise, love.” She cupped Agatha’s cheek gently, her thumb grazing the tear-streaked skin like it was sacred.

 

Agatha let out a short, bitter laugh — dry as sand. She stepped back a little, but not out of anger this time. Just out of need to breathe her own air again.

 

“ You gods. You beings. You immortal cosmic whatever-the-fucks. You crash into my life like tidal waves and think you can just take over because you know the last leaf that fell on the ground and the first baby that cried at dawn.” She ran a hand through her tangled hair, her voice sharpening with every word. “I might not know those things. But I still survive so much .”

 

Her voice rose, stronger now, her frustration boiling into something beautifully defiant.

 

“Which one of you has pushed out a baby ? Three goddamn times because of your fucking cosmic fingers , Rio. Alone ?” she hissed, her hand gesturing sharply toward her stomach. “Which one of you bleeds every month and still wakes up at 6 a.m. to pack lunches, dress two hyper children with the energy of small lightning storms, put on heels, and go teach a classroom full of idiotic, hormonal teens who think TikTok is a source of wisdom?”

 

Her hands clenched at her sides, and her eyes burned — not just with tears now, but fire.

 

“It might not seem like a lot to you,” she said, spitting the word like venom. “ But to a human , that is a hell of a lot. I get tired . But I’m not weak .”

 

Rio and Eva stood frozen in place. For once, even divinity looked startled. Humbled.

 

“I can take so much more than you think I can. And if you erase my memories, that won’t save me from breaking. That’ll break me , just in a way where I won’t know why I’m broken . And I refuse to live like that.”

 

Rio lowered her eyes. And for once, the immortal — who had witnessed plagues, collapses, extinctions — cried . The tears slid down her face like raindrops against a window she couldn’t close. Ever since she learned what it was to weep, she hated it . Every time. Especially now.

 

Agatha’s voice softened, barely above a whisper, but full of resolve. “Eva… erase everything from that other life. I don’t want to know how I died. I don’t care why Rio took Nick too early, or who Lilia was to me, or what Wanda meant back then. I don’t need to remember being some all-powerful witch who sank the goddamn Titanic for the love of her life.”

 

She looked at Rio now, directly, her expression carved from something ancient and tender. 

 

“I don’t need that life to know I love you. And if taking it from me dulls that feeling... then maybe I didn’t love you enough. And you, Rio, will just have to make me fall in love with you again. But if you run this time?”

 

Agatha stepped forward, lifted Rio’s chin with two fingers, and gently wiped away a tear from her cheek. Her touch was soft, but her gaze was brutal in its honesty.

 

“I’ll find you. I’ll drag you back .”

 

Rio let out a soft, strangled breath. She looked like something divine and broken all at once. Like Death finally realized what life tasted like and couldn’t bear the thought of losing it again.

 

“Or,” Agatha added, turning to Eva, “you slow the pace. Let the memories come in their own time. Let me decide one day which version of me I want to keep. But don’t you dare erase me. Not one part. Because if I do remember... and I find out you took even a single second of my truth from me... I swear to every deity who ever dared breathe — I will find a way to kill every last one of you cosmic bitches.”

 

She took another step closer. Her voice dropped like a curse wrapped in velvet.

 

“And I won’t need Vengeance’s help to do it.”

 

For a heartbeat, the silence was absolute. Even the wind outside seemed to pause. Eva and Rio both stared at Agatha like she had suddenly turned into something far bigger than mortal flesh. Her eyes gleamed with an eerie, familiar violet glow. It was only for a second — but it was enough.

 

“Did you hear me?” Agatha snapped.

 

“Yes, my love,” Rio said, immediately.

 

“Yes, ma’am,” Eva echoed, her voice quieter than usual.

 

Agatha turned on her heel with a theatrical huff, her robe swishing like a queen’s cloak. “ Good . Now let’s eat. Lilia made dinner. The kids are upstairs waiting. And I’m starving .”

 

She disappeared around the corner, leaving both entities rooted in place, stunned.

 

Eva’s jaw dropped slightly. Her mouth moved before her brain caught up. “I understand now.”

 

Rio blinked. “Understand what?”

 

Eva turned slowly to face her, her expression a strange mix of awe and exasperation.

 

“What you see in that woman .”

 

Rio smiled softly, a little crooked and full of heat. “I love her.”

 

Eva’s mouth twisted into a smirk. “You’re so fucked.”

 

Rio leaned back on the sofa, eyes on the doorway Agatha had vanished through. “ I know. Isn’t it perfect? ”

Chapter 14: Chapter 13

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The dining room was too warm. Not from the fire burning steadily in the hearth or the candles flickering softly across the table, but from the pressure — the kind of dense, invisible weight that settled when multiple cosmic beings tried to act civilized over something as deceptively innocent as a pasta dinner. The air felt too thick, the kind that wrapped around your shoulders like an overly affectionate relative, refusing to let you breathe without reminding you of everything you were trying to forget.

Agatha sat at the head of the table, her posture immaculate, as if perfect posture could somehow anchor her to the present. Her fingers trembled slightly against her glass of water, catching the light like it might be the only thing holding her together. She hadn’t really touched the food — not beyond a few vague stabs at rigatoni that ended with pasta being pushed in lazy arcs across her plate. Her eyes wandered often, closing between words and blinking as if trying to force reality to stay in one place. Her jaw clenched, then loosened, then clenched again. A rhythm of resistance.

 

Because every time she blinked too long, something came.

 

A scream — guttural and inhuman. The explosion of violet fire bursting from her own hands. A witch on her knees, chanting an ancient dialect until her mouth dissolved to ash.

 Agatha blinked herself back to the present and lifted the glass. The water was blessedly cold against her lips.

To her right sat Rio — half-leaning, half-hovering, like her soul couldn’t decide if it wanted to watch or interfere. She hadn’t touched her plate. The chair wasn’t even pulled properly to the table; she’d sat down without care for formality, elbows planted, chin resting in one hand, gaze locked on Agatha like she might miss the moment the woman unraveled. Her expression was unreadable to most, but to Agatha, it was a mosaic of fear, love, and relentless devotion. Her other hand rested between them, palm up, an open invitation.

Agatha hadn’t reached for it yet.

At the other end of the table sat Eva, looking like the smug poster child of a divine fashion house. Dressed in white silk with golden embroidery that caught every flicker of candlelight, she twirled her fork through fettuccine with celestial grace and moaned — loudly — after taking a bite.

 

“My gods,” Eva sighed with scandalous satisfaction, “Lilia, did you enchant this? No human should be able to cook like this. What is this sauce?”

 

From the archway of the kitchen, Lilia rolled her eyes so hard it might’ve counted as a minor seismic event. She wiped her hands on a floral towel and replied without looking, “Tomato. Basilico. And the tears of my patience. Eat. Don’t talk . You talk too much. Like your sister. All tongue, no filter.”

 

Rio’s mouth twitched dangerously close to a smirk, the kind she only allowed when Lilia was around — because even the personification of Death knew better than to test the woman who made the lasagna. Lilia passed behind Agatha and, with terrifying precision, used a pair of tongs to drop an aggressive heap of green beans onto her plate.

 

Agatha sighed and didn't look up. “I don’t want beans.”

 

“They’re not for wanting,” Lilia snapped. “They’re for not dying.” 

 

Agatha groaned and dropped her forehead onto the table. "I hate all of you."

 

"You love us," Rio corrected, sliding her hand up Agatha's spine gently.

 

Lilia, completely unfazed, walked around the table and smacked a napkin into Agatha's hand. "No face on the wood. I polished it."

 

Agatha raised her head just enough to glare at her. "You didn't even ask how I'm feeling."

 

Lilia shrugged. "You didn’t eat your beans. I assumed you were dying."

 

Nick, mouth full of garlic bread, giggled. “Lilia’s scary.”

 

Nicole didn’t laugh. She was staring at Eva, head tilted, lips pursed like she was trying to calculate something with her eyes. “ She ’s scary.”

 

Eva grinned, undeterred. “That’s not very polite, Nicky. I’m your aunt.”

 

“My what now?” Nicole asked, incredulous.

 

“Aunt. Sort of. Cosmic aunt. We kinda share the same cosmic DNA or whatever… I helped you moms create you. ”

 

Nicole blinked. She looked at Rio. Then Agatha. Then back to Eva. Her frown was surgical.

 

“That’s not how babies are made.”

 

Nick piped in from his side of the table. “Like with the stork, right?”

 

Agatha groaned and pinched the bridge of her nose. “No birds at dinner. None. Once you start with it'll never end until you reach the penguins.”

 

But Nicole was still watching Eva with the eyes of someone who didn’t yet have the language for what she felt — but felt it all the same. A low, steady awareness. Gravity, pulled toward something she didn’t yet understand.

Nick, on the other hand, had already decided this was the best dinner of his entire life. 

 

“I didn’t even know pasta could look like this,” he said through a mouthful, gesturing toward the layered lasagna slice on his plate with awe. “This is like... anime food. You know? Like, Studio Ghibli level.”

 

Lilia, apron dusted with flour and expression of long-suffering patience, walked past and dropped a few extra green beans onto Nicole’s plate. “Eat. All of it. You need iron. And don’t talk with your mouth full, Nico.”

 

Nick swallowed dramatically. “Yes, Grandma.”

 

“I’m not your grandma,” Lilia muttered, but she didn't mean to correct him. “I’m too young and too beautiful.” But her voice softened on the last word, her hand brushing his curls before she turned her back.

 

Rio leaned in, voice low and meant for Agatha’s ears alone. “You’re not breathing again.”

 

Agatha startled as if dragged from underwater. She blinked fast and gave a shaky, embarrassed smile. “Sorry, baby. I just—”

 

White tile painted in blood. Screams echoing off stone. Her name screamed in desperation as a spell cracked reality. Violet light bleeding through the walls. Rio. Her hands glowing. Her mouth whispering something ancient. A kiss to her wrist. The beginning of everything.

 

“— I’m fine,” Agatha finished lamely.

 

Rio raised a brow, unimpressed. “You’re full of shit. And your hand is shaking.”

 

“That’s just what happens when your sister dresses like the pope’s concubine.”

 

“I heard that,” Eva chimed, mouth full of pasta.

 

“You were meant to.”

 

Lilia circled again, refilling glasses with the kind of energy that could end wars or start them. She poured more wine into Agatha’s and patted her cheek. “ Eat . Or I feed you with a funnel.”

 

Nick nearly inhaled a breadstick laughing. “Do it, Granny!”

 

Eva leaned toward Nicole again and stage-whispered, “Your family is so violent. I’m obsessed.”

 

Agatha didn’t laugh. Her eyes closed again. Just for a second.

 

Power exploding from her chest. Witches falling to their knees. Smoke. Screaming. A battlefield turned to glass.

 

Her breath caught in her throat. She gripped the edge of the table.

 

Rio stood in one smooth motion, her chair screeching backward. “Enough. She’s not okay .”

 

But Agatha’s hand reached out, wrapping around Rio’s wrist. Her touch was firm.

 

“Sit,” she said, quietly but firmly. “Please.”

 

Rio didn’t sit right away. She hovered.

 

Eva licked a smear of sauce off her thumb and said in a lazy drawl, “You’re all so dramatic. This is why I don’t do family dinners.”

 

Agatha opened her eyes again. They were wet.

 

“Eva,” she said, her voice barely above a whisper. “What happens if I stop remembering?”

 

Eva tilted her head like a curious owl. “Do you want honesty?”

 

“ No ,” Agatha whispered. “But I need it.”

 

“Then you stop being her . The her you were. The her you are. You become someone else. Maybe that’s not the worst thing.”

 

Agatha’s throat worked like she was swallowing broken glass. No words came.

 

Then a small, warm hand covered her forearm. Nicole.

 

“You’re still my mom, right?” she asked, her voice very small.

 

Agatha looked at her daughter — and she smiled.

 

“Yeah, baby,” she whispered. “I’m still your mom. Always .”

 

But somewhere deep inside her chest, something was splintering apart like ice under too much weight. And Rio felt it like thunder cracking through bone.

 

Rio let the moment settle — let the laughter hang like faint perfume in the air — before she moved again.

 

With a soft sigh, she looked toward the children, her voice dropping into that gentle but firm register that every parent developed over time. "Alright, you two," she said, tapping the table with two fingers. " Time for bed . Grown-ups need to have a very boring, very adult conversation."

 

Nicole narrowed her eyes in suspicion immediately. "Why do adults always say it’s boring when it’s obviously top-secret and stressful?"

 

Nick, ever the agreeable chaos child, jumped out of his seat. "Top-secret? Cool! Night!"

 

Nicole didn’t budge. Her gaze flicked from Agatha’s pale face to Rio’s rigid shoulders, then to Eva — who was now delicately licking tomato sauce off her thumb with the smug calm of someone who knew too much and gave too few damns.

 

" Nicole ," Rio said again, and this time her tone was edged with something protective. Not harsh. Not commanding. Just... final.

 

Nicole groaned, dramatically rolling her eyes. "Fine. But I want a full debrief in the morning. None of that 'you’re too young' nonsense. I’m basically a godling, you know."

 

Rio blinked. "What did you just say?"

 

Nicole shrugged as she stood up. "I don’t know. It felt right."

 

Nick darted over to Agatha, pressing a loud, messy kiss to her cheek. "Night, Mom! You smell like soap and burnt toast."

 

"Thanks, sweetheart. I think," Agatha murmured, trying — and failing — to smile.

 

Lilia rose from her seat and placed her napkin down with care. She walked over to Agatha first, cupping her face between warm hands. Her touch was motherly, grounding.

 

"You don’t need to explain anything to me, cara mia," she said gently, her accent thicker with emotion. "Just get better. And don’t be stubborn."

 

Agatha’s breath caught. Her throat tightened again. But she managed a nod.

 

Then Lilia turned to Rio, and the sharp Italian matron returned.

 

"You take care of her, or I swear I’ll drag you back from the underworld by your ear. Capisce?"

 

Rio bowed her head slightly, one hand to her chest. "I swear it."

 

Satisfied — though muttering something that sounded suspiciously like a curse against all divine beings — Lilia snapped her fingers. "Kids. Upstairs. Now. I’ll tell you the story about the haunted pasta pot."

 

Nick gasped. Nicole squinted. "That better not be a metaphor."

 

And with that, Lilia ushered them out, the warm murmur of their voices trailing away like a fading song.

 

Rio closed the door behind them. The silence that followed was heavier.

Agatha’s shoulders dropped. Her fingers trembled slightly again, and she looked down at the table like it had betrayed her somehow.

 

Eva, still twirling pasta, said nothing. Just waited.

 

And then, finally, Rio moved. She slid her hand over Agatha’s again.

 

"Alright," she said softly. "Let’s talk about what’s breaking you before it breaks everything else."

 

The silence that followed the children’s exit was louder than anything that had come before it. Their laughter and the scuffle of feet up the stairs faded into muffled echoes, swallowed by the thick, expectant stillness in the room. The kind of silence that weighed heavy behind the ribs. The kind that demanded truth.

Agatha sat with her back straighter than before, the skin around her eyes tight, her jaw locked with decision. Rio never left her side. One arm behind her chair, one hand on the table, fingers brushing the back of Agatha’s. The contact was grounding. She didn’t speak — only watched, waited.

“I want it gone,” Agatha finally said, voice low but steady. “The other life. All of it. ”

Rio’s breath caught. “Agatha…”

“No. Listen.” She turned to Eva now, locking eyes with her. “Erase that life, Eva. Every flicker of it. I don’t need to know how I died or who I was or what I did. I don’t want to carry that weight anymore. I’ve got enough in this life already.”

Eva leaned forward slowly, the smirk she usually wore replaced with something calmer, quieter. “You’re sure?”

“I’m sure of this,” Agatha whispered. She took Rio’s hand fully now, laced their fingers together. “Everything I need is here. In this life. In her .”

A silence passed like wind through a graveyard — cold, stirring, but not unwelcome.

Eva’s eyes narrowed a bit. “There are consequences.”

“I know,” Agatha said, though the tremor in her hand betrayed the weight of what she was accepting. “I’ll feel hollow. I’ll dream things that don’t make sense.I might be afraid all the time. That my brain might reach for something I won’t understand and scream at me in my sleep.”

Rio’s hand tightened around hers, but Agatha kept going.

“You said if I ever tried to find it again, it could kill me. Or worse.”

Eva nodded. “Yes. If your soul tries to reawaken those memories — if something triggers them — you could collapse mentally. Or mutate . Your essence could shift into something else. Something not... human.”

Agatha raised an eyebrow. “Define ‘ not human .’”

Eva leaned back, folding her arms. “Hitler.”

Agatha blinked. “What?”

Rio let out a dry, startled laugh. “Seriously? She’s not that asshole, Eva. You’re overreacting.”

“It’s just an example,” Eva said with a shrug. “We tried to help him, Rio. Rebirth, redirection, redemption... but he kept going back to the wrong memories. Refused to change course. And he became what we call a Nexus — untouchable, unmoldable. Chaos with a heartbeat.”

“Okay, wow.” Agatha blinked. “That’s... wildly unhelpful.”

“Worked with Madonna too. Same process. Not as destructive, but just as persistent. I think Lilia still hasn’t forgiven her from some past lives.”

“She hasn’t,” Rio muttered under her breath. “She still doesn't listen to her music.”

Eva leaned forward. “You’re not either of them, Agatha. But I have to say it. Just in case.”

Agatha exhaled. Her voice cracked slightly. “You’ve seen my kids. You’ve seen what they mean to me. Don’t take them away from me too.”

“I wouldn’t,” Eva said quickly.

“Don’t touch this life,” Agatha continued. “Not my kids. Not my job. Not what I feel when I look at Rio. If you wipe that too, I’ll know. I will know. There will be a hole too loud to ignore. And I’ll chase you to the gates of hell because of it.”

Rio turned, her other hand cradling Agatha’s jaw now, thumb stroking beneath her eye.

“My love,” she murmured, voice shaking with the intensity she’d buried for so long. “Even if it’s gone, I’ll stay . I’ll remind you. I’ll love you again from the beginning if I have to. I’ll burn the world to keep you close.”

Agatha leaned into the touch.

Eva cleared her throat. “There’s one more thing.”

“Of course there is,” Agatha muttered.

“If I erase the connection from that life, the thing that originally brought Rio to you — your soul’s echo of recognition — it might shift how you see her. You might not understand why you love her, or what she is. You might fear her.”

Agatha frowned. “But I already know what she is. She’s Death. She’s here. I know why.”

“No,” Eva said, shaking her head slowly. “You think you know. But you only understand it now because your past self paved the road. Every time she touched you, every intimate moment, every time you dreamed of her — those unlocked what you remembered. What you were . I can keep the moments. But I’ll have to change the context. She’ll be someone you met by chance. Not someone whose existence vibrated through time to find you again.”

Agatha paused. Her throat moved with the effort of swallowing. “And then?”

“Then Rio will have to tell you again. Gently. Carefully. Slowly . Not like the freight train she was last time.”

“Subtlety is not her strong suit,” Agatha said, half-smiling.

Rio groaned softly. “I tried . But you kissed me before I could lie properly.”

Agatha laughed. Just a little. Then it faded.

“What if I don’t believe her this time?” she asked. “What if I don’t love her the same way?”

“You will,” Rio whispered. “Maybe differently. Maybe slower. But it’s you and me. Always has been.”

Agatha’s eyes glistened again. “Okay,” she whispered. “Do it.”

She turned back to Eva.

“But promise me — don’t touch the kids. Don’t touch Rio. And don’t take the part of me that knows how to fight for what I love.”

Eva studied her for a long moment, then nodded once.

“You’ll forget how she entered your life. Not why she stayed.”

The room had gone quiet again, not from fear this time — but reverence. The silence was thick and full of meaning, like the moments before a storm or a ceremony. Eva took her time crossing the space between them, the emerald velvet of her robes whispering against the old wooden floor. She sank gracefully into the chair across from Agatha, the velvet groaning in protest, as if even furniture could sense the weight of what was about to happen.

Rio remained behind Agatha’s chair, unmoving, her presence a steady anchor in a sea of unknowns. She didn’t speak, but her hands did — fingertips brushing soft, grounding circles into Agatha’s shoulders. The touch was deliberate, slow, sacred. Her thumbs lingered over the bones of Agatha’s clavicle as if to memorize their warmth, as if already mourning what was about to change. Eva leaned forward then, hands folding gently, almost maternally, on either side of Agatha’s head. Her fingers were warm. Brighter than skin should be. The glow of something ancient pulsed beneath her nails, and her white eyes softened to something close to grief.

“You’re sure, Agatha?” she asked, her voice quiet but threaded with steel.

Agatha hesitated, just for a second. Then she nodded once. “Yes. In at least one life… I think I deserve to be happy . Just don’t…” Her voice cracked — barely audible — but the fear beneath it was a scream.

Eva’s smile, though faint, was genuine. “Take what makes your heart beat. Got it.” She tilted her head with mock dramatics. “You humans are such romantics. It’s charming. And very inconvenient.”

Agatha raised a brow. “You’re not inspiring confidence.”

“Oh, please.” Eva rolled her eyes. “I’m an entity, not your barista. Confidence is implied. Now close your eyes, honey. Picture Nicholas. Nicole. And Rio. Lock them in your mind. Their faces. The sound of their voices. That will help me isolate the right pieces.”

Agatha’s breath caught. “Wait — can you mess this up?”

“I don’t make mistakes,” Eva replied smugly. Then she shrugged. “But… better to be sure. Unless you want to end up the next Hitler. Or worse, the next Madonna. Do not make me reroute your soul into a pop star. I won’t survive it.”

“Fuck you, Eva,” Agatha groaned. “Start already.”

She turned slightly and met Rio’s gaze. Her voice dropped to something more fragile, almost reverent. “Te veo?”

Rio leaned forward, brushing her lips softly against Agatha’s temple. “Te veo.”

And then, everything changed.

The world fell away like paper peeling from old walls. Warmth surged through Agatha’s skull first — golden, humming heat that wasn’t painful but wasn’t comfortable either. It was light made liquid, poured directly into the corridors of her consciousness. She gasped softly but didn’t pull away, because she wasn’t afraid. Not of the magic. Not of the pain. Only of forgetting what mattered. She felt her mind opening — not metaphorically, but tangibly. It was like watching herself unfold, layer by layer, until even the air inside her lungs had a memory.

A forest of thorns. Her feet bare and bloody. A circle of witches chanting in Old Greek. Her voice rose above theirs. Her hand outstretched. One by one, the witches fell. Their bodies convulsed. Their magic ripped from their chests and swallowed by the violet crown pulsing above her head.

Agatha felt her body slowly falling into darkness, and with each new memory that surfaced, she no longer remembered what had happened in the one before. Only the emptiness in her chest remained, pressing against her like a sharpened blade at her throat. She could feel her soul fighting against every memory being stripped away — every loss she had endured in that other life, every pain, every spell cast being reset to zero.
She apologized to that first Agatha — the witch, the mother, the wife of Death . It wasn’t her fault, the choices she had been forced to make. It wasn’t her or Rio’s fault for what had happened to Nick. She was deeply sorry to have to live this new life without the essence of what that other Agatha had gone through. But it was for the good of both of them, because in the end, they were the same soul — just carrying different wounds.

Stone corridors. The scent of mold and blood. A mother’s voice screaming in fear — her own mother, Evanora. A child — herself — hidden behind a column, teeth clenched, watching her future burn beneath torches of those she would one day command.

The basement. Runes that flickered with Wanda’s breath. Her own laughter, unhinged and shaking as the walls crumbled. She was the predator in that scene. Wanda had been right to fear her.

A mirror, cracked. Her own face splintered into dozens. Each reflected a different life: ruler, murderer, lover, savior, monster.

Rio’s face. Lips parted in a whisper. Her thumb brushing Agatha’s cheek as Agatha’s skin turned cold. Their last kiss in another life. Violet light blooming between their mouths like a farewell spell. A goodbye not meant to be final.

“So that’s how I died… I gave myself to Death. My Death.”

And then…

Gone.

Like pages ripped from a book. Like doors slammed shut. Each memory yanked from her, each one leaving behind the ghost of a heartbeat. Agatha cried out softly — but not from pain. From absence . A thousand memories vanishing into white nothingness, like trying to remember a dream seconds after waking.

Silence.

Eva slowly drew her hands back, the glow fading from her skin. Her fingers trembled slightly as she settled them into her lap. Agatha opened her eyes just for a second — wide, hazy, unfocused — locking onto Eva like she knew her, like something inside her still screamed: “You! You did this!” For a fleeting second, Eva thought Agatha might be able to resist the memory block — the way her eyes seemed to glow with purple and control. But the thought didn’t finish forming. Agatha’s voice never had the chance to leave her lips as they parted to speak. Agatha’s eyes rolled back, and her body went completely limp — out of exhaustion, weakness, and because that was one of the effects Eva embedded in every living being whose mind needed to be reset. Her body swayed, and before gravity could claim her, Rio was already there. She caught her gently, like she was the only thing that had ever mattered. Agatha’s head rested against Rio’s chest, her breath shallow but present. Rio pressed her lips to her forehead, her tears falling silently into Agatha’s hair.

“She’s stronger than most,” Eva murmured, her voice low and tight. She blinked rapidly, realizing — too late — that she’d started crying . “Most people don’t come back looking at me like that . Daring me, challenging me. She almost made me stop in the middle of everything.”

Rio nodded, brushing Agatha’s hair behind her ear. “That’s Agatha. She always was impossible.”

Eva smiled weakly. “When she wakes, she won’t know me as Life anymore. Just... Eva.”

“I’ll remind her that she made you cry, you know? She’ll love that.” Rio turned, ready to carry Agatha upstairs — but Eva’s voice stopped her.

“One more thing.” She stepped forward, serious now. “I’d erase the truth from her friends. Everyone who knows what you are. All it takes is one joke, one off-hand comment, and everything could come back. I didn’t erase her past like I normally do — it would’ve broken her beyond repair. You would lose her again. So I sealed it. Locked it in a place her mind can’t access. But the door still exists. Triggers can still reach it.”

Rio tightened her hold on Agatha, like shielding her physically might help. “I’ll do it. I’ll take care of everything.”

“Good.” Eva exhaled, watching her sister cradle the woman they both knew had changed everything. “And Rio…”

“What?”

“You’re my favorite. And I am proud to see you happy and… human. But don’t let it go to your head.”

Rio rolled her eyes, smiling faintly as she turned toward the stairs. “Too late.”

The curtains stirred with the early morning breeze, casting a soft golden shimmer across the bedspread like sunlight straining through a memory. The room had been still for two days. Not quiet — still. The kind of stillness that makes every tick of the clock feel like it’s holding its breath. The kind of stillness that clings to grief before it’s born.

Rio hadn’t left the chair beside the bed.

Her body was there — arms resting on her knees, chin occasionally cradled in her palm — but her soul hovered somewhere closer to the mattress, closer to Agatha. She hadn’t slept. She hadn’t eaten. She didn’t dare blink too long in case she missed something. Anything. The flick of a finger. The flutter of a lash. A sound that might mean Agatha was coming back .
For forty-eight hours, Rio had lived in quiet desperation. Covering tracks. Scrubbing traces of herself from memories that no longer belonged to her — except for Wanda and Lilia. She couldn’t risk explaining everything again from scratch if something went wrong. They were her anchors, should the worst resurface.

The children were left untouched. Rio wouldn’t violate what they knew. Nicole had needed a full hour of sarcasm, stubborn silence, and one accidental tear before she promised not to say too much. Nick — Nick was easy . His world was cartoons and cereal and the vague understanding that his family was weird in ways he didn’t fully care to question. For now, that was enough.
To everyone else, Rio had rewritten herself into something soft. An intern. A student. A shadow at Agatha’s side who had slowly, shyly, earned her love.

But now… A breath. It broke the air like a ripple through still water.

Rio sat upright, frozen.

Agatha’s fingers twitched. Her eyes blinked once, slowly, then again, as if adjusting to a brightness she hadn’t known in years. When her gaze finally found Rio, something cracked — soft and silent — in Rio’s chest. Recognition bloomed instantly. But not fully. Agatha looked at her with warmth, familiarity, and something else — something like confusion wrapped in certainty. Her gaze was full of Rio, but missing the edges of how and why. Like reading a poem she once memorized, now only half-recalled.

She tried to sit up. Her limbs didn’t obey. Her body felt like it belonged to someone else, and that someone hadn’t used it in years. Rio was already at her side, slipping an arm around her back, gently lifting her, guiding her until she could sit against the headboard. A glass of water pressed into her palm.

“Here. Go slow,” Rio said, her voice trembling beneath the softness. “You’ve been out for two days. Your body’s still catching up.”

Agatha took the glass, sipped, then looked at her. Her brows pulled together, and her lips parted with hesitation.

“Something’s different,” she murmured, her voice like gravel and silk.

Rio’s breath hitched. Her hands froze where they hovered beside the blanket.

Of course she noticed.

“Is it me?” Rio asked, trying to sound casual — but the fear bled through. The kind of fear only soulmates knew. The fear of being forgotten by the one who made you whole.

Agatha’s expression softened. She smiled, and though her face was pale and tired, her smile held truth. “No, my love... it’s not you. It’s never you.”

The weight in Rio’s chest broke, collapsing inward with relief. Her hand found Agatha’s again.

“Just...” Agatha’s voice faltered. “Teach me some things again, okay? How to love. How to forgive. Some of it feels... wrong. Disconnected . Like I know it, but the shape changed.”

“I will,” Rio promised, leaning forward. “Anything you want to learn, I’ll tell you. This time, I’ll tell you everything slow. Gentle .”

Agatha scanned the room, the traces of light, the familiarity that felt ever so slightly... reconstructed. “Where are the kids?”

“In the kitchen. Having breakfast. I was going to take them to school. They’ll be thrilled you’re awake.” Rio smiled, brushing Agatha’s hair behind her ear. “Nicole’s been spiraling. Nick cried every hour. It was... a lot.”

Agatha frowned. “Why? Why did I sleep so long?”

Rio hesitated, her thumb trailing down Agatha’s cheek.

“Side effect,” she said, almost playfully. “Comes with dating Death, baby. You should’ve stuck to Tinder. Maybe found a nice yoga instructor. Or a florist.”

“How boring” Agatha exhaled a laugh — weak, but real. “And give up the title of the woman who brings Death to her knees every night? Please . My ego wouldn’t survive the loss.”

Rio laughed with her, but her heart had started pounding again. Something about the way Agatha spoke... too clear. Too composed. Her tone had changed. And then Agatha tilted her face toward the touch of Rio’s hand. Her lips parted slightly.

“It’s good to be back in control of my body and mind ,” she said, almost too calmly. “I’d been feeling... trapped .”

Rio’s hand froze mid-stroke. Her eyes narrowed. Trapped?

That was a word Agatha shouldn’t have remembered. A sensation that should’ve been gone. Buried with the sealed memories. Compartmentalized and unreachable.

And yet…

Rio stared at her and Agatha met her gaze. Her smile lingered — too long, too sure . Too Agatha.

It tilted. Shifted. That smirk — playful, teasing, dark with something beneath it — spread like ink in water. Slowly. Carefully . Then her eyes changed. Just a flicker of Purple . Vivid. Alive.

Rio stepped back, a hand pressing instinctively to her chest. Not in fear.

In awe.

“Agatha...?” Her voice was paper-thin.

Agatha tilted her head, a mockery of innocence in the angle. Then her voice slipped out in a whisper that was both hers and not just. “Miss me, my love?”




Chapter End Notes

Hey everyone, just a heads-up that we're heading toward the end of the story. Just one or two more chapters to go before the conclusion. Thank you so much for staying with me this far.

Chapter 15: Chapter 14

Chapter Notes

Sorry I'm late

Rio hadn’t moved.

She stood frozen, like a broken marionette, hands half-raised, chest barely rising with breath, her entire being short-circuiting beneath the weight of what she was seeing. It was Agatha — Agatha's voice, her face, her scent — but the way her mouth curled into a smirk, the way her eyes shimmered like dusk over a battlefield, was something else entirely. It wasn’t just familiarity. It was familiarity dressed in something dangerous. Something ancient. Something Rio had felt only once before — on the day she watched that woman die in her arms.

“ You —” Rio’s voice cracked, stuttered, then broke entirely. Her lips parted but no words came. She blinked, shook her head as if it might clear the surreal fog curling around her mind. “You… I mean… You— how ?”

Agatha stretched.

Her arms rose above her head with feline laziness, her back arched just slightly beneath the blanket, a sigh slipping from her lips like a woman who had just been handed back her throne. The movement was languid, calculated, every inch of it a silent performance — the kind meant to be watched. Her body remembered the luxury of command. Her fingers twitched in the air, muscle memory recalling spells she no longer had access to, but still loved the feeling of casting.

“Oh, sweet merciful Death ,” Agatha murmured with exaggerated relief, rolling her neck until it popped. “Lying in that bed was murder for my spine. If I have to be human again, I at least expect silk sheets and a foot massage.” She glanced at Rio through thick lashes and gave a wicked smile. “You still give those, right?”

Rio stared at her, mouth slightly agape, visibly trying to reboot her entire understanding of reality.

“You—” she tried again, her voice barely holding form, “You can’t expect me to not freak out right now! Agatha, what you just did — what you are — it’s not supposed to be possible! You manipulated Eva’s power! Life ! You rewired reality like it’s your private little puppet show! You should be— dead . Gone. Or worse—”

Agatha interrupted her by grabbing Rio’s face between both palms, her hands warm, unbothered, almost amused by the way Death herself looked ready to collapse.

“Shhh,” she said gently, mockingly. “Another five seconds and you’re going to burst a blood vessel in that pretty head of yours, my love. And I would hate to ruin this masterpiece that is your face.”

Rio tried to pull away, but Agatha’s grip held her just firmly enough to keep her in place — not in control, not dominating, but anchoring. She looked into Rio’s eyes, and though her expression was playful, her gaze was sharp enough to carve stone.

“ Listen , I know this is... shocking,” Agatha said slowly, like she was explaining math to a child. “I wasn’t exactly planning on coming back with all my parts intact, you know. The PTA mom and the nightmare witch all in one tidy, sarcastic little package.” She let go of Rio’s face with a sigh, letting her hands drop dramatically into her lap. “But I figured since the universe was already screwing with me, I might as well screw it back.”

Rio staggered a step back, visibly thrown, fingers curling into fists at her sides.

“ You’re insane ,” she breathed. “You are completely, impossibly, insane .”

Agatha lifted her chin, brushing her hair over her shoulder in one practiced, theatrical flick. She smiled like a villain at the top of the tower, completely unbothered by the rising storm below.

“Yes,” she said sweetly. “But I’m your insane.”

Rio stared and Agatha stared back. Then she laughed . A soft, throaty laugh that escalated into something warmer and more genuine — until her hand lifted again, fingers swirling like she was conjuring the memory of old spells, even though she knew they wouldn’t come. But the gesture felt too good to resist.

“Oh, it’s so good to be back,” she sighed with an indulgent grin. “Don’t you think? All this—” she gestured around the room with a flourish “—this domestic bliss and celestial drama. It’s like a soap opera where God got drunk in the writers’ room.”

Rio still didn’t move.

“Seriously, cariño, you’re looking at me like a kicked puppy,” Agatha said, tone dipping into something resembling affection. “Don’t be so heartbroken. I’m still me. Just… upgraded .”

Rio’s voice was quieter now, colored with disbelief and the ghost of grief. “How much do you remember?”

Agatha’s eyes gleamed. “ Enough .”

“Enough to what , Agatha? Enough to destroy the balance of the timeline? To unravel yourself? To die again? To —”

“ To love you again . And again. And again,” Agatha cut in sharply, her voice suddenly tender. She leaned forward, resting her elbows on her knees, hands folded under her chin as she looked up at Rio. “I didn’t survive two lives to forget the only thing that ever made either of them worth living.”

Rio blinked hard, her jaw tightening, her breath shaking with the pressure of everything she wanted to say but couldn’t yet name.

“I want to see the kids,” Agatha said lightly, straightening with the same grace she always carried. “We’ll discuss the full ‘ I defied the will of the universe ’ speech later, okay? I’m starving and I’d like to not die again from low blood sugar.”

Rio opened her mouth, closed it, opened it again.

Agatha winked. “You’re adorable when you glitch. Like a broken technology…”

“I’m going to kill you,” Rio whispered.

“ You tried ,” Agatha grinned. “Didn’t stick, right?.”

Rio closed her eyes. “Gods, I hate you.”

Agatha smirked, voice a purr. “And yet... you love me.”

And Rio, still disoriented, still reeling, still gripping onto the fraying edges of logic, couldn’t deny it.

Because she did. More than anything.

Even now.

The scent of toasted bread and warm honey lingered in the kitchen, golden light slanting across the tiled floor in long, quiet stripes. The world outside was mundane — birds chirping, a car humming by, the faint rattle of the wind against the windows. But inside, everything felt like glass. Fragile . Holding its breath.

Agatha stepped into the kitchen as though the very air might break her. She paused at the threshold, her bare feet brushing the cool floor, her eyes locking on the two forms at the table. Nicole sat with one knee pulled to her chest, picking lazily at a bowl of cereal while scrolling something on her tablet. Nick was halfway through his second piece of toast, kicking the leg of the table with small, unfocused movements, humming a tune under his breath.
They were just... there. Whole. Alive. And Agatha — despite the memories of this life that still floated in her mind like dust caught in light — felt as if she hadn’t seen them in a thousand years. In another life, she had lost them. Nicole didn’t even get the chance of living. And Nick… he… In another life, they were memories she carried like wounds. Her heart clenched painfully, the phantom grief of that loss rising like a wave she could barely breathe through.

Nicole looked up first. Her brown eyes — sharp, always watching — locked onto Agatha’s instantly. And for a moment, something in her face tightened. Not fear. Not joy. Just a flicker of... awareness . Something was off . Something was different . She knew her mother — better than most. And that version of her standing in the doorway had a weight behind her gaze that didn’t quite match the woman she kissed goodnight two days ago. But when Nicole saw Rio, just behind Agatha in the hallway, shake her head once — calm, subtle — she understood. Not everything needed to be said right away.

"You’re awake," Nicole said instead, pushing her chair back and walking toward her. “I thought you were going to sleep forever.”

Agatha hesitated. Her hands were halfway raised, then lowered, then raised again. She didn’t know if she deserved to hold them — her babies, from this life. Her babies from any life. But Nicole didn’t wait. She stepped in and wrapped her arms tight around Agatha’s waist, her cheek pressed to her mother’s chest. Agatha exhaled shakily and melted into the embrace, her arms wrapping around her daughter with a trembling grip.

"Mama didn’t tell us everything," Nicole continued against her, "about what happened with you and Aunt Eva. But I figured... something big . I just didn’t know it would make you disappear like that."

Agatha pressed her lips to the top of Nicole’s head and closed her eyes. Her throat felt too tight to speak. "She did the right thing," she whispered eventually. "I’ll tell you both everything. When the time is right. I promise, sweetheart."

Nick had come up behind them now, uncertain, clutching a half-eaten toast in one hand. He looked up at his mother, his expression pinched with worry that didn’t quite fit on his little face.

“Are you okay, Mom?” he asked in a small voice, watching her as if she might disappear again at any second. “You look sad.”

Agatha turned and dropped to her knees in front of him, gathering him into her arms without hesitation this time. She held him tight, her fingers buried in his hair, her lips pressed to his temple. Then again. And again. Like she had to keep confirming he was real. That this was real.

“I missed you,” she whispered hoarsely. “ So much , my darling. Both of you. I missed you both more than I can say.”

Nick blinked, confused. “But… we’re right here.”

Agatha pulled back just enough to look at him, cupping his cheeks. Her smile trembled.

“You are now,” she murmured. “Exactly where you’ve always belonged.”

The silence that followed was full — not uncomfortable, but thick with things unspoken. Rio stood just a few steps away, watching the scene with eyes that shimmered too brightly for comfort. She knew Agatha was holding onto more than just the children — she was holding onto every thread of pain and love from both lives. And she was doing it well . Too well.

But the cracks would come. Rio cleared her throat gently, breaking the silence.

“Nicky,” she said softly. “Would you mind grabbing the e-bike and taking your brother to school today?”

Nicole turned with a groan. “ Seriously ?”

Rio gave her a look.

“I need to stay with your mom this morning,” she explained, her voice carefully even. “She needs me here. I promise we’ll sit down later and talk. Everything you’re wondering about — we’ll talk. But not right now. Right now, she just needs to be... here.”

Nick nodded solemnly. “Okay. I can take him. Let’s go, little demon.”

Agatha stood again and turned to the kitchen counter, where two carefully packed lunchboxes waited. She picked them up, paused, and then bent to kiss the tops of both their heads.

“Thank you, my loves,” she said. “I’ll be right here when you get back. I promise.”

Nicole looked at her a second longer, then took her brother’s hand and headed for the door.

Rio placed a hand gently on Agatha’s back, guiding her toward the table. “You okay?” she whispered.

Agatha didn’t answer at first. Her eyes stayed on the door where her children had just left, her fingers still gripping the edge of the table as if steadying herself. Then, slowly, she exhaled and looked over her shoulder at Rio.

“I will be,” she said. “Eventually.”

But the way her voice dipped — low and distant — told Rio that part of Agatha still wasn’t in the room.

Not yet.

The kitchen had quieted again. The laughter of the children outside was replaced with a low, ticking silence that pulsed between them like an invisible heartbeat. Agatha leaned against the counter, her arms crossed tight beneath her chest, fingers digging into the sleeves of her robe as if clinging to something solid. Rio stood a few feet away, watching her like one might watch the sea right before a storm — trying to predict where the next wave might hit.

Agatha wasn’t speaking.

She kept her eyes low, staring at nothing, as though afraid that if she looked at Rio too long she might say too much. Her silence wasn’t passive — it was electric, a fuse waiting to burn out. Rio’s patience cracked. Her hands slapped the table with a dull thud and she took a step forward, her voice rising — not in fury, but in sheer exhaustion.

“Your other self was so much easier to deal with,” she snapped, gesturing with both hands. “Gods, Agatha, we are past this. Come on. You’ve got two versions of yourself swirling in there — pick one and talk to me. Damn it, it’s me. I’m right here. Stop shutting me out.”

Agatha flinched, barely, but enough. Her head turned, lips parted, and for a second Rio thought she was going to say something cruel. Something sharp and sarcastic to deflect like she always did. But instead, her voice came out too thin. Brittle.

“I know!” she burst out, voice shaking. “It’s not that easy, okay? Everything inside of me is still... sorting itself out . I don’t remember everything , I don’t understand all of it. It’s like... I’m flipping through a book where half the pages are missing, and the ones that are left are out of order. I’m trying, Rio. I’m trying to breathe in this new skin. I’m… scared.”

Rio’s jaw tensed, her chest rising with the weight of her breath. “What are you scared of?”

Agatha blinked at her. Once. Twice. Then slowly, her lips trembled, and the dam cracked.

“I’m scared that what I did is going to cost me everything,” she said, voice so quiet it was almost swallowed by the room. “ You. Our children. Our lives. I rewrote the rules, Rio. I danced with power I didn’t even understand . What if the price isn’t memory or pain — what if it’s losing you? Losing them?”

Rio exhaled sharply and let out a sound between a laugh and a growl. “You can sleep like a baby, Agatha. Fuck the balance of the universe. Let it all burn. So long as you are alive and breathing, that’s all I care about.”

Agatha blinked rapidly, as if trying to keep tears from falling. She failed. Her chin dipped slightly, her shoulders curled inward. A breathy, humorless laugh escaped her.

“Why do you even love me?” she asked, voice breaking under the weight of self-loathing she’d buried so deeply in both lifetimes. “I’m manipulative, I’m bossy, I fake confidence better than I actually have it... and apparently I’m willing to override the will of fucking Life just because I refuse to go to therapy.”

Rio's lips curled upward despite herself. She stepped closer, her gaze softening, arms now crossed in mock judgment.

“Exactly,” she said with a faint grin. “That’s my girl.”

Agatha sniffled, swiping under her eyes like it offended her to cry in front of anyone—even Rio. Then, true to form, she straightened her spine, tossed her hair over her shoulder with theatrical grace, and raised a single eyebrow as if delivering a monologue on stage.

“Well. Glad to know I still do it for you. Even when I’m slightly unstable and reborn through cosmic cheating.”

Rio let out a soft, real laugh this time, then stepped in and wrapped her arms around Agatha, slow and firm, pulling her close until their bodies aligned like puzzle pieces. She felt the moment Agatha gave in — the way her muscles relaxed, the way her forehead pressed into Rio’s shoulder, the way her breath finally settled into rhythm.

“You always do it for me,” Rio whispered against her hair. “Even when I want to strangle you. Especially then.”

Agatha closed her eyes and let herself be held. Her entire body sagged into the embrace, as though for the first time in days she could finally stop fighting gravity. The weight of two lives, of two women, collapsed against the one person she had always returned to. And as Rio held her in that quiet kitchen, the scent of toast and jam fading around them, Agatha clung to her like she was the only anchor left in a world that wouldn’t stop shifting.

Rio backed away slightly from where she’d been leaning against the table, her arms folded, expression sharp. Her voice was low, but there was that deadly kind of calm — the kind that came before a storm with bones in its mouth.

“All right,” she said, already turning toward the kettle on the stove. “Here’s what we’re going to do. I’ll make that strawberry tea you like so much, and while I do, you’re going to tell me exactly when you started rooting yourself into this timeline. Into this life.” She shot Agatha a look over her shoulder. “And don’t even think about lying to me, Agatha. I may have been blind before, but I know now  —manipulation like this takes years of adaptation. You didn’t just seize the opportunity when Eva was stitching your soul back together. You were already in . Now tell me how the fuck did you do it.”

Behind her, Agatha rolled her eyes so hard it might’ve qualified as a ritual in itself. She gave a theatrical shrug and flounced into the nearest kitchen chair like she was settling into a throne.

“Fine. If that’s what you want. But it’s going to kill the romance. I mean, really — wouldn’t it have been nicer to believe our souls were simply two halves desperate to reunite across galaxies, woven by fate into a perfect, cosmic love story? I had a title in mind, by the way. Starbound Hearts . Very marketable.”

“Agathaaaa,” Rio snapped, turning just enough to give her a warning glare.

“Okay, okay.” Agatha waved a hand and then brought it to her heart in mock solemnity. “Here we go.”

Rio busied herself with the tea, boiling water, steeping the herbs. She needed the task to focus, to not lose her mind as Agatha opened her mouth with that familiar cadence — half confession, half performance.

“I was five,” Agatha began, twirling a spoon between her fingers, “when I first started dreaming. Violet light. Power humming under my skin. Witches kneeling. But I thought I was just an imaginative kid. Evanora always said that. ‘ You’re not a witch, Agatha, you’re just a dramatic little girl.’ ” She snorted softly, almost fondly. “But I always felt it — like something was missing. A part of me was stuck somewhere. I used to think... maybe I was just lonely. Maybe it was depression, trauma, whatever the fuck a human feels. But then you came into my life.”

She paused, tapping the spoon against the edge of her cup. Her expression didn’t change, but her voice lowered.

“Every night, I dreamed... watched , really. I saw myself, the other me — the poor powerless human — being touched by him, that repulsive pig. Him trying to plant his legacy in me like I was just another investment. Actually , Ralph was not really the whole problem, y’know? When you learn how it feels to be loved, to be touched by someone that matters your whole life and then… that ? It felt like torture . I wanted you back . I couldn’t move. Couldn’t scream . I saw everything through the eyes of that small, confused human version of me. It was... cruel.” Her throat tightened. “ I begged you . Every night. I didn’t even know why , but I begged you to come home .”

Rio’s hand froze mid-motion, fingers clenched around the teapot. Something in her chest cracked at the realization. So that was the voice. That was the whisper she had heard echoing across realms, a desperate pull that spanned timelines — it hadn’t been fate alone. It had been Agatha all along . Calling her . Subconsciously, silently, breaking through galaxies with nothing but pain and will.

Agatha’s lips curved again, but softer this time when she sees the realisation reaches Rio’s mind.

Rio sat slowly. Carefully. Her hands trembled once before curling around her own mug of tea. “That’s why I heard you,” she murmured. “I thought it was your soul calling me. But it wasn't just it… it was you. Actually you.”

Agatha nodded, sipping her tea. “When Nicole was born, it got easier, y’ know? I could feel you more. Not see you — not yet — but I knew you were close. The way Nicole slept? I knew Death was near. You were near. She was always calm. So I started asking for more.” She looked at Rio over the rim of the cup. “I wanted Nick back. I cried for him. Begged . I told myself it was selfish  —stealing from myself. But I wanted our family again.”

Rio covered her mouth with her fingers, eyes glassy.

“And then,” Agatha continued, tapping the side of her cup with a single fingernail, “I started searching. In my dreams, in my sleep. While the other Agatha — that poor woman — slept, I explored. Dug through scraps of ancient rituals. Built a summoning. Built my way bay to you. That night with my friends? The stupid little ritual we did for fun?” She leaned in, voice dropping. “I made it real. The Latin that left my mouth wasn’t from this life or a fuckin’ stupid mortal history book. It was from me. The witch. The woman who never forgot how to command things bigger than herself… Like Death.”

Rio gaped at her, utterly dumbfounded. “You’re kidding me.”

Agatha gave a theatrical shrug, tossing her hair over one shoulder. “Wouldn’t you like to believe that?”

“You manipulated the powers of my sister . Life , Agatha. You messed with Life .” Rio, still standing there with wide eyes and a forgotten cup of tea in her hand, finally let out a stunned breath. “I don’t know if I’m impressed or terrified.”

Agatha grinned and tilted her head, fingers toying with the rim of her cup.

“Whichever one gets you hotter at night for me, baby.”

Rio blinked like she was glitching .

Agatha laughed, absolutely delighted with herself. “Oh, and Ralph? That part was deliciously accidental. Delicious, perfect timing you showing up and messing with his head while I was messing with mine. We are definitely soulmates, my love, aren’t we? Well, but everything else? That was all me. Pushing little memories into myself. Letting the current Agatha believe it was just your influence.”
She took another sip, then reached over and gently poured more tea into her cup. Her fingers didn’t shake once.

“You woke things in me, sure. But most of the work? That. was. me . Of course it was me.”

Rio set the teacup down. Hard . Her mouth opened like she wanted to say something, but the only thing that came out was a strangled half-syllable. She didn’t speak, just watched her. Watched the way Agatha sipped the tea without hesitation, savoring it.

“ You manipulated the will of Life herself, ” Rio said flatly, eyes wide with disbelief. “Do you have any idea what that means?”

“Sure.” Agatha shrugged one shoulder and took another sip of tea. “It means I’m exceptional .”

Rio ran a hand down her face, exasperated.

Agatha’s eyes twinkled with mischief, but the next part of her story sobered her features.

“There’s more, honey… Things got messy when Ralph and that parasite did whatever they did. It shattered the wall. All my memories poured in at once. I couldn’t stop it. So that’s why I convinced myself that the idea of erasing everything wasn’t so bad, because, deep down, it wouldn't And then... Eva stepped in. She thought she was sewing it shut. Resetting me. But she didn’t realize I was already... awake . Not just a person with memories, but me , fully formed. You can’t reset what’s awake . So I watched. Every memory, every scar, every spell — as the witch . Not the mother, not the teacher. Her . And I didn’t lose them. Because to me, they weren’t memories. They were my life . That’s the loophole.”

Rio just stared.

“I used the coma,” Agatha went on, swirling her tea slowly, letting the aroma rise, “to rest. To align. I talked to her — the other me. We agreed. Merged. One soul. One story. And now? I remember both lives. As if I’d never died. As if I just... kept living.”

Rio didn’t move at first. She sat frozen, her spine straight, hands limp on the edge of the table as if every tendon had suddenly forgotten how to function. Her face was a picture of scrambled calculation — brows drawn tight, eyes squinting with disbelief, lips parted slightly like she was stuck halfway between shouting and sobbing. One could almost hear the whirring of her mind trying to reboot itself, like a machine fed too many conflicting commands at once.

Agatha’s words echoed through the air like the last note of a spell still buzzing through the room. The way she spoke, unbothered and smug, sipping her tea like she hadn’t just casually admitted to breaking fundamental cosmic laws, made it worse. Infinitely worse.

Rio’s eyes narrowed.
Then she blinked.
Twice .

She leaned forward, elbows planted on the table, hands slowly dragging down her face. It wasn’t just shock anymore. It was shock with a side of existential dread.

“You’re telling me , THE DEATH,” she said, voice hoarse, “that you gaslit Life herself. Watched her do the surgery and then walked away with your soul upgraded like it was a damned iOS patch.”

Agatha didn’t even blink. She stirred her tea slowly, her expression somewhere between saint and sinner.

“That’s one way to put it. I prefer to think of it as... creative resilience .”

Rio pushed her chair back with a screech and stood up abruptly, pacing behind Agatha like a woman trying to outrun her own nerves. One hand was gripping her jaw, the other pulling at her own ponytail.

“You’re not serious. You can’t be serious. You can’t be serious,” she muttered, like saying it three times would make it untrue.

Agatha tilted her head and offered an annoyingly calm smile. “Is this about the coma part or the part where I fused two lives into one coherent timeline without destabilizing the entire mortal plane?”

“ YES! ” Rio snapped, gesturing wildly at everything and nothing. “All of it! You — you can’t just do that!”

“Oh, honey, clearly I can. Did. Past tense.”

Rio groaned and let herself fall forward until her forehead hit the table with a soft, defeated thud. She stayed like that, unmoving, as Agatha leisurely reached across the table and gently patted her head as if calming a frazzled pet.

“It’s okay, baby,” Agatha cooed. “It’s a lot to take in. Would you like me to write it down in a little poem? Something with rhymes and footnotes?”

Rio let out a muffled, pained noise against the table. Then she turned her head just enough to peer up at Agatha with one eye, like she was about to accuse her of witchcraft — which, of course, she was .

“You’re dating a cosmic loophole wrapped in a hot body ,” Agatha reminded her, voice low and smug as she reached again for her tea. “You’re welcome.”

Rio lifted her head just enough to groan again, more like a growl this time. Her whole face was flushed — part disbelief, part irritation, and just a little bit of reluctant admiration . She dragged her hands through her hair, then stood up again with too much force, stepping away from the table as if space might help her understand this woman.

But even as she paced, one truth was undeniable and throbbed like a heartbeat in her skull: It was Agatha all along.

Rio groaned and let her head fall forward onto the table. Agatha smiled sweetly and reached over to pat her hair.

“Tea’s good, by the way. Really hits the ‘I just broke the rules of reality’ spot.” 

Rio hadn’t stopped moving.

She was an orbiting storm, pacing so fiercely that even the kitchen walls seemed to lean back from her fury. Her bare feet slapped the floor with controlled chaos, her hands cutting the air in sharp, frustrated gestures as she ranted — not to Agatha, but to the universe, to herself, to whatever gods were brave enough to listen. Spanish, English, celestial murmurs, ancient curses — all swirled out of her in rapid-fire rhythm.

“Manipulative. Arrogant. Fearsome. Bruja completamente insana, ” she snapped, turning again with the grace of a blade unsheathed. “You gaslit Life! A la propia Vida , Agatha! You stitched two timelines together with fucking glitter glue and sarcasm and just—just— ¿qué carajo pasa por tu cabeza, mujer?! ”

Agatha, lounging with unbothered poise in her chair, watched this cosmic meltdown with growing satisfaction. Every furious pass, every dramatic exclamation, only made her smile widen. She stirred her tea with the elegance of a queen and tilted her head slightly every time Rio spun past, like she was enjoying a theatrical performance she’d bought front-row seats for. Eventually, she sighed, long and exaggerated, and set the teacup down with a soft clink. Then she stood. Slowly. Precisely. Her robe shifted around her with the movement, tied just loose enough to suggest intention. She walked with a grace that was too purposeful to be casual, straight into Rio’s warpath.

A divine being sucker-punched by flesh and nerve and beauty. Her lips parted but no sound came out. She was officially broken.

Rio finally found her voice — barely. “Agatha, eso no se hace,” she grumbled, her tone small and petulant, bottom lip pushing out in a dramatic pout.

The kiss wasn’t fast.
It wasn’t rushed or desperate.
It was intentional.

Agatha kissed her like a vow. Like an apology. Like a resurrection.

It was a mirror of the last kiss they had shared — when Agatha, dying and mad with borrowed power, had pressed her lips to Death’s and crumbled in her arms. This kiss wasn’t just passion. It was memory . A call and an answer. A declaration that stretched across time and rebirth. She kissed Rio like she was whispering, I’m here. I’m here again. I came back for you. And Rio — speechless, wide-eyed, trembling — could only kiss her back.

When they finally parted, just barely, Agatha’s breath ghosted over her lips.

“I’m sorry,” she murmured, “for the chaos. For the cheating. For the drama. But for you, for us, I would have done it again.”

The kiss deepened the way fire catches dry wood — inevitable, greedy, slow only for a second before it devours. Agatha let her hands slide up the sides of Rio’s face, fingers threading through the midnight strands at her nape, pulling her closer as her mouth claimed what had been hers across lifetimes. Her body moved like memory — fluid, certain, like every step was already choreographed in the blood.

Benny stood in the doorway, jaw slack, expression twisted between horror and secondhand embarrassment, dressed in full Officer Daniels disguise — right down to the overly neat haircut that made him look like a failed soap opera extra.

He blinked once, muttered something in very fast Spanish that even Rio didn’t entirely catch, and looked directly at Agatha’s very exposed back. Rio’s instinct kicked in instantly. Agatha huffed, furious at being interrupted mid-reunion, but nodded once, tight-lipped. “Okay,” she whispered back, though her whole body screamed murder. The temptation to vaporize Benny’s cheap wig and false mustache was tangible.

Because if this turned into another celestial intervention, another trial for bending the fabric of existence, she'd have more than just her own soul to worry about now. She had two children. She had Rio. Still — she was Agatha . And she didn’t do fear. But she did do calculation.

Benny cleared his throat and tried to make his eyes look at literally anything else. “ Rio, en serio? Don’t you two have a bedroom?” His tone was part judgment, part older brother disgust.

Rio rolled her eyes and let out a groan, still shielding Agatha behind her.“When Eva showed up out of nowhere, we were in our bedroom, you idiot. Que haces aqui?” She looked him up and down, frowning. “And that ridiculous hair?”

“ Es un disfraz, ” he said defensively, running a hand through the stiff, too-short hair.

“A shitty disguise.”

“I’m here to take Agatha in for questioning.” He adjusted the belt around his fake uniform. “I might be your brother, but I’m still a cop. Ralph’s back . He was found again — in her classroom. And this time, he’s not just raving. He’s gone . Chief wants a full statement. He wants to know what the hell is going on .”

Rio’s expression darkened in a way that made the air feel colder.

“He tried to kill her,” she said flatly.

“Then she can say that . In court if that is what it takes. But right now, she’s still legally married to him and cheating on him with you And she’s a primary witness. We can’t just ignore this because it’s messy.”

Rio’s voice dropped to something that barely resembled human sound. “I can get a death certificate if necessary.” Her hand tightened at Agatha’s hip, eyes glowing faintly.

Benny didn’t even flinch. “I’ll be outside. Get dressed. For the love of all gods, both old and new, put some pants on.” He stormed off muttering curses, the door swinging behind him.
The silence left behind wasn’t awkward. It was charged.

Agatha sighed and stepped back, smoothing her robe again. “Well. I was this close to letting you take me on the counter, and now we have to go play legal drama.”

Rio ran her hands down her face. “We’re going to kill him one day.”

“Oh, absolutely,” Agatha said sweetly, already walking toward the stairs. “But for now? We put on pants. We answer some questions. And then... you owe me a counter scene, Death. ”
