The fluorescent light made her skin look colder, like porcelain, but her gaze could cut glass. She looked more like a client suing the department for emotional damage than someone being questioned about a deranged ex-husband.

The door creaked open.

A uniformed officer peeked inside. “Uh—her lawyer's here.”

Agatha scoffed, not even glancing toward the door. “Sorry, sweetheart. I don’t have a lawyer. I know how to defend myself.”

But then— Black heels. Crisp lines. A dark blazer that molded perfectly over narrow shoulders. That bun so tight it could hold secrets. And in her hand, a leather briefcase so slim Agatha instantly distrusted it. Rio entered the room like a storm in slow motion. Controlled. Timed. Devastating .

Agatha blinked once, lips parting.

Well. She is deliciously overdressed for this kind of scene.

“ Jesus, ” Agatha muttered under her breath. “She even brought a prop.”

Rio didn't look at her. Not yet.

“Mrs. O’Connor, who’s that?”

Rio’s attention zeroed in on the woman across the table — the detective — who’d just made the mistake of calling her client Mrs. O’Connor.

“First,” Rio began with razor-coated silk, “her name is Harkness. O’Connor means nothing to her. Now.” She turned slowly, locking eyes with the detective. “Who gave you the right to question my client without my presence?”

The detective, a short-haired woman in her thirties with a tired badge and an expression of constant doubt, hesitated. “I didn’t know she had legal representation.”

“Neither did I,” Agatha added under her breath, smirking — until Rio shot her a look that could freeze oceans. Agatha bit her lip. Not in guilt. In amusement.

“My name is Rio Vidal,” she continued coolly. “I’m here on behalf of Ms. Harkness as her legal representative. Now tell me — how much suspicion have you already dumped on my client? Are you honestly entertaining the story of an unmedicated schizophrenic ex-husband rambling about witches, reincarnation, and alternate lives?”

The detective opened her mouth, but Rio didn’t give her time.

“My client,” she continued, tone now laced with sarcasm, “can’t make herbal tea without setting off the smoke alarm. In the Inquisition, she’d have been dismissed as too useless to even burn. ”

“That was rude,” Agatha muttered behind her hand, pretending to be offended.

Rio finally turned toward her and took the seat beside her, placing the slim briefcase on the table with a loud click. Agatha eyed it like it might bite. Rio opened it slowly, revealing exactly what Agatha expected: absolutely nothing useful . Just two crumpled comic books — Nick’s favorites — and what looked like an empty folder.

“I swear to everything,” Agatha whispered, “if there's a Pokémon card in there, I’m walking out.”

Rio ignored her. She slid the folder open, laid out a few seemingly mundane documents. But beneath the surface, the subtle enchantments she’d placed were already shifting perception. Where the detective saw hospital forms, bank reports, bruising records, restraining orders — none of it was real. Yet under the influence of Rio’s quiet invasion of her mind, it felt real. Unquestionably real.
She didn’t force it. That wasn’t how mental suggestion worked. No . She simply made it... easy. Easy to believe that Ralph was unstable. That Agatha had been a victim. That all this talk of magic and other lives was just trauma-induced projection.

Rio’s voice softened, soothing and casual, the kind of calm that people wanted to agree with.

“We’re not here to make trouble, detective. We just want what’s fair. A woman came to work and found her unstable ex-husband raving in her classroom. That’s not mythology. That’s domestic violence. He’s clearly not well. You’ve seen the reports, haven’t you?” She tapped the papers gently. “Wouldn’t a psychiatric facility be more appropriate than a jail cell? For his safety. And hers.”

The detective was blinking slower now. Her pen stilled over the page. “I... I’ll pass the information forward, Dr. Vidal.”

“ Good .” Rio smiled. Not smug. Not threatening. Just satisfied.

Agatha arched a brow. “Doctor now? You’re just stacking titles today.”

“Shh,” Rio murmured out of the side of her mouth. “ Let me work .”

Agatha leaned back in her chair and crossed her arms. “You just brainwashed a cop with a comic book and a suggestion spell, but I’m the problem?”

“ Yes ,” Rio said sweetly, not missing a beat. “Because I didn’t almost hex the receptionist on the way in.”

“She was rude.”

“She was breathing.”

Agatha rolled her eyes but smiled, and for a brief second, Rio saw the tension drain from her shoulders. She reached under the table and gave Agatha’s hand a brief squeeze — firm, grounding, wordless.

The detective gathered the ‘evidence’ together and rose slowly. “I’ll see to it Mr. O’Connor is transferred to St. Jareth’s psych facility by the end of the week. Pending approval.”

Rio nodded once, already knowing the approval had happened the moment she’d stepped through the door. And just like that, the spell was sealed.

As they walked out, Agatha leaned close, brushing her shoulder against Rio’s.

“Next time you cosplay my lawyer, maybe tell me first.”

“I tried,” Rio murmured, “but you were too busy trying to seduce me with your robe again.”

“No regrets,” Agatha purred, already plotting their next rule break.

And behind them, the mortal world spun — blissfully unaware of how close it had come to collapsing around a comic book, a smirk, and the soft whisper of a very persuasive Death.

The glass doors of the station hissed shut behind them, muting the fluorescent hum of bureaucracy and the dull chatter of mortal messes. Outside, the air was sharp and bright, the sun high but somehow gentler than it had any right to be — like the universe itself was holding its breath to see what Agatha would do next.
Rio walked ahead, silent, hands in her pockets, tension vibrating through her shoulders like a tight wire. She hadn’t spoken since they left the interrogation room. That should’ve worried Agatha.

It didn’t .

Not when Rio looked like that in a blazer. Not when Agatha had just watched her bend reality and law with nothing but a voice, a smirk, and an enchanted copy of The Amazing Spider-Man .

Agatha followed at a comfortable pace, heels clicking like punctuation marks behind Rio’s every step. She caught up just as they reached the black car parked half a block away — definitely not regulation, definitely something Rio had commandeered.

Agatha leaned against the passenger door before Rio could open it, arms crossed, lips tugging into a smug little curve. “You know,” she said, voice low, “if you ever get tired of playing Death, you’d make an excellent corrupt lawyer. All that power and barely any soul.”

Rio unlocked the car with a sharp beep and gave her a look. “Get in the car, Agatha.”

“Not until you admit it.”

“Admit what ?”

“That I looked hot being interrogated. Come on. I was glowing .”

Rio sighed and opened the driver’s side, sliding in with military precision. “You were glowing because you were this close to combusting the table with rage.”

Agatha slipped into the passenger seat, smoothing her skirt like she hadn’t just traumatized a government official. “Still counts.”

The doors shut. The moment quieted. For a beat, neither of them spoke.

Then Rio gripped the wheel, head dropping briefly to rest against the leather. “You’re going to be the death of me,” she murmured.

Agatha leaned closer. “That’s literally your job, baby.”

Rio turned her head slowly, giving Agatha a long, measured look. “You are so lucky I love you.”

“I am lucky,” Agatha said softly, for once without sarcasm. “Lucky that I got you back. Lucky that we all came back.”

That rare sincerity lingered a second too long.

And then —

A knock on Rio’s window. Rio jumped. Agatha groaned, dragging her hands through her hair like she wanted to rip it out by the roots.

“You’ve got to be fucking kidding me!” she muttered through clenched teeth. “Do your stupid latinos siblings ever let us fuck in peace ?!”

Outside, standing with her arms crossed and all the divine elegance of someone who could make angels cry just by blinking, was Eva. Immaculate ivory blazer. Perfect heels. Hair pulled into a no-nonsense twist. Expression that said they were both grounded until the end of time.

Agatha rolled down the window with an exasperated sigh. “Let me guess. You felt a disturbance in the fuckin’—”

Rio slapped a hand gently over her mouth before she could say anything incriminating.

Eva arched her brow. “You had five minutes of peace and immediately started fusing timelines, seducing Death on government property, and enchanting official records with magical manga.”

Rio coughed into her fist. Agatha looked entirely unbothered.

“Technically,” Agatha said, lips curling, “the seduction started waaaay before the station. But I will say — the acoustics in that interrogation room? Immaculate. ”

Eva closed her eyes, pinching the bridge of her nose like she was personally holding the multiverse together through sheer irritation.

“I only came to say your part’s done. The rest is on me and Benny now.”

Rio could see it. The exact second Agatha was about to brag about manipulating Eva’s magic with a single damn sentence. She grabbed her hand before the words left her mouth.

“Does this mean you and Benny will stop breaking into our house at inappropriate times?” Rio asked instead, voice sharp but calm.

“For now, yes.”

“Perfect.”

Rio’s finger hovered over the button to roll up the window, but Eva spoke again — this time gently. Her gaze lingered on Agatha, then turned to Rio.

“She’s okay?” she asked. “Did it work, hermana?”

The way Eva asked made lying impossible.

Rio hesitated, just long enough to feel it in her chest. “She’s Agatha,” she said finally. “She’s okay. In her own way.” The window closed.

Rio started the engine. “It’s incredible you have zero sense of self-preservation.”

“Why would I?” Agatha said, stretching back in the passenger seat. “I have you. Now... about that suit of yours — I’d very much like you to charge me and prosecute me as a wicked witch while wearing it.”

Rio huffed a laugh. “That was so cheesy.”

Agatha shrugged. “I’ve got four hundred and some years stacked across two lifetimes. Sue me.”

Rio shook her head, fighting a smile as she shifted the car into drive, her heart steadying — finally, finally steadying — because even when the world burned and the sky cracked and reality turned on itself…

Agatha was still Agatha. And she was still hers.

The moment the front door clicked shut behind them, the tension snapped like a bowstring. Agatha didn’t even wait for Rio to drop her keys.

She moved fast — faster than she had any right to in heels — grabbing Rio by the collar of that sinfully tight blazer and slamming her back against the wall with a satisfying thud. The house held its breath as Rio let out a surprised gasp, laughter still caught on her lips as Agatha’s mouth crashed into hers. It wasn’t a kiss of gratitude. It was possession. Hunger. A collision of teeth and longing that had waited through two lives and one too-long interrogation. Agatha kissed her like she meant to brand her name on Death’s lips. Her hands tangled roughly in Rio’s hair, pulling her head back just enough to expose the soft column of her throat. Agatha bit down on the skin there — not hard enough to hurt, but firm enough to remind her who was touching her.

Rio moaned, low and breathy, gripping Agatha’s waist as if it was the only thing keeping her upright. “Someone missed me,” she breathed, eyes fluttering.

Agatha smirked against her jaw. “I missed owning you.”

And then, something in her shifted. A twitch in her fingers. A flicker in her mind.
Instinct.
Old muscle memory.

She pulled back slightly, lifting her hand and twisting her wrist in a motion that had once, across battlefields and blood rituals, summoned magic strong enough to collapse cities. Her eyes glowed a deep violet. The air around them seemed to pause — crackle — like it remembered her too. But nothing happened.

Too big. Too late. Too silent .

In their past life, the trauma had ended in grief. And Agatha nearly said yes. Again.

Because she remembered. She remembered a night — one filled with trembling hands and aching love — where Rio had once whispered, “ I wish I could show you how much I love you .” And she had answered without thinking, “ Then show me. I trust you. ”

Chapter 16: Chapter 15

Chapter Summary

The Final Chapter

Chapter Notes

Okya, guys. This is the last chapter of this story. I thank you very, very much for you presence, your theories, your comments and kudos. Thank you very much for the time we spend together in this and in my other stories. I love you all.
I hope to be here again with new stories, and new moments with you.

My contact is:
Intagram: @valin_bia
Twitter: @godnessoflie

Thank you very much again. I love you all.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

The living room was too quiet.

 

The kind of quiet that swallowed sound, the kind that wrapped itself around people like fog — thick, unmoving, suffocating. Sunlight filtered weakly through the windows, casting pale shadows across the soft beige carpet. The fireplace was off. The clock on the wall ticked, intrusive and unforgiving.

 

Nicole and Nick sat side by side on the couch, small forms swallowed in cushions that suddenly felt far too large.

 

Nick clutched his Ankylosaurus like it was a shield, his knuckles white from the pressure. He held it against his chest, his shoulders hunched protectively as if bracing for a storm. Nicole sat straighter but was no less tense — her lip pinched between her teeth so harshly it was on the verge of splitting. Her fingers curled into the hem of her sleeve, twisting the fabric in small, nervous movements.

 

Across from them, Agatha sat on the edge of the armchair, leaning forward, elbows on her knees, hands clasped tightly as if trying to ground herself. Beside her, Rio was motionless, one hand resting on Agatha’s back, the other fidgeting with the seam of her pants. Her jaw was clenched. She’d never felt more exposed — more uncertain — than she did now.

 

"I know it’s a lot to take in," Agatha finally said, her voice soft but unwavering, the weight of truth coating every syllable. “ It’s a lot … even for us. But we promised you we’d always be honest. No more secrets .”

 

Silence followed. A thick, choking kind of silence.

 

Nicole didn’t blink. Nick didn’t even breathe for a second.

 

Rio, who had faced gods and watched stars collapse into themselves, suddenly found herself the most nervous she’d ever been. Her palms were damp. Her chest tight. She didn’t dare move. 

 

For her, explaining things to Nicole should’ve been easier — Nicole already knew, in a way. She’d always felt it. That she was something more. That her mothers weren’t like the others. But hearing it. In detail . No more metaphors or soft bedtime stories. Just truth laid bare on the table like bones under a forensic lamp… that was different .

 

Nicole’s lip trembled, and finally — finally — her voice emerged, so small it almost didn’t make it past her teeth.

 

“So…” she murmured, eyes fixed on the floor, “does that mean I’m not even real?”

 

Agatha’s breath caught like glass in her throat. She surged forward, hands reaching instinctively before catching herself, afraid to overwhelm.

 

“No,” she said instantly, her voice trembling now, urgent and fierce. “Nicole, no , sweetheart. You are real. You’re so real.”

 

“But I wasn’t even there,” Nicole whispered, her voice cracking. “ I wasn’t even born . I didn’t exist.”

 

“You are everything,” Agatha said, crawling from her chair to the floor, kneeling now, heart open and exposed. “You were made from something stronger than magic. You were made from love. That doesn’t make you less real — it makes you more.”

 

Nicole’s eyes shimmered with tears she refused to let fall. Her lip finally split, a thin line of red sliding downward.

 

Rio moved with a gentleness that contradicted everything she was. She leaned forward slowly, carefully, and dabbed the blood away with a soft tissue she conjured from her pocket. Her fingers were precise and delicate, brushing Nicole’s chin like she was made of porcelain.

 

“You’ve always been real, sweetheart,” Rio said quietly, her voice hoarse but strong. “You are the most real thing I’ve ever known. You’re the purest thing in this world. The fruit of the love of Death — a being that was never supposed to feel love — and a witch without a coven who everyone believed was unlovable.”

 

Nicole blinked rapidly, breath hitching. She took the tissue from Rio’s hand and pressed it to her mouth, her eyes falling closed as she nodded. She didn’t speak again. But she didn’t bite her lip anymore, either.

 

That alone was an answer. 

 

But Nick hadn’t moved. Agatha turned her attention to him, swallowing hard against the ache forming behind her ribs.

 

“Nick?” she asked gently, her voice dipped in honey and fear. “Baby?”

 

His grip tightened on the dinosaur. His eyes didn’t lift. His lower lip quivered, and then he shook his head — hard, like he could shake the entire truth away with it.

 

He clutched the dinosaur tighter. His small fingers twitched. His lip wobbled, and he shook his head, hard. “I don’t wanna talk.”

 

Four little words . Four devastating little words.

 

Agatha’s chest cracked in half. Not because he was angry — she could hold him through a thousand storms of fury. But because of how he said it: soft, small, like he was trying not to break. Her mouth opened, but no sound came out. She could handle anger, yelling, anything. But this — this soft, quiet retreat — this broke her.

 

Rio couldn’t stay still.

 

She slid off the edge of the couch and knelt on the floor in front of him, tucking her hands on her thighs so she wouldn’t touch him too quickly. Her posture was open, vulnerable. She looked up at him, even though it tore her apart.

 

“Nick,” she said softly, “you’re allowed to feel whatever you’re feeling. You can be mad. You can cry. You can yell if you want. I just want you to know that nothing — nothing — changes how much I love you . Nothing. Ever .”

 

Nick finally looked at her, and that look shattered her. His lashes were damp. His eyes were huge, glassy, a sea of emotion barely held back. His chest rose and fell too fast. His jaw trembled.

 

Nick swallowed. His eyes flicked to her face for the first time, and they were glassy, lashes wet, wide with something Rio didn’t want to name — fear. Confusion. Betrayal .

 

“You’re Death.”

 

Rio didn’t look away. She took it . She absorbed every ounce of the weight in his voice.

 

“Yes,” she said after a beat. “I am, baby.”

 

His chin quivered. His voice cracked. “Does that mean you’ll take me one day? Like you did before? Leave Mommy alone again?”

 

Agatha let out a broken sob and immediately covered her mouth, as if trying to shove it back in. Tears slipped down her face in silence. Her shoulders shook. Her grief was quiet, but it scorched everything in its path.

Because that was the thing she hadn’t even let herself say aloud: that Rio had taken him once . That Nick wasn’t supposed to live. That Agatha had been left alone. Utterly. For a lifetime.

 

Rio’s voice cracked. She leaned in closer, her hands still on her thighs. “ No . No, baby. That is not how it works. I’m sorry... I don’t get to choose who goes. I never have .”

 

She reached out slowly, deliberately, placing her hand on the dinosaur instead of him, as if asking permission to touch.

 

“But I swear to you,” she said, trembling, “I will never let anything happen to you. Never . I won’t let anything take you. And I’ll never let your mom be alone again. Ever. Not while I breathe . Not while I exist .”

 

Nick looked down at the toy.

 

Then, slowly, painfully, he leaned forward. Not much — just a few inches — but enough to rest his forehead against the top of Rio’s head.

Her breath caught. She closed her eyes and let her hands rise, gently, to cradle his back.

 

“I’m scared,” he whispered, voice shaking, as if the words alone might fall apart in the air.

 

Rio kissed his hair, lips pressing against the crown of his head like a silent vow.

 

“I know,” she whispered. “ Me too . But you’re not alone. Not ever.”

 

Agatha reached forward, wrapping her arms around both of them, holding her world together with the fragile strength only a mother could summon.

 

And for a moment — just one quiet, aching moment — there was nothing but warmth.

 

And the beginning of healing.




The kitchen felt too big for the four of them at first — too wide, too quiet , like a stage waiting for actors unsure of their lines. It wasn’t the space itself, but the absence of something unspoken — ease, perhaps, or innocence. The kind of warmth that usually danced between them in flour-dusted jokes and stolen spoonfuls of sauce now hung back, uncertain, reluctant to return too soon.

 

Outside, the sun was slipping behind the hills, spilling amber light across the countertops and casting long shadows that stretched like fingers over the tiled floor. It should’ve been comforting. Familiar . But the hush in the room made everything louder. The creak of a drawer felt like a crack of thunder. The click of silverware against ceramic seemed far too sharp. Even the gentle hum of the refrigerator carried a kind of pressure, as if daring someone to speak first.

 

Agatha stood at the far end of the counter, posture straight, but her shoulders a little too stiff. Her sleeves were rolled to the elbows, and her hair was tied up in a loose knot, a few stray strands already falling into her eyes. She cut vegetables with the kind of precision one might use disarming a bomb — meticulous, mechanical, and far too quiet. Every slice was identical. Too perfect.

 

Nicole hovered near the sink, rinsing tomatoes with small, precise movements, her face half-turned away as if pretending she wasn’t watching everyone. She stood on the balls of her feet, shifting slightly every few seconds, trying to stay grounded in a moment that still didn’t feel quite real.

 

Nick, standing on the old wooden stool near the center island, had both arms plunged into a mountain of flour-dusted dough. His fingers worked diligently, clumsily, pressing and folding, pressing and folding — but the dough was stubborn, and so was he. It stuck to him like a second skin. He didn’t complain, but every now and then, he let out a sharp sigh, like he wanted to, and just didn’t know how.

 

Rio drifted between them like a shadow, her movements measured, almost reverent. She lit the stove, pulled out a pan, grabbed a bottle of olive oil, all in silence. She didn’t want to be the one to break whatever fragile thing had formed between them. She could feel it stretching — this wordless tension — like a glass thread, delicate and invisible, pulling tight between each of them.

 

It wasn’t anger that hung in the air. Not quite sadness, either. It was the weight of knowing too much. Of trying to act normal in a space where the truth still echoed in the corners. Like walking barefoot across shards of memory, unsure which one would cut deepest.

 

They didn’t look at one another for long. Just small glances. The kind that spoke of questions left unasked. Of wounds still stitching themselves closed. No one said it aloud, but they all felt it: this dinner was an act of hope . Of effort. A soft, trembling attempt at holding something together.

 

And despite the silence, despite the heaviness… They were here.

 

Together. And that, maybe, was enough to begin.

 

But slowly — so slowly it was almost imperceptible — something shifted.

 

It wasn’t a grand gesture. No one said the right words. No one forced a smile. It began in the small things, like how a garden starts to grow again after a long frost: silently, tenderly, stubbornly.

 

Nicole reached across the counter and handed Agatha a plump, ripe tomato — not because she was asked , but because she knew she’d need it next. Her fingers brushed Agatha’s wrist as she passed it, and for a split second, their eyes met. No words. Just a nod. Just enough .

Nick, still elbow-deep in flour, nudged the mixing bowl toward Rio with a gentle push of his knuckles. He didn’t look up when he did it, but the motion was intentional. A quiet offering. Like saying, I see you. I’m trying.

And when the sauce began to bubble too violently on the back burner, Agatha reached over on instinct to lower the flame — only to find Rio’s hand already there, already turning the knob. Their fingers touched. A brief overlap. Warm. Familiar. Their gazes locked, just for a breath. Neither said a thing. Neither needed to.

 

There were no instructions. No commands barked across the counter. Just the fluid motion of four people orbiting each other, their movements synced by something deeper than habit — something woven between them like thread. Trust. Muscle memory. The need to be together, even if no one said it aloud.

 

It became a dance.

 

Nicole stirred the simmering sauce with slow, deliberate circles, her brows furrowed in focus as the scent of tomatoes and garlic deepened in the pan. Nick shaped misshapen dough circles, humming under his breath now, his concentration broken only by the occasional giggle when the dough stuck to his palm and flopped over like a creature trying to escape.

Agatha sprinkled herbs over the sauce with her usual flair, fingers elegant, wrists turning with grace that felt innate. She didn’t need to look — she knew the amounts, the rhythm. Her body remembered what her mind was still healing from.

And Rio — steady, silent, always watching — rolled out the pasta with practiced strokes, her forearms dusted in flour, sleeves pushed high. She looked up between each press of the pin, her gaze sweeping the room — not because she was checking on anyone, but because she couldn’t stop looking . Because for the first time in too long, this didn’t feel like penance. It felt like life.

 

The scent of rosemary began to rise as Agatha dropped a few sprigs into the bubbling sauce, mingling with garlic and olive oil, and the sweet warmth of the dough Nick had finally started getting the hang of. The heat of the stove bathed the room in something more than temperature. It gave off comfort. Security . A kind of hope you could smell.

 

And the silence, once so loud it had filled every corner of the room like fog, began to hum with something else.

 

Something lighter.

Something human.

Something healing.

 

Not joy — not yet — but the first step toward it. The kind of softness that comes only after the storm has passed and you’re still learning how to breathe again.

 

They didn’t need to say they loved each other.

 

It was in the way Nicole passed a spoon without being asked. In how Nick leaned his shoulder into Agatha’s hip as she passed behind him. In the way Rio set a clean towel beside the counter for whoever needed it, without a word.

 

They were learning how to be again. How to exist not as four fractured pieces… but as one whole, imperfect, messy, loving thing .

 

A family.

 

And then... Rio broke it.

 

She didn’t mean to. Or maybe she did. Just a little. With Rio, it was always hard to tell — where accident ended and mischief began.

 

She reached for the wooden spoon to taste the tomato sauce, the one she’d been carefully tending for the last fifteen minutes, and as she turned, the edge of her hip brushed against Agatha’s. A small jolt of connection — bare skin meeting apron — before Rio’s elbow tilted too far. The spoon tipped, and with a soft but unmistakable plop , a dollop of red sauce flew from the spoon and splashed directly onto Agatha’s cheek, landing just beneath her left eye in a glistening smear of crimson.

 

The world stopped.

 

Nicole froze mid-stir, the spoon hovering above the pot like she was afraid to move it. Her wide eyes tracked between the two women like a cat caught between two fighting wolves.

Nick’s gasp was sharp, loud, scandalized. He clutched his dough like a lifeline, his mouth falling open as if someone had smacked him with cold air.

 

Even the sauce on the stove bubbled less enthusiastically, as if it too had suddenly realized it was in danger.

 

Rio's eyes widened, horror blooming across her face. “ Oh no ,” she muttered, already reaching forward with a napkin she’d grabbed by reflex. “Ags, I didn’t mean to—”

 

But Agatha turned. Slowly . Precisely .

 

Like a glacier about to split the sea.

 

Her expression was unreadable, carved in frost. Her eyes narrowed into a slit of dangerous calm, and her cheek — painted with that bright streak of red — looked like war paint.

 

“Did you just...” she began, voice as soft as falling snow, “ throw sauce on my face?”

 

Rio froze mid-reach, napkin in hand, suddenly unsure if she was facing judgment or execution.

 

“I didn’t throw it ,” she said carefully. “ It splashed . There’s a difference.”

 

Nicole gripped her spoon tighter, eyes darting. Her knuckles went pale.

 

Nick, still watching with the intensity of a child who’d seen this movie before, whispered, “She’s gonna explode…”

 

Nicole gave him a sharp elbow to the ribs without even glancing away.

 

Agatha stared at Rio. Her fingers came up, slow and deliberate, and she wiped the smear of sauce with the tip of her finger. She studied the red on her skin like it was a personal betrayal.

 

Then she looked up again. “You ruined my face.”

 

Rio's mouth twitched. She tried, tried to hold it in.

 

“Not possible, you're too beautiful” she murmured, the smile slipping free despite her better judgment. “I mean, I know you think your face is divine, but it survived worse than a tomato ambush.”

 

Agatha’s eyes darkened — dramatically, intentionally. She took a single, measured step forward.

 

Rio instinctively took a step back. “Okay, okay, I’ll get a napk—”

 

But it was too late.

 

In one fluid movement, Agatha turned, dipped her fingers gracefully into the large bowl of flour Nick had left on the counter, scooped up a handful, and spun back with purpose. She stepped into Rio’s space, raised her arm, and with terrifying elegance, smeared a thick, white cloud of flour right across Rio’s face — cheek to cheek, nose to temple, like she was christening her with vengeance.

 

The room went silent again — but this time, it vibrated with anticipation.

 

Rio stood there, blinking slowly.

Flour clung to her lashes, to her lips, to her dark eyebrows now turned powder-white. A puff of the stuff hovered in the air around her like mist, settling into the curls of her hair. She looked less like Death and more like a spectral baker who’d wandered into the wrong afterlife.

 

The moment stretched.

 

Nicole’s mouth dropped open. Nick made a strangled sound that might have been a laugh, or might have been him trying not to laugh.

 

Rio stared at Agatha. Blinked. Licked her lips, the flour coating her tongue.

 

Nicole burst into laughter first — a bubbling, breathless sound that spilled from her like soda fizzing over the top. She doubled over the counter, gasping, shoulders shaking. Nick joined instantly, his body bouncing with every giggle, his sticky hands smearing dough across the counter as he tried to hold himself upright.

 

Agatha smiled — finally — and even she couldn’t suppress the twitch of amusement tugging at the corner of her mouth.

 

Rio grinned, her whole face still dusted in flour, and crossed her arms in challenge. “You’re lucky you’re hot,” she muttered, and Nick let out a high-pitched shriek of laughter.

 

Agatha didn’t laugh — not at first. She kept a stern expression, lips pursed, eyes narrowed.

 

“You call that revenge?” she asked slowly, reaching for a pinch of flour herself. “Because I think I can top that.”

 

Agatha raised a brow. “ Try it , and I’ll make you eat raw pasta.”

 

Rio flicked a bit of flour at her shoulder.

 

Agatha gasped. “How dare you.”

 

“Too late now, Lady Harkness .”

 

The flour war began.

 

Nicole squealed and ducked behind the counter with her spoon, covering her mouth as she laughed. Nick didn’t even pretend to hide — he flung a tiny ball of dough that landed with a plop against the fridge.

For the first time that day, they weren’t thinking about who they were. About Death . About past lives or the weight of truth.

 

They were just four people in a too-warm kitchen, laughing. Flour flying. Sauce bubbling. Laughter overlapping with breathless gasps and empty threats.

 

When the chaos settled, they were all dusted in white and speckled in sauce. Rio’s hair was a mess. Agatha’s apron was stained. Nick had somehow gotten flour on his eyebrows. Nicole had tears of laughter streaking down her cheeks.

 

Agatha looked around, shaking her head in mock despair. “This is your fault,” she muttered to Rio, barely able to suppress her grin.

 

“Guilty,” Rio said, leaning in and stealing a kiss from her cheek.

 

“Ugh,” Nick groaned. “Seriously?”

 

Nicole laughed again.

 

And for the first time in what felt like forever… it felt like home.




Dinner was served in a glorious, chaotic mess.

 

The four of them sat around the wooden table in the dining nook, the room still steeped in the lingering aroma of rosemary, garlic, and baked dough. A warm golden light from the kitchen pendant lamp cast a soft glow over their flour-splattered clothes, tomato-stained aprons, and tangled hair. The table itself was no better — speckled with smudges of sauce, crumbles of crust, and a lonely basil leaf stuck to the salt shaker.

 

They hadn’t even bothered to change .

 

Nick had dried streaks of dough on his elbow and flour crusted under his fingernails. Nicole’s cheek still bore a pale smudge she hadn’t noticed, and her curls were wild from all the laughter. Rio sat comfortably slouched in her chair, a line of red on her neck from earlier splashing and a faint streak of flour down her jawline like war paint. And Agatha... Agatha had a hardened chunk of dough curled in her hair near her temple like a secret battle scar.

 

The first bite into their imperfect, slightly burned, slightly beautiful homemade pizza brought a strange quiet — not uncomfortable, but sacred. That quiet you get when food fills the room with something older than words. Something safe.

 

Rio leaned back and chewed slowly, inspecting the thin crust she held in one hand.

 

“This pizza is very thin,” she observed with dramatic seriousness.

 

Agatha shot her a look over her glass of water, one brow raised as she twirled a stiff lock of hair around her finger. “It would be thicker if you hadn’t thrown half the dough into my hair, Vidal .”

 

Nick snorted into his slice, trying to muffle the sound but failing. A muffled hffft ! escaped him, followed by a strangled hiccup of laughter. Nicole, ever more composed, fought her smile by stuffing a hot slice into her mouth with unnecessary speed, cheeks puffed out like a squirrel.

 

Rio grinned around another bite. “It gave you character,” she said, smirking.

 

“That wick hasn’t moved in an hour ,” Agatha muttered, poking the cemented curl like it personally offended her.

 

Nicole swallowed quickly, eyes gleaming. “By the way, I filmed everything . It’s all going on my Instagram feed.”

 

Agatha froze mid-chew.

 

Her gaze snapped to Nicole like a death glare channeled through a kitchen witch. “You didn’t.”

 

“Oh, I did.” Nicky smiled like a villain in a cartoon. “It’s already uploading .”

 

“Nicky,” Agatha groaned, slumping dramatically in her chair like she'd just been sentenced. “Please, I’m begging you. Delete it.”

 

Nick giggled behind his napkin, and Nicole just leaned her chin on her palm, smirking like a cat who’d just dropped a mouse at the door.

 

“Okay,” she said sweetly. “No videos.”

 

Agatha exhaled in relief.

 

“But…” Nicole added innocently, “there are pictures. And two Boomerangs.”

 

Agatha stared at her daughter with betrayal dripping from every blink. “You little snake.”

 

Nicole beamed. “You’re welcome.”

 

Rio nearly choked on her bite of pizza, laughing as she patted her chest with her napkin. “Oh, it’s going to be delightful tomorrow. Imagine it — Professor Harkness, terrifying, flawless, untouchable… covered in flour and tomato sauce.”

 

“I will hex you,” Agatha growled, grabbing her napkin and flinging it at Rio.

 

It landed squarely on her chest, sticking briefly before fluttering to her lap. Rio raised her hands in surrender, still laughing. “ Abuse ! Domestic abuse!”

 

“And you,” Agatha pointed at her, lips twitching as she tried to maintain her dignity, “shut your mouth. Insolent woman.”

 

Nick was giggling so hard now he had tears in his eyes. “Mommy called Death insolent ,” he wheezed.

 

“Mommy does not fear the reaper,” Rio declared dramatically, holding up her pizza like a sword. “How terrifying I am.”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes at Rio's drama.

 

Nicole lifted her cup. “To the flour war of 6PM.”

 

Nick lifted his too. “To pizza that survived the apocalypse.”

 

Agatha shook her head, lips twitching. “To future therapy bills.”

 

They clinked their glasses and cups together with a little too much energy, water sloshing over the edges, and no one cared. The sound of it — glass against glass, laughter, warm chewing, napkins rustling — filled the space with something they all needed.

 

Not just joy.

 

But belonging .





The university café was buzzing as always — students milling about with half-full mugs of burnt coffee, the smell of toasted bread and paper-thin anxiety in the air. Agatha entered like a storm disguised in boots and tailored black slacks, her stride clipped, her expression somewhere between exhausted and exasperated.

 

Her friends were already seated at their usual table near the windows, sipping their drinks, half-watching her approach with matching smirks.

 

“Well, well,” Jen said, stirring her coffee with a slow elegance that meant trouble. “I see someone changed her hairstyle.”

 

Agatha paused mid-step, instantly suspicious.

 

Jen’s grin widened. “That crispy dough streak really did suit you, sweetheart.”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes so hard it looked like an exorcism. “Shut up, Cynthia Erivo,” she muttered, before flopping dramatically into the chair beside them, tossing her sunglasses onto the table like a woman returning from war.

 

Behind her, Rio walked with the grace of someone who had not only not gone through a domestic flour war the night before — but had emerged from it smugly victorious. She was balancing Agatha’s tote bag on one arm, her lecture notes and a thermos in the other, looking more like Agatha’s personal assistant than her lover. She placed everything on the table with careful, practiced ease and took the seat next to Agatha with a small, devastating smile.

 

“Good morning, ladies,” she greeted smoothly, crossing her legs and looking entirely unbothered.

 

Lilia raised a brow behind her tinted reading glasses. “Looks like you two managed to patch things up.”

 

Agatha lifted her coffee cup in a lazy toast. “ We’re trying .”

 

“Oh, it shows,” Alice muttered into her drink, not bothering to hide the bite in her tone. “For a second, I really thought the intern had finally done what we all secretly wanted.”

 

Agatha didn’t miss a beat. “Kiss me, you Asian gremlin?”

 

“Slit your throat, you dramatic butch,” Alice replied sweetly, her voice utterly devoid of malice. “That tomato sauce on your face looked like blood.”

 

“Much less flavorful, I assure you,” Agatha deadpanned, reaching for the sugar with a flourish. “Would’ve been a better scene if I’d screamed.”

 

“Honestly, who woke her up from that coma?” Wanda asked with a sigh, leaning back in her chair like she needed divine intervention. “Go back to sleep, Agatha.”

 

“Believe me, I tried ,” Agatha muttered, sipping her coffee. “But then someone”— she gestured vaguely at Rio without looking —“decided to go full Italian horror movie on me in the kitchen.”

 

Rio tilted her head, smiling innocently. “You’re still alive, aren’t you?”

 

“Barely.”

 

“And prettier than ever,” Rio added.

 

“That’s not how trauma works, darling.”

 

The table burst into laughter, a mix of groans and chuckles bouncing between them. Even Alice cracked a smile behind her cup. The tension from the last few days seemed lighter now — like it had finally exhaled.

 

For just a moment, it was easy to forget that one of them had once brought people back from the dead, and the other was Death in a leather jacket.

 

Just women. Coffee. Sass. Secrets.

 

And a very public Instagram post Nicole had uploaded for the entire world to enjoy.




The bathroom tiles were cold against Agatha’s knees — unforgiving, bone-deep cold that seeped straight through her skin and into her joints, grounding her in the worst possible way.

 

Her fingers curled over the porcelain rim of the toilet, knuckles pale, muscles tight, as another violent wave of nausea climbed up her spine and clawed at her throat. She barely had time to brace herself before her body convulsed again, expelling whatever remained in her stomach with a broken, guttural heave. Her hair stuck to her cheeks, sweat and strands tangled together, and her knees pressed harder into the tile as she leaned over the bowl, shaking.

 

When the worst of it passed, she stayed there — draped over the toilet like a woman half-exorcised — gasping through parted lips, her chest rising and falling with shallow, exhausted breaths. The sharp tang of stomach acid stung the back of her throat, mingling with the bitter taste of old mint toothpaste and the faint lemon scent of bathroom cleaner. It was nauseating, dizzying. The kind of mix that made her want to vomit again just by existing.

 

She wiped her mouth lazily with the back of her hand, then grimaced at herself. Classy . She slumped back against the wall, neck tilted, eyes half-lidded and burning at the corners, her breathing finally beginning to steady.

 

“What the hell did I eat?” Her voice was hoarse, barely audible, like it was afraid of being overheard.

 

She let her head thunk lightly against the wall and closed her eyes, trying to piece the last few days together like a forensic puzzle. Pasta. Grilled salmon. A suspicious yogurt Rio swore was " fine " even though it was two days past expiration. Half a chocolate bar Nick had hidden under the couch cushion and forgotten about . It had a little lint on the side, sure, but it still tasted decent.

 

Nothing . Nothing worthy of this kind of betrayal. This wasn’t food poisoning. This wasn’t a random virus. This wasn’t even one of those week-long work of stress nausea.

 

This felt… familiar. Too familiar.

 

Her mind didn’t want to go there, but it did — slipping back, uninvited, to a certain night a few weeks ago. The night when Rio had looked at her like she was both altar and flame, when Agatha had whispered I trust you against her lover’s mouth as magic surged between their bodies.

 

And she'd meant it. She always meant it .

 

She remembered the way Rio's fingers had glowed with that soft, ancient power as they moved inside her. How their soulmate marks — those thin red threads etched into their wrists — had pulsed in unison, hot and alive . She remembered the high, the fullness, the surrender. And she remembered how every time she surrendered like that — fully, without shields or sarcasm — she ended up with one of Rio’s cosmic spawn growing inside her.

 

“Shit,” she whispered.

 

The ache that had settled in her bones after. The way her body had trembled for hours , limbs boneless from Rio’s magic and touch. Her skin had hummed for days afterward, as if Death herself had left fingerprints beneath the surface.

 

And she had . Again.

 

Agatha groaned and dropped her head back against the wall with a dull thunk , eyes wide and distant.

 

She remembered exactly what Rio said right before taking her apart — slowly, thoroughly. Whispering promises of another child , of not stopping until you’re mine again.

 

“I trust you,” Agatha had whispered back. And the memory echoed in her mind again.

 

Just like she always did. Every damn time .

And every damn time … she ended up with one of Rio’s little soldiers growing inside her just to grow up and look the same as Rio.

 

“ Bloody fucking hell ,” she muttered, pressing a hand to her stomach like it might give her answers. Or at least deny the truth. But it didn’t. It was warm. Soft. Tender. And the nausea twisting inside her wasn’t just physical — it was familiar. Terrifyingly familiar.

 

Her shaky hand over her stomach was not because she expected to feel anything yet, but because it was instinct. Her palm rested against the still-flat plane of her belly, and the realization curled low in her chest like a flicker of heat.

 

Of course .

 

Of course the cravings, the morning nausea, the offhand tears during a cereal commercial, the irrational need to physically throw Rio out the window (even more than usual) — it was all there. All the signs .

 

She exhaled slowly and dragged herself upright, using the sink for support. Her reflection in the mirror looked… like someone who’d been steamrolled by divine irony. Her hair was wild. Her eyes rimmed in pink. She was pale and radiant in that faintly cursed, slightly glowing way she always got during the early stages.

 

Great .

 

She'd been through this before. She'd survived this before. But something about this time made her chest tighten. Not with panic. Not yet . With... anticipation. Dread. Hope. All tangled into a single knot that sat beneath her ribs.

 

“I can’t believe I let her do this again ,” she muttered aloud, eyes flicking to the ceiling like the tiles might answer for her.

 

And yet… she’d known. She’d known what Rio wanted. She remembered the glint in Rio’s eyes. The way her hands trembled with hunger and reverence. The low growl of her voice when she said Let me have you like that again . And Agatha had opened herself to it. To her .

 

Again . For the fourth time.

 

She brushed a palm down her abdomen again.

 

“Okay, Agatha,” she murmured, grounding herself in the sound of her own voice. “You’ve done this before. It’s not new. It’s just a soul-bound pregnancy orchestrated by the cosmic personification of death. Totally normal… Right?”

 

She let out a short, dry laugh that broke at the end. Her throat felt tight.

 

“She wants this too,” she whispered. “It’ll be okay this time.”

 

So why did her hands tremble? Why did her chest feel like it was folding in on itself?

 

She flushed the toilet, the sound loud and final in the too-still room, like the end of a conversation she wasn’t ready to have. Then she reached for her toothbrush, moving with the detached precision of someone trying to pretend they were just getting ready for class, not unraveling.

 

She scrubbed her teeth. Once. Twice. A third time. She scraped at her tongue like she could erase the bitter taste of panic from the back of her throat. The toothpaste burned. Good .

 

When she looked up, her reflection in the mirror stared back, pale and sweat-damp, with strands of hair plastered to her temple. Her eyes were wide and rimmed in pink, but dry — like even her tears were holding their breath. She looked furious. And terrified. And utterly betrayed by her own body.

 

With a sharp exhale, she splashed cold water on her face, hoping it might shock the spiral out of her system. It didn’t . But it made her feel cleaner . Less like someone who might cry in a pharmacy aisle.

 

She patted her skin dry with the towel, grabbed her coat from the hook, and swung her bag over her shoulder in one sharp motion.

 

“Pharmacy first,” she muttered, voice low and brittle.

 

Then, after a pause, she added —

 

“Panic later.”

 

And walked out the door.




The fluorescent lights of the pharmacy were unforgiving.

 

They buzzed faintly overhead, casting a pale, sterile glow that made everything look more exposed — more real . Agatha stepped through the sliding glass doors with her head lowered and her sunglasses still on, despite the cloudy sky outside and the fact that she was, without question, indoors. Her long black coat was buttoned to the top, swallowing her frame, and her posture was stiff, deliberate. She moved through the aisles with the grace of a woman on a covert mission — one she prayed no one would notice.

 

She passed the cold medicine without slowing. Pretended to examine a bottle of multivitamins with great interest. Took a sharp left at the foot creams like she knew exactly where she was going.

 

Then she reached the aisle. The aisle.

 

It stared her down without mercy. Discreet packaging in shades of pink, blue, and beige. Feminine branding that tried to be subtle and failed miserably. Soft fonts, pastel smiles, words like early result and clear answer and peace of mind, all screaming the same thing in slightly different accents.

 

She hovered in front of the options, frozen. One hand curled over the strap of her purse, the other hesitant in mid-air, torn between a digital test and the kind that looked like a cursed thermometer from the 90s.

 

She was just reaching toward the shelf when a voice rang out behind her.

 

“Well, well... if it isn’t Miss ‘I’m Fine, I Don’t Need Help, Stop Asking Me Things.’ ”

 

Agatha’s entire spine locked. She didn’t even have to turn around.

 

“Wanda,” she sighed, already regretting every decision she’d made since waking up.

 

Wanda Maximoff appeared beside her like a vision in red, arms crossed, one brow lifted in devastating, theatrical judgment. She wore an oversized sweater, leggings, and that annoyingly effortless bun that made her look like a magazine ad for magical moms who do yoga and control chaos with ease.

 

Her eyes flicked from Agatha’s sunglasses to the shelf of pregnancy tests, then back.

 

Agatha remained silent.

 

For once in her life, Agatha Harkness had absolutely nothing to say. And that was the most worrying sign of all.

 

Wanda stepped closer, her voice saccharine. “Looking for vitamins? UTI test? Ooh — checking your ovulation window for funsies?”

 

Agatha turned her head slowly, glaring through her sunglasses like they were a weapon. “I swear to every cosmic law, if you breathe a word—”

 

Wanda lifted both hands in mock surrender, her tone softening. “Relax. I’m not judging you.”

 

“You’re absolutely judging me.”

 

“No,” Wanda said, plucking a box off the shelf and tossing it into Agatha’s basket. Then another. And a third. All different brands. “I’m validating your questionable life choices and timing.”

 

She added one more test box. “Here, backup confirmation. Just in case .”

 

Agatha snorted, despite herself.

 

Wanda smiled, sly. “Your husband was just committed for schizophrenia. Or so I heard.”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes. “You’re an awful person .”

 

“And you’re pregnant ,” Wanda murmured, not even phrased as a question. Her gaze softened then, the sarcasm draining just a little. “Is it Rio’s?”

 

Agatha turned to her, lifting her sunglasses halfway down her nose just to glare properly. “ Who else do you think it could be?”

 

Wanda blinked. “Right. Dumb question. Although... she is a woman, technically, no very dumb question… unless she has, you know —” Wanda gestured vaguely in front of her pelvis in a motion that might’ve been trying to mimic a penis.

 

“ Stop talking .”

 

They stood in silence. A weird, aisle-five kind of silence.

 

Finally, Agatha whispered, “I’m not even sure yet. It’s just a theory.”

 

Wanda looked at her flatly. “You’re in this aisle. That already says enough.”

 

Agatha sighed, thumb brushing the edge of the cardboard box in her hand. “ She wants this . She’s wanted this for a long time. She says she wants to be present. She wants to do it right. Since... I didn’t really let her be close before. Not the other times.”

 

Wanda leaned against the shelf, nudging Agatha’s arm gently. “You’re always scared before something wonderful happens. You’re like... emotionally allergic to joy.”

 

“That’s not true.”

 

“You tried to dismantle a wedding cake at the Stark wedding because it looked ‘too optimistic.’”

 

“It was suspiciously tall.”

 

Wanda chuckled and stepped away, brushing invisible dust from her sweater. “Go home, Aggie. Take the test. Then tell her.”

 

Agatha raised a brow. “Why me ?”

 

“Because she’s Rio, and if I find out before she does, I’ll tease you into the afterlife. But if she finds out I knew before she did?” Wanda paused, deadpan. “I’ll probably wake up dead tomorrow.”

 

Agatha nodded, quietly resigned. “Fair.”

 

She adjusted her sunglasses, lifted the basket like she was preparing for battle, and marched toward the checkout with her chin high.

 

Behind her, Wanda called softly, “Hey, Aggie—”

 

Agatha didn’t stop walking. “What?”

 

“You’ll be a great mom again.”

 

Agatha didn’t answer. She didn’t look back. But her fingers curled protectively around the edge of the basket.

 

And somewhere, beneath the steel armor she wore like a second skin… Her heart fluttered.




Positive.

Positive.

Positive...

Positive.

 

Four different boxes. Four different brands. All the same result.

 

The only thing remotely negative in the room was Agatha herself — sitting on the edge of the bathtub, head in her hands, stomach threatening another revolt. She was surrounded by empty boxes, wet sticks on a towel, and several now-unlabeled plastic cups that had once held orange juice, potion ingredients, or Nick’s sidewalk chalk rinse water.

 

She had ignored Rio the entire afternoon. Dodged questions, avoided eye contact, muttered things like I’m fine and just tired while practically speed-walking through their house. But now she was locked in the bathroom, caught red-handed and… literally pants-down, peeing into various containers to “ test a theory ” she had already confirmed four times over.

 

So why was she freaking out?

 

She’d been pregnant before. Three times . She’d raised two chaotic demigods who were probably inventing time travel in the living room as she spiraled in here. She had done this before. Survived it. Even found joy in it.

 

But this time — this time felt different. Too quiet. Too real. Too possible .

 

The baby was Rio’s. Her soulmate. The love of her life. The woman for whom she had rewritten the rules of existence, bent fate backward just to be with. So why did it feel like her lungs were trying to close?

 

“Ágata?”

 

Her name came softly through the door, laced with that thick, unguarded Spanish accent Rio only had when she was relaxed… or distracted. It was how she said it when she wasn’t paying attention to her mouth — just her heart. Which meant Rio wasn’t worried about being careful. But she was worried.

 

“Ags, you’re acting weird. Are you okay? I can hear your heart going a thousand beats a minute. Like there’s two in there. It’s been like that for days.”

 

Agatha squeezed her eyes shut, the words hitting too close. Too accurate .

 

The gentleness in Rio’s voice seeped through the crack in the door like warm honey. “Do I need to call a doctor? Because you know, it’s normal, right? You’re human now. You don’t have spells to fix you anymore.”

 

Yes , Agatha thought bitterly. I know .

 

No magic to numb this. No spell to undo it.

 

Her gaze flicked to the tests again, still laid out like little soldiers of truth. Her heart slammed harder. What was she supposed to do?

 

What if Rio had only said she wanted this in the heat of the moment? A whisper in the dark, during that night when their soulmate marks burned like wildfire and Rio’s magic had driven her to the edge of the universe and back. What if this child wasn’t the beginning of something, but the beginning of the end?

 

What if — when — something went wrong, it was Rio who had to take the baby away? To guide it into death’s arms again?

 

What if Agatha hated her for it?

 

Again?

 

And that was it.

 

That’s where the fear was coming from. It wasn’t rejection. It wasn’t doubt . It was terror .

 

Not of having the baby.

But of losing it.

Of losing Rio.

Of living through that silence again.

 

She pressed her hands to her mouth, trying to keep in the cry that clawed up her throat. Her chest trembled. A small sob escaped anyway, cracking through her like glass under pressure.

 

“Agatha?” Rio’s voice sharpened with urgency. “Open the door. Please . Let me in.”

 

Agatha inhaled, then slowly rose to her feet. The world swayed under her for a second, nausea giving her one last cruel tug. She looked down at the tests in her hand — then at the door.

 

There was no hiding this.

 

Even if Rio hadn’t figured it out with her absurd ability to hear her heartbeat from across a room, she would’ve known. She always knew. She was Death — she could feel when a new soul entered the world.

 

And now… there was another. A soul made of starlight and heat and trust. A piece of both of them.

 

She opened the door.

 

Before Rio could speak, before she could even see the tests, Agatha dropped everything and threw herself into her arms — burying her face into Rio’s chest, her fingers clawing into the soft cotton “Happy Not-Mother’s Day” shirt Nick and Nicole had painted with messy little hearts and stick figures.

 

Rio held her instantly, her arms folding around Agatha’s trembling frame with the kind of instinctual love that didn’t need to ask questions.

 

“Hey…” she whispered, brushing her hand up and down Agatha’s back. “You’ve been so emotional lately, you know that? Are you on your period again? Are these... human hormone things?”

 

Agatha let out something between a laugh and a sob into her shirt.

Rio kissed the top of her head and pulled back just enough to cradle her face. Her thumb traced a tear down Agatha’s cheek, gently.

 

Rio was just opening her mouth to ask what was going on when her eyes dropped — instinctively, unerringly — to Agatha’s hands.

 

The pregnancy tests dangled limply from Agatha’s fingers, suspended at her sides like little flags of truth. Four of them . All undeniably, glaringly positive. Agatha hadn’t even realized she was still holding them. She stood in the doorway, barely breathing, as if her body had gone numb under the weight of knowing.

 

Rio stared at the tests.

 

One beat.

Two.

Three.

Each second stretched like an eternity.

 

Then her eyes snapped up to meet Agatha’s. Softly, disbelievingly, she murmured, “Oh…”

 

Another pause. Then the weight of the realization hit her fully.

 

“ Oh !” Her voice rose slightly with surprise, her eyes widening. She blinked, as though seeing something new within Agatha — something glowing. “There really is another heartbeat,” she whispered, wonder dripping from every syllable.

 

Agatha let out a teary laugh, sharp and choked, as she wiped her cheek with the back of her wrist. Rio’s face — so open, so unguarded in that moment — made her chest ache. She looked like someone who had just stumbled into a miracle. Innocent. Lost. Radiant .

 

“Yeah,” Agatha said, her voice cracking around the word. “Apparently so.”

 

Rio reached out and carefully took the tests from Agatha’s hands, like they were sacred objects she didn’t want to disturb. She examined each one like she didn’t quite believe her senses — even though she could feel the heartbeat, even though her very nature knew another life had joined the world. Still, she needed the proof. She needed the physical affirmation.

 

“I’m going to be a mom?” Rio whispered. “ Again ?”

 

Her voice trembled, and before Agatha could answer, Rio’s eyes shimmered. They filled instantly, without hesitation, with tears that spilled down the moment she blinked.

And that was when Agatha knew — without any room for doubt — that Rio wasn’t scared. She wasn’t overwhelmed or conflicted or uncertain. She was happy . So purely, deeply happy that it radiated off of her like sunlight.

 

All the fear in Agatha’s chest — the weight of it, the what-ifs, the shadowy possibilities of loss — sputtered and cracked under the warmth of that joy. She suddenly felt a little foolish for being so afraid.

 

“Yes, sweetheart,” Agatha murmured, finally letting herself smile fully through her tears. “You’re going to be a mom again. A very good mom.”

 

This time, the tears that came weren’t heavy. They were light . Cleansing. Grateful.

 

Rio set the tests gently down on the counter, then knelt in front of Agatha, her hands rising with reverence to touch her stomach. There was no shape yet, no visible sign. Just skin, soft warmth, and something more — something only Rio could feel. A presence. A pulse.

She closed her eyes and rested her palm there, and her lips parted like she was listening to music no one else could hear.

 

Then her voice, hushed and trembling with emotion: “Do you want this too, Agatha?”

 

Even in her joy, even in her awe, Rio made space for her. Because she knew joy didn’t erase fear. Because the choice would always belong to Agatha . She wouldn't have joy if Agatha didn't want it, if Agatha wasn't happy with her. Joy isn't joy when it's one-sided .

 

Agatha looked down at the warm hand on her stomach, fingers so careful, so steady. A new wave of emotion swelled in her chest. The doubt crept in again — those quiet questions, the old ache of what if, the lingering ghosts of everything they’d already lost.

 

But then she looked into Rio’s eyes and all she saw was love . Real, unshakable, I’d-die-for-you love. That was enough.

 

“More than anything,” Agatha whispered.

 

Rio closed her eyes and exhaled slowly — like a prayer had been answered.

And for the first time that day, Agatha didn’t feel afraid. She felt ready. Maybe not ready for the chaos or the sleepless nights or the weird cravings. But ready for this life. Ready to do it together .




Chapter End Notes

I hags,
Since I'm a very nice person, I'm living for you a plus chapter. A Prologue during Agatha's pregnacie and Rio being a full present mom.

Chapter 17: Prologue

The nausea came with a vengeance. Morning, noon, midnight — didn’t matter . Agatha could be doing something entirely mundane, like brushing her teeth or simply existing near the smell of toast, and suddenly she’d be bolting toward the nearest sink like her soul had decided to evacuate.

 

Rio followed behind her every time, a quiet guardian armed with ponytail holders, a cool damp cloth, and the occasional grim commentary like, “If you die throwing up, I swear I’ll resurrect you just to yell at you.”

 

“You’re Death,” Agatha once hissed between dry heaves, “ just take me . End my suffering.”

 

“I could, but I won’t . You made me watch Bridgerton season three. This is fair retribution.”

 

The cravings came next.

 

Not just food — but absurd, strangely poetic combinations that made Rio question the laws of chemistry and common decency. Pickled strawberries. Garlic ice cream. Seaweed with strawberry jam, which Agatha insisted — very seriously — helped with her migraines. At one point, she claimed she could taste colors and asked Rio to help her hunt down “the blue version of cinnamon.” Rio still didn’t know what that meant.


One particularly cursed night, at 2:36 a.m., Agatha shook Rio awake, her face an eerie combination of desperation and command. Her voice was hushed, deadly serious.

 

“I would literally trade your immortality,” she whispered, “for a bowl of lemon risotto… with marshmallows.”

 

Rio blinked at her. Twice. “Are you possessed?”

 

Agatha narrowed her eyes. “ Do I look like I’m joking? ”

 

She didn’t . She looked like a woman on the edge of stabbing Death with a salad fork.

 

So, Rio got up and made it. Twice . Because the first time, the rice was “too confident,” and the marshmallows were “emotionally flat.” Rio didn’t argue. She just sighed, muttered something about “suffering for love,” and started over. But even with the 3 a.m. cravings, the tears over commercials, the mid-conversation bathroom runs, and the ongoing war between Agatha and her suddenly super-sensitive nose (RIP Rio’s lavender shampoo), none of it outweighed the joy.

 

Because this time, Rio was there.

Really there. Not lurking in the periphery, not fading in and out of planes, not inventing errands in the underworld to avoid the ache of attachment. She wasn’t hiding behind ancient grief or pretending to be untouchable. She was present. Emotionally. Physically. Constantly.

Every step. Every breath. Every flutter of panic. Every hormonal meltdown. Every bizarre craving. She was there, hand on Agatha’s back when she threw up. Hand in hers at every appointment. Hand around her hip at night when sleep refused to come.

And Agatha noticed. She noticed the way Rio’s eyes softened whenever she looked at her. The way she absentmindedly traced patterns on her belly while reading out loud — ancient poetry or children's books, depending on the day. She noticed the way Rio pressed soft, reverent kisses to her skin just below her navel each morning, whispering Hey, baby like it was a secret between them.

 

She noticed how Rio breathed differently now. Like every breath was fuller, steadier, anchored in a life she never thought she’d get to live. Agatha had been through this before. But never like this . Never with Rio’s full presence. Her laughter. Her tenderness. Her awe.

And somehow, in between the chaos of mismatched meals and late-night existential spirals, Agatha found herself falling in love all over again. Not just with Rio. But with the life they were building.

 

One absurd, beautiful craving at a time.

 

The first ultrasound had been scheduled for a cloudy Tuesday morning.

 

The sky was gray and moody, casting soft light through the windows, the kind that made everything feel a little slower, a little quieter — as if the world itself was holding its breath.

 

Rio had been up before dawn, pacing the kitchen barefoot in mismatched socks and clutching her fifth cup of black coffee like it might steady the nervous buzz under her skin. She’d already refolded the same dish towel three times. Her phone was plugged in and fully charged, just in case the baby decided to start breakdancing mid-scan and she needed photographic proof.

 

At 6:00 a.m., she checked the time again. At 6:02, she did it again.

 

Agatha finally emerged from the hallway in her oversized hoodie, hair barely tamed, one hand supporting her lower back, and the other pointed directly at the cat who had been staring at her belly like it might hatch.

 

“If he touches me again, I will turn him into a decorative pillow.”

 

“He’s just curious,” Rio said, hiding her grin behind the coffee mug. “Maybe he feels the divine chaos growing inside you.”

 

Agatha grunted and waddled to the chair with the flair of a pregnant goddess on a warpath. “He’ll feel my boot if he keeps looking at me like that.”

 

That's right, a cat. Because somewhere in the first few weeks, Rio thought it would be an excellent idea to bring in a stray cat from the street to be the new Harkness-Vidal. Agatha was still adjusting to the presence of the new member who seemed to judge her all the time.

 

By 7:30 a.m., they arrived at the clinic.

 

By 7:45, Nick had already spilled juice down the front of his hoodie and was now poking his own stomach to see if he, too, had a baby in there. Nicole sat beside him with crossed legs and closed eyes, claiming to be “centering her energy” for the new life about to be revealed.

 

“Children,” Agatha whispered under her breath, rubbing her temple.

 

“Chaos goblins,” Rio corrected, sipping from her now-cold coffee cup.

 

When the technician finally called their names, the four of them stood as one. Agatha moved slowly, Rio steadying her with a hand on her back. Nick clutched the end of her coat like a security blanket. Nicole adjusted her headband with a business-like calm and marched in first, as if she had personally scheduled the appointment herself.

 

The room was dim and hushed, the air thick with anticipation.

 

Rio didn’t let go of Agatha’s hand, not even for a second. Her other hand hovered nervously in the air, unsure where to go. Nick sat on the small bench beside Agatha, chewing his lower lip, sneakers swinging gently. Nicole stood upright beside him, eyes trained on the machine like a royal guard at a sacred ritual.

 

Then the screen lit up.

 

And there it was.

 

Tiny. Perfect. Fluttering.

 

A flicker of movement, a pulsing rhythm, steady and impossibly small.

 

A heartbeat.

 

Agatha gasped — softly, a sharp intake that caught in her throat. Her grip tightened around Rio’s fingers. Unlike Rio who could hear the baby's heartbeat since the day his heart was formed, Agatha couldn't. This was the first time she had actually heard the baby's heartbeat. Her baby. She understood why she often woke up at night with Rio resting on her belly and saying " shh, I'm listening .”

 

Rio didn’t breathe. Her entire world narrowed down to that single, blinking speck of light. Her heart stuttered. Her lips parted, but no words came.

 

Nick leaned forward, eyes wide and glowing. “Is that it?”

 

Nicole, never missing a beat, nodded slowly. “That’s our future sibling. I can tell. Has the same ‘please help me’ energy as the rest of us.”

 

Rio let out a laugh — but it broke halfway through, collapsing into a quiet, surprised sob. The kind that sneaks up on you, soft and sudden. Her shoulders shook. Tears slipped down her cheeks, uninvited but welcomed.

 

Agatha turned to her, already crying a little herself. “You’re a mess.”

 

“I’m so happy,” Rio whispered, her voice barely above breath. “This feels… real .”

 

Agatha smiled and leaned her head back slightly, brushing her temple against Rio’s. “It is real,” she murmured. “And if this kid is anything like the rest of you, it’s already plotting to steal my bed and all of my favorite mugs.”

 

Nick raised his hand. “Can we name it T-Rex if it kicks really hard?”

 

“ No ,” said both mothers in perfect sync.

 

Nicole, who had come prepared, pulled a tiny floral notebook from her backpack and began writing. “I’m making a list. We’ll vote democratically.”

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow. “That means Rio’s definitely going to lose.”

 

Rio leaned in, brushing a kiss against her temple. “As long as I don’t lose this, I’ll survive.”

 

She placed her hand gently on Agatha’s stomach, where the flicker of life still pulsed, strong and steady.

 

There was no shape yet. No face. No name . But there was a heartbeat. And for the first time in a long, long time, everything felt right.

 

The nausea was gone.

 

Thank God .

 

But what came in its place was arguably more dangerous: Agatha's wrath.

 

She had reached a stage of pregnancy where every hormone in her body apparently conspired to make her a paradox of emotions. She wanted affection. But she didn’t want to be touched. She needed Rio’s presence — her scent, her warmth, her voice — but if Rio breathed too loudly near her for more than ten seconds, she would throw a pillow with surprising precision.

 

“Why are you looking at me like that ?” Agatha snapped one morning as Rio entered the kitchen.

 

“I didn’t even open my eyes yet, my love” Rio mumbled, clutching her coffee like a shield.

 

“Well, try blinking more silently .”

 

Nick had learned to walk through the house with caution. Nicole had started referring to her mother’s mood as “the Storm Phase.” Rio kept a pre-packed bag by the door in case she needed to flee to another dimension for a few hours.

 

Still, somehow, there was love.

 

And a baby room to build.

 

It started one Saturday with a hammer, a cursed IKEA instruction manual, and three very determined people.

 

“Well, we’re going for lilac and green,” Rio explained, holding up two paint swatches like they were holy artifacts. “Agatha doesn’t want to know the gender yet, and frankly, she might curse me if I try to tell her.”

 

Nick sat cross-legged on the floor, covered in paint specks and betrayal. “Why am I even here? I’m just lifting things and getting judged for my brush strokes.”

 

Nicole, without looking up from the paint tray, said calmly, “Because this is what siblings do. We build. We protect. We choose aesthetic .”

 

Nick blinked. “That’s your job. I’m the comic relief.”

 

“You’re also tall enough to reach the top of the bookshelf,” Rio added, passing him a roller. “So suck it up, comic relief .”

 

The walls soon became a soft lilac with leafy green vines stenciled across the lower half. There were glow-in-the-dark stars hidden in the corners — Nick’s idea. Nicole picked curtains with subtle constellation patterns. Rio painted a wooden shelf by hand with calming runes Agatha used to mutter during thunderstorms.

 

Agatha poked her head in once, took one look at the chaos, and muttered, “If a single piece of glitter ends up in my tea, I will burn this room down with my mind.”

 

Then she waddled off to go scream at a cereal box for not closing correctly.

 

Rio did know the baby’s gender. Of course she did. She was Death. Life didn’t exactly hide its secrets from her. But she kept her mouth shut.

 

Not because she didn’t want to tell Agatha — but because Agatha deserved to choose when to know. And because deep down, Rio kind of loved the mystery. The potential. The name debates at 2:00 a.m., the guessing games, the bets with Nick (who insisted the baby was a dragon) and the quiet certainty in Nicole’s eyes.

 

Because Nicole knew .

 

She didn’t say it out loud. Not really. But one night, as Rio stood in the almost-finished nursery, she felt a presence behind her and turned to find Nicole watching her.

 

“You know too, don’t you?” Rio asked softly, amused.

 

Nicole nodded once. “It’s not that hard. I’m made from both of you. The baby feels like… light. Not loud. Like balance .”

 

Rio smiled. “You’re not going to tell your mom, are you?”

 

Nicole gave her a look. “I want to survive this trimester, thank you.”

 

They both turned back to the glowing walls, comfortable in their cosmic silence.

 

Meanwhile, Agatha stormed through the house one afternoon, glaring at the shelves Rio had built in the hallway.

 

“These shelves are crooked.”

 

“They’re literally level,” Rio replied.

 

“They feel crooked emotionally .”

 

Rio opened her mouth. Closed it. Then just said, “Okay, honey.”

 

Nick stood nearby, slowly placing a cup of tea on the table like he was delivering food to a wild animal.

 

Agatha narrowed her eyes. “What is that?”

 

“Chamomile?” he answered cautiously.

 

“I hate chamomile,” she snapped. Then paused. “...Thank you, baby.”

 

Nick blinked. “...You’re welcome?”

 

Rio watched the exchange with the patience of someone who had once argued with a dragon and lost.

 

Later that night, Agatha curled up in bed, sobbing because her sandwich had “too much bread energy,” while Rio spooned her gently and whispered, “It’s okay. I’ll go talk to the bread.”

 

Agatha hiccuped. “Kill it.”

 

Despite everything — the tears, the mood swings, the deep need to cry at perfume commercials — there was a rhythm settling in.

 

A quiet. The nursery was finished. Lilac and green. Stars and vines. Chaos and calm.

 

Nick still thought the baby might be born with wings. Nicole had already written three poems and chosen a theme song. Rio still hadn’t told Agatha the gender, and Agatha still threatened to stab her daily with a butter knife.

But when she fell asleep each night, her hand on her belly and her back pressed against Rio’s chest, the house went still.

 

And for a moment, even Death knew peace.

 

The last trimester was brutal.

 

Agatha was over it.

 

Her belly had taken on a gravitational pull of its own. None of her clothes fit the way she liked. Her once-favorite dresses now clung in the wrong places or rode up in the back, and every attempt to put on shoes turned into a small war that left her cursing gravity, shoe laces, and the concept of toes. Her ankles were swollen, her skin stretched tight, and her balance… well, she hadn’t seen her own feet in weeks.

 

And underneath it all, that quiet, creeping voice had started to whisper again. The one that echoed in the silence of her own thoughts. The one that made her doubt whether Rio still looked at her the same way. Whether she still felt beautiful. Whether she was still herself under all this flesh, sweat, and stretch marks.

 

She didn’t say it out loud. Not directly. She just got quieter. Tired-er. Snapped a little more. Laughed a little less.

 

Rio noticed. Of course she did.



One evening, after a long day of trying to feel normal and failing, Agatha shuffled into the bedroom and started undressing with slow, frustrated movements. Her body ached. Her spine hurt. Her stomach felt impossibly heavy.

 

She didn’t notice Rio until a pair of cool hands gently pulled her arms back and helped her out of her shirt.

 

“What are you—?”

 

“Shhh,” Rio said softly.

 

Agatha let her. Too tired to argue. Too curious to fight it.

 

Rio guided her — nude now, belly full and glowing — toward the large standing mirror in the corner of their room. The curtains were drawn, the light dim. The silence in the room was soft, humming. A space held just for them.

 

“Look,” Rio said, voice barely above a breath. She stood behind Agatha, her body flush against her back, one arm curling slowly around her front.

 

Agatha averted her eyes.

 

“I look like a walking melon,” she muttered.

 

“ No ,” Rio whispered. She gently bent her knees and brought her hands under Agatha’s belly, sliding beneath the weight of it with reverent care. Then she lifted — slowly, carefully — supporting the full curve of it in her palms.

 

Agatha inhaled sharply. It was the first time in weeks she hadn’t felt the pressure pressing down on her pelvis. The first time her back stopped aching. The weight, the gravity of it, was suddenly... shared.

 

“Oh my God,” Agatha whispered, eyes widening.

 

“I’ve got you,” Rio murmured.

 

She pressed her cheek against Agatha’s shoulder, her lips brushing the curve of her neck. Her arms remained under her belly, holding her up — not just in gesture, but with all the steadiness of someone who had held dying stars and broken souls, and now held her.

 

They stared into the mirror together.

 

Agatha saw herself. Really saw. The curve of her hips. The swell of her stomach. The fullness of her breasts. The softness in her arms. The strength in her stance. She looked like something ancient. Sacred. Like earth and flame and love all tangled into one trembling, living thing.

 

“You are carrying the most precious thing in the universe,” Rio whispered, eyes locked with hers in the reflection. “And I don’t just mean our baby.”

 

Agatha swallowed hard.

 

“You’re powerful ,” Rio continued. “Not in magic. Not in spells. Just you . You’re creation. You’re courage. You’re every heartbeat and breath and tear and laugh that brought us here. You’re the most beautiful thing I’ve ever seen.”

 

Agatha’s chin trembled. “You’re just saying that because you want sex later.”

 

Rio smiled against her shoulder. “I always want sex later. But that doesn’t make it less true.”

 

Agatha laughed — wet and cracked and raw. Her hands came up to cover Rio’s, still holding the weight of their unborn child.

 

They stood like that for minutes, unmoving.

 

Just two women. One holding life. The other holding her. And for that brief, sacred stretch of time, the weight wasn’t so heavy anymore.




It started with pain.
