A deep, sudden ache that wrapped around Agatha’s abdomen like an iron band. It pulled her from sleep in a rush of heat and pressure, making her bolt upright in bed, hands instinctively flying to her belly.

 

She couldn’t breathe for a second. She just sat there, hunched forward, legs dangling off the edge of the bed, her fingers digging into the skin of her own stomach like she could somehow hold the pain in place with sheer will.

 

The clock read 4:23 a.m.

 

Her breath came in shaky gasps.

 

Beside her, Rio stirred, then jolted awake with a startled gasp, nearly falling off the bed in her scramble to sit up.

 

“Agatha?” she rasped, disoriented, hair tangled, voice thick with sleep.

 

Agatha didn’t respond immediately — her face was scrunched with pain, her lips parted in a half-growl, half-breath. But when Rio leaned closer, what caught her attention more than the pain was what she saw behind Agatha’s eyes.

 

Fear . Raw. Clear. Sharp.

 

“Okay,” Rio said quickly, already climbing out of bed, heart in her throat. “Okay, okay, I’m going to get the bags and wake the kids. You stay here, sit back, breathe . Like that exercise we practiced — the breathing thing with the hands. In, out. Easy . Just breathe, amor, and I’ll—”

 

“Rio Vidal, I swear to every entity in your stupid dominion if you say breathe one more time I will — AHHH, FUCK!” Agatha doubled forward, gripping her belly with both hands as the contraction hit hard, stealing every bit of oxygen from her lungs.

 

Rio spun on her heel and sprinted like the house was on fire.

 

She shook Nick awake, shouted something about bags and towels, gently pulled Nicole out of a meditation nap (“I knew it was today,” she said groggily), and dragged everything they’d packed weeks ago from the hallway closet.

 

By the time she came flying back into the bedroom with two bags and a half-dressed Nick behind her, Agatha was still in the same spot — but now she was sweating. Her hair clung to her forehead, her breathing uneven. But it was the way she held her belly that stopped Rio cold.

 

Not just in pain. In defense .

 

Arms wrapped protectively, possessively, around her bump. Like she was ready to fight off the universe if it came too close.

And then Rio understood. Agatha wasn’t just in labor. She was scared. She was remembering.

 

The last time she’d carried a child into the world… Rio had taken him away. Her job had taken him away. And that memory — that ancient, silent wound — was carved into every tense muscle in Agatha’s body now.

 

Rio dropped the bags.

 

She stepped closer, voice quiet and full of care. “Agatha… can I come closer?”

 

Agatha’s eyes flicked to her. She was pale, her lips trembling, eyes shining but fierce. Still protecting. Still uncertain. But slowly — shakily — she nodded.

 

Rio knelt down in front of her, carefully resting a hand on the bed. “I’m here as me . As Rio. Your wife . The mother of this baby. Not the collector. Not Death . Just me.”

 

She laid a gentle hand against Agatha’s knee.

 

“She’s okay, Ags,” she whispered. “She’s strong. She’s ready. And I didn’t come to take her. I came to meet her.”

 

Agatha’s head snapped up. Her eyes widened.

 

“She?” she croaked.

 

Rio blinked. Then blanched.

 

“Oh shit — shit! That wasn’t — I didn’t mean to — That just slipped out! I was worried , you were afraid of me, and it just—”

 

“RIO!”

 

“I’m sorry! I panicked !”

 

“It’s your job to take lives , not ruin surprises !”

 

“She’s your daughter too! And she was kicking my lungs, okay?! I was trying to be tender!”

 

Agatha exhaled shakily, her face half-twisted in pain and half in disbelief.

 

“Rio,” she said slowly. “This baby is trying to climb out through my ribs. If she doesn’t stop, I swear on your underworld throne you are not touching me for months . I mean it. MONTHS . I will put binding spells on my underwear.”

 

Rio laughed — despite the tears forming in her eyes. She cupped Agatha’s face gently and kissed her forehead. “Fair.” Then softer, her voice trembling. “But please… let me take care of you. Let me protect you. Let me stay .”

 

Agatha looked at her, eyes full of fire and water and everything in between. She reached out and pulled Rio close, fingers curling into the back of her shirt, lips meeting hers in a kiss that was hot and desperate and full of pain and love and defiance and hope.

 

“Then get me to the goddamn hospital,” Agatha breathed against her mouth. “Because your daughter is dramatic as hell and I will not give birth in our bedroom.”

 

Rio stood like a soldier. “Yes, ma’am.”

 

And as Agatha tried to get up, groaning and glaring all at once, Rio wrapped an arm around her back and whispered, “She’s going to be beautiful. Like you.”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes. “She better come out with my face and my sarcasm this time. Otherwise, I’m asking for a refund.”

 

Rio grinned, kissed her one last time, and yelled down the hall:

 

“Nicole! Nick! Operation Baby Is Go!”

 

Nick’s scream echoed back: “Do I still get to cut the cord?!”

 

“ No !” both mothers answered.

 

And just like that, chaos descended. And life prepared to rise.

 

The delivery room was a blur of voices, sterile lights, and sweat-drenched tension.

 

Agatha was gripping the rails of the bed so hard her knuckles had turned white, her legs trembling, hair plastered to her face. Every contraction hit like a wave crashing through her spine. She screamed, cursed, cried, swore she'd hex the doctor, and at one point, threatened to summon a blood demon if anyone told her to "just breathe" again.

 

Rio had never been more terrified.

 

She stood beside her, one hand on Agatha’s damp forehead, the other gripped tightly by fingers that could crush stone. She whispered every grounding spell she knew, even the fake ones, just to keep talking. Agatha barely heard her.

But when the moment came, when the final cry tore out of Agatha’s throat and her body went limp with exhaustion, the room filled with a sound that made everything else fall away.

 

A cry. High-pitched. Fierce. Alive .

 

The doctor held her up. “She’s perfect,” she said with a smile. “Congratulations.”

 

Agatha's head rolled slightly to the side, her eyes glassy with exhaustion, her breath shallow. 

Rio was still frozen in place.

 

The baby cried louder. Her skin was flushed, her hands curling into tiny fists. The nurse was already turning to place her in Agatha’s arms when Agatha raised a trembling hand.

 

“No… wait .” She barely had the strength to speak. “Rio. Let her hold her first.”

 

Rio blinked, stunned. “ What ?!”

 

“You never… got to hold them. Not Nick. Not Nicole. You… never got that first moment. I want you to have it.”

 

The weight of that truth hit Rio like a brick wall. Her lips parted, her chest clenched.

 

“Agatha…” she whispered, shaking her head.

 

“Hold her,” Agatha insisted, tears glistening in her eyes — purple now, deep and endless. “She’s yours too. And you deserve to meet her first.”

 

The nurse looked to the doctor, who nodded gently. A moment later, the baby — tiny, warm, wailing — was carefully placed into Rio’s trembling arms.

Rio stiffened instantly, like someone had handed her a glass sculpture made of lightning. She held the baby awkwardly at first, her hands cupped so delicately it looked like she feared she'd crush her.

 

Agatha, still breathless, watched from the bed with a weak smile. “You look like you’re holding a bomb.”

 

“I feel like I’m holding a bomb,” Rio breathed.

 

The baby squirmed softly against her chest. Her skin was already calming. Her cries softened into little hiccups.

 

Rio's eyes filled with tears.

 

“Tell me how she looks like, Rio,” Agatha murmured, voice cracking. “Tell me. I can’t see well yet.”

 

Rio looked down again, her breath catching. “She… she looks like you. Finally, right?”

 

Agatha gave a weak, breathy laugh.

 

“She has your eyes,” Rio whispered, her thumb brushing the baby’s soft cheek. “Those deep, ocean-blue eyes. And your lips. She’s so tiny… Is she supposed to be this small?”

 

She looked over at the doctor, half-panicked.

 

The woman chuckled. “Exactly nine months and one day. Right on time. Perfect weight. A little tall, honestly. Congratulations, ladies Harkness-Vidal.”

 

Rio looked back down, blinking through tears. “She doesn’t feel big. She looks like one of those weird dolls Nicole keeps in the basement.”

 

From the hospital bed, Agatha raised a weak hand and pointed at her.

 

“Did you just call my daughter a creepy basement doll?”

 

Rio winced. “No! I mean—yes? But in a very… good way?”

 

Agatha narrowed her eyes, too exhausted to argue but clearly storing the insult for future vengeance.

 

“She’s perfect,” Rio added quickly. “She’s ours .”

 

The baby gave a little grunt, wriggled in Rio’s arms, and let out a sigh so loud it made the nurse chuckle.

 

Rio sat down beside Agatha and carefully laid the baby in her arms, helping guide her hands. Agatha cradled her daughter like something she'd been waiting her whole life to hold again.

 

Rio leaned in, forehead to forehead.

 

“I told you,” she whispered. “She’s here. And I didn’t come to take her. I came to love her.”

 

Agatha's eyes brimmed again, but this time… she didn’t cry.

 

She just nodded. And whispered back, “Welcome home, my little storm.”

 

Agatha lay back against the pillows, hair damp against her forehead, skin pale but glowing in the kind of way only mothers did — fragile and powerful all at once. Her arms cradled the tiny weight resting on her chest, warm and curled into herself, breathing in little fluttery sighs.

The baby’s forehead was wrinkled and soft, her skin still pink and delicate like the inside of a seashell. Her scent was new and raw — milk, cotton, and something sacred, like the beginning of something no one else could touch.

 

Agatha’s fingers gently traced over the baby’s brow, as if memorizing each line, each curve.

 

“What’s her name going to be?” she asked softly, voice hoarse from hours of labor but filled with something warmer. She didn’t look at Rio when she spoke, just kept her gaze on her daughter, hypnotized by the slow rise and fall of her chest. “I assume you and the kids took this mission very seriously.”

 

Rio sat beside her, her hand resting over Agatha’s leg, thumb moving in soft circles. Her own eyes were heavy with tears she hadn’t had time to shed yet, and exhaustion lined every part of her posture — but there was light in her face, still.

 

She chuckled low in her throat. “Nicole wants Victoria . Says it’s the Latin root for Nicholas. She claims it’s symbolic.”

 

Agatha gave a breathy, worn laugh, her lips parting just enough to show her teeth. Her chest shook from the effort. “Of course she does. That girl takes symbolism as seriously as I take wine.”

 

Rio smiled and leaned in slightly, brushing a strand of hair from Agatha’s cheek, her touch reverent. Then her voice dropped into something quieter, something vulnerable.

 

“But I was thinking… Eden .”

 

Agatha blinked and finally lifted her gaze to Rio, curiosity soft in her eyes. “Like the garden?”

 

Rio nodded, her eyes distant, almost nostalgic. “Yes. It was one of the first creations. I used to walk those paths with my sister, long before you humans ever touched it. Helped name the animals. Helped care for the plants. It was quiet. Balanced. Beautiful .”

 

Agatha held her gaze. “You loved it there.”

 

“I did,” Rio whispered. “And she feels like that. Like that peace. Like the start of something that doesn’t belong to the world’s chaos.”

 

There was a stillness between them for a long moment, broken only by the baby’s tiny breath against Agatha’s skin. Then, slowly, Agatha smiled.

 

“Okay,” she murmured. “I like it.”

 

Rio exhaled, as if releasing something ancient and held too long. Agatha shifted slightly, the movement small, protective. She lowered her chin to kiss the baby’s temple and then turned toward Rio with glassy eyes and the most honest voice she’d used all night.

 

“You’re going to watch over Eden,” she said softly. “And I’m going to sleep for at least twelve hours. Possibly longer. If I don’t wake up by Thursday, bring wine.”

 

Rio laughed, her chest rising with the sound. She leaned in, resting her forehead against Agatha’s temple for a moment before whispering, “You deserve it. You did amazing. Again .”

 

Agatha barely nodded, already halfway gone into sleep.

 

But before she drifted fully, she murmured, “Thank you, Rio.”

 

Rio looked down at the tiny creature between them — her daughter, this impossible, beautiful girl — and whispered back with a lump in her throat, “No, my love. Thank you .”

 

And as Agatha surrendered to rest, Rio remained awake, watching over both of them like a guardian meant to be exactly where she was — finally, fully present at the beginning of life.

 

Not to take. But to protect.



More than eight hours had passed.

 

Agatha slept soundly, her body finally surrendering to rest. Her chest rose and fell in slow, steady rhythms, her lips slightly parted, one arm curled instinctively over where Eden had once pressed against her from within. Every so often, Rio would rise from the small armchair beside the bed, adjust her pillow, tuck the blanket around her shoulders, and smooth the stray strands of hair that clung to her temple. 

She looked so peaceful like that. So soft . It was almost hard to believe that hours earlier she had threatened to kill an entire medical staff if someone dared touch her foot during labor.

 

Across the room, near the incubator glowing softly in pastel light, Nick and Nicole sat on padded stools with legs swinging and eyes wide. They hadn’t moved for the past half hour, utterly fascinated by the squirmy little creature that made odd noises and blinked at them like she already knew all their secrets.

 

Eden’s pale blue eyes flitted between them with a curious sharpness, her tiny fingers twitching like she was taking mental notes.

 

“She really looks like Mom,” Nicole said, one elbow propped on her knee as she gently brushed a fingertip over Eden’s impossibly small knuckles. “She stares like a hawk. No, wait. Like an eagle . She’s totally monitoring us for weaknesses.”

 

Eden blinked slowly, as if confirming the accusation.

 

Nick, meanwhile, was pouting. His chin in his hands, his face pressed to the side of the incubator. “She’s so small,” he muttered. “I still think she should’ve been a dragon.”

 

Nicole didn’t even look at him. “Nick, drop it.”

 

“She could’ve hatched.”

 

“She literally came out of a woman, you nerd.”

 

Behind them, Rio sat stiffly in the corner chair, holding a thick paperback titled First-Time Parenting: A Practical Survival Guide for the Chronically Underprepared like it was the Necronomicon. Her eyes were darting over the chapter where Rio wrote in red pen on the first day: How Not to Snap Your Baby in Half While Changing a Diaper , and she looked vaguely horrified.

 

“Why are they so fragile?” she whispered, flipping a page. “They don’t have scales. Their bones are bendy. They can’t even hold their own heads. How did humanity survive evolution like this ?”

 

Nicole snorted. “You’re literally the personification of death and you’re scared of a diaper.”

 

“I’m not scared of the diaper . I’m scared of breaking her,” Rio hissed. “She’s like a puddle made of hope and cartilage.”

 

Eden let out a high-pitched grunt, then a loud frrrrpt echoed off the walls.

All three of them froze. The baby blinked. Then wriggled. And then looked vaguely offended by her own noise.

 

Nick and Nicole lost it. Nicole was doubled over, laughing silently, tears in her eyes. Nick had slid halfway off his stool, clutching his stomach. Even Eden gave a startled hiccup, like she’d surprised herself.

 

Rio, however, looked terrified.

 

“Oh no,” she whispered. “That was the signal, wasn’t it? That was the poop sound.”

 

Nicole wiped her eyes and grinned wickedly. “Looks like it’s time for your first diaper change, mom.”

 

“I’m not ready. You do it!”

 

Nicole leaned back smugly. “ You made her, you change her. I didn’t ask for another sibling. But you asked for another child. This one's on you.”

 

Rio pointed at her like she was declaring war. “I’m going to remember this. When you’re seventeen and begging me for a car, I will pull this day from my memory like a cursed scroll.”

 

Nicole gave a flawless, innocent shrug. “Then you better learn to change diapers fast. She’s not going to wait for your trauma therapy.”

 

Nick, still wiping tears, added, “At least she didn’t breathe fire. Small wins.”

 

Rio inhaled slowly. Rose from her chair like a condemned woman walking to the gallows. And looked down at Eden, who was now squinting up at her with that same owl-eyed intensity as Agatha, like she knew exactly what was about to happen.

 

“Oh, little one,” Rio muttered. “Please don’t remember this part of your first day.”

 

She turned to the changing table. Unfolded the kit with the precision of a combat medic.

 

“Let’s do this,” she whispered to herself.

 

And behind her, Nicole quietly took out her phone.

 

“Smile, Mom. This is going on the ‘First Times’ baby album.”

 

“Nicole.”

 

“I’m creating memories!”

 

“I will haunt you .”

 

“And you’ll still have to wipe poop.”

 

Rio groaned. “I miss being feared.”

 

Eden gave another fart.

 

The room exploded into laughter again.

 

And from the bed, still half-asleep, Agatha mumbled faintly, “If you get poop on my sheets, I’m exiling all of you.”

 

“You don’t think that’s a little too tight?” Nicole raised a skeptical eyebrow as she eyed her baby sister, now wrapped in a brand-new blanket like a sacred artifact. Her diaper was changed, her bodily functions approved by the hospital’s nursing staff, and yet Eden looked... mildly inconvenienced by life.

 

The baby blinked slowly. If she even tried to move, she’d likely roll across the table like a fat little worm.

 

“The book says it has to be like a burrito ,” Rio said, holding up The First-Time Mother’s Illustrated Guide like it was gospel. “Burritos are tight so the filling doesn’t fall out.”

 

“She’s not a burrito, Rio,” Agatha groaned from the hospital bed as she pushed herself upright, wincing slightly. “She’s your daughter. Your human daughter. If she stays wrapped like that one second longer, she’s going to develop spine issues and probably resentment. Give her to me.”

 

Rio hesitated, glancing down at the perfectly swaddled bundle in her arms. “Are you sure she won’t unravel like... like loose meat from a poorly rolled tortilla?”

 

“ Rio Vidal !” Agatha barked with sharp, zero-patience authority.

 

That was enough. With all the care of someone handling the last Phoenix egg in existence, Rio passed Eden over, her hands trembling only slightly.

 

Agatha, despite her exhaustion, took the baby with practiced grace — rewrapping her swiftly, expertly, with the kind of ease that only someone with multiple children and excellent muscle memory could manage.

 

“There,” she muttered. “Now she’s secure and breathing properly.”

 

Rio stared, awestruck. “You make it look so easy.”

 

“That’s because it is easy. Now hand me that pillow, I need some support — and she needs to feed.”

 

Nicole made a gagging noise from the corner. “ Ew . I’ll wait outside.”

 

“You’re grossed out, emo child? You latched onto my chest like a baby calf for two years ,” Agatha said dryly, adjusting the pillow under her arm. “Take your brother with you and buy him breakfast. Use your own money.”

 

Nicole rolled her eyes but grabbed Nick’s hand. “Come on, future dragon boy. Let’s go find food.”

 

Nick didn’t resist. “As long as there’s pancakes.”

 

The door clicked shut behind them, leaving the room in gentle silence. Just the two of them. Agatha. Rio. And Eden — small, squirmy, and slightly indignant. Rio sat down beside Agatha again, almost pressed against her side. She was close enough to hear every breath the baby made, to see every flutter of her lashes. Her eyes never left the newborn.

 

When Eden finally latched onto Agatha’s breast, Agatha flinched, a sharp breath escaping her lips. “Oh — damn. That hurts.”

 

Rio leaned in, alarmed. “She bit you? How ? She doesn’t even have teeth yet.”

 

“No, darling,” Agatha breathed out slowly, trying to settle into the ache. “It’s just... the beginning always hurts. It always does. You forget, and then — well. You remember .”

 

Rio’s eyes dropped to the baby, her expression shifting from concern to guilt. “I’m sorry. I didn’t think about how much you’d have to go through. I should’ve... I should’ve thought about that more before I — before we —”

 

“Rio.” Agatha’s voice cut through her ramble with gentle finality.

 

She reached up with her free hand and cupped Rio’s cheek, her thumb brushing softly against her skin.

 

“This kind of pain?” Agatha said quietly. “It’s the kind I promise is worth every second . Love hurts too, you know. And I’ve never once regretted this. Not you. Not her. Not any of it.”

 

Rio’s throat bobbed. She pressed her hand over Agatha’s where it still rested on her face, holding it there.

 

“But the factory’s closed ,” Agatha added, eyes narrowing slightly. “Do you understand me? No more little Death babies. This uterus is officially on lockdown.”

 

Rio smiled, sheepish. “Okay. I’m happy with three little me’s.”

 

“ Shut up,” Agatha snorted. “She looks like me . Finally. My genes actually showed up for something.”

 

Rio looked down at Eden, who blinked up at her like she knew what they were talking about.

 

“Okay,” Rio conceded, lips twitching. “She has your eyebrows. Very judgmental.”

 

Agatha smiled softly and leaned back, adjusting Eden as the baby suckled peacefully.

 

Rio didn’t say anything else. She just sat there, watching them — Agatha glowing despite the pain, Eden feeding quietly, her tiny fingers twitching — and realized that for the first time in her eternal, chaotic existence...

 

She didn’t want to be anywhere else.

 

Afterword

Please drop by the Archive and comment to let the creator know if you enjoyed their work!
